DOC.HEAD: Blacks Twice as Likely as Whites to be Robbery Victims
DOC.TEXT: Blacks are more likely than whites to be victims of violent crimes such as aggravated assault, rape and robbery, according to a federal study. The rate of such violent crimes occurring against black Americans age 12 or older was 44 per 1,000 compared with 34 per 1,000 whites in the same age group, according to data collected by the Justice Department's National Crime Survey between 1979 and 1986. There were 13 robberies per 1,000 blacks during the seven-year period, compared with five robberies per 1,000 whites, the study said. The rate of aggravated assaults was 14 per 1,000 blacks and 9 per 1,000 whites. There were 1.5 rapes per 1,000 black women, compared with 0.8 rapes per 1,000 white women. Whites were more likely to be victims of simple assault with a rate of 19 per 1,000 compared to 16 simple assaults per 1,000 blacks. Blacks were more likely to be physically attacked or threatened with violence than whites during the commission of a crime, the study said. Among victims of aggravated assault, 48 percent were black, while 41 percent were white. In addition, blacks were more likely to be attacked by someone holding a knife, gun or some other weapon. The statistics gathered from the survey showed that 48 percent of black victims of violent crimes reported facing an armed attacker, compared with 33 percent of the white victims of those crimes. The injury rate for black victims of aggravated assault also was higher than for whites. Twenty-four percent of black victims, compared with 16 percent of whites, sustained serious injuries such as knife wounds, bullet wounds or broken bones. Whites were more likely to be attacked and injured during robberies than blacks. Thirty-four percent of white robbery victims were injured, compared with 28 percent of blacks. But blacks were more likely to be severely injured. Sixty-one percent of black victims who were injured received medical treatment, compared with 46 percent of injured white victims. The overnight hospitalization rate for injured black victims was 8 percent, compared with 4 percent among whites. The data was collected from the nationwide survey of 50,000 households conducted every six months by the department. Members of each household are asked if they have been victims of crimes during the previous six months. The survey does not include murder statistics. But the report contained FBI crime statistics for 1986 showing that the murder rate among blacks was 31.2 per 100,000 compared with 5.4 per 100,000 whites. The rate among black males was 52.3 per 100,000 compared with 7.9 per 100,000 white men.

DOC.HEAD: Nigeria At-A-Glance
With PM-Nigeria, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Nigeria:

THE LAND: Stretching inland from the rain-swept West African coastline to arid lands on the edge of the Sahara Desert, Nigeria covers 356,600 square miles, about the land area of Texas and Utah combined.

THE PEOPLE: The population is estimated at more than 100 million, Africa's most populous. Moslems predominate in the north and a Christian majority is in the south. Dozens of languages are spoken among the more than 250 tribes. The main ones are Hausa, spoken in the north, Yoruba in the southwest and Ibo in the east. English is the lingua franca.

THE ECONOMY: At independence from Britain in 1960, agriculture was the most important industry. Oil became the major source of income in the 1970s, but falling prices in the early 1980s, coupled with mismanagement and corruption, brought a sharp economic decline.

THE HISTORY: Nigeria's many peoples were brought together arbitrarily under the flag of British colonialism in a union plagued to this day by tribal conflicts. In the 1967-69 Biafran War, the Ibo tribe tried to secede and form the state of Biafra in eastern Nigeria. More than 500,000 civilians and 100,000 soldiers died before the easterners succumbed. The last civilian president, Shehu Shagari, was overthrown by Gen. Muhammadu Buhari in December 1983. Buhari was ousted by the present leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, Aug. 27, 1987.

DOC.BYLINE: Brain-Dead Infant Gives Life to Twin Sister ^By BETH HARRIS
DOC.TEXT: Timothy and Paula Whisman thought their hands would be full with two demanding infants by now. Instead, their arms are aching to hold one newborn daughter, who clings to life because of her twin brother's heart. Alison Page Whisman was born April 10 with a fatal heart condition. Her brother, Tyler, was born brain dead minutes later. Doctors saved the girl's life by giving her Tyler's heart in what they believe is the first heart transplant between infant twins. ``We just want to have her where we can hold her and feed her and all those things that you do with a baby,'' Mrs. Whisman said. ``I just want to get her where I can have some snugglies.'' Page _ as her parents call her _ is in the newborn intensive care unit at Riley Hospital for Children. She is hooked to a heart-lung monitor. Dr. Randall Caldwell, medical director of the Riley pediatric cardiac transplantation program, said Page had hypoplastic left heart syndrome, a fatal congenital abnormality that occurs in about one in 6,000 births. Without help, infants with the condition die within 15 days. Drugs can forestall death for about 45 days. Researchers don't know what causes the condition, which develops about four to nine weeks after conception. The Whismans have been told that if Page continues improving they can take her home within three weeks. For now, they make the hour-long commute daily from their home in Cicero, Ind., about 20 miles from Indianapolis, to visit Page. ``It's limited the time we can spend with her. She was really alert today and her eyes were bright. She knows when her lullabies were playing,'' Mrs. Whisman said in a telephone interview Sunday night. The twins were artificially conceived in August because the Whismans had been unable to conceive on their own. Page was born one minute before Tyler. He was born brain dead, asphyxiated in the womb just before birth, doctors said. Page appeared strong at delivery, but doctors discovered the heart defect within 12 hours. The Whismans had the idea for a transplant. ``It was just a passing thing. I had made the comment that wouldn't it be amazing if it was up to Tyler to save his sister's life,'' said Mrs. Whisman, 40, who began taking fertility drugs in July when she had difficulty getting pregnant. Because the twins were not identical, the chances of an organ match weren't certain. But in four of the six compatibility factors that surgeons test for, the twins matched. When Page is old enough, Mrs. Whisman said, she will be told of her brother's gift of life. ``We've got pictures of Tyler. We'll tell her. We think it's real important that she know that it was her brother that saved her life,'' she said. The Whismans also decided to donate Tyler's liver to a Pennsylvania newborn. ``Even if the tissues hadn't matched to help Page, we would have still wanted his life to touch someone else, to help someone else,'' Mrs. Whisman said. She said the couple believes the unique operation represents even more than the life of their daughter. ``Each time it's done they learn more and maybe it'll make things easier for the next little baby out there who has the same problem Page has.''

DOC.HEAD: World Collects Garbage, Uses Leg Power Mark Earth Day
With PM-Earth Day Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In displays of concern over the planet's plight, people of the world spent Earth Day rallying on streets and mountaintops, collecting garbage on beaches and shunning fossil fuel-burning beasts for bicycles. On Sunday's 20th anniversary of the first Earth Day, an estimated 200 million people in 136 countries took part in events dedicated to saving the environment, organizers said. Students carried a globe on a stretcher, symbolizing a sick Earth, in a parade in Hong Kong's twin city of Kowloon. About 1,000 people marched, many dressed as trees or animals and waving green ribbons and banners. In Chamonix, France, ice sculptors Christian Claudel and Francis Cuny carved a giant thermometer on the Mer de Glace glacier to protest global warming resulting from air pollution. ``If Earth Day does nothing else, it will ... give the clear message to politicians that millions of people are aware of the problems facing the earth and what needs to be done about it,'' said Andrew Lees, of the British branch of Friends of the Earth. In Istanbul, Turkey, police arrested 11 people for holding an unauthorized demonstration to celebrate Earth Day, the semi-official Anatolia news agency reported. In Paris, French activists spelled out the words ``Jour de la Terre'' (Earth Day) with 40,000 empty bottles at the Trocadero across from the Eiffel Tower to symbolize the need to recycle glass. In Tibet, an international climbing team traveled to the Everest base camp to clean up rubbish left by previous expeditions. About 35,000 people gathered on Japan's Yumenoshima, or Dream Island, an artificial island in Tokyo Bay made from landfill consisting mostly of garbage from Tokyo. A temporary facility for recycling tin cans was set up to emphasize the problem of waste disposal on the island nation. In western Japan, volunteers gathered six tons of trash on a beach and set it ablaze, according to the public TV network NHK. In Gdansk, Poland, students bicycled through the Baltic port's Old Town to protest air pollution, and a similar protest was held in Rome. Environmentalists on bicycles, roller skates and other motorless vehicles marched through the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius. Moscow has virtually cut off the Baltic state's energy supplies in a bid to break its independence drive. East Germans gathered near the Berlin Wall to view exhibits and celebrate their newly won freedom to raise environmental and other issues. Under the Communist regime ousted in October, environmentalists had to operate underground. Hundreds of people lined the main highway along the Cape Peninsula in South Africa to protest a government plan to allow mining on scenic Chapman's Peak. Later, they presented a petition against the mining signed by 50,000 people to Gert Kotze, minister of environmental affairs. He has been criticized for supporting mining in the nation's largest wetlands. Participants around the world, including Czechoslovakia's President Vaclav Havel, planted trees. In northeast Italy, Franciscan priests planted hundreds of trees along the Piave River. The United States, through an aid program, sent 93,000 seedling apple trees to farmers in Afghanistan, where once-lush orchards have been devastated by the 12-year-old war between U.S.-backed guerrillas and the Soviet-backed government. The Greenpeace environmental group floated a hot-air balloon above Plaza Colon in downtown Madrid to demand a ban on the production of chlorofluorocarbons, which scientists say destroy the Earth's fragile ozone layer.

DOC.HEAD: Williams Admits Visiting Prostitutes as Young Man
DOC.TEXT: Clayton Williams' spokesman says the Republican gubernatorial candidate's admission that he patronized prostitutes as a young man demonstrates his ``greatest strength'' _ honesty. Democrat Ann Richards' campaign charged that Williams' remarks raise new questions about the 58-year-old oilman-rancher's attitudes toward women. The Houston Post reported Sunday that Williams admitted patronizing prostitutes in Texas and Mexico as a teen-ager and as a student at Texas A&M University. He said it had been at least 35 years since he had done so. ``I've never claimed to be a perfect man,'' Williams told the newspaper. ``It's part of growing up in West Texas. ... It's like the Larry McMurtry book, The Last Picture Show.'' He added: ``It was a lot different in those days. The houses were the only place you got serviced then.'' Williams press secretary Bill Kenyon, trying to turn the remark to the candidate's advantage, said, ``One of Clayton's greatest strengths as a person is one of his greatest `weaknesses' as a politician; he always tries to be honest.'' Kenyon said that Williams had answered a reporter's question by telling the truth, ``even when it wasn't politically expedient.'' Williams was in Arizona and not available for comment. ``In recent months, the Republican nominee has made several comments which taken together drive this wedge between men and women, and I think that's unfortunate,'' said Glenn Smith, Ms. Richards' campaign manager. Smith said the state treasurer, who was vacationing, didn't wish to comment on Williams' statement. Smith said Williams has made a series of remarks about women that should be a topic of debate. ``He implies that women are here to `service' men. That kind of an attitude is as insulting to men as it is to women,'' Smith said. A month ago, Williams came under fire for a remark during a cattle roundup on his ranch. Williams likened bad weather to rape and said that if it is inevitable, ``just relax and enjoy it.'' He apologized the next day. During a visit to Washington before the Democratic runoff, Williams told reporters he would feel uncomfortable running against a woman. Prostitution is legal in some areas of Mexico, including most border cities. Prostitutes must have health cards and undergo weekly checkups. In Mexico City and some other areas, prostitution is illegal but tolerated. Ms. Richards won the Democratic nomination on April 10 after a mudslinging campaign in which her opponent, Attorney General Jim Mattox, accused her of using illegal drugs as recently as 10 years ago. A recovering alcoholic, Ms. Richards declined to give a yes-or-no answer when asked about drug use.

DOC.HEAD: President of Mexico to Address AP Annual Luncheon
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper executives gathered to hear President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico address the annual meeting of The Associated Press today and to choose directors of the news cooperative. Prior to the luncheon at the Century Plaza Hotel, AP was to hold its annual meeting at the Shubert Theater. The meeting and luncheon are attended by publishers and editors representing the news cooperative's 1,486 newspaper members. They are the opening-day events at the 104th annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association. Salinas, 42, took office Dec. 1, 1988, for a six-year term. Since then, he has cracked down on government corruption and drug traffickers. He also has opened the economy to foreign investment and imports. The AP meeting will include a report to the membership by William J. Keating, chairman of the AP's board of directors, and Louis D. Boccardi, president and general manager of the AP. Keating is chairman and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer. AP members also will see a video presentation called ``AP '89: Witness to History'' and hear a panel discussion on Eastern Europe. Boccardi will moderate the panel consisting of Walter R. Mears, AP vice president and Washington columnist; Mort Rosenblum, AP special correspondent based in Paris; Alison Smale, AP chief of bureau in Vienna; Juergen Ruhfus, West Germany's ambassador to the United States; and Arnold Horelick, senior corporate Fellow on Soviet Affairs at the Rand Corp. AP members also will elect six members of the cooperative's board of directors from 12 nominees. Incumbents seeking re-election are: James K. Batten, chairman and chief executive officer of Knight-Ridder, Inc., based in Miami; J. Stewart Bryan III, chairman and publisher of the Richmond (Va.) Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader; Ruth S. Holmberg, publisher of The Chattanooga (Tenn.) Times; Tom Johnson, chairman of the Los Angeles Times; and Joe D. Smith Jr., president of the Alexandria (La.) Daily Town Talk. Other nominees include: Walter E. Bartlett of The Greenville (S.C.) News; Richard L. Conner of the Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram; Robert H. Hartmann of The Evansville (Ind.) Press; Beverly Kees of The Fresno (Calif.) Bee; and George W. Wilson of the Concord (N.H.) Monitor. One nominee representing a city of less than 50,000 population will be chosen to succeed retiring director John O. Emmerich Jr. of the Greenwood (Miss.) Commonwealth. Emmerich was not eligible for re-election because he has served the maximum three consecutive three-year terms on the board. Candidates are Ted M. Natt of The Daily News of Longview, Wash., and David J. Whichard II of the Greenville (N.C.) Daily Reflector.

DOC.HEAD: Syracuse Dedicates Wall to Flight 103 Victims
DOC.TEXT: A wall in memory of 35 students killed in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 has been unveiled at Syracuse University. ``The students we honor this day will serve as an inspiration for all students over the years to live full, warm and contributive lives,'' Syracuse Chancellor Melvin Eggers said during the unveiling Sunday. Students and victims' families were in the crowd of more than 600 at the dedication of the 4-foot-high, semicircular limestone wall with the students' names engraved in an 18-inch granite band around the top. The wall is on a bricked plaza at the university's main entrance. The pathway to The Place of Remembrance is lined with pear trees and heather. The students were killed in the Dec. 21, 1988, terrorist bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland. They were returning home after a semester aboard under a Syracuse program. Of the 35 students, 25 attended Syracuse and 10 were from other schools. All 259 people aboard the jetliner died. Eleven others were killed on the ground. Robert P. Berrell, whose son Steven died in the bombing, said the dedication helped switch everyone's focus ``back to the victims who died, instead of the victims who lived.''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: District Judge David Young is not a man to be toyed with. Young has become so weary of lollygagging attorneys and other court officials that he's imposed a fine for tardiness, even penalizing himself three times. The minimum mandatory for latecomers? A Transformer or Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle will do just fine. Those fined must bring a toy to court. ``The real thing I want people to learn is I expect them to be on time, to keep their calendars in order and to keep things moving,'' he said. ``At the same time there are a lot of children who can benefit from something like this.'' When the pile of toys behind the judge's bench gets too high, they are taken to local charities. Lawyer Bob Merdith, who was overdue for a hearing, was the latest to take the cure. ``Hey, I got nailed. But I thought, well, I'll be glad to comply,'' he said. ``I think it's a fantastic idea.'' More than 20 lawyers have already been busted, the judge said.

Milton Graton says there are quicker ways to pull a 70,000-pound bridge into place than with two oxen and wooden rollers. But there isn't a better way. Hundreds of residents watched the animals inch the covered-bridge builder's latest masterpiece onto its foundations over the weekend. ``It's the difference between doing it the right way and the wrong way,'' the 81-year-old said Saturday. ``It takes longer to do it the right way.'' With the yoked oxen strolling in circles to turn a capstan, the 60-foot-long, 14-foot-wide bridge was pulled in place using chains, 500 feet of heavy rope and an old block and tackle. Each time the oxen made a circle, the bridge slid forward about three inches on wooden rollers. Though the process was about as lively as watching corn grow, Marion Merrill of the Ashland Historical Society's Squam River Covered Bridge Association said, ``It's nice to show people how it was done years ago.'' ``It's a great engineering feat,'' she said. ``We today think we have all the knowledge and they didn't have it years ago.'' The state had proposed a $1.1 million steel-and-concrete span to replace a condemned concrete bridge over the Squam River. But in 1988 town selectmen entered into an oral agreement with Graton _ that's the only way he does business _ to build the bridge for $189,000. The covered-bridge association raised about $200,000 in donations for the project. Graton and Associates, operated by Milton and one of his three sons, Arnold, 52, began construction last year. Arnold Graton said the old-fashioned bridge is just what you'd expect to find in a town like Ashland. ``You don't go play golf on a cement golf course with plastic grass,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged lower against the Japanese yen today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange also fell in listless trading. The dollar closed at 157.55 yen, down 0.05 yen from its 157.60 yen close on Friday. It opened at 157.40 yen and traded between 157.05 yen and 157.58 yen. Currency dealings were dominated by cross trading between the yen and the West German mark that kept the dollar-yen rate fairly stable, dealers said. Kaneo Ogino, senior dealer with Goldman Sachs in Tokyo, said the yen was likely to remain weak against the mark ahead of a May 6 decision on unifying the East and West German currencies. The yen also is being weakened by speculation over possible West German and U.S. interest rate increases that would enhance the appeal of the mark and dollar, dealers said. The dollar, meanwhile, is expected to remain in a ``box,'' trading between 155 and 160 yen, Ogino said. Dealers said it was hard to determine the dollar's direction, because no incentives were driving the currency. At the same time, there is speculation that the U.S. acceptance of a weak yen is waning because of fears of a deterioration in the trade imbalance, they said. The weak yen makes Japanese exports more price competitive overseas. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 156.37 points, or 0.52 percent, closing at 29,679.07. It lost 109.97 points Friday. An estimated 330 million shares changed hands in thin trading. Analysts predicted little movement in prices ahead of the ``Golden Week'' holidays. Japan's financial markets will be closed next Monday, Thursday and Friday for the series of holidays. ``People are in a holiday mood,'' said Christopher Leighton, manager of international sales at Schroder Securities. A ``temporary equilibrium'' was believed to exist in all three major financial markets _ bond, currency, and equities _ and ``no one wants to disturb it,'' he said. The equilibrium level for the Nikkei was believed to be 30,000 points; for the dollar, 160 yen, and for the benchmark Japanese government bond, a yield of about 7.3 percent, Leighton added. The price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds declined to 86.19 points as of 4 p.m. from Friday's close at 86.36. The yield stood at 7.325 percent, up from 7.29 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Polhill: ``I Tried To Stay Angry''
PM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from a Syrian state television interview with released American hostage Robert Polhill on Sunday night:

Q: How do you feel after being released? A: I'm very happy and grateful to all the people who spent time on my case. I'm still deeply concerned about my two friends and others who are still held in the conditions I was held in. Some of them have been held longer than me. My happiness tonight is a bit toned down that they're not with me. I'm looking forward that we'll be together again, all of us ... I don't know where I'm going. I think it's better you ask me specific questions. I'm not sure. I can't summarize 39 months of my life. It's a little bit difficult at this moment. I didn't have time to begin relecting yet on those 39 months of my life. Q: How was your first day in captivity? A: I remember my first day in captivity more than the rest of my days in captivity ... It was boring. We were kept away to ensure the security of our being kept. That prevented us from doing anything. We were not allowed to speak loudly. We had something to read, but we were deprived materials that gave any news about us. As to our specific conditions, I can tell you it could have been a lot worse. We were not maltreated, thanks to those who guarded us, who tried to give us things within the limits of the restrictions on them. We played cards ... We were very much in the dark about our status. We didn't know where we stood. That was the worst. We didn't know whether we were going to be released and when or whether we were ever going to be released. In fact, I know that those left behind and others still in captivity in places I'm not aware of ... quite possibly don't know that I've been released. But I guess they'll have hope if they know I've been released. Q: What does freedom mean to you? A: Freedom is something that, believe it or not, neither me nor my two associates spent a lot of time thinking about. It's a bit like you wish you had a T-bone steak in front of you. Knowing you were not going to get it right away makes you more hungry, makes you want that steak more. So we didn't spend time thinking or talking about when we'd be freed. Our most difficult assignment was to find things to think about. To keep our minds active so we didn't begin to vegetate. I don't know what psychologists say about this. My belief is that part of the symptom of a mind beginning to stray and go bad to the point of danger is the loss of anger. I was angry at what was done to me, at being taken away from my wife and family, my friends and students. And so I strived to continue to be angry, knowing at all times that if I began to lose that anger I would just sort of become a vegetable, and I didn't want that to happen. Q: What do you want to say to the world? A: One thing I probably should say is that I was a little bit surprised to find out that the specific demand these men (the kidnappers) are making and want the world to know seems to be precisely the same they made about two weeks after our kidnapping, when Alann Steen made the videotape _ releasing the 400 prisoners held in Israeli jails. We seem right back at ground zero. One of the last words I heard today from one of them as they went out was that was still their demand. I don't know if it's still the same 400 prisoners or others. Besides that, I don't think I have any other messages that I'm supposed to be carrying to the people or governments of the world or the United Nations ... As I say this is rather surprising. I'd have thought things would have changed over the three years, that some of those prisoners got released, I don't know. Q: What are your plans for the future? A: I really don't have any plans for the future yet, except to see my wife, mother, sons and friends and family. People I haven't seen in three years, or 39 months, and together talk about things like that. About the future.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Hostage Situation
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events in the holding of American kidnap victims in Lebanon:

_ The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco abducted in Beirut. _ Jeremy Levin, Beirut chief for U.S. Cable News Network, kidnapped earlier in west Beirut, gains his freedom. He says he escaped; Islamic Jihad says it freed him. _ Terry Anderson, chief Mideast correspondent for The Associated Press, abducted on Beirut street. _ David P. Jacobsen, American director of American University Hospital, kidnapped. _ American Thomas Sutherland, acting agriculture dean at American University, kidnapped. _ American Presbyterian pastor Benjamin Weir freed after 16 months in captivity. _ CIA officer William Buckley, a hostage since March 16, 1984, killed after Israeli air raid on PLO headquarters in Tunisia.

_ American University librarian Peter Kilburn, an American, and two other hostages, British educators Leigh Douglas and Philip Padfield, found shot to death east of Beirut two days after U.S. air raids on Libya. _ Revolutionary Organization of Socialist Moslems says it has killed kidnapped British journalist Alec Collett in retaliation for British complicity in U.S. attack on Libya. _ Jenco freed. _ American educator Frank Herbert Reed kidnapped in west Beirut. _ American University accountant Joseph Cicippio abducted on west Beirut campus. _ American writer Edward Austin Tracy kidnapped in Beirut. _ Jacobsen is released in Beirut. _ First reports surface that the United States arranged arms shipments to Iran in exchange for hostage releases.

_ Anglican Church mediator Terry Waite kidnapped. _ Three Americans _ Jesse Jonathan Turner, Alann Steen and Robert Polhill _ and Indian Mithileshwar Singh, all faculty members of Beirut University College, kidnapped from the campus. _ American journalist Charles Glass kidnapped; turns up two months later and says he escaped. _ Kidnappers issue videotape of Anderson in which he appeals to President Reagan to win the hostages' release, saying, ``There is a limit for how long we can last.''

_ U.S. Marine Lt. Col. William R. Higgins, member of U.N. observer force in Lebanon, abducted. _ The last three French hostages in Lebanon are set free. They say a fourth French hostage, Michel Seurat, died in captivity. _ Indian professor Mithileshwar Singh is freed.

_ Lebanon's most influential Shiite Moslem cleric, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, says the foreign hostages should be freed. _ Israeli commandos abduct Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, a clerical leader of fundamentalist Shiite group Hezbollah, from his Lebanese home. Organization of the Oppressed on Earth kills Higgins and says it was reprisal for Obeid's kidnapping. _ Kidnappers release photo of Anderson, accompanying another demand for release of comrades jailed in Kuwait. _ U.S. releases $567 million in frozen Iranian assets.

_ Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani says he believes the hostage issue ``is moving toward a solution.'' The Revolutionary Justice Organization, one of several groups holding hostatges in Lebanon, said it did not intend to release its hostages. _ The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine releases U.S. hostage Robert Polhill.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I was angry at what was being done to me, being taken away from my wife and family. And so I strived to continue being angry, knowing at all times that if I began to lose that anger I'd just sort of become a vegetable.'' _ Freed U.S. hostage Robert Polhill on how he survived 39 months in captivity in the Mideast.

``I don't want to come back here 20 years from now and have to tell your sons and daughters that you didn't do your duty. We've got to raise a conservation generation.'' _ Earth Day founder Gaylord Nelson, addressing more than 100,000 people at a Washington rally on the event's 20th anniversary.

``We just want to have her where we can hold her and feed her and all those things that you do with a baby. ... I just want to get her where I can have some snugglies.'' _ Paula Whisman of Indianapolis, on her 2-week-old daughter, Alison Page. The girl clings to life on a heart transplanted from her twin brother, who was born brain dead.

DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma Teachers in Upbeat Mood After Walkout
DOC.TEXT: Oklahoma teachers realize they will be held accountable for better schools after a four-day strike that won them the biggest education funding bill in state history, union officials say. The walkout ended with the Legislature approving the $230 million bill on Thursday. Most teachers were back in class the next day. Schools that did not reopen Friday were expected to resume classes today. Teachers realize the bill is ``just a first step and is not going to solve all the problems of education,'' Karla Feeley, spokeswoman for the 31,000-member Oklahoma Education Association, said Sunday. Teachers celebrating at a union meeting Friday and Saturday ``were euphoric and sharing their happiness and talking about the need to get down to it and make it happen,'' she said. The strike began last Monday to protest legislative inaction on the bill, which calls for raising $230 million by increasing sales and income taxes. A one-half cent increase in the 4-cent state sales tax would raise $104 million, as would a 10 percent increase in personal income taxes. An increase in the corporate tax from 5 percent to 6 percent would produce $22 million. The bill calls for spending $68.1 million to raise minimum teacher salaries by $1,500 a year for four years. It also provides money for special education and early childhood development programs. Oklahoma teachers say they rank 48th in pay among the states, making $22,000 a year compared with the national average of $29,648.

DOC.HEAD: Official Media Reports Deaths, Says Moslem Activists Call For Own Republic
DOC.TEXT: Two days of fighting between Moslem separatists and Chinese security forces in the country's far west claimed 22 lives, the region's media said in reports that broke two weeks of official silence on the unrest. The local television reports in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region said 15 Moslem protesters, a provincial official and six policemen were killed and 19 police wounded in the April 5-6 clashes in Akto County. In its report Sunday, the station claimed militant separatists in the region had formed the Islamic Party of East Turkistan and proclaimed a holy war to establish an independent republic. Akto County is 25 miles south of the ancient bazaar city of Kashgar and less than 60 miles from the Soviet border. Foreign travelers in Xinjiang's capital of Urumqi said at the time of the rioting that troops had been sent in to quell disturbances in Kashgar and two other cities, Hotan and Kuqa, and that an estimated 50 people were killed. The weekend television reports, monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. did not mention unrest anywhere except Akto's Baren Township. The foreign sources said the rioting broke out after a dispute over the building of a mosque, but Xinjiang television called the clash in Akto a premeditated ``counterrevolutionary armed rebellion'' and made no mention of the mosque dispute. More than half of Xinjiang's 14 million people are from Moslem minority groups such as Uygurs, Kazakhs, Taziks, and Kirghiz, many with close cultural ties to the restive Moslem nationalities of Soviet central Asia. Relations between Moslems and Han Chinese in Xinjiang have long been strained. In May, serious rioting broke out in Urumqi when Moslems angered by a Chinese-language book on Moslem sexual habits stormed Communist Party headquarters. In recent months, Xinjiang officials have repeatedly made unspecified warnings about the threat of ``separatists'' using religion to undermine the unity of the nation. Media reports have said the government is tightening controls over religious activities, including closing unauthorized religious schools and stripping Moslem imams, or high priests, who violate laws against proselytizing of their religious qualifications. In its Sunday broadcast, the local Xinjiang station said a ``very small number of reactionary elements'' in Baren had declared the ``holy war'' seeking an independent republic. The group was reported to have vowed to form Moslem death squads and preached the triumph of Islam over Marxism, Leninism and socialism. ``This gang, under the banner of religion, incited a religious craze, and wildly proclaimed the launching of a sacred war to eliminate the heathens,'' the television report said. The report quoted an unnamed leader as saying, ``Even Moslem women must kill the enemy.'' It said ringleaders included fugitive murderers, former labor camp inmates and habitual thieves who met together many times. They recruited dozens of young people whom they trained to be ``hired thugs'' and amassed weapons and ammunition, including long knives, dynamite packs and grenades. They allegedly forced ``ill-informed masses'' to make trouble on April 5, and surrounded officials and security forces who tried to maintain order. ``They frenziedly stopped and attacked the public security personnel who went to perform their duty, robbed them of their weapons and killed six armed police officers and fighters, injured 13 others and destroyed four police vehicles,'' it said. The next day, they opened fire and hurled bombs at police and officials, wounding three more police officers. Police retaliated, killing 15 rioters. A provincial official was killed and three security officials hurt during the pursuit, the report said. Following the unrest, Xinjiang closed the area to all foreign visitors. Officials in both Urumqi and Beijing have refused to comment on the reported clashes. National news media have ignored the strife. The Communist Party's official newspaper, the People's Daily, on Sunday carried a lengthy front-page article praising the central government's support for Xinjiang's economic and cultural development. It said the government's policies have strengthened unity among the region's various minorities.

DOC.HEAD: `Joke' About Pilot's Sobriety Delays Northwest Flight
DOC.TEXT: A woman blamed for a four-hour delay of a Northwest Airlines flight says she was just joking when she questioned the pilot's sobriety. ``I said, when they told us that a pilot was on his way in to staff the plane, `I hope he hasn't been partying.' I didn't even say `drunk,''' Ann Beaver said Saturday in a telephone interview from Atlanta, where she was visiting her children. A flight attendant and the pilot, whom Northwest has refused to identify, took the comment seriously, and the pilot demanded a blood test, which showed no alcohol in his system, the airline said. Results of a urine test were expected today. The pilot had been assigned to Flight 497 from Detroit to Atlanta on Thursday after the scheduled pilot was delayed en route from Milwaukee. Beaver said she made her remark as the substitute pilot was driving to the Detroit airport. She said she told him she was only joking, but ``he said, `You made an allegation, and now I have to go to a hospital and take a blood test.' The flight was delayed while another substitute pilot was procured. When the plane finally left, Beaver and her husband stayed behind because other passengers were mad at them, Northwest said. The couple took a flight Friday. Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons said Beaver seriously questioned the pilot's sobriety and integrity. He said the pilot has an ``impeccable record'' in his more than 20 years with the airline. Beaver said she has been made a scapegoat. ``I'm a certified social worker with a master's degree,'' said Beaver, 50. ``I'm not a nut.'' Three Northwest pilots were arrested on March 8 in Minneapolis and accused of flying from Fargo, N.D., while drunk. They were fired and face state and federal charges. ``By the conduct of three former crew members, we made ourselves a target for some jokes, and we're able to withstand it,'' Gibbons said. ``But this was more than a joking remark in the estimation of the man who was going to fly the plane.''

DOC.HEAD: 4,000 Teen-agers March at Auschwitz to Honor Victims
DOC.TEXT: After marching from the Auschwitz death camp to the crematoria of Birkenau, the roughly 4,000 teen-agers from 36 countries marking Holocaust Memorial Day lighted torches and heard a prayer for the dead. In Israel, sirens wailed for two minutes Sunday as life briefly came to a standstill in remembrance of the 6 million Jews slain by the Nazis. Writer Elie Wiesel, diplomats and Israeli parliamentarians joined the young marchers in southern Poland for the two-mile ``March of the Living.'' The sunny day turned cloudy and light rain started as Wiesel stood at a podium before a gray stone monument to recall his time at Auschwitz: ``Years and years ago I saw _ I cannot tell you what I saw. I'm afraid that if I told you we would all wake up in tears and would not be able to stop. I see a young girl. ... ,'' he said before stopping, apparently unable to continue. He silently left the podium. Many cried as the students _ some carrying Israeli flags and others bouquets of flowers _ walked along the train tracks that ended at the cremetoria. Dandelions waved in the wind-swept grass now covering the rubble of the camp. Torches were lighted, poems read and mournful violin songs played before a reading of the Kaddish, a Jewish prayer for the dead. Shawn Tepper, 17, of Miami Beach, Fla., held hands with a row of other young American Jews. She said the experience was overwhelming but ``proved to everyone that we are alive, we are together and we are strong.'' The march was in memory of those who died in Nazi death camps as well as in the Warsaw ghetto uprising that began April 19, 1943. In the uprising, several hundred Jewish insurgents staged a desperate three-week struggle against the Nazi drive to liquidate the last 75,000 residents of the walled ghetto. Sunday's event was the second ``March of the Living.'' Participants said it had special significance because of the drive toward German unification and Israel's rapid renewal of ties with Eastern European countries that once had flourishing Jewish communities. The Nazis built Auschwitz as the main engine of Hitler's ``Final Solution.'' Estimates of the death count vary, but recent research has put the toll at the camp at about 1.5 million, more than 90 percent Jews. In Israel, as the sirens sounded at 10 a.m. Sunday, traffic ground to a halt, and thousands stood silently at attention to honor the victims. Hundreds of Israelis also marked the day by participating in ceremonies across the country at which the names of victims were read by relatives and friends. According to recent statistics, 302,404 Holocaust survivors live in the nation of 4.7 million people, including Polish-born Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and other top military and political leaders. ``I remember my family members who have died in those terrible and fearsome days,'' said Shamir, 74, during a ceremony outside parliament. He lost his parents, two sisters, their husbands and children during World War II. The Holocaust still deeply influences private lives and politics in Israel, reflected in both the right-wing preoccupation with security and the liberal drive to guard human rights. But its impact on the younger generation is diminishing.

DOC.HEAD: Freed American Loved Lebanese, But Hated Captors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITS a0488 to ADD byline.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Robert Polhill, who used to talk of his love for his wife's native Lebanon, left that country a weakened man who said he kept his sanity during 39 months of captivity by staying angry at his captors. ``I was angry at what was done to me, at being taken away from my wife and family, my friends and students,'' the 55-year-old American educator said in a Syrian television interview after his release Sunday. ``And so I strived to continue to be angry, knowing at all times that if I began to lose that anger, I would just sort of become a vegetable and I didn't want that to happen.'' Polhill, a professor of business and accounting at Beirut University College, was kidnapped with two other U.S. educators on Jan. 24, 1987, by the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. He had lived in Lebanon for four years with his second wife, Feryal, who is Lebanese. His mother, Ruth Polhill, a retired high school librarian who lives in Fishkill, N.Y., said in an interview before her son's release that he had visited Lebanon on one of his first business trips for a New York City accounting firm. ``It was very beautiful,'' she recalled. ``He loved the people. He loved the campus.'' Despite his anger while held 1,182 days by the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants, Polhill said he tried not to think about when he would be released. ``Freedom is something that, believe it or not, neither me nor my two associates spent a lot of time thinking about,'' he said in the Syrian interview. ``It's a bit like you wish you had a T-bone steak in front of you. ``Knowing you were not going to get it right away makes you more hungry, makes you want that steak more. So we didn't spend time thinking or talking about when we'd be freed.'' Polhill said he was not mistreated and that his guards tried to provide amenities within the limitations placed on them. But the uncertainties terrified him and his two fellow captives. ``We were very much in the dark about our status,'' he said. ``We didn't know where we stood. That was the worst. We didn't know ... when or whether we were ever going to be released.'' Polhill, a diabetic, attended Cornell University and graduated from New York University in 1961. He later began work as a New York City accountant. He was described as a photography buff, an avid New York Giants fan and a committed educator. Polhill had two children from a previous marriage. His mother said he told her before his abduction that he was not fearful living on the Beirut campus. ``Now that's what he tells his mother,'' she said. ``He had all the confidence he's be safe on the Beirut campus.'' Said son Brian: ``We knew it (kidnapping) was a possibility, but it wasn't something he put a big accent on. He was extremely careful. He kept a low profile.'' Syrian TV on Sunday showed Polhill being driven through Beirut, Lebanon, sitting in the back of a car and puffing heavily on a cigarette. He appeared drawn after his long ordeal and smiled wanly several times. He said his first day of captivity stood out mostly clearly in his mind. ``I remember my first day in captivity more than the rest of my days in captivity. ... It was boring,'' he said. He added, ``We were not allowed to speak loudly. We had something to read, but we were deprived materials that gave any news about us.''

DOC.HEAD: Warm Weather Prevails in Much of U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Unseasonably warm weather prevailed in much of the nation today, though severe thunderstorms threatened to cause more damage in the South, Southeast and the Plains. Temperatures were expected to edge up into the 70s and 80s in many places today and Tuesday. But clouds and showers were expected to keep temperatures down in the Rockies and the Northwest, while a cold front moving southward through New England was bringing cooling Northeast winds. It was only 39 degrees this morning in Portland, Maine. On Sunday, thunderstorms in Florida spawned a tornado in Jacksonville and high winds that downed trees and power lines around the town of Bunnell. Thunderstorms in Mississippi produced golf ball-size hail at D'Iberville and in Jackson County on Sunday. Thunderstorms in Oklahoma produced golf ball-size hail at Cheyenne. Showers and thunderstorms also were over the southern high Plains region Sunday night. A thunderstorm in southwest Texas dropped inch-thick hail in Balmorhea. Showers associated with a cold front were over the northern and central Rocky Mountain region. Showers associated with another cold front were over the northern and central Pacific Coast region. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation. Strong southerly winds prevailed across the central U.S. on Sunday, with winds above 30 mph in North Dakota and Minnesota. But the winds did not drive out heat in the Dakotas, where several record highs were set. The afternoon high of 92 degrees at Huron, S.D., surpassed their previous record for the date by 7 degrees. Chamberlain and Pickston, S.D., recorded the high temperatures for the Lower 48 states _ 94 degrees. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most other major currencies in calm trading in Europe this morning, but traders said they didn't expect the currency to rise much further. Gold prices were mixed. Traders said the dollar was up because of higher U.S. interest rates and uncertainty over the future of the West German mark during the German unification process. ``The dollar still has some possibilities to move higher (Monday), but the margins remain very limited,'' one Milan trader said. He predicted the dollar would run into strong resistance around 1.6970 West German marks, before resuming its longer-term downward trend. The market was quiet and not much activity was expected until the opening of the U.S. market, he said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.05 yen to a closing 157.55 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 157.50 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.6943 West German marks, up from 1.6895 _1.4880 Swiss francs, down from 1.4910 _5.6878 French francs, up from 5.6695 _1.9050 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8910 _1,243.50 Italian lire, up from 1,240.00 _1.1625 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1619 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.6363, compared with $1.6357 late Friday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $376.50 a troy ounce, up from $374.75 bid late Friday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $375.65. In Zurich, the bid price was $375.85, down from $376.50 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 38 cents to close at a bid of $376.98. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.09 a troy ounce, from Friday's $5.08.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Rights Activists Announce Drive in Democratic Primary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and 7th graf to CORRECT style on `persuade.' For Release 11 a.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: An abortion rights group is jumping into the Iowa governor's race with an ad campaign that attacks an anti-abortion Democrat but also aims to persuade one of two pro-choice candidates to drop out. Kate Michelman of the National Abortion Rights Action League concedes it's a high-risk tactic, but says her group's campaign dramatizes the importance of gubernatorial races since the Supreme Court expanded the power of states to regulate abortion. ``No election is more important than Iowa's race for governor this year,'' Ms. Michelman said. Ms. Michelman said her group will launch a series of ads attacking Attorney General Tom Miller, a Democrat, contending ``voters won't have a choice'' if he's nominated to run against incumbent Republican Gov. Terry Branstad. Both Miller and Branstad take anti-abortion positions. Miller, asked last weekend about the planned ad campaign, called NARAL a single-issue group and added, ``They represent all that's wrong with politics in America today.'' The campaign ran into an immediate complication, as seven of eight commercial television stations refused to carry the ads. That left the group with cable television and radio stations, but it vowed to move ahead. Ms. Michelman said the drive could wind up persuading one of the two pro-choice candidates to drop from the race to avoid splitting the vote. ``Our going in at this moment may also contribute to one of the pro-choice candidates emerging as the leading candidate,'' she said. Democratic contenders House Speaker Don Avenson and retired banker John Chrystal both favor abortion rights, and Ms. Michelman said both are ``good people.'' ``This is tough, it's very hard to say you hope one will get out,'' she said. ``If it makes sense and we believe strategically it would ensure that Branstad has a pro-choice challenger, we may end up endorsing ... the candidate we believe has the best chance of winning.'' That announcement probably wouldn't come until a few weeks before the June 5 primary, she said. Avenson has been endorsed by virtually all labor unions in the state, and by some women's groups. He is generally considered the leading pro-choice contender. He has held discussions with Ms. Michelman about a possible endorsement. The campaign underscores the focus being placed on Iowa by both pro-choice and anti-abortion activists. The state is the home of the first presidential caucuses every four years. Abortion also is a major issue in Iowa's U.S. Senate race, in which incumbent Democrat Tom Harkin favors abortion rights and GOP challenger Tom Tauke is anti-abortion. Following last year's Supreme Court decision, the main abortion battleground is in the states, Ms. Michelman said. ``Governors are now the most important elected officials in the nation,'' she said. The ads provide an escalation in a Democratic primary that's already heated. Miller, the ads declare, ``wants to let the government interfere in your most personal decision.'' ``The fact is that Tom Miller is the only anti-choice candidate in the Democratic primary and it's very important for Democratic voters to understand that,'' Ms. Michelman said. Picking between two candidates who support abortion rights is more difficult, she conceded. ``This is a very unusual step,'' she said. ``We generally do not endorse in a contest where there are two pro-choice candidates.''

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Accident Sends Fumes Over Trailer Parks; 1,000 Evacuated For Hours
DOC.TEXT: An accident at a chemical factory sent a cloud of hydrochloric acid fumes drifting over two trailer parks, forcing evacuation of about 1,000 people for four hours, authorities said today. The residents were evacuated about 11:30 p.m. Sunday and were allowed to return home about 3:30 a.m. today, said Dion LeMieux, fire chief for Muskegon County's Egelston Township. A mechanical malfunction at the Lomac Inc. chemical plant caused phosphorus oxychloride to come in contact with lime, which produced a violent chemical reaction and released a cloud of the highly toxic acid fumes, LeMieux said. Two firefighters were treated for exposure to the fumes at Mercy Hospital in Muskegon and released, he said. He said an unknown number of residents also sought treatment. Mercy Hospital wasn't immediately able to provide information on those it treated, a switchboard operator said. The acid cloud forced evacuation of a six-square-mile area of Egelston and Muskegon townships, LeMieux said. He said he had no idea how many people were forced to flee. He said many took temporary shelter at Oak Ridge High School. The federal Environmental Protection Agency and state Department of Natural Resources have joined the investigation of the spill, he said. Most of those forced to flee lived in two mobile home parks, Arlington Estates and Eaglecraft park, authorities said. Together, the two parks have about 1,000 residents, said Gordon Christian, manager of Arlington Estates. ``You could see the brown in the air,'' Christian said. During the evacuation, he said, residents ``were real calm; they were orderly. I'm proud of them. Everybody looked out for everybody else. They do look out for their neighbors.'' A man answering the telephone at Lomac early today said ``everything's under control here.'' He declined to comment further except to say the company would make a statement later today.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Rebels Claim Capture of Key Outposts
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian guerrillas claimed they overran three key government positions today in a major attack to retake a strategic northwestern town destroyed in recent months by seesaw fighting. About 2,000 guerrillas began attacking the town of Svay Chek on Sunday, said Ok Serei Sopheak, spokesman for the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. His group is one of two non-Communist factions in a three-party alliance fighting the Cambodian government. Western and guerrilla sources also have reported heavy fighting recently in three other provinces where the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas operate. Ok Serei Sopheak claimed his faction's guerrillas overran three villages north of Svay Chek today: Treas, Tas Moan and Don Pok. They had also seized five other government positions around Svay Chek, he said. He gave no casualty report. The guerrilla spokesman also claimed his group's forces had carried out a commando raid at the provincial capital, Sisophon, which is a major strategic crossroads about 30 miles east of the Thai border town of Aranyaprathet. The force of 38 men destroyed a fuel depot there, Ok Serei Sopheak said. ``The purpose of the attack on Sisophon was to demoralize the (government forces) and show we can strike at the heart of the enemy defense system,'' he said. The guerrillas say if they can retake Svay Chek, they will have recovered all the territory they lost in a government counter-offensive that began in February. About 15,000 people lived in Svay Chek before it became the center of heavy fighting. The town was burnt to the ground after guerrillas attempted to retake it in early March. Thousands of civilians have fled the recent fighting, some across the border to refugee camps in Thailand. The guerrillas had made big gains in northwestern Cambodia after Vietnam's announcement in September it had pulled its troops out of the country. The Vietnamese have been backing the Cambodian government. However, the guerrillas claim thousands of Vietnamese troops have returned since then. Vietnam denies that.

DOC.HEAD: Friends Of British Hostages Welcome American's Release
DOC.TEXT: Friends and family of British hostages in Lebanon today welcomed the release of American Robert Polhill as a step toward freeing all the captives, and urged the government to talk to those who influence the kidnappers. ``We seem to be in a period now where people are being released rather than taken, and of course that is grounds, I would say, for great optimism,'' said David Waite. His brother, Terry Waite, the archbishop of Canterbury's envoy, disappeared in Beirut in January 1987 while trying to negotiate the release of American hostages. A spokesman for Anglican Archbishop Robert Runcie welcomed Polhill's release and said: ``If it is a step towards closing the hostage file, that is even better news.'' The Friends of John McCarthy, a British journalist kidnapped in April 1986, warned that if Britain does not begin discussions with Iran and Syria, it might be the only country unable to bring its hostages home. The group said in a statement: ``The American government will have achieved this hostage release through diplomacy and negotiations with the Iranian and Syrian governments, a process the Friends of John McCarthy have been appealing to the British government to undertake on behalf of the British hostages for some years now.'' The U.S. government says it made no deals with Polhill's kidnappers. After Polhill was released Sunday, however, President Bush thanked Syria and Iran for their roles in influencing the kidnappers. Britain broke diplomatic ties with Syria in 1986, accusing it of complicity in the attempted bombing of an El Al jetliner at London's Heathrow Airport. Relations with Iran were severed in February 1989 following the publication of ``The Satanic Verses,'' the novel by Salman Rushdie that has angered many Moslems. Conservative lawmaker Robert Adley, chairman of the British-Syrian Parliamentary Group, called on his party's government to restore diplomatic relations with Syria immediately. The Foreign Office said it has been in close contact with American officials in recent weeks. ``They have assured us they are pressing for the release of all Western hostages,'' said a spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity in keeping with British custom. Britain also seeks the release of retired pilot Jack Mann and schoolteacher Brian Keenan, who also holds Irish citizenship. The Foreign Office says it seeks word on Alec Collett, a New York-based British journalist whose Palestinian abductors claim they killed him. But his body was never found.

DOC.HEAD: Bonn Says it will Grant Equal Currency Trade on Wages
DOC.TEXT: West Germany gave in to a key East German demand today and said it would convert East German wages to an equal number of West German marks. The East German mark is officially valued at 3-1 against the West mark but unofficially worth almost nothing outside East Germany. Both nations have said they expect a full merger of the economies of the nations to be in place on July 1. East German salaries will be valued at a straight 1-1 rate to the powerful West mark, said Dieter Vogel, spokesman for West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Vogel's announcement cleared a major hurdle to an agreement between the Germanys on eventual unification. The East German government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere wanted a straight 1-1 exchange for wages, pensions and bank accounts to offset the effects of eliminating the heavy subsidies of the former socialist system. West Germany's central bank had proposing a 2-1 swap, saying a 1-1 exchange would dilute the value of the West German mark and possibly cause high inflation and rising interest rates. Kohl is nearing completion on a West German proposal for unification. He met with his Cabinet on Sunday, and the country's three major political parties held separate discussions today on the terms of unification. The proposal being put together by the Kohl government would outline West Germany's terms for economic and social unification. It is in effect an answer to a similiarly broad series of proposals put together two weeks ago by de Maiziere's coalition government. De Maiziere's government wants some employment and housing guarantees for East Germans who now rely on government housing and jobs. Kohl and his main opposition, the Social Democrats, are trying offer a compromise that will satisify the East Germans without alienating West Germans, who vote in nationwide elections on Dec. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Town Plans Evacuation Due to Flooding
DOC.TEXT: The entire population of a small outback town in eastern Australia _ about 1,600 people _ prepared today for an immediate evacuation because of rising floodwaters, authorities said. The Warrego River was expected to inundate Cunnamulla, a town about 500 miles west of Brisbane, sometime Tuesday. The river is rising after more than two weeks of heavy rain that have caused the worst flooding in western Queensland state in more than a century. Four people have been confirmed dead, and five are missing. About 30,000 were still isolated today as farmers in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria reeled from the loss of an estimated 100,000 sheep and cattle. Authorities said in a statement that helicopters today ferried about 90 residents of Cunnamulla to the town's airport. The early evacuees included pregnant women, mothers with young children and some elderly people. They were expected to be airlifted to Brisbane. ``Evacuation preparations are well under way in Cunnamulla,'' a police spokeswoman said. ``They're preparing for the worst.'' Queensland Premier Wayne Goss said he feared some of the small rural communities may never recover from the floods. ``I have seen the clear look of heartbreak and absolute shock in the eyes of the people who can't believe what has happened to them,'' Goss told a news conference. ``They have no houses, no possessions, and many have no futures unless the community is prepared to help them get back on their feet.'' Goss today announced a relief package, including police to guard against looting. He launched a public appeal for contributions. Water levels at Charleville, 65 miles upstream from Cunnamulla, began falling today and some of the 3,000 residents evacuated from the homes began mopping-up operations. The receding floodwaters left houses uprooted from their foundations. A search still was under way for a family of five reported missing after leaving their isolated homestead by boat.

DOC.HEAD: Some Americans Urge Goodwill Gesture Toward Iran
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 18 grafs new to include today's reaction; picks up 18th graf pvs, The seven.
DOC.TEXT: An influential congressman says the United States should make a goodwill gesture in response to the release of an American hostage, but an administration official said today President Bush is ``not into gestures.'' Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on the Middle East, said the release of hostage Robert Polhill on Sunday made it ``appropriate for the United States to send some kind of a gesture that we're willing to enter into a dialogue with Iran.'' John Kelly, assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, said today, ``The policy is very clear. We don't make deals. The president has said, as he did on inauguration day, that good will begets good will, but as he noted yesterday, he wants all the hostages out.'' Interviewed on NBC's ``Today'' show, Kelly noted that President Bush has said ``he's not into gestures.'' Nevertheless, Kelly added, ``we're always looking at how we can improve the situation and attempting to figure out ways that will speed the release without compromising our principles.'' Hamilton and others spoke after Polhill was freed in Lebanon after spending almost 39 months as a hostage. Their comments came before Bush reacted publicly to the release by reaffirming his absolute policy against trading for hostages, but expressing willingness to give credit where credit is due for Polhill's release. ``It's establishing a dialogue that is critical,'' Hamilton said. ``There are a lot of things that could be done here _ short of aid, short of normalization, short of credits _ that might be a gesture in response to the release of a hostage,'' he said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation.'' In an initial written statement, Bush thanked Iran and Syria for their roles in Polhill's release, but subsequently told reporters he wasn't sure how much Iran had to do with it and said he was purposely ``stopping a little short'' in his expressions toward Iran. ``I don't want to give credit when I don't know the facts,'' he said. While insisting that he had no intention of trading for hostages or dealing with kidnappers, and declaring that he was not ``trying to think up any gesture'' toward Iran or anyone else, Bush did say: ``I'd have goodwill to those who facilitated the release. If that included Iran, absolutely.'' But he emphasized that he does not ``have forgiveness in my heart as long as one American is held against his will.'' In an editorial in today's editions, the Tehran Times newspaper said another hostage should be freed to test ``President Bush's claim that `goodwill begets goodwill.''' ``This they should do swiftly in order to leave the ball in the other party's court to demonstrate its goodwill, if it has any,'' said the English-language newspaper, which often reflects the views of Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani. Iran's foreign minister, meanwhile, was quoted as saying the pro-Iranian extremists in Lebanon wanted a quick reciprocal move. The official Syrian Arab News Agency, quoting Ali Akbar Velayati in New York, specified that move would be the release of Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, a Lebanese Shiite clergyman abducted by Israeli soldiers in July. Kamal Kharazzi, Iran's ambassador to the United Nations, said today on ABC's ``Good Morning America'' that Iran will continue ``trying our best'' to facilitate the release of hostages. ``We are actually involved in encouraging Lebanese militant Moslems to free hostages,'' he said. Asked if there would be another release soon, he said, ``We hope so.'' But he said Bush's policy of no reciprocity unless all the hostages are released ``would put some more complexity to the situation. ...these sort of statements may present problems.'' Richard Murphy, a former assistant secretary of state for the Near East in the Reagan administration, said today on NBC that ``I don't think they (the Iranians) have any reason to expect a positive gesture hostage-by-hostage and that's what the president in effect is telling us in his statements. He wants them all out.'' The seven Americans and other Western hostages are believed to be held by different groups of Shiite Moslems in Lebanon under differing degrees of influence from Iran. Gary Sick, a Columbia University professor who dealt with Iranian matters during the Carter administration, said Western nations probably must make concessions to get their hostages out of Lebanon. ``This is not going to be easy,'' he said. ``If the West wants to get their hostages out, they're going to have to provide some concessions to Iran and others along the way,'' he said on ``Meet the Press.'' ``Our policy for a long time has been that we will talk directly with the government of Iran, but there can be no normalization of our relations with the Iranian government until they reject the notion of terrorism and until they do everything they can to obtain the release of our hostages,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said at a news conference. ``Our policy is that we do not negotiate with hostage-holders and we don't make deals for hostages,'' Baker said. ``And the reason we don't is because we think that will simply lead to more and more hostage-taking.'' Since the end of the devastating Iran-Iraq war last year, Rafsanjani has made overtures toward Western nations in an attempt to rebuild his country's shattered economy.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Holy Sites To Close In Protest Over Jewish Settlement
DOC.TEXT: A day after the government admitted financing a Jewish settlement in the Old City's Christian quarter, church leaders said they will close the major Christian sites for a day and ring bells in protest. The protest Friday will mark the first time all Christian holy places in Jerusalem, Bethlehem and Nazareth will close, Samir Kafiti, Anglican bishop in Jerusalem, said today. On Sunday, the Israeli government acknowledged it had put up $1.8 million for the settlement of 150 Jews in a complex not far from the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. The colony, which was set up on April 11, has provoked angry demonstrations by Christian clerics and Palestinians, both Christian and Moslem. It also has brought legal moves by the Greek Orthodox Church, which owns the building and wants the Jews evicted. The government's acknowledgment Sunday was the first confirmation of official involvement in buying Arab property in Jerusalem's walled Old City, captured by Israel during the 1967 Middle East war. The settlement, called Neot David, is the only Jewish presence in the Old City's Christian sector. Its spokesmen have consistently said no government money was involved in the settlement. The Christian leaders, who met early today to consolidate their response to the settlement, said Israeli government involvement in the matter ``endangers the survival of all Christian communities in the Holy City.'' Among the church properties to be closed are the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem and the Church of the Annunciation in Nazareth. Avi Pazner, a spokesman for caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said the churches' planned protest was too hasty, since the issue of the Jewish settlement is before Israeli courts. ``I think with the reputation of Israeli justice it would be worthwhile for those organizations to wait until there is a court decision,'' Pazner said. ``I hope they will reconsider this decision.'' The government money for the settlement passed from the Housing Ministry to a subsidiary trusteeship of the Jewish National Fund, the ministry said in a statement. The fund, part of a quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, was created in 1901 to buy land for the founding of Israel. The funds then went to a Panamanian company, SBC, which invested an additional sum to buy legal rights to the four buildings. It then rented the space to a religious Jewish group, which created the settlement. ``This government-backed settlers' action continues to provoke almost daily violent incidents in and around the area containing the Holy Sepulcher and the centers of church governance,'' read a statement signed by ten Christian church leaders. Signatories included the Greek Orthodox Patriarch Diodorus I, the Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem, Michel Sabbah, and leaders of other churches. They said ``freedom of access to the Holy Sepulcher and freedom of worship within it have been threatened'' and the settlement ``seriously jeopardizes the integrity, cultural, and religious autonomy of the Christian, Armenian and Moslem quarters in violation of the centuries-old status.'' The Christian leaders demanded immediate eviction of the settlers, and return of the property to the Greek Orthodox Church. The church claims that a former tenant sold his rights illegally. Israel's Supreme Court is expected to continue its hearing of the eviction dispute Thursday. The court stayed an eviction order during the proceedings. A separate case on the property dispute is before a lower court, and attorneys for the church say a ruling in not expected before six months. The church closure will be in effect between 9 a.m. Friday and an unspecified hour the following day, and church bells will play a funeral toll on the hour from 9 a.m. until noon Friday. However, both Diodorus I and Kafiti, who addressed reporters to announce the protest measures, say the closure may remain in effect longer than announced.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Earth Day Rdp, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0444,0935
DOC.HEAD: Millions Celebrate 20th Anniversary of Earth Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, bgng `In Washington...' with 3 grafs to to UPDATE with Wall Street protest today, transition, SUBS grafs 18 to end, bgng `The day...,' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Earth Day evacuations from chemicals in 3 communities, tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: An estimated 200 million people all over the planet celebrated the 20th anniversary of Earth Day as activists pleaded for the rise of a new ``conservation generation'' to care for the fragile environment. Even as a hot air balloon representing the Earth rose in Times Square and tens of thousands demonstrated at the U.S. Capitol on Sunday, some worried about sustaining interest in the environment so that it becomes more than a fad. ``Earth Day is primarily a light we turn on so that we can see the work. The work is still yet to be done,'' said novelist Wallace Stegner, who led a pledge of allegiance to the Earth in Palo Alto, Calif., where Earth Day has its headquarters. Some of Sunday's activism spilled over into today, when about 400 protesters blocked traffic and overturned garbage bins along New York's Wall Street during the morning rush hour. More than 100 people were arrested. A coalition of groups calling itself Earth Day Wall Street Action said it hoped to shut down Wall Street for a day to call attention to ``corporate abuse'' of the environment. But officials said trading began as usual this morning. In Washington on Sunday, Earth Day founder Gaylord Nelson urged more than 100,000 people massed at the foot of the Capitol to work to motivate politicians and corporate leaders to environmental action. ``I don't want to come back here 20 years from now and have to tell your sons and daughters that you didn't do your duty,'' said Nelson, 74, who originated Earth Day when he was a senator from Wisconsin. ``We've got to raise a conservation generation.'' Earth Day was celebrated in more than 3,600 U.S. communities and in 140 other nations, according to organizers. Environmentalists collected tons of garbage from Japanese beaches, sculpted a giant thermometer from a French glacier to protest global warming and carried a globe on a stretcher, symbolizing a sick Earth, in a parade in Hong Kong's twin city of Kowloon. In New York, an estimated 1 million people turned to the greenest part of Manhattan, Central Park, for a concert that included performances by Hall and Oates, the B-52's, the Roches and the Saturday Night Live Band. Concerts also drew hundreds of thousands to Earth Day activities in Boston and San Francisco. ``Within 50 years, if we don't change the way we do things, we won't recognize this Earth,'' consumer activist Ralph Nader told a crowd of about 1,000 at North Carolina State University in Raleigh. In New Orleans, nearly 1,000 ``mourners'' watched as a band played dirges in a jazz funeral for polluted Lake Pontchartrain, where environmentalists have found evidence of ``dead zones'' _ areas that no longer support aquatic life. In the nation's capital, environmental activists blasted President Bush for bypassing the rally for a vacation in Florida. ``Where is the president today? He's gone fishing!'' railed Ruth Caplan, executive director of the Environmental Action Foundation. Bush took a break from his fishing trip in the Florida Keys to give what he calls a ``point of light'' award to the citizens group Reef Relief, which is working to save the coral reef flanking the Keys. In Missouri, thousands of volunteers got down on hands and knees Sunday to plant 10,000 trees along the Mississippi River. ``The thing that was so incredible was that it was obvious people wanted to do this kind of thing. This is environmental awareness in action,'' said Skip Kincaid, urban forester for the Missouri Department of Conservation. Pennsylvania Gov. Robert P. Casey led an ``All Species Parade'' in Philadelphia, playing the pied piper to children in animal costumes made from recycled materials. Youngsters dressed up as trees or animals in Carbondale, Ill. ``Earth Day will not save the Earth _ it will take several generations of hard work to save the Earth. So that starts with children,'' said event organizer Gary Wolf. In three U.S. communities, Earth Day was commemorated most ironically: _ In Redwater, Texas, up to 2,000 people were out of their homes for several hours after hydrogen sulfide gas spewed from an oil well. _ In Muskegon, Mich., about 1,000 people in two trailer parks were evacuated late Sunday when an accident at a chemical plant sent a cloud of fumes over their homes. They were allowed to return home early today. _ In Craigsville, Pa., at least 200 people were evacuated Sunday and others were on standby today after 29 cars derailed on a train carrying a caustic chemical and crude oil. The resulting explosion sent flames hundreds of feet in the air and 100,000 gallons of oil leaked into an Allegheny River tributary. Earth Day did not pass without criticism. Sunday's activities represent the ``fad stage of issue-awareness cycles,'' said Steven Lamy, an associate professor of international relations at the University of Southern California. After the euphoria ``comes the awareness of how much a real commitment will cost in time, convenience and money,'' Lamy said. ``That's the stage of the ... cycle when the public tends to lose interest, and when concern of the issue reverts back to experts.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Welcomes Release, Give No Sign It Will Free Prisoners
With PM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Officials today welcomed the release of a U.S. hostage by pro-Iranian Shiite kidnappers but gave no indication Israel is ready to free Arab prisoners to encourage further releases. Robert Polhill, 55, a business professor, was freed Sunday after 1,182 days of captivity. Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati called immediately for a swift reciprocal move _ the freeing of Shiite Moslem cleric Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, who was abducted by Israeli troops in Lebanon last July. Avi Pazner, spokesman for caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, gave no indication that Israel planned to free Obeid or urge the freeing of about 300 Shiites and Palestinians held in the Khiam prison by the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia. ``We are very pleased to hear about the release of this (American) hostage and would like to see the day when all hostages, Americans, others and especially Israelis are also released. We pray that that day will come soon,'' Pazner said in an interview. He acknowledged that ``on the (hostage) issue as a whole, of course, we are talking with the United States, as we do on every issue.'' But Pazner stressed ``there was no coordination on the release of this hostage'' between Israel and the U.S. government or any other party. Israel has offered to trade Obeid for all foreign hostages, along with an Israeli an air force navigator and two soldiers who were captured by Shiite guerrillas in Lebanon in 1986.
