The South Lebanon Army said it had no intention of freeing Shiite prisoners in response to Polhill's release, according to Israel radio. However, it could still make such a gesture Thursday or Friday in connection with the Id Al Fitr, the Moslem holiday marking the end of the month-long Ramadan fast. Prisoner releases are traditional during the holiday. An Israeli army spokesman declined to say if Israel would release any of the nearly 9,000 Palestinians jailed in connection with the 28-month Palestinian uprising. The Tehran Times, which is close to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, called in an editorial for goodwill gestures to expedite further releases. But it said that as long as Israel holds scores of Arab prisoners, the hostage holders ``will certainly find it hard to comply with this request and their position is quite understandable.'' In the days before Polhill's release, Israel carried out two attacks in Lebanon that were seen by some observers as increased pressure on pro-Iranian groups holding hostages. On Friday, Israeli troops struck beyond Israel's self-proclaimed security zone in south Lebanon, killing six guerrillas of the Hezbollah, the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militia that is believed linked with groups holding Western hostages. The day before, Israeli airplanes bombed two bases in Lebanon belonging to Ahmed Jibril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, which has ties with Iranian radicals.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery's Astronauts Back for Second Try; Weather Looks Good
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with weather forecast improves to 80 percent; quote. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Discovery commander...'.
DOC.TEXT: Discovery's astronauts are back for a second try at a spaceshot, and they're optimistic the shuttle will lift off with the Hubble Space Telescope on Tuesday despite one crewman's bad luck with launches. Meanwhile, Columbia was rolled out Sunday to the launch pad, 1.6 miles from Discovery, only the second time both pads at Kennedy Space Center have been occupied. The first time was just before the Challenger explosion in 1986. Discovery is due to lift off at 8:31 a.m. Tuesday. Forecasters today said they expect an 80 percent chance of favorable weather, up from the 70 percent predicted Sunday. NASA expects to launch Columbia no earlier than May 16, one week late because of Discovery's two-week delay. ``Today I bring you only good news,'' NASA test director Al Sofge said today. ``The launch vehicle is in good shape. The Hubble Space Telescope is in good shape. The flight crew is ready ... and the weather looks good. So at this point, everything is go.'' Discovery commander Loren J. Shriver and his four crew members returned to Cape Canaveral on Sunday. Shriver poked fun at Steven A. Hawley's unwanted distinction of having the most shuttle launch ``scrubs,'' or postponements. Hawley experienced three postponements on his first flight, in 1984, and six on his second in 1986, a mission he shared with Discovery's pilot, Charles F. Bolden Jr. He felt so jinxed he donned a Groucho Marx mask to disguise himself while waiting aboard Columbia on its seventh _ and successful _ launch attempt. Discovery's first launch attempt, halted four minutes before liftoff April 10 because of a faulty power unit, was Hawley's 10th mission scrub. ``We feel very confident despite the fact that we did not make Steve wear any kind of disguise or do any kind of masquerade yet, he and Charlie both,'' Shriver joked. NASA test director Mike Leinbach said the countdown, which began Saturday, was proceeding smoothly and the shuttle appeared to be in perfect condition. The malfunctioning power unit was replaced a week ago. The $1.5 billion telescope, NASA's most expensive and complex payload, will enable astronomers to look back to nearly the beginning of time and solve some of the universe's mysteries. Discovery will aim for an altitude of 380 miles, the highest a shuttle has ever gone, so the telescope can be placed in its proper orbit far above Earth's distorting atmosphere. Hawley will use the shuttle's mechanical arm to lift the 24,250-pound telescope into space on the second day of the five-day mission. A $100 million observatory called Astro will accompany Columbia's seven astronauts into space next month and probe ultraviolet radiation. Columbia commander Vance Brand said he does not believe NASA is rushing to get his shuttle up. ``In some cases it could be a problem'' having shuttles on both launch pads, he said. ``In this particular case, everything's fitting together.''

DOC.HEAD: Bus Line Reports Two More Shootings
DOC.TEXT: Shots were fired at two buses owned by strike-plagued Greyhound in separate attacks in central Pennsylvania during the weekend, but no injuries were reported, authorities said. Shots have damaged 36 buses and three terminals since Greyhound's 6,300 drivers and 3,000 maintenence and office workers walked out March 2 over wages and job security at America's only nationwide bus system, Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said. Four people have been arrested. A bus bound for Philadelphia on U.S. 322 east of Lewistown, northwest of Harrisburg, was hit by a bullet on the driver's side above a baggage door Saturday evening, Gravley said. The second shooting occurred early Sunday on Interstate 81 at Harrisburg, he said. A bullet struck the right side of a bus en route from Pittsburgh to New York, he said. State police Trooper Charles McBreen confirmed the shootings and said the FBI was investigating. During the strike, Greyhound has continued to operate with 515 union drivers who crossed picket lines and 2,300 new drivers, Gravley said. The Amalgamated Transit Union has denied any involvement in the shootings. Talks between the union and company have ceased and Gravley has said the company will not resume talks until at least a week passes without violence. Greyhound is offering a $100,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of anyone for shooting a Greyhound bus or terminal.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Reinstate California Murder Conviction of Black Panther
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to reinstate the California murder conviction a Black Panther Party member who was shackled during his 17-month trial. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the shackling at Johnny Spain's trial violated his rights. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said Spain is entitled to a new trial or to go free because he was forced to wear 25 pounds of chain more than 10 hours a day while on trial for allegedly murdering two San Quentin prison guards. In a 2-1 ruling last August, the appeals court said the shackles prejudiced the jury against Spain by making him appear guilty. The appeals court said the shackles caused him so much physical and emotional pain it was difficult for him to assist in his own defense. If extraordinary steps were needed for courtroom security, it would have been preferable to bar Spain from the trial or permit him to miss some days to rest and regain his strength, the appeals court said. Spain had said that to avoid chaining he was willing to give up his right to be present at the trial. California prosecutors urged the justices to reinstate Spain's conviction and life prison sentence. Spain, 41, was convicted in 1976 of murdering two guards in a widely publicized case. He was freed on $350,000 bail in March 1988 while the state appealed to the 9th Circuit court to reverse a federal judge's ruling that overturned Spain's conviction. Since his release, Spain has worked as an electrician and taught a course entitled, ``Society Behind Bars'' at the University of California at Berkeley. Spain has spent 21 years in prison, beginning in 1967, for a murder committed in 1966, when he was 17. In the case acted on today, Spain was among six inmates dubbed the ``San Quentin Six'' after they were charged with taking part in a bloody escape attempt Aug. 21, 1971. Three guards and three inmates were killed in the incident. One inmate who died was George Jackson, a black revolutionary writer and author of the book ``Soledad Brother.'' He was shot down attempting to flee San Quentin after taking over the solitary confinement unit with a gun he produced following a visit with one of his attorneys. The lawyer, Stephen M. Bingham, was later acquitted of murder and conspiracy. During their trial in a San Rafael, Calif., courtroom, all six defendants were chained around the legs, wrists and waist, and other extraorindary security measures were taken. The measures were prompted in part by the killing of a judge at the same courthouse in 1970 when George Jackson's brother, Jonathan, took over a courtroom and attempted to exchange the judge, a prosecutor and a juror for his brother and other inmates. The case is Rushen vs. Spain, 89-1336.

DOC.HEAD: Courts Rejects Pittsburgh Company's Challenge to Clean Water Standards
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected a chemical company's challenge to federal standards for clean water. The court, without comment, left intact rules that govern more than 1,000 factories producing organic chemicals, plastics and synthetic fibers. The Environmental Protection Agency adopted the guidelines in 1987 to limit pollutants dumped into the nation's waterways. The limits were challenged by PPG Industries Inc. of Pittsburgh, which said the guidelines are too stringent and that some violations are unavoidable. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals rejected the company's arguments last year. PPG said the appeals court ``unjustifiably concluded that as long as a hypothetical `best' plant ... theoretically could achieve the full set of limitations, then it is irrelevant that no actual plant can do so.'' The Bush administration urged the justices to reject PPG's appeal, saying the claims are unsupported by technical evidence. The Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group that has said the EPA regulations should be tougher, denounced PPG's appeal. ``PPG has had more than its fair day in court, and this persistent frontal assault on EPA's rules should be stopped in its tracks,'' the environmental group's lawyers said. The case is PPG Industries vs. Environmental Protection Agency, 89-1079.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Appeal by former Member of Scientology Church of California
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by a former member of the Church of Scientology of California who wanted the church declared a phony religion. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by Larry Wollersheim of Aspen, Colo. Still pending before the justices is an appeal by the Church of Scientology of California aimed at overturning a $2.5 million ``emotional distress'' award won by Wollersheim. A California appeals court ruled that the church must pay Wollersheim $500,000 in compensatory damages and $2 million in punitive damages. A trial jury had awarded Wollersheim $30 million in damages but that amount was reduced by the appeals court. Scientology was founded by L. Ron Hubbard, who died in 1986. Scientologists believe they can progress toward spiritual awareness through private sessions in which members' skin responses to questions are monitored by an electronic device called an E-meter, which Hubbard invented. The church calls such monitoring sessions ``auditing.'' Wollersheim, a Scientologist from 1969 to 1979, said church members harassed him and tried to drive his novelty business into bankruptcy. Scientology officials denied the charges, but a jury in Los Angeles ruled for Wollersheim. Upholding the jury's finding that church officials inflicted emotional distress on Wollersheim, the state appeals court last August said, ``There was substantial evidence to support a factual finding that the auditing, as well as other practices in this case, were conducted in a coercive environment.'' The state court therefore ruled that the church's asserted religious freedom could not shield it from having to pay the damages award. Lawyers for the church are arguing in its appeal that the Constitution ``prohibits courts from imposing emotional distress tort liability based upon peaceful religious practices by permitting juries to determine that such practices constitute coercive persuasion.'' The still-pending appeal also raises a due-process challenge to the $2 million punitive damages award, an issue the justices already have under study in another case. In Wollersheim's appeal rejected today, he accused Scientology of being ``a mockery of religion'' and a ``religious front.'' But the appeal did not appear to ask the court for any remedy except a formal declaration that Scientology is not really religion. In response, lawyers for the church told the justices Wollersheim's appeal sought ``an advisory opinion (that) could have no possible effect on the outcome of this case in its present posture.'' The case is Wollersheim vs. Church of Scientology of California, 89-1367.

DOC.HEAD: Nigeria's Leader Claims To Have Defeated Coup Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to update with scene in Lagos today, details on fighting and Babangida's narrow escape, commanders pledging loyalty to president. Pickup 9th graf pvs, ``The rebellion ...
DOC.TEXT: Military ruler Gen. Ibrahim Babangida appeared firmly in control of this West African nation today after narrowly escaping death in a coup attempt. President Babangida said his troops had crushed a coup attempt Sunday after fierce fighting with rebel soldiers, who said they aimed to end domination of the government by Moslem northerners. Traffic jammed the roads of the sprawling coastal capital today, and the only extraordinary security in sight was around Bonny Camp on Victoria Island, where rebels captured in the failed coup attempt were believed held. Senior commanders and other members of Babangida's Armed Forces Ruling Council pledged their support to the president Sunday evening. The mutineers, led by middle-ranking officers, attacked before dawn Sunday in the West African nation's capital and engaged loyalist forces for about 11 hours in gun and mortar battles. They captured state-run Radio Nigeria offices and announced that the government had been overthrown. But Babangida's forces later retook the station after what state media described as ``heavy bombardment and sporadic shooting.'' There was no word on how many people were killed in the fighting, but reporters said casualties appeared heavy. The fighting began at 2 a.m. Sunday with an attack on Dodan Barracks, the military headquarters where Babangida has his residence. The president escaped moments before his residence was shelled, according to government sources. Babangida then fled to Bonny Camp to direct a counterattack by loyal forces. The coup attempt failed as senior commanders in other regions of the country went on the radio to declare their support for Babangida. Witnesses also reported heavy fighting around State House. Gunfire was reported at several other military installations in the city of 6 million on the Atlantic Ocean. Babangida said his aide, Lt. Col. U. K. Bello, was killed in the gunbattle at the military headquarters, the official News Agency of Nigeria reported. ``The unfortunate situation in Lagos this morning has been brought under control,'' Babangida told reporters Sunday night. There were no reports of fighting elsewhere in Nigeria. Babangida said many rebel soldiers had been arrested and would soon face trial, but he did not give any specific figure. Among those arrested, he said, were ``majors, lieutenants and second lieutenants'' in the military. The rebellion apparently was led by officers opposed to traditional domination by Moslem northerners over the central and southern states, which are mainly Christian and animist. When the rebels took over the radio station, they broadcast an announcement accusing the states of Borno, Bauchi, Kano, Katsina and Sokoto in the Moslem-dominated north of ``messing up'' the rest of the country. A rebel officer said those states would not be allowed to be part of Nigeria until they fulfilled conditions proving loyalty to a new government. A similar conflict along religious and tribal lines caused the 1967-1969 Biafran War. More than 500,000 civilians and 100,000 soldiers died when easterners attempted to form the state of Biafra and secede from Nigeria. Moslems are a slight majority in the oil-rich nation of 100 million people, Africa's most populous. The country gained independence from Britain in 1960. The rebellious soldiers on Sunday tried to stir up popular support with radio broadcasts. They told Nigerians, ``This is the opportunity to free yourselves from internal slavery.'' The official news agency said other parts of the country were calm. However, in Ibadan, a southern university city, thousands of students took to the streets in support of the coup plotters. Eleven hours after the fighting began, Lt. Gen. Sani Abacha, army chief and chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, went on national radio to say the coup had been smashed. He also urged remaining rebels to surrender. The News Agency of Nigeria quoted Col. Ishaya Bamaiyi as saying earlier announcements by rebel troops who seized the Lagos radio station represented ``the view of a few disgruntled officers.'' Babangida's military government has been viewed as weighted in favor of the Moslem north since the dismissal in December of Lt. Gen. Domkat Bali, a Christian, as defense minister. In one rebel radio broadcast, a man identifying himself as Maj. Gideon Ngwozor Oka announced: ``Fellow Nigerian citizens, on behalf of the patriotic and well-meaning peoples of the Middle Belt and southern parts of this country, I ... wish to happily inform you of the successful ousting of the dictatorial, corrupt, drug-baronish, inhumane, sadistic, deceitful, homosexually centered and unpatriotic administration of General Ibrahim Babangida.'' Babangida took power Aug. 27, 1987, when he overthrew Gen. Muhammadu Buhari in a bloodless barracks' coup. Nigeria has been led by military governments for much of its history. The general has promised elections and a return to civilian government in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Court Agrees to Consider Reinstating Hawaii Assault Conviction
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to consider reinstating a Hawaii woman's assault conviction, thrown out because a federal magistrate, not a federal judge, presided over jury selection in her trial. The justices said they will review a ruling that overturned Darlina France's conviction and five-year prison sentence for shooting her husband. Mrs. France was convicted of assault with a deadly weapon, assault with intent to murder and related charges. She was sentenced to five years in prison plus three years probation. The case was tried in federal court because Mrs. France and her husband, Neil, were living on an Army base in Hawaii when the shooting occurred Dec. 20, 1986. Prosecutors said Mrs. France shot her husband in the shoulder after he took her beer from the refrigerator and put it in the backyard. They said the couple had argued earlier in the day, and that she became upset when he knocked over a Christmas tree. Mrs. France said her husband provoked the shooting by attacking her. France testified that he believed the gun went off accidentally, urged that his wife not be prosecuted and said they were reconciling. In overturning Mrs. France's conviction last September, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court relied upon a Supreme Court ruling the previous June. In it, the high court said federal judges, to ensure an impartial trial, may not delegate the task of presiding over jury selection to magistrates. Federal judges, unlike magistrates, are appointed for life to assure they will not be swayed improperly by popular opinion. In the case decided last June, the defendants had objected to having a magistrate preside over jury selection. Mrs. France made no such objection prior to her trial but the 9th Circuit court said the distinction has little significance. The appeals court said she should not be penalized for failing to object to what, at the time of her trial, was the generally accepted rule that magistrates could select juries. The appeals court, in an unusual move, also said federal prosecutors were too harsh in charging Mrs. France under a 1984 federal law that carries a mandatory five-year prison term for offenders. ``We ... have been left with the sense that Darlina France may not be the sort of hardened, violent offender whom Congress had in mind when it enacted'' the 1984 law, the appeals court said. Justice Department lawyers, in the appeal acted on today, said Mrs. France forfeited her right to have jury selection conducted by a federal judge because she failed to object to the magistrate's role before trial. Dozens of convictions could be thrown out if the 9th Circuit court ruling is not reversed, the government lawyers said. The 9th Circuit court has jurisdiction in Hawaii, Alaska, Arizona, California, Nevada, Oregon, Idaho, Montana and Washington state. The case is U.S. vs. France, 89-1363.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Virginia Action Against Charity Fund-Raisers
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by Virginia officials seeking more power to prevent fraud by businesses that solicit charitable donations. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that lets federal judges block some anti-fraud measures for violating free-speech rights. The dispute stems from an investigation by Virginia consumer protection officials into the conduct of Telco Communications, which raises funds for police organizations and firefighter unions. The state Office of Consumer Affairs said it received complaints that Telco was misleading potential donors. For example, the state said, one solicitor allegedly lied and claimed he was a volunteer. State officials met with Telco officials in 1988 without reaching any resolution. About two weeks later, the company sued in federal court to block the state from taking any action. The state said the federal judge should not interfere, particularly since the state's investigation was incomplete. But the judge ruled against the consumer protection office. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last September upheld much of the judge's ruling. The appeals court said federal judges may bar state enforcement in such cases ``where state proceedings were in a preliminary stage and where the state had imposed a prior restraint upon protected speech.'' Otherwise, the appeals court said, it ``would leave a party's constitutional rights in limbo while an agency contemplates enforcement but does not undertake it.'' The appeals court said there no longer is a live controversy over one of the state's anti-fraud laws that required professional solicitors to tell potential donors how much of their contributions will go to the charities. A Supreme Court ruling in 1988 prohibits such laws, the appeals court said. The appeals court also struck down a Virginia regulation that solicitors must submit to the state, in advance, a written script of what it tells potential donors. That kind of review by the state amounts to an unconstitutional prior restraint on speech, the appeals court said. But the 4th Circuit court upheld a Virginia regulation requiring solicitors to tell potential donors in writing that the fund-raiser's financial statements are available from the state consumer affairs office. The appeals court refused to decide whether the state may suspend or revoke a fund-raiser's right to do business for violating the anti-fraud rules. It would be premature to decide that issue since Telco was not accused of violating any regulations, the appeals court said. The case is Carbaugh vs. Telco Communications, 89-1311.

DOC.HEAD: Polhill Malnourished, Iran Seeks Reciprocal Gesture For Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with UPDATE with Musawi saying another release `in the cards,' U.S. comments, details. Pick up 8th pvs, `Polhill a...' Minor editing thereafter to trim, conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FRA1
DOC.TEXT: A frail-looking Robert Polhill, the first American released by pro-Iranian Lebanese captors in nearly 3{ years, walked slowly off a plane today after winning freedom with the aid of Syria and Iran. Doctors who later examined the 55-year-old educator said he was malnourished and mildly dehydrated. Polhill's release Sunday after 1,182 days of captivity was followed by a reported call by Iran's foreign minister for a swift reciprocal move _ freedom for a Shiite Moslem cleric kidnapped by Israeli troops in July. President Bush thanked Iran and Syria _ whose military forces in Lebanon picked up Polhill in west Beirut and drove him to the Syrian capital of Damascus _ for their help in securing the release. But the president said he would make no deals with the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants in Lebanon still holding 17 Western hostages, seven of them Americans. An Iranian newspaper close to that country's president, Hashemi Rafsanjani, today called on the Lebanese kidnappers to release another American hostage immediately and without conditions. Rafsanjani is among Iranian leaders seeking better relations with the West. The Bush administration has expressed willingness to improve ties if the hostage crisis is settled. And in Beirut, Hussein Musawi, a leading pro-Iranian Shiite cleric, said today that freeing another Western hostage was ``in the cards.'' But he stressed there must first be reciprocity on the part of Washington. Musawi, interviewed by the communist-run Voice of the People, said: ``The possibility of another release is in the cards, but I don't know when, how or for what. ``Such a step (Polhill's release) has to have a reciprocation. It is not feasible that all releases would be made as goodwill gestures,'' he said. He refused to speculate on which hostage might be freed next. U.S. officials said today in Wiesbaden that they had no information about another U.S. hostage being released. They said they were ``not aware of any message for Bush'' Polhill may have brought from his captors. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Polhill was kept in the same building as American hostages Jesse Turner and Alann Steen, but ``he probably doesn't know about Terry Anderson or Terry Waite.'' Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. He has been held the longest of the foreign hostages. Waite, 50, British envoy of the Anglican Church, disappeared in Lebanon on Jan. 20, 1987. Polhill, a New Yorker, looked extremely frail today and was hunched over as he came down the steps of the U.S. Air Force C-141 at Rhein-Main air base in a cold rain, supported by two airmen. He was dressed in a military camouflage jacket and carried a football given to him as ``a touch of America'' under one arm during the short walk to a military van. About two dozen people nearby applauded, and the gaunt Polhill responded with a wave. A helicopter whisked the freed hostage and his Lebanese wife, Feryal, to a U.S. military hospital in nearby Wiesbaden. ``Welcome home, pray for the others,'' read one banner hung outside the hospital, where Polhill began medical tests and was to be debriefed by U.S. intelligence agents. Military spokesman Cmdr. John Woodhouse said Polhill's stay at the hospital, which has received other freed U.S. hostages, could be anywhere from ``a couple of days to a few weeks.'' ``He is alert, stable, ambulatory and somewhat tired,'' said a medical bulletin based on Polhill's first two hours in the hospital. ``Although he appears to be in relatively good shape, he is malnourished and mildly dehydrated.'' It said doctors would also make an evaluation of Polhill's diabetes, which he has had for 25 years. Polhill arrived at the hospital saying he was hungry, and quickly downed a breakfast of grapefruit, scrambled eggs, bacon, English muffins, milk and coffee. The ex-hostage later had a ``relaxed conversation with medical staff,'' according to the statement. About 100 people cheered and clapped as Polhill arrived in Wiesbaden. In Damascus, the business professor said his unrelenting anger at his captors had kept him alive and sane during the ordeal. He also said that his joy at being free was tempered by the knowledge that others were still held. ``I was angry at what was being done to me, being taken away from my wife and family,'' he told a Syrian TV reporter as he was being driven from Beirut to Damascus. ``And so I strived to continue being angry, knowing at all times that if I began to lose that anger I'd just sort of become a vegetable.'' Iran's foreign minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, said in New York after the release that Iran and the Shiite factions in Lebanon want the Israelis to release Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid in return, the official Syrian Arab News Agency reported. Obeid was kidnapped in south Lebanon. The Tehran Times, which is close to Rafsanjani, said in an editorial today that as long as Israel still holds scores of Arab prisoners, the captors ``will certainly find it hard to comply'' with the request for more releases. ``But perhaps the release of one hostage alone will not be enough to establish the kind of overwhelming trust needed to bring the whole hostage crisis to an end,'' it said. Though pale and apparently fatigued, Polhill managed to joke with reporters shortly after being turned over to U.S. Ambassador Edward Djerejian in Syria. ``The first thing I'd like to say is that I'm sorry I kept you waiting so long,'' he told a news conference at the Syrian Foreign Ministry. Polhill was abducted along with two other professors from Beirut University College on Jan. 24, 1987 by the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. The group still holds the other two: Jesse Turner, 42, of Boise, Idaho, and Alann Steen, a 51-year-old Boston native. The last American hostage to be freed was David Jacobsen, former director of the American University Hospital in Beirut. He was kidnapped in Beirut on May 28, 1985, and released Nov. 2, 1986. He had been held by another Shiite faction, Islamic Jihad, or Holy War.

DOC.HEAD: Court Agrees to Decide Prison Inmate Issue in Colorado Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether prison inmates who testify in federal court proceedings should be paid witness fees. The court said it will hear an appeal by a Colorado state prison inmate seeking compensation for testifying at a 1988 federal trial. The inmate, Richard S. Demarest, testified for the defendant on March 15, 1988. He said he should be entitled to the same fee as anyone else who is a witness in federal court. The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last September that federal law does not require that prisoners be paid for appearing at federal trials. ``Beyond their loss of the very modest compensation they might receive from participating in prison jobs programs, prisoners generally do not incur financial costs serving as witnesses,'' the appeals court said. The appeals courted noted that the $30-a-day witness fee is much more that inmates make working in prison industries. Demarest, for example, is paid $40 a month in his job at the Arkansas Valley Correctional Facility in Crowley, Colorado. The appeals court said paying prisoners could lead to abuses since it would tempt inmates, who number in the millions, to file suits and then subpoena inmate friends to testify. The Bush administration urged the Supreme Court to reject Demarest's appeal. The case is Demarest vs. Manspeaker, 89-5916.

DOC.HEAD: Court Agrees to Hear Appeal of Georgia Death Row Inmate
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear the appeal of Georgia death row inmate James A. Ford, convicted of kidnapping and killing a Newnan gas station manager in 1984. The court said it will decide whether Ford is entitled to a new trial because prosecutors used so-called ``peremptory challenges'' to exclude blacks from the jury. The justices in 1986 barred prosecutors from disqualifying potential jurors based on their race. And in 1987, they said that the 1986 ruling was to be applied retroactively to perhaps hundreds of other convicted defendants. But Georgia courts refused to apply the Supreme Court decisions in Ford's case. Today, the justices said they will judge the validity of the Georgia courts' refusal. Ford was convicted of killing Sarah Dean after taking her from a gas station on March 1, 1984. Ms. Dean's ody was found locked in the trunk of her car, which was submerged in a pond. Police said she had drowned. The case is Ford vs. Georgia, 87-6796.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Say 50 Civilians Killed, 110 Wounded in Air Raids
DOC.TEXT: Government warplanes dropped cluster bombs in two raids on the guerrilla-held Red Sea port of Massawa, killing 50 civilians and wounding 110, Ethiopian rebels said today. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front said it expected the death toll to rise from Sunday's attacks as most of the wounded were in ``very bad condition,'' according to a clandestine radio report monitored in the Kenyan capital of Nairobi. About 50 houses were destroyed in the mid-morning and early evening raids, the radio said. The rebel-operated Voice of the Broad Masses of Eritrea gave no further details of the air strikes, the latest since secessionist guerrillas captured Massawa from government forces in February. The report on the air raids could not be independently verified. Massawa is one of two strategic harbors that traditionally handle most of Ethiopia's trade and relief supplies for millions of people threatened with starvation in the face of war, drought and poor harvests. The Eritrean Front has been fighting for control of Ethiopia's northernmost province since 1961, a year after the former Italian colony lost political autonomy and was forcibly annexed by the late Emperor Haile Selassie as a province. Rebels hold other towns and villages in Eritrea and, with backing from other guerrilla armies, are seeking to overthrow Marxist President Mengistu Haile Mariam. The rebel radio has reported several previous raids by warplanes dropping cluster bombs and napalm on civilians. They have been denied by the Addis Ababa government. Israel has been accused of supplying the cluster bombs, which contain dozens of smaller grenade-like bomblets that hurl shrapnel over wide areas. Both Israel and Ethiopia have denied these claims.

DOC.HEAD: Crowd Takes Home Earth Day Message But Not Trash
With AM-Earth Day Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Old habits die hard, even for the environmentally aware. After Earth Day 1990 activities Sunday, the grounds of the old state capitol and the Centroplex auditorium were strewn with beer cans, soda cups, hamburger wrappers and other rubbish. ``You're not going to change people's actions overnight,'' said local Earth Day chairman Paul Davidson. ``I'd like to think it's cleaner than at past festivals, but I don't know.'' City worker Bonnie Miles and his seven-member cleanup crew worked for three hours, filling about 65 trash bins to overflowing. Several volunteers also stuck around to help clean up. Cathy Hickman dragged around a 30-gallon trash bag filled with aluminum cans, which can be recycled. ``I started out with one of those (convenience store) bags with two handles, and I ended up with this one,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Premier Arrives in Moscow; Meets With Ryzhkov
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Peng meeting with Ryzhkov; Pickup 7th graf pvs, `Gorbachev's historic...'
DOC.TEXT: Chinese Premier Li Peng arrived today for the first visit in 26 years by a Chinese head of government to the Soviet Union, China's longtime rival for leadership of the Communist world. The four-day trip is to promote normal relations and ease border tensions at a time when both countries are confronted with serious domestic problems. The 61-year-old premier was expected to hold at least two rounds of talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who last May went to China in the first visit by a Soviet leader in three decades. ``Li's visit to the U.S.S.R. underscores the importance of continuing the Sino-Soviet dialogue at the summit level, which began a year ago and signalled the normalization of relations,'' the Tass news agency said. Li was met at the airport by Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov and Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. ``I will be exchanging views with President Gorbachev, Chairman Ryzhkov and other comrades from the Soviet leadership on matters concerning bilateral relations and on major international issues of common concern,'' Li said at the airport. Tass said Ryzhkov and Peng began meeting Monday but did not report what they were discussing. Gorbachev's historic visit to China was overshadowed by student-led pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing, which ended weeks later when Li and other Chinese leaders sent in troops to crush the movement. In Moscow, Gorbachev is contending with the crisis in Lithuania, which declared independence March 11. The official Chinse press, before Li's departure, said his trip would have ``profound significance'' on peace in Asia and the world. China and the Soviet Union split over ideological differences in 1960 and fought a brief border war in 1969. In 1972, China restored relations with the United States, in part because then-leader Mao Tse-tung saw the Soviet Union as China's most serious military threat. Western diplomats in Beijing said China has stressed it will never be a docile Soviet ally as it was in the 1950s, and they noted that China's inherent suspicions of Soviet aims have grown with Gorbachev's reform policies. The ideological hard-liners who now rule China reportedly blame Gorbachev for the fall of Communist parties in Eastern Europe and see perestroika _ Gorbachev's program of political and economic reform _ as leading to the demise of socialism. Tass said both the Soviet Union and China agreed that the latest rounds of talks will not presage a return to the relationship of the 1950s, ``but the departure from the confrontation that existed in the past.'' The news agency said the two sides have shown readiness to reduce troops deployed in the area of the Soviet-Chinese border and have agreed to a treaty on the reductions. It said the current talks will enable the two countries to improve cooperation in trade, economic, scientific-technical, cultural and other areas. The last Chinese premier to visit Moscow was Li's foster father, Chou-En-lai, who met then-Soviet leaders Leonid Brezhnev and Alexei Kosygin in 1964. Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, Deputy Chief of General Staff Xu Xin and Li's wife, Zhu Lin, accompanied the premier on his visit.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says No Deals For Hostages
DOC.NOTE: EDs: TOPS with 10 grafs with White House comments today; picks up 3rd pvs, John Kelly...; edits at end to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today that the United States will not deal for hostages, and it will take the unconditional release of all those still in captivity in Lebanon to ``open the door towards better relations with Iran.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said preliminary reports from a U.S. Air Force hospital in Wiesbaden, West Germany, indicate Robert Polhill ``is malnourished and dehydrated, but ... in relatively good condition'' after being freed Sunday after 39 months in captivity. Fitzwater did not say what the United States would do next, but said, ``We are not going to trade for hostages, however, or make deals.'' ``We do not know what was the specific motivation for the release. We have always believed that Iran has control or at least influence over the hostage holders,'' he said. ``Iran has been supportive of Mr. Polhill's release. We appreciate that.'' He said debriefing of Polhill was just beginning. ``The only information we have is that he was with (fellow teachers Jesse) Turner and (Alann) Steen throughout most of his captivity, up until the last few days. But I don't have any other details, other than they are alive and he was with them.'' He echoed the hard line that Bush struck after learning of the release Sunday while fishing off the Florida Keys. ``As the president said yesterday, we want the release of all hostages. That would open the door towards better relations with Iran,'' said Fitzwater. Fitzwater said the United States is ``also looking for an accounting as to the status of the two missing hostages _ William Buckley and Lt. Col. Richard Higgins'' _ both believed killed by their captors. Bush said he would make no gesture towards Iran or others until all the hostages are free. ``This is a mission uncompleted. There are other Americans held against their will,'' Bush said in Islamorada, Fla., after speaking by telephone with Polhill. John Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, said today that Bush's policy on the hostages ``is very clear. We don't make deals.'' However, Kelly, appearing on NBC-TV's ``Today'' show, said ``we're going to be talking to the Syrians. We have been in contact indirectly with Iran and we're going to keep working as hard as we can on this issue.'' Asked if release of another hostage was imminent, Kelly said ``it's too early to say with any certainty whether that will be the case but we certainly hope it is.'' Bush's initial written reaction made a small bow in Iran's direction. The written statement thanked ``those who had a hand in the release, particularly the governments of Syria and Iran whose efforts have contributed to the release of this hostage.'' Syria's role was obvious, as its diplomats arranged to pick Polhill up in Beirut from his captors then whisked him to safety in Damascus. However, Bush omitted Iran from his words of appreciation in a face-to-face meeting with reporters. He said, ``I can't tell you I honestly know what (Iran's role in the release) is. But I'd have goodwill to those who facilitated the release. If that included Iran, absolutely.'' His spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said, ``There were no deals, no negotiations with the hostage-takers. We have no way of identifying any specific action on our part that could have been a contributing factor'' to the release. Bush, who last week refused the kidnappers' request that he send envoy John Kelly to Damascus, said he felt ``great joy,'' but ``I don't have forgiveness in my heart as long as one American is held against his will.'' ``I will carry the burden of the other hostages with me until every single one of them is free,'' he said. ``There's not a night goes by that I don't think about it.'' The Tehran Times newspaper said in an editorial today that another hostage should be freed to test ``President Bush's claim that `goodwill begets goodwill.''' Meanwhile, Iran's foreign minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, was quoted today by the official Syrian Arab News Agency as saying the pro-Iranian extremists in Lebanon wanted a quick reciprocal move. The United States maintains that Iran has influence over the groups still holding the Americans and 10 other Westerners in Lebanon. The hostages include Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, kidnapped on March 16, 1985. Polhill was a hostage for almost 39 months, along with two fellow American teachers at Beirut University College who ignored U.S. warnings to leave the war-torn country. Bush told reporters on Sunday, ``I'm not trying to think up any gestures'' to make toward Iran. ``I'm not making gestures. I don't trade for hostages. I don't go ante up, one step and another,'' he said. On the Soviet crackdown against Lithuania, Bush said he has not yet decided what action to take. The White House said Friday that Bush would confer with leaders of Congress early this week after completing consultations with U.S. allies. Bush received word of Polhill's release by ship-to-shore phone as he was fishing in the Everglades with national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and other. Bush began his observance of Sunday's Earth Day on an Islamorada beach at sunrise, honoring activists who work to protect the Keys' coral reefs and announcing an effort to declare the waters within 10 miles of the Keys off limits to big ships and oil freighters.

DOC.HEAD: Abernathy Recalled as a Unifying Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to update with number of people viewing body, raise reference to funeral, picking up at the 11th graf pvs, `On Sunday...'. Funeral begins noon EDT; late PMs lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights leaders sent up a chorus of praise for the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, saying they preferred to remember him for his contributions to the cause rather than for the controversy that followed him to the grave. About 2,000 people attended a memorial service Sunday at the Baptist church where the Rev. Martin Luther King's closest friend and chief lieutenant had been pastor since 1961. Abernathy died of a heart attack Tuesday at age 64. Officials at Abernathy's church, West Hunter Street Baptist, said about 2,500 people had filed through the church Sunday and this morning to pay their respects. Funeral services were scheduled for this afternoon at the church. Abernathy was to be taken to his crypt at a in a mule-drawn wagon, the symbol of humility he had suggested for King's funeral. The motorcade was to travel along Martin Luther King Jr. Drive. Among those who had worked closely with Abernathy, gone was any trace of outrage for writing in his autobiography about King's alleged marital infidelity. Abernathy was branded a Judas last year because of the passages. ``There's always been unity, even when there's been disagreement,'' said former Mayor Andrew Young, now a candidate for governor. ``I wouldn't be doing what I'm doing now if Ralph had not been where he was, doing what he was doing.'' ``We must judge him on what he meant to our struggle, and he was high up on the honor roll,'' said Jesse Jackson. ``I think those who would focus on a point they may disagree on must mix the bitter with the sweet, and it comes out much sweeter.'' Abernathy, who with King founded the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, worked with him to organize the Montgomery, Ala., bus boycott, marched with him in Selma, Ala., and in Washington, and cradled his bloody head when he was cut down by an assassin's bullet in Memphis, Tenn., in 1968. ``At every great, critical moment, he was present,'' Jackson said. ``Very few people can say their fingerprints are on each wall that fell down.'' On Sunday, mourners, some carrying children, walked past the coffin, and several touched the sleeves of Abernathy's white ministerial robe. Those attending included Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Martin Luther King III. Abernathy had written his own epitaph, ``I tried.'' ``Yes, Ralph, you did try,'' said the Rev. Robert G. Grant, president of the American Freedom Coalition in Washington. ``You tried to bring your people those normal things of life that most people take for granted.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Give New Lift to Suit Over Shirley MacLaine Book
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS spelling of MacLaine in 3rd graf, bgng, Silva's suit...
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to give new life to a copyright lawsuit over actress Shirley MacLaine's 1983 best-selling book, ``Out on a Limb.'' The court, without comment, let stand rulings that MacLaine's book about reincarnation and other spiritual subjects did not infringe the copyright of a 1977 book written by Charles Silva. Silva's suit sought monetary damages from MacLaine and the American Broadcasting Companies Inc., which in 1987 made a television movie based on the book. Silva, from Peru, authored ``Date With the Gods'' in 1977, and sent a copy to MacLaine. She later discussed it with him, and eventually traveled with him to areas of Peru described in his book. Silva's book tells of his asserted encounters with an extraterrestrial woman high in the Andes mountains. As described by U.S. District Judge Horace Gilmore, ``Date With the Gods'' does not discuss reincarnation in detail but implies that when one dies, his spirit might become embodied in another living form. Silva's suit was filed in Detroit. His book's publisher, Living Waters Publishing and Distributing Inc., is based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Gilmore dismissed Silva's suit after concluding that there is ``no substantial similarity'' between the two books. The 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld Gilmore's ruling last Nov. 7. The case is Silva vs. MacLaine, 89-1475.

DOC.HEAD: Court Sets Aside Ruling in Minnesota Amish Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today raised the possibility that Minnesota officials may enforce a traffic safety law against certain members of an Amish sect in rural Fillmore County. The court set aside a Minnesota Supreme Court ruling that barred such enforcement. The justices told the state court to reconsider the case in light of their decision last week allowing states to outlaw the religious use of the illegal drug peyote. In a brief order today issued over two dissenting votes, the court said the Minnesota court should restudy the Amish controversy after examining the peyote ruling from Oregon. In that case, members of the Native American Church contended that punishing the religious use of peyote violated religious freedom. In the Minnesota case, the state Supreme Court ruled that requiring the Amish to display a ``slow-moving vehicle'' warning emblem on the back of their horse-drawn buggies violated their religious freedom. A state law requires that slow-moving vehicles display a yellow-orange triangular emblem to warn other drivers. The law provided for one alternative _ a black and white triangular emblem. Not all members of the Amish sect living in Fillmore County, in southeastern Minnesota near the Iowa border, object to the emblem. But 14 who did were issued citations for refusing to attach the emblems to their black buggies. The 14 say the loud colors and worldly symbols conflict with Biblical admonitions against putting their faith in anything but God. A state trial judge ruled that enforcing the traffic law against the 14 Amish members did not violate any right, but the Minnesota Supreme Court unanimously threw out all charges against them last August. The state's highest court ruled that the requirement infringed on the exercise of a sincerely held religious belief and, most importantly, the state's compelling interest in traffic safety could be served by a less-restrictive requirement. Noting that the Amish do not object to outlining their buggies with silver reflective tape or to displaying red lit lanterns to supplement the tape, the state Supreme Court said, ``There does exist a less restrictive alternative to serve the state's public safety concerns.'' In the appeal acted on today, County Attorney Robert R. Benson argued that the state court ``impermissibly advances religion by allowing the Amish special rights, which individuals outside that religious group cannot enjoy.'' Lawyers for the Amish said Benson is wrong. ``There is ample room for legislatures and courts to craft religious accommodations and yet not establish (or advance) religion,'' they said. ``The Minnesota Supreme Court ... has not established religion by allowing the Amish to use reflective tape and the traditional red lantern on their buggies instead of forcing them to use an orange fluorescent or black worldly symbol.'' Justices John Paul Stevens and Sandra Day O'Connor dissented from the high court's action today, without stating their reasons. The case is Minnesota vs. Hershberger, 89-804.

DOC.HEAD: Trouble Flares At Two British Prisons
DOC.TEXT: About 100 inmates remained on the roof of a prison on the outskirts of Bristol today following a night of violence that left three guards injured. Authorities also reported overnight trouble at Long Lartin, a high security prison in Evesham, northwest of London, where an inmate took another prisoner hostage and held him in a cell at knifepoint. Authorites speculated that the disturbance at the Pucklechurch Remand Center near Bristol in western England may have been inspired by the riot 23 days ago at Manchester's Strangeways Prison. Seven inmates remained on the Strangeways' roof today while prison negotiators continued what they called their ``softly, softly'' strategy for talking the men down. Officials at Pucklechurch said they would be more aggressive about retaking the wing of the facility held by the prisoners. ``Our intention is to retake the occupied areas of the establishment as quickly as possible using the minimum amount of force necessary for that aim,'' said Mick Cook, a spokesman for Pucklechurch. It was not known what caused the riot at Pucklechurch. The Strangeways riot was sparked by overcrowding, but authorities said Pucklechurch is not overcrowded. At Pucklechurch, about 120 inmates snatched a prison officer late Sunday as they returned from the exercise yard. They took away his keys, released other prisoners and then freed him less than an hour later, authorities said. The prisoners climbed on the roof and began hurling missiles onto the staff. Three prison officers were injured, including one officer who required hospitalization after being hit in the face with a brick. Before dawn today, prison staff had retaken the central wing, one of three wings in the male section, authorities said. A Home Office spokesman, speaking on condition he not be identified, said 20 prisoners had given themselves up. The inmates who spent the night on the roof, lit fires to keep warm. The remaining prisoners were locked in the other wings, and more than 40 female prisoners were moved out of Pucklechurch. A senior member of the prison staff said special contingency plans had been put into operation, and officers from other prisons trained in control and restraint techniques, were called in to the scene. The Home Office spokesman said there were no indications over the weekend that a disturbance was likely. At Long Lartin, efforts continued through the night to persuade the captor to give up his victim, but the rest of the jail was quiet, the Home Office spokesman said. It was not known if the hostage-taker had made any specific demands. On April 4, prison staff at Long Lartin foiled a breakout attempt by nine inmates who were caught as they cut through an inner perimeter wire fence. At the same time, 32 other inmates staged a demonstration and barricaded themselves into one of the prison's wings for 13 hours before surrendering.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Use Mississippi Death Row Inmate to Provide Questioning Guidelines
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to use the case of a Mississippi death row inmate to provide new guidelines for police questioning of suspects. The court said it will hear an appeal by Robert S. Minnick, a convicted murderer who said his confession was unlawful because he was denied his right to have a lawyer present. Minnick and James ``Monkey'' Dyess escaped from Clarke County, Miss., jail in April 1986 and went looking for guns, authorities said. Police said the two men fatally shot Donald Ellis Thomas and Lamar Lafferty when the victims returned to Thomas's mobile home to find Minnick and Dyess there. Minnick was arrested in Lemon Grove, Calif., on Aug. 22, 1986. FBI agents ended their questioning of him when he asked for a lawyer. Minnick then met with an attorney who advised him not to answer any more questions. A few days later, Deputy Sheriff J.C. Denham of Clarke County flew to California and questioned Minnick. The defendant confessed to murder, saying he shot Lafferty because Dyess was threatening to kill Minnick if he did not. Minnick was convicted in Mississippi and sentenced to death. He said in his appeal that his rights were violated because he never agreed to talk to Denham without a lawyer present. The Mississippi Supreme Court upheld his conviction, ruling use of the confession was lawful. The state court said since Minnick previously had talked to a lawyer but still agreed to speak to Denham, his right to have a lawyer was not violated. The state court said Denham's questioning of Minnick did not violate the rule the U.S. Supreme Court established in 1981 when it barred police from questioning a suspect who has asked for a lawyer unless the suspect initiates the conversation. The case is Minnick vs. Mississippi, 89-6332.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian President Says Gorbachev Raising Stakes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Landsbergis comments; EDITS to trim; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is staking everything on the Lithuanian crisis by not excluding the use of Soviet troops in the Baltic republic. Landsbergis also asked the Lithuanian parliament, the Supreme Council, to draw up emergency plans to deal with mass layoffs expected in the republic because of the Kremlin's economic blockade. The republic of 3.8 million began its first full work week since the Soviet president cut off supplies of oil, natural gas and other raw materials to the republic, which declared independence on March 11. Vilnius' main thouroughfare, Gedimina Street, was practically devoid of vehicles today as Lithuanians struggled with gasoline rationing that limits them to about seven gallons per month. Bus service among cities also was curtailed sharply. On Sunday Lithuania halted exports to Soviet republics and foreign customers, claiming Moscow was imposing a total embargo. But also Sunday, a visiting Soviet official denied any general blockade existed. The British Broadcasting Corp., meanwhile, quoted Gorbachev's senior military adviser, Marshall Sergei Akhromeyev, as saying the Red Army won't hesitate to use force to crush illegal protests in Lithuania. ``If the Lithuanian separatists break the law, then we will take measures to enforce the law. I am not afraid of using force if necessary,'' he said in an interview for broadcast on the BBC's ``Panorama'' program. When asked about Akhromeyev's comments, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis told reporters: ``We must worry about such insanity. It's military madness. Force is always a real threat as long as there is no willingness to use politics. If they use force in Lithuania, it means they would be prepared to use force in the world.'' According to a parliamentary spokeswoman, Rita Dapkus, Landsbergis later told lawmakers that by refusing to rule out the use of force, Gorbachev was staking everything. The Lithuanian president used card-players' slang that Gorbachev was ``playing the bank'' _ literally risking all. ``There are signs from the U.S.S.R. that raise worries,'' Landsbergis added, according to Ms. Dapkus. ``President Gorbachev is being placed in the artificial position that plays the role of putting the rest of the world into a dilemma of whom to support _ Lithuania or Gorbachev.'' Ms. Dapkus said Landsbergis called this ``an artificial ploy.'' Soviet troops have used force twice already, to round up Lithuanian army deserters and to occupy a Vilnius printing plant. In Moscow, Arkady Maslennikov, Gorbachev's press secretary, said today the Kremlin might negotiate with Lithuania if it freezes its declaration of independence for two years. But Maslennikov made it clear the breakaway republic also would have to admit it is subject to the Soviet Constitution. Lithuanian leaders refuse to do that, saying the republic was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Soviet leaders are willing to talk to Lithuanian officials if they acknowledge jurisdiction of the Soviet Constitution ``either by rescinding or freezing'' the independence decisions, Maslennikov said at a press briefing. Over the weekend, Landsbergis denied reports the declaration of independence would be frozen for two years in hopes of reaching a compromise with Moscow. Maslennikov said he did not know if any Soviet leaders would meet a Lithuanian delegation that arrived today. ``It depends on what they've come with.'' Ms. Dapku quoted Landsbergis as saying parliament should draft an emergency plan for when Gorbachev's economic blockade starts throwing Lithuanians out of work. ``We have to think about what we will suggest to the people, how to act in an extreme situation when they will lose their jobs,'' she quoted him as saying. The embargo is expected to take jobs from 70 percent of the republic's workforce of 500,000 people. Landsbergis referred to Gorbachev's embargo as a ``total blockade.'' A Soviet official on Sunday denied that any general blockade existed. ``Plans for a total blockade don't exist,'' said Andrei N. Girenko, a Communist Party Central Committee member. However, Lithuanian Deputy Premier Romualdas Ozolas said Sunday Lithuanian ports have stopped loading goods bound for foreign countries and stopped sending some products to other Soviet republics. Lithuania said in a telegram to Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov the Soviet cutoff would choke Lithuanian processing and manufacturing of goods meant both for export and for the Soviet domestic market. A Leningrad journalist said today long lines already were forming at gasoline stations in that city as residents feared that refined petroleum products processed in Lithuania would be cut back. Gorbachev said last week he would halt the shipment to Lithuania of exportable products unless Lithuania backs away from measures furthering its independence decree. An embargo on oil and most natural gas began Wednesday and Ozolas said Lithuania's only oil refinery, at Mazhiekiai, would shut down today. Lithuania and itsd Baltic neighbors Latvia and Estonia are trying to restore independence lost in 1940 when they were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Discuss Lithuania With Congressional Leaders
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will meet on Tuesday with congressional leaders to discuss a U.S. response to the Soviet Union's economic blockade of Lithuania, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said today. ``We don't want to give any indication to what actions we might take,'' Fitzwater. He declined to comment on speculation that the United States might postpone planned trade and investment assistance to the Soviet Union. However, Fitzwater said, ``I rule out no options.'' U.S.-Soviet trade liberalization talks were scheduled to begin in Paris on Tuesday. ``The decision has not been made by the president yet. It depends upon analysis being conducted by the NSC (National Security Council) and the State Department at this time,'' Fitzwater said. Bush was to meet with congressional leaders Tuesday morning. ``We may or may not have an announcement at that time,'' Fitzwater said. Asked about news reports suggesting a possible framework for negotiations between Moscow and the rebellious Baltic state, Fitzwater said: ``The statements this morning do appear to show some flexibility. We are hopeful that's the case.'' ``We have urged peaceful dialogue as a way of resolving this issue. It's impossible for us to know exactly what these statements this morning mean. But if they are indicative of the two sides being able to get together, that's a welcome sign,'' Fitzwater said. Meanwhile, Fitzwater announced that a planned meeting between Alexsandr Yakovley, the Soviet Communist Party secretary, and Vice President Dan Quayle had been postponed.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed for release 12:01 a.m. EDT Tuesday; time set by source
DOC.HEAD: Senators Got $96 Million From PACs In 1983-1988
DOC.TEXT: Incumbent senators received more than $96 million in donations from political action committees from 1983 through 1988, a group seeking restrictions on such donations said Tuesday. Four senators received more than $2 million from PACs, according to Common Cause, one of several groups lobbying for an overhaul of campaign finance laws. The group said 44 of the 99 incumbents received at least $1 million in PAC money during the six-year period. The totals were compiled from Federal Election Commission data. Sen. Spark Matsunaga, D-Hawaii, who died earlier this month, was not included. The four senators whose PAC donations from 1983-88 exceeded $2 million were: Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, $2.5 million; Pete Wilson, R-Calif., $2.3 million; Slade Gorton, R-Wash., $2.2 million; and Phil Gramm, R-Texas, $2 million. Common Cause said finance-industry PACs _ those associated with banks, savings and loans and other financial institutions _ were the top contributors during the period. The top recipient of finance-industry PAC donations was Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, according to Common Cause. Riegle, the group said, received $344,000 in such donations. Common Cause and its allies long have sought legislation to outlaw PAC donations. The groups have focused this year on trying to persuade Congress to adopt voluntary campaign spending caps. Those caps would include a limit on how much of that money could come from PAC donations. Senate debate on the issue is expected to begin this week.

DOC.HEAD: Snake Shoots Hunter During Struggle
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian hunter was shot to death Monday near Tehran by a snake that coiled itself around his shotgun as he pinned the reptile to the ground, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, quoted another hunter as saying that the victim, Ali-Asghar Ahani, tried to catch the snake alive by pressing the butt of his shotgun behind its head. But the snake coiled around the butt and accidentally pulled the trigger with its thrashing tail, firing one of the barrels and shooting Ahani in the head, IRNA said. The other hunter tried to grab the shotgun, but the writhing reptile triggered the other barrel, the agency said. ``I was lucky not to get hurt,'' the unidentified man was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Gunfire Erupts Nightly Along Pakistan-India Cease-Fire Line
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: ALONG THE CEASE-FIRE LINE, Kashmir, Pakistan (AP) _ Gunfire erupts nightly along the cease-fire line that weaves through the spectacular snow-covered peaks and lush, freshly tilled valleys of disputed Kashmir. Pakistani and Indian soldiers crouched in their camouflaged bunkers only yards apart routinely take pot shots at each other, raising fears that a fourth war could break out between the two nations. ``Any time any place they can come, we can take them,'' Col. Naeem Abid of Pakistan boasted from his commamd center at Pandu, overlooking one of the most explosive spots along a cease-fire line that splits the former princely state of Kashmir between India and Paksitan. A Pakistani flag still flies from an Indian bunker at Chakhoti, thousands of feet almost directly below Pandu. ``They are afraid we will shoot at them if they try to take it down,'' Abid said. ``There is fear in their minds.'' Three Pakistanis died putting that flag up in February. They were shot when Indian border guards opened fire on a crowd of several thousand people, mostly students, who swarmed across the border. Keeping the flag in place has now become a matter of pride for the Pakistan soldiers guarding the area, Abid said. Time passes slowly for soldiers manning the remote peaks of the Pir Panjal mountain range. Foreign journalists visited their bunkers Sunday during a helicopter tour of the cease-fire line arranged by Pakistan's government. Both countries talk of war, and the latest rhetoric between the governments in Islamabad and New Delhi dominates long evening conversations, Abid said. Twice the two neighbors have gone to war over Kashmir _ in 1948 and in 1965. A third war was fought over Bangladesh, or what was then East Pakistan. ``If it's forced upon us, we'll ... teach them a lesson,'' Abid said. The normal Indian troop strength along the 490-mile cease-fire line is 245,000 military and paramilitary troops, said a Pakistan Defense Ministry spokesman who cannot be identified under briefing rules. The Indian government does not disclose such numbers. The Pakistani spokesman said India has deployed another 70,000 throughout Jammu-Kashmir state, India's only Moslem state. Most of those soldiers, he said, are assigned to quell a Moslem secessionist uprising that has claimed at least 292 lives since Jan. 20, when the Indian government ordered a crackdown. The militants once demanded that the Kashmir valley become part of Pakistan, but now they want independence and the status of a neutral nation. Pakistan has 100,000 soldiers along the cease-fire line, which was negotiated and now monitored by U.N. peacekeeping forces. India regularly accuses Pakistan of fomenting violence in its troubled state, a charge as often denied by Pakistan. The accusations have intensified in recent weeks, with each side accusing the other of preparing for war. The foreign ministers of India and Pakistan are attending a U.N. session on Third World economies in New York this week, and they have indicated they may meet privately to try to defuse tensions between their countries. From a helicopter flying along the cease-fire line Sunday, there was little evidence of a troop buildup on Pakistan's side. Only sporadic traffic moved on the roads snaking through the mountain passes. ``Being on the border we have to be on maximum alert, be it day or night,'' said Lt. Col Abdul Rasheed. He spoke from his isolated outpost 7,800 feet up in the mountains at Chirikot. Rasheed's compound, with its labyrinth of tunnels and underground bunkers, was the first stop on the helicopter tour along the cease-fire line. Indian and Pakistani soldiers at Chirikot had exchanged gunfire for about five hours on Saturday, he said. ``It happens every night,'' Rasheed said. Two days earlier, a 14-year-old girl was rushed to the hospital with gunshot wounds, he said. ``They resort to shooting civilians. We resent that,'' he said. ``They are intentionally provoking us.'' New Delhi says civilians shot along the border are en route to Pakistan for training and weapons to continue their violent insurgency in Jammu-Kashmir. The entire population of the village of Khantawal, only miles inside Indian-held Kashmir, fled to Pakistan about one week ago, accusing Indian border guards of a litany of abuses. While Pakistan denies training and arming the militants, thousands are reportedly in Pakistan-held Kashmir. In a small tent village on the grounds of an abandoned factory in Muzzaffarabad, the capital of Azad (Free) Kashmir, about 70 young boys wait for weapons. ``We want weapons _ guns, rocket launchers, pistols, everything,'' said Salim, 20, who uses only one name. ``But Pakistan still is not doing anything for us.''

DOC.HEAD: Milken Won't Have to Name Names, Source Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, Milkin is...', to UPDATE with judge's office confirming Tuesday as date for hearing. Note that a0500 should have been slugged 2nd Ld - Writethru. A longer version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Junk bond king Michael Milken will not have to name names of Wall Street cheats in exchange for being allowed to plead guilty, a source says. The arrangement differs sharply from the deal reached by Milken's accuser, Ivan Boesky, who was required to give evidence against others in exchange for leniency after he was accused of running an insider trading network in 1986. ``Part of Boesky's deal was he would cooperate and turn on (others),'' a person who was briefed on Milken's plea deal said Sunday. ``That has nothing to do with Michael Milken's settlement.'' Milken, though, will face questioning from the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission if his plea is approved by U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood. Such questioning is standard in criminal guilty pleas. ``That would be a real victory for him and I think a real victory for his clients and the whole junk bond structure,'' Alan Bromberg, a securities law professor at Southern Methodist University, said of the reported terms of the plea bargain. Milken on Friday agreed to plead guilty to six felonies and pay $600 million in penalties to settle charges contained in a 98-count fraud and racketeering indictment handed up a year ago. Prosecutors are expected to recommend a prison term of about five years for Milken. The $600 million fine is the largest ever against an individual, and is said to cover both criminal and civil penalties. After his indictment, Milken set aside about $700 million to guarantee payment in the event of conviction. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the deal precludes any further criminal prosecution of Milken, who spearheaded some of the biggest takeovers of the 1980s as head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s junk bond department. Milken, 43, controlled a network of buyers and sellers in the $200 billion market for the high-yield debt securities and was widely believed to have knowledge the government may been able to use in its probe of illicit trading. The U.S. Attorney's office had given Milken until last Friday to accept a settlement or face a new, expanded indictment. Barring last-minute changes, Milken is to enter the guilty plea on Tuesday. A hearing before Wood was scheduled for Tuesday morning, according to the judge's office. Milken, his brother, Lowell, and former Drexel trader Bruce Newberg were charged in the indictment, which alleged securities law violations in several takeovers. The plea bargain contains no insider trading or racketeering charges and the government agreed to drop its case against Lowell Milken. That was said to be a key component of Milken's decision to plead guilty. The specific charges in the plea were not revealed. Milken had maintained innocence since he was linked to illegal trading in 1986 by Boesky, who pleaded guilty to one charge, paid $100 million and cooperated with investigators. Boesky's testimony led to convictions from or guilty pleas by several Wall Street figures. Milken's plea agreement apparently does not settle charges against Newberg. Lawyers for Newberg said Sunday they had not been contacted by the government about their client's status. In a related case, Newberg was convicted last year of racketeering and securities faud in connection with illegal tax trading by Princeton-Newport Partners, a now-defunct securities firm. He was sentenced to three months in prison. It also was unclear whether any action would be taken against individuals who had received ``target letters'' from the government last year indicating they would be charged in a new Milken indictment. Drexel last year pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $650 million to settle related fraud charges. The firm collapsed in February and is liquidating.

DOC.HEAD: `There is Someone in My Grave'
DOC.TEXT: City Hall is trying to help an elderly woman who went to visit a cemetery plot where she planned to be buried alongside family members only to discover it was already occupied by a stranger. Yong Yu Min, 78, said she purchased the plot at Cheras Catholic Cemetery from the Kuala Lumpur City Hall in 1962 and that she had hoped to be buried there one day alongside her sister and two brothers. A few days ago, she discovered that her plot was occupied by the remains of a man unknown to her. The Malay Mail Daily published her story on Monday under the headline ``There is Someone in my Grave.'' A City Hall official said the man in the grave died in 1987 and was supposed to be buried in the nearby Protestant cemetery. Funeral directors put his body in plot No. 1865 in the Catholic cemetery, instead of plot No. 1865 the Protestant one, she said. She said she did not understand why there had been no complaints until now, but that City Hall would try to resolve the problem.

DOC.HEAD: 100,000 Gallons of Oil Spilled On Earth Day Train Derailment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `It's so...', to delete extraneous first reference to Betsy Mallison.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XCGV1; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A train carrying a caustic chemical and crude oil derailed and exploded, spewing about 100,000 gallons of oil and releasing a chemical cloud that forced 200 people to evacuate. Twenty-nine cars in a 97-car Buffalo & Pittsburgh Railroad freight train jumped the tracks in a steep ravine along Buffalo Creek late Sunday, John H. Bell, the railway's vice president, said today. At the fire's peak, flames shooting several hundred feet high could be seen 30 miles away. At midmorning, the fire was still burning but was under control, authorities said. Bell said only a small amount of the spilled oil leaked into Buffalo Creek, a tributary of the Allegheny River, and that it didn't appear to be a threat to drinking water. In addition to the oil, one tanker leaked sodium hydroxide that sent a chemical cloud drifting toward Worthington, causing 200 people to be moved from their homes overnight. All but 50 had returned by midmorning, said Worthington Fire Chief Don Grafton. He said about 300 people were told to be on standby for possible evacuation this morning but that the danger posed by the cloud appeared to be easing. A dike collected most of the sodium hydroxide, a caustic substance used to clean drains, Bell said. It can cause oil to ignite, according to a 1980 Department of Transportation hazardous materials handbook. At late morning, crews were using hoses to suck oil and sodium hydroxide from the ground. ``What a weird time time for this to happen _ on Earth Day,'' said one resident, the Rev. Sharon Schwab. ``Maybe it will make people begin to realize that we need to do things so this sort of thing doesn't happen as often as it does now.'' She said she heard a strange noise from the train ``like something was dragging or hitting the tracks wrong'' before the accident. The 12 oil tankers that derailed carried more than 300,000 gallons of oil, Bell said. About 100,000 gallons ``give or take a few thousand'' had leaked from four ruptured cars, he said. The other eight oil tankers derailed but didn't rupture. Except for the tanker carrying the sodium hydroxide, the other train cars carried miscellaneous freight. Firefighters had the fire under control ``to a point'' when officials decided to let the oil burn away, said Bob Walker, the director of hazardous materials handling for Armstrong County's emergency services office. ``There's product in Buffalo Creek, but it's dark and the crude is black,'' Betsy Mallison, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Resources, said early today. ``We're focusing on making sure areas are diked and boomed to keep most of the product out of the creek.'' ``It's so hot and volatile and it's difficult for firemen to get in there and get a close look,'' she said. Buffalo Creek flows into the Allegheny River 10 to 15 miles downstream. Communities along the Allegheny were told they might have to close their drinking water intake valves. Dead fish were starting to rise to the surface in a two-mile stretch of Buffalo Creek, said Emil Svetahor, spokesman for the state Fish Commission. Three firefighters suffered chemical burns, but their injuries were not serious, said Ms. Mallison. A mobile home was damaged. ``There was an instant when that one fireball went up that I thought it was coming right on us because you could feel the heat,'' said one evacuee, Rose Davis, 46, who lives in a trailer park near West Franklin Township. ``It lit our yard up like daylight. You could hear the roaring of the fire.'' The cause of the derailment was under investigation. The two train operators, who weren't injured, were undergoing drug and alcohol tests under the Punxsatawney-based company's policy, Bell said.
