The train derailed as Earth Day festivities wound down 45 miles away at Pittsburgh's Point State Park, where an estimated 40,000 celebrated the environmental awareness day. Tens of thousands of people along the Allegheny were left without water earlier this month after a pipeline broke and spilled 75,000 gallons of mixed fuel.

DOC.HEAD: Military Government Says Coup Attempt Crushed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from military leader's radio speech, remarks by gov't spokesman linking coup bid to March plot, additional details, adds byline. Pickup 5th graf pvs: The sources ...
DOC.TEXT: Sudan's military government said today that loyalist forces had crushed a revolt by junior army officers, the second reported attempt in a month to overthrow the ruling junta. Sudan's military leader, Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, said his troops arrested the rebels and were in control of this East African nation. He did not mention any casualty figures or the number of arrests. ``All those involved in the attempt have been arrested, those who are in active (military) service and those who are retired,'' el-Bashir said in a speech broadcast at midday over Radio Omduran, the official government station. El-Bashir said the coup plotters had been under surveillance from the start of the takeover attempt. Without elaborating, el-Bashir said the abortive coup was masterminded by ``the alliance in coalition with the outlaws.'' The government has often used the term ``outlaws'' to refer to the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army, which has been waging a seven-year insurgency seeking autonomy for the country's southern region. ``The alliance'' was possibly a reference to political parties disbanded by el-Bashir after he took control of the country June 30. An official government spokesman said today's coup attempt was a continuation of a bid uncovered in March to topple the military government. Authorities ``took measures to prevent the move from the start'' after receiving information that rebel officers were planning today's coup attempt, said government spokesman Mohammed Khogali Salihein. He said today's attempted coup was plotted by two retired officers, Maj. Gen. Abdul-Kadir al-Kadaru and Brig. Gen. Mohammed Osman Hamid Karrar. He said both officers were in custody, but no civilians had been arrested. Informed sources in the capital of Khartoum said the army appeared to have had little trouble putting down a series of attacks led by junior army officers. The Sudanese sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the attempted coup began at midnight and the rebels tried to take over Khartoum airport and official government radio but were quickly overpowered. The sources said several officers tried to shoot their way into the armed forces general command in Khartoum, apparently in search of el-Bashir, but could not get through the front gate. They said a guard at the general command was wounded in the hand. Khartoum airport was closed briefly and telecommunications cut for several hours. But by midmorning, Khartoum was peaceful. ``It was an attempted coup around midnight by a small number of very low-level officers,'' said a source who said he details came from people at the general command. ``They tried to take over the airport and the radio in a rather pathetic way and were very unsuccessful,'' the source said. Tanks were seen on vital bridges and around the general command. The army was on full alert, but overall security did not seem heightened in the streets of the capital. In a dispatch from Khartoum, Egypt's state-run Middle East News Agency said the coup attempt involved junior officers but was masterminded by some retired officers. It did not identify them. In late March, the official Sudan News Agency reported that a number of civilians and military officers were arrested for allegedly planning a coup. Later, el-Bashir was quoted as saying that only 20 people were involved and that investigations were under way. The junta seized power June 30 by overthrowing Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi's civilian government. At the time, el-Bashir said his principal aims were to end the 7-year-old civil war in the south and improve the country's beleaguered economy. He has had little success.

DOC.HEAD: Two Palestinian Youths Die After Being Shot In Clashes
DOC.TEXT: Two Palestinian youths died today after being shot in clashes with troops, and merchants in Arab east Jerusalem defied strike orders in a growing rebellion against Palestinian uprising leaders. The boys were shot in the head by soldiers dispersing Palestinian stone-throwers Sunday and died of their wounds early today, Palestinian reports said. An army spokesman confirmed the deaths and said the circumstances were under investigation. Yousef Atta Al Kishawi from the Shati refugee camp in the occupied Gaza Strip died at Israel's Tel Hashomer Hospital, and troops clamped a curfew on the area, the army said. Israeli authorities said he was 13, while Palestinians said he was 10. The second fatality was Moussa Mohammed Husseini al Alameh, 14, from the southern West Bank town of Beit Ummar. Husseini died at Jerusalem's Mukassed hospital, officials said. Today's deaths brought to 676 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians in the 28-month uprising against Israeli rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. As of March 31, 142 of those killed were children age 16 and under, according to the Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories. Since the start of the uprising, an additional 208 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of cooperating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have also died. In east Jerusalem, merchants opened their shops today after Palestinian activists canceled strike calls by the pro-PLO Unified National Leadership of the Uprising. A strike to show Christian-Moslem solidarity was called for Sunday in the wake of a recent move by Jews to set up a settlement in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem's Old City. A second day of strikes was called for today in support of so-called ``liberated'' villages. The two-day strike order, contained in the latest Unified Leadership leaflet, has angered many Moslem Palestinians because it comes in the middle of the shopping period before the three-day Id al-Fitr holiday later this week. Moslems exchange gifts and prepare festive meals to celebrate Id al-Fitr which marks the end of the month-long Ramadan fast.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Airmen Killed in Helicopter Collision
DOC.TEXT: Seven Israeli airmen were killed when two U.S.-made transport helicopters collided and burst into flames during a training flight over the occupied West Bank, the army said Monday. The collision of the two Sikorsky CH-53 helicopters, known as Sea Stallions, occurred Sunday night in the Baal Hatzor region north of the West Bank town of Ramallah, the army said. Gen. Avihu Bin-Nun, the air force commander, ordered an investigation. Israel radio said the two helicopters collided about 300 yards from the West Bank's Alon Highway, burst into flames and crashed to the ground. Six airmen were killed immediately, and a seventh died in a hospital after suffering serious injuries, the radio said. A government announcment said one of the dead was an air force lieutenant colonel.

DOC.HEAD: Elephant Undergoing C-Section After Drug Fails To Trigger Labor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with preparations for surgery under way after labor-inducing drug fails.
DOC.TEXT: A veterinary surgical team began a risky Caesarean section operation today to help Babe, a 36-year-old Asian elephant, deliver a calf after her labor stopped five days ago. The seven-member team led by Dr. Michael Schmit, a veterinarian from the Washington Park Zoo in Portland, Ore., began preparations for the surgery at about 11 a.m. after drugs administered to the 7,700-pound elephant failed to induce labor. ``Everybody's kind of nervous. We've got several hours worth of surgery ahead,'' said Yvonne Pelletreau, a spokeswoman at the Burnet Park Zoo. It will be the third time the veterinary team has attempted a C-section on an Asian elephant, she said. Only one of the operations was successful, she said. Babe would become the oldest first-time elephant mother to give birth in a North American zoo. Babe began labor Wednesday, but stopped it early Thursday. Female elephants have the ability to stop their labor when they are feeling pain and it is not unusual for elephants to take up to five days to deliver a calf. But zoo officials became concerned about both mother and infant as the delay continued. On Saturday, a group of four veterinarians from Cornell University checked Babe and found that her cervix was probably too small for her calf to pass through. They injected her with Estrabiol to start her cervix dilating, said Pelletreau. The drug had some effect, but not enough, so on Sunday the veterinarians gave Babe a second injection, she said. That second injection caused the elephant's cervix to widen enough for a calf to pass. Early today, the veterinarians gave Babe ocytocin, a labor-inducing drug, but it didn't work, she said. Babe is one of eight Asian elephants currently pregnant in North American zoos. A second Burnet Park elephant, Romani, is expected to give birth in July 1991. Asian elephants are an endangered species that number fewer than 45,000 in the wild.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Leaves 10 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to raise toll to 10 killed and 72 injured, update with clashes spreading throughout the city and additional details, deletes outdated material in grafs 9-11, The procession ... immediately known. Pickup 12th graf pvs, `Earlier today...'
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators clashed with police throughout the capital of Katmandu today in the first major violence since the nation returned to democracy two weeks ago, witnesses said. Ten people were reported killed and 72 injured. In today's clashes, six policemen were beaten to death by protesters and four demonstrators were fatally shot by police, witnesses said. The violence broke out when a mob of several hundred paraded three unconscious and bleeding men through the streets. The group claimed its captives were policemen belonging to a banned right-wing gang called Mandale, which was once allied with the monarchy and is now blamed for an outbreak of looting, mugging and arson. Police opened fire in at least four places as the mob with the three captives marched toward the royal palace. Some men were beating the three unconscious captives, who were tied together in a sitting position on a pushcart. Others chanted: ``Birendra, thief, leave the country!'' On April 8, King Birendra yielded to a groundswell of pro-democracy demonstrations and lifted a 29-year ban on political parties. The march was halted by police, who rescued the three unconscious men accused of belonging to Mandale. Two of the captives died and were identified as policemen after their bodies were brought to Bir Hospital, where the third man was in serious condition. His identity was not immediately known. Four civilians who died of bullet wounds were also brought to Bir Hospital, doctors said. It was not immediately known whether they were part of the march on the palace or were shot in other locations. Four policemen were beaten to death by a mob that attacked a police station in Katmandu's western Teku neighborhood, according to a reporter who witnessed the killings and spoke on condition of anonymity. He said police at Teku initially fired tear gas, then warning shots in the air and finally gunshots into the crowd. It was not known if there were any casualties. Crowds were seen attacking at least six other police stations. Demonstrators also set fire to a two-story building housing offices of the general commissioner, the top civil administrator for the Katmandu region. Doctors at two local hospitals said the injured included 24 people with bullet wounds and 14 others who were suffering from stab wounds inflicted by the mob. Other people were injured in the stampede as crowds dispersed. Police imposed a curfew in central Katmandu. Earlier today, irate residents beat 12 suspected Mandale members with iron rods and then set fire to four police jeeps, accusing the police of failing to protect them, the Cabinet's home minister said. When the minister, Yog Prasad Upadhyay, and Hem Bahadur Singh, Nepal's top police official, went to the scene of the beatings, they were surrounded by hundreds of people, who forced them to address a public meeting and later pounded their jeep. The rage stems from the growing wave of arson, looting and muggings that followed this Himalayan kingdom's return to democracy. Victims and other witnesses say the attacks are the work of the Mandale. After the group was banned in 1979, they say, it went underground and served as a vigilante squad supporting Nepal's old nonpartisan system. The pro-democracy movement was launched Feb. 18 by two banned political groups. The two dominate a government that took office Thursday. The movement snowballed until April 6, when 200,000 demonstrators marched on the royal palace. Police opened fire, killing up to 200 people, according to witnesses. The king's government maintained that only 10 people were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: A 3,000-ton vehicle used to haul space shuttles and other spacecraft around Kennedy Space Center has logged its 1,000th mile _ after a quarter of a century. The crawler transporter's odometer reached the milestone Sunday while carrying Columbia from the Vehicle Assembly Building 3.4 miles to a launch pad where the shuttle will await a mid-May liftoff. ``She isn't very pretty, and it isn't very fast, not very streamlined. But it's truly an elegant machine,'' Doug Sargent, president of Lockheed Space Operations Co., said at a brief ceremony. The 25-year-old transporter moves on four double-tracked trucks at a pace of 2 mph _ when not loaded. While carrying a shuttle, the vehicle zips along at less than 1 mph. The center has two of the transporters; the other has logged about 975 miles.

Six-year-old Elizabeth Gregory wanted desperately to be a flower girl in someone's wedding, so her parents placed a classified advertisement saying she was available. ``We had about 10 calls from brides and we accepted four of them,'' said her mother, Anne Gregory. The ad also attracted the attention of reporters, and friends of Anne and her husband, Randy, have told them they heard the story on national radio and television shows, Mrs. Gregory said. The first bride, Sheila Donner, stopped by the Gregorys' home a week ago to meet with Elizabeth. It was love at first sight, Mrs. Gregory said. Elizabeth agreed that the pairing was a good one. ``When the bride came over, she said she wanted our dresses to match,'' she said. ``I'm going to give a flower to everyone on the ends'' of the pews. Elizabeth said she wasn't nervous about the duties she faces. ``I think I have it under control,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Guerrillas Call on Najib to Run for Re-Election
DOC.TEXT: Afghanistan's Moslem guerrillas Monday called on their archenemy, President Najib, to test his popularity in an election, but not under the banner of his Communist-style party. The loose, broadly defined proposal for a non-party election represents a major concession by the seven guerrilla groups fighting for 12 years to overthrow the Soviet-backed government in Kabul. The proposal came as rockets slammed into the Afghan capital, hitting a mosque and others sites and killing 19 people and wounding 11, Radio Kabul said. The report blamed the U.S.-backed guerrillas for the attack. ``We're talking about general elections and that means everybody can participate,'' said Azim Nasser-Zia, an author of the plan and a spokesman for the National Islamic Front of Afghanistan, a moderate guerrilla group. But the plan drew a cool response from the Kabul government's highest-ranking diplomat in Pakistan, Charge d'Affaires Qudrahullah Ahmadi. ``We gave our proposal three years ago for a six-month cease-fire followed by elections. We are ready for those elections,'' Ahmadi said. The guerrillas, however, have rejected the cease-fire. ``They'll eventually come over to our proposal,'' he said. The guerrillas, who have spent as much time fighting each other as they have Najib's troops, have come under heavy pressure from the United States and other financial backers to close ranks and come up with a political solution to the protracted war. Senior U.S. officials in Islamabad said guerrilla leaders have been warned that their multimillion dollar weapons' pipeline could dry up next year. Washington annually ships between $500 million and $700 million worth of military supplies to the guerrillas, also known as the mujahedeen. They are also financed by Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and other sympathetic Arab states. Moscow reportedly pumps billions of dollars worth of supplies to Kabul. Skeptics among the rebels say talk of elections is a stalling tactic to satisfy the doves while the hawks prepare for one last fighting season. Spring weather is melting the snow on Afghanistan's rugged mountain passes and allowing rebel fighters to resupply their positions inside the country. The guerrillas control nearly 80 percent of the countryside but have yet to capture a major city. Najib's forces have failed to make significant military gains, leading to calls for a political settlement to the bloody stalement. Najib has repeatedly offered to negotiate peace anytime, anywhere and on any terms with the guerrillas in the last year. The rebels and their backers rejected the offer, demanding Najib step down first. Washington later said Najib could stay during peace talks but would eventually have to go before elections, a condition Kabul rejects. While guerrilla leaders appear ready to compromise on Najib's participation, Nasser-Zia added, ``Under no circumstances could elections be held under Najib or the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan.'' The proposal was drafted by a National Islamic Front of Afghanistan leader, Pir Sayed Ahmed Gailani. It calls for a United Nations' team to conduct elections in areas controlled by the government and for representatives of the Organization of Islamic Countries to monitor polls in guerrilla-held areas. Voters would elect representatives to a traditional Afghan jirga, or grand assembly, which would choose the person to form a new government. The plan, the latest in a series drafted over the past year, was outlined at a meeting Sunday with Pakistan President Ghulam Ishaq Khan and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 13 Killed in South African Violence
DOC.TEXT: Rival black factions clashed with guns and knives and attacked homes during the weekend, killing at least 13 people, including two black police officers, authorities said Monday. Police said 11 people were killed during the weekend in factional fighting in Natal Province. The dead included a 15-year-old boy and a 70-year-old woman, who were shot in separate incidents, police said. Police gave few details on the fighting in other parts of the nation. Two black police officers were killed in separate incidents in Cape Province and Natal, police said. Police backed up by South African army troops arrested about 70 people in a sweep Sunday through a black township near Viljoenskroon in Orange Free State, police said. Police declined to say why the suspects were rounded up. The Citizen newspaper reported Monday that police had said they would not allow extreme right-wing whites to form private militias. Police officials said such groups were stockpiling weapons and were a threat to law and order. ``We reject the concept of any militant right-wing organizations, because we cannot allow any member of the public to take the law into his own hands,'' a police spokesman, Capt. Peet Bothma, was quoted as saying. Extreme right-wing groups that oppose giving blacks political rights have claimed to be forming armed units. Several air force members and right-wingers have been arrested on charges of helping steal air force guns last week for an extremist group. On Sunday, African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela called for intensified armed struggle against the white government to force speeding up negotiations on the end of apartheid. ``There can be no talk of a lasting peace while government agents continue to massacre people,'' Mandela said, referring to three recent incidents of police firing on black protesters or hitting bystanders while shooting at rioters. But Mandela told a crowd estimated at 70,000 in Umtata, the capital of Transkei, the homeland where he was born, that ``only successful negotiations can convince us to end the armed struggle, and peace will come as a result of negotiations. It is not negotiations which will come as a result of peace.'' President F.W. de Klerk, whose Cabinet will hold talks with a Mandela-led ANC delegation next week, has said the ANC's continued calls for armed struggle are an obstacle to formal negotiations on a new constitution which would give the black majority the vote. De Klerk said in an interview broadcast by British television on Sunday that he was ``strongly opposed to war talk'' and considered it ``a stumbling block in the way of negotiations.'' South Africa has been hit by a wave of violence in recent weeks that has claimed hundreds of lives. Much of the violence involves power struggles between rival black groups that disagree over plans for a future South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Woman Loses Appeal in Sperm-Donor Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs fourth graf from end, Mrs. Crouch's appeal, to restore dropped words in quote.
DOC.TEXT: An Oregon woman who does not want to share parenting rights with the California man who donated his sperm for her artificial insemination lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that Kevin McIntyre is entitled to a trial in seeking to prove he donated sperm only after Linden Crouch said she would let him help raise the child. Ms. Crouch says no such agreement was made. Nationwide, more than 20,000 children are born each year through artificial insemination, the court was told. In most cases, women are inseminated with sperm obtained through a sperm bank from donors who remain anonymous to them. But McIntyre, from Moraga, Calif., has known Ms. Crouch, from Ashland, Ore., for over 13 years. Ms. Crouch gave birth to a daughter, Glenellen Susan, on Nov. 24, 1986, after being artificially impregnated with sperm she had asked McIntyre to donate. He says Ms. Crouch told him before he agreed to donate his sperm that she wanted him to share parenting with her. He says she also agreed to his request for visitation rights. In other action today, the high court: _ Agreed to use the case if a Mississippi death row inmate to provide new guidelines for police questioning of suspects. The court said it will hear an appeal by Robert S. Minnick, a convicted murderer who said his confession was unlawful because he was denied his right to have a lawyer present. _ Refused to reinstate the California murder conviction of a Black Panther Party member who was shackled during his 17-month trial. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the shackling at Johnny Spain's trial violated his rights. _ Rejected an appeal by a Utah city accused of unlawfully promoting religion by subsidizing the Mormon Church and by putting a church symbol on city property. The court, over one dissenting vote, refused to kill a lawsuit that says the city violated the constitutionally required separation of church and state. _ Refused to give new life to a copyright lawsuit over actress Shirley MacLaine's 1983 best-selling book, ``Out on a Limb.'' The court, without comment, let stand rulings that MacLaine's book about reincarnation and other spiritual subjects did not infringe the copyright of a 1977 book written by Charles Silva. _ Rejected an appeal by a former member of the Church of Scientology of California who wanted the church declared a phony religion. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by Larry Wollersheim of Aspen, Colo. Still pending before the justices is an appeal by the Church of Scientology of California aimed at overturning a $2.5 million ``emotional distress'' award won by Wollersheim. _ Rejected a chemical company's challenge to federal standards for clean water. The court, without comment, left intact rules that govern more than 1,000 factories producing organic chemicals, plastics and synthetic fibers. Oregon's artificial insemination law denies any parental rights to sperm donors who are not the woman's husband. The law states, ``Such donor shall have no right, obligation or interest with respect to a child born as a result of the artificial insemination.'' Invoking that law, a state trial judge threw out McIntyre's lawsuit seeking parental rights. But a state appeals court, by a 2-1 vote, reinstated his suit in 1988. The appeals court said the state law, when applied to McIntyre, violated his constitutionally protected due-process rights. The appeals court said McIntyre is entitled to a trial in Jackson County, Ore., on his allegation that Ms. Crouch broke an oral agreement. The Oregon Supreme Court refused to hear Ms. Crouch's ensuing appeal last Nov. 30, but postponed any trial until Ms. Crouch could appeal to the nation's highest court. In the appeal acted on today, Ms. Crouch's lawyer argued, ``Mr. McIntyre's claim, at the most and if proven, is that he has lost a quantity of sperm because he was tricked by Ms. Crouch.'' ``This was conduct between private parties,'' the appeal said. ``The government was not involved (so) a liberty interest under the (Constitution's) due process clause does not exist.'' Ms. Crouch's appeal said the appeals court ruling ``calls into question the legal relationships among donors, fathers and children conceived by artificial insemination in Oregon.'' Her appeal said most states have artificial insemination laws. McIntyre's lawyer urged the justices to reject Ms. Crouch's appeal. He said McIntyre had tried since 1980 to adopt a child, and since 1983 had sought to have a child through a surrogate mother. The case is Crouch vs. McIntyre, 89-1424.

DOC.HEAD: Riots in Nepal Threaten Transition to Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Mobs beat six policemen to death, and security forces shot and killed five civilians during daylong riots Monday that threatened the Himalayan kingdom's transition to democracy. The mobs accused police of condoning and sometimes joining an underground monarchist group blamed for a wave of crime that swelled up last week after a new government headed by pro-democracy leaders took office. Armed policemen in riot gear patrolled Katmandu and its suburbs after the state-run radio announced a 10-hour curfew beginning at 8 p.m. Doctors said 78 people were injured in the violence, the worst since security forces opened fire April 6 on pro-democracy demonstrators. Witnesses said as many as 200 people were killed that day, but King Birendra's government said only 10 people died. The killings and the burgeoning movement for democracy forced Birendra to abolish his 29-year-old system of government in which political parties were banned. A new coalition government, dominated by once-outlawed political parties, took office on Thursday. Within 24 hours, there was an outbreak of arson, mugging and looting. Residents blamed the trouble on the Mandale, an outlawed organization composed of supporters of the old political system and the monarchy. The Mandale, whose name means ``group'' in the Nepali language, went underground in 1979 when Birendra officially banned it because of its violent tendencies. In several neighborhoods, residents set up local vigilante groups on Sunday after receiving anonymous telephone threats that Mandale members would raid their houses. There appeared to be no political pattern to the people targeted. Monday's trouble started in the morning after residents captured three men dressed in police uniforms and accused them of belonging to the Mandale. The men were beaten and paraded on a pushcart through Katmandu and around the walls of Birendra's palace. The three unconscious men, their bleeding heads lolling and faces puffed from beatings, were tied together in a sitting position as the crowd continued to beat them and chant: ``Birendra, thief, leave the country.'' More than six hours after the three were captured, police broke up the procession and rescued the trio. Two of the men were dead on arrival at Bir Hospital, and the third was in critical condition. Doctors who spoke on condition of anonymity said all three were policemen. Later, groups of men and boys attacked police stations in at least eight other neighborhoods. Four more policemen were beaten to death, according to an Indian reporter who asked not to be identified. Police fired tear gas and rifles in several places throughout the capital in an effort to disperse the crowds. In Bir Hospital, where most of the casualties were taken, five civilians had fatal bullet injuries, doctors said, speaking on condition of anonymity. They said 24 other people were hospitalized for treatment of bullet wounds at Bir Hospital and Teaching Hospital, Katmandu's largest medical institutions. Fourteen other people were hospitalized with knife wounds. The doctors said they were stabbed by mobs who accused them of belonging to the Mandale. Most of the other casualties were beaten or were injured in stampedes. ``This is threateneding the new-found democracy,'' said Rishikesh Shaha, a former foreign minister and now a prominent human rights activist. ``These are not just teething troubles of democracy but more serious problems.'' He also accused the Mandale of instigating the violence. The chief government spokesman, Radheshyam Bista, said Prime Minister Krishna Prasad Bhattarai met King Birendra for more than one hour Monday night. Bhattarai, a top leader of the Nepali Congress party and the pro-democracy movement, later met with Home Minister Yog Prasad Upadhyay and inspector general of police Hem Bahadur Singh to review the situation. Bhattarai and others have said Nepal may be headed for a constitutional monarchy.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Swears in New AID Aministrator
DOC.TEXT: Ronald Roskens was sworn in Monday as administrator of the Agency for International Development, with President Bush on hand to wish him ``godspeed.'' AID provides economic assistance and advice in more than 70 developing nations. ``You take the helm at AID at an extremely important time,'' Bush told Roskens, former president of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. ``Around the globe new democracies are being born and nations are seeking to establish free-market, democratic institutions.'' Bush called AID ``a very, very important agency'' that ``will play a vital role in nurturing such transformations and in sharing our knowledge and our skills worldwide.'' ``In this good work, I wish you godspeed,'' said Bush, before Roskens was sworn in by Ambassador Joseph Verner Reed, the U.S. chief of protocol. Roskens' wife, Lois, and mother, Delores, held the Bible as he took the oath at the White House. Vice President Dan Quayle attended the ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Sentenced For Performing Sex Change Operation
DOC.TEXT: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France (AP) _ Two doctors were fined and given suspended prison sentences Monday for performing a sex-change operation on a patient who committed suicide in 1988, eight years after the surgery. An appeals court convicted the doctors of willful aggravated assault on Jean-Eric Oyac, who had requested the operation because he wanted to become a woman. French law forbids sex-change operations unless stringent conditions are met regarding the psychological need for the surgery. During a hearing before the appeals court last year, a government lawyer, Pierre Berard, said the doctors should be punished because there was no medical proof beforehand that the operation was necessary. Dr. Jean Vacant, the chief surgeon for the operation, and Dr. Jean-Claude Masson, who assisted him, were each fined $3,400. Vacant received a six-month suspended sentence and Masson a four-month suspended senetnce. Dr. Jean Just, a psychiatrist consulted by the other doctors prior to the operation, was fined $1,360. Prior to the operation in March 1980, Oyac worked as a nurse at a psychiatric hospital in Nice and called himself Jennifer. He filed a complaint in 1984 asserting that the operation had not been successful and that he was in constant pain. In May 1988, he committed suicide.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Welcomes Polhill Release
With AM-Hostage Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials on Monday welcomed the release of a U.S. hostage in Lebanon but gave no indication that Israel would comply with Iranian demands that Israel free a kidnapped Lebanese Shiite clergyman. Sources close to the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army said militia chief Antoine Lahad would decide on Tuesday whether to free some of his 300 prisoners for Id Al Fitr, the Moslem holiday marking the end of the Ramadan fast. Pro-Iranian radicals holding 17 Western hostages and three Israeli soldiers in Lebanon could interpret the release of the mostly Shiite Moslem inmates from the Al Khiam prison just north of Israel's border as a goodwill gesture. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there was a tradition of freeing prisoners during the holiday. But they said any release would be up to Lahad and unconnected with the issue of Western hostages. Earlier in the day, Israel radio quoted the South Lebanon Army as saying it had no intention of freeing Shiite prisoners in response to the release of the American hostage. Iran called for goodwill gestures and a reciprocal move after U.S. hostage Robert Polhill, 55, an educator held for 1,182 days, was set free Sunday. Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran demanded the release of Shiite Moslem cleric Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, who was abducted by Israeli troops in Lebanon in July. The Tehran Times, an English-language daily close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani, noted Israel's detention of scores of Arab prisoners impeded efforts to free Western hostages. Israeli army spokesmen and other officials gave no indication that Israel planned to free Obeid. Avi Pazner, spokesman for caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, welcomed the freeing of the American hostage and said Israel was making efforts to free its own soldiers held captive in Lebanon. ``We are very pleased to hear about the release of this (American) hostage and would like to see the day when all hostages, Americans, others and especially Israelis, are also released. We pray that that day will come soon,'' Pazner said in an interview. He acknowledged that Israel and the United States discussed the hostage issue but said: ``There was no coordination on the release of this hostage.'' Israel has offered to trade Obeid for all foreign hostages, including an Israeli air force navigator and two soldiers who were captured by Shiite guerrillas in Lebanon in 1986. An Israeli army spokesman declined to say if Israel would release any of the nearly 9,000 Palestinians jailed in connection with the 28-month-old Palestinian uprising. In the days before Polhill's release, Israel carried out two attacks in Lebanon that were seen by some observers as increased pressure on pro-Iranian groups holding hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Court Keeps Artificial Insemination Suit Alive
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday kept alive a lawsuit in which a California man seeks parental rights to a child he fathered by artificial insemination. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by the mother, Linden Crouch of Oregon, who says she never agreed to share parental rights with sperm donor Kevin McIntyre. The justices refused to block a trial in which McIntyre hopes to prove he donated sperm only after Ms. Crouch said she would let him help raise the child. Ms. Crouch's appeal said McIntyre has no constitutional right to share in rearing the child, now 3. ``Mr. McIntyre's claim, at the most and if proven, is that he has lost a quantity of sperm because he was tricked by Ms. Crouch,'' the appeal said. In other action, the high court: _Refused to give new life to a copyright lawsuit over actress Shirley MacLaine's 1983 best-selling book, ``Out on a Limb.'' The court let stand rulings that MacLaine's book on reincarnation did not infringe the copyright of a 1977 book written by Charles Silva. _Raised the possibility an Amish sect in Minnesota may be forced to display a ``slow-moving vehicle'' warning on the back of its horse-drawn buggies. The justices ordered the Minnesota Supreme Court to restudy its ruling exempting the Amish from the traffic warning emblems. _Refused to reinstate the California murder conviction of Black Panther Johnny Spain, who was shackled during his 17-month trial. A lower court overturned the conviction on the ground the shackling violated his rights. _Agreed to use the case of a Mississippi death row inmate to provide new guidelines for police questioning of suspects. The convicted murderer said his confession should not have been admitted as evidence because he was denied his right to have a lawyer present. _Rejected an appeal by a former member of the Church of Scientology of California who wanted the church declared a phony religion. Still pending before the justices is the church's appeal to overturn a $2.5 million ``emotional distress'' award won by the former member. _Rejected a chemical company's challenge to federal standards for clean water. The court left intact rules that govern more than 1,000 factories producing organic chemicals, plastics and synthetic fibers. The justices were told in the sperm donor case that more than 20,000 children are born each year through artificial insemination. In most cases, sperm banks are used and the donors and the women are unknown to each other. But McIntyre, from Moraga, Calif., has known Ms. Crouch, from Ashland, Ore., for 13 years. Ms. Crouch gave birth to a daughter, Glenellen Susan, on Nov. 24, 1986, after being artificially impregnated with sperm she had asked McIntyre to donate. He said he agreed to the arrangement only after Ms. Crouch told him she wanted him to share parenting with her and would let him have visitation rights. Oregon's artificial insemination law denies any parental rights to a sperm donor unless he is married to the recipient. A state trial judge threw out McIntyre's lawsuit seeking parental rights. But a state appeals court, by a 2-1 vote, reinstated his suit in 1988. The appeals court said the state law violated McIntyre's constitutionally protected due-process rights. The appeals court said McIntyre is entitled to a trial in Jackson County, Ore., on his allegation that Ms. Crouch broke an oral agreement. ``This was conduct between private parties,'' Ms. Crouch's appeal to the Supreme Court said. ``The government was not involved (so) a liberty interest under the (Constitution's) due process clause does not exist.'' Ms. Crouch's appeal said the appeals court ruling ``calls into question the legal relationships among donors, fathers and children conceived by artificial insemination in Oregon.'' Most states have artificial insemination laws, her appeal said. McIntyre, in urging the justices to reject Ms. Crouch's appeal, said he has tried since 1980 to adopt a child and since 1983 has sought to have a child through a surrogate mother.

DOC.HEAD: Paulette Goddard, Star of Chaplin Films, Is Dead
DOC.TEXT: Paulette Goddard, the wide-eyed, waiflike actress who co-starred with husband Charlie Chaplin in films such as ``The Great Dictator'' and ``Modern Times,'' died Monday at her home in southern Switzerland. A municipal employee in the village of Ronco said official records show the actress was born on June 3, 1905, making her 84. However, reference books give her year of birth as 1915 or 1911. The employee, Pia DellaMora, said the exact cause of death was not known ``but one could assume she died of old age.'' A member of her household said the actress had a brief illness. Ms. Goddard, born Marion Levy in Whitestone, N.Y., began her career on stage in New York. Her Hollywood debut came with a small part in ``The Girl Habit'' in 1931, the first of more than 40 movies. She starred alongside Chaplin in ``Modern Times'' in 1936 and ``The Great Dictator'' in 1940. Their marriage, her second, ended in divorce in 1942. Other films in which the actress had leading roles included ``Dramatic School,'' ``Nothing but the Truth,'' ``I Love a Soldier,'' ``The Diary of a Chambermaid,'' ``Woman of Vengeance'' and a 1947 British production, ``An Ideal Husband.'' Her last TV film was ``The Snoop Sisters.'' Her third marriage, to American actor Burgess Meredith, broke up in 1944. In 1958, she married Erich Maria Remarque, the German-born American novelist. He became famous in the 1920s for his anti-war ``All Quiet on the Western Front,'' which was banned in Nazi Germany. They settled in Ronco, a picturesque hillside village close to the Italian frontier and overlooking Lago Maggiore. Remarque died in 1970. Ms. DellaMora said Ms. Goddard was to be cremated with funeral ceremonies planned for Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Slayings in Six Weeks Has NY Cabbies Driving in Fear
DOC.TEXT: It's after dark and car service driver Ronnie Ramchand is answering a call in the Bronx. The address is on a dark street and the caller turns out to be a teen-ager carrying a baseball bat. ``Should I, or shouldn't I,'' Ramchand wonders, scrutinizing the young man. If he guesses wrong, it could be deadly. A Bronx cab driver found Sunday with a bullet in the back of his head was the sixth hired driver to die in that borough in six weeks. Another was found dead Saturday in Brooklyn. Police believe robbery was the motive. This time, Ramchand guesses right. He gave the teen-ager a ride and lived to tell about it. ``I'm taking precautions,'' he says. ``I'm not picking up anybody I don't like the looks of.'' Mayor David Dinkins has ordered undercover police officers to drive cabs in hope of catching the killer or killers. Soon, they may become the only night-time cab drivers in the Bronx _ scores have quit driving after dark. ``Why should I?'' asked Carlos Rosado, a driver for Parkway Car Service. ``It's crazy. I'm only 20. I'm not going to lose my life. No way.'' But that's why Ramchand, who had been driving for a living for two months, works nights. So many night drivers have quit that Ramchand, who normally works days, is driving well into the night to help Express Taxi Service with its driver shortage. Three of the shootings have been linked through ballistic tests to the same .22-caliber gun. Those three victims had been called to pick up passengers late at night at addresses within a mile of each other in the Bronx. Ramchand admits there's little he can do to protect himself. Unlike many other drivers, he doesn't even carry a crowbar as a weapon. ``Passengers sit right behind you,'' Ramchand said. ``You can't see them. You're not going to know if they're going to hit you.'' Conventional ``medallion'' cabs, which are allowed to pick up passengers who hail them on the street, often have bullet-resistant partitions between the driver and passengers. But the vehicles used by car services often are ramshackle and have no such partitions. The city's car services respond to telephone calls and may not pick up passengers who hail them on the street. In New York's outer boroughs, medallion cabs are hard to find. They make more money picking up fares in busy Manhattan. Some of the upscale chauffeur services accept vouchers, reducing the amount of cash a driver carries. But some, like Ramchand's, take only cash, making them moving targets for robbers. He says he will not pick up a fare that ``doesn't feel right.'' That teen-ager with the baseball bat called from a section of street where the lights were not working. Ramchand went to the address and blew his horn, and the young man walked toward him. Ramchand looked carefully. He noticed the bat was accompanied by a glove, and the sweat and dirt on the youth's baseball clothes. ``As long as I'm careful, I'll be OK. I'm not scared but my wife is,'' Ramchand said. Elsewhere in the Bronx, driver William Barnwell was less sanguine. One of his cousins was among the slain drivers. ``What can I say? I'm scared to death,'' Barnwell said. ``I've been robbed. I've been beaten up. I've had my (tooth) caps knocked out. I got 14 stitches in my head last year. And now this guy not only wants your money, he wants to kill you,'' he said. Barnwell, who works days, says he has been robbed so often that other drivers tease him. ``That last guy, he didn't even say `stick 'em up,''' Barnwell recalled. ``Man, I've never seen so many guns pointed at me since I took this job.'' The attacks have taught him what kind of fare to avoid. ``The tipoff is when somebody late at night wants to go only a short distance. Don't pick those calls up,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Lands Plane on Interstate
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of a single-engine plane that was having engine problems landed the craft on Interstate 64 near Richmond International Airport, police said. No one was injured Sunday night when Ryland W. Fleet landed the 1976 Grumman American two-seater on the westbound lanes, said state police Sgt. E.L. Maxie. ``He really handled this well,'' Maxie said. Fleet, 34, of Richmond, was a few miles from the airport, his destination, when the engine trouble began, Maxie said. ``We were just very fortunate that with it being a Sunday night, traffic was what we considered to be very light,'' Maxie said. Neither Fleet nor his passenger, identified only as Michelle Trollope, asked for medical attention, Maxie said. The plane, which took off from Heathsville, was towed two miles to the airport.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Marks National Volunteer Week
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, surrounded by volunteers, signed a proclamation in the Rose Garden on Monday designating this National Volunteer Week. The honorees included a spry 102-year-old woman, Tero Coleman of Washington who looks after housebound church members in their 70s and 80s. ``Truly amazing,'' the president said. Bush also presented his daily ``point of light'' award to G. Van Standifer of Hyattsville, Md., who founded a ``Midnight Basketball League'' to give youths a late night alternative to the streets and drugs. ``All of you here are proof of what Americans have always known: that when we ban together in service, there is no problem too big, no obstacle too stubborn to overcome,'' Bush told 150 volunteers from federal agencies. ``It's with great pride that we salute the 80 million Americans who serve as volunteers,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Amtrak Train Derails in Southeast Iowa
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak passenger train from California derailed Monday, the Jefferson County Sheriff's Department said. There were no immediate reports of injuries. The 15-car California Zephyr was traveling from Oakland, Calif., to Chicago along Burlington Northern Railroad tracks though southern Iowa. Batavia is 80 miles southeast of Des Moines.

DOC.HEAD: Watkins Criticizes Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Energy Secretary James Watkins unleashed a scathing attack Monday on the Northeast, saying the region's continued opposition to pipelines, refineries and nuclear plants likely will cause repeats of last winter's heating oil crisis. The Northeast has ``not participated ... in the agony'' in balancing their desires for a pristine environment with assuring a secure and adequate supply of energy, Watkins told a House energy subcommittee. A national energy strategy being prepared for President Bush will emphasize the Northeast's greater reluctance than other regions to supply its own energy needs, he said. ``I don't see anybody clamoring for a reduced standard of living,'' Watkins told the three members of the Energy panel's oversight and investigations subcommitee present at the hearing. ``But if you don't so some of these things, then you're going to have to face the consequences.'' For example, he said, 11 refineries with a combined production capacity of 2.5 million barrels a day have been rejected over the past two decades for environmental reasons by state and local governments in the region. ``If some of these refineries had been built, the additional capacity might have helped to alleviate last winter's supply problems in the Northeast,'' he said. Watkins said the proposed energy strategy to be submitted to Bush in December will seek to ``level the playing field'' and present options to eliminate obstacles to moving toward an energy policy that better balances costs among regions of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Fails To Pinpoint Cause Of Cargo Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety investigators concluded Monday that an improperly latched cargo door popped open before a cargo plane crashed in Texas last year, but said they could not determine the cause of the crash. The accident at Carswell Air Force Base near Fort Worth killed the pilot and co-pilot, who were the only people aboard the DC-9 operated by Evergreen International Airlines. The National Transportation Safety Board, after a meeting on the March 18, 1989, crash, said inadequate procedures used by Evergreen for preflight verification of cargo door security contributed to the crash. The board also blamed the Federal Aviation Administration for approving procedures used for verification of cargo door security and for failing to order modifications to the open door warning system on DC-9s used as cargo planes. McDonnell Douglas was cited for failing to provide the flight crew guidance on in-flight opening of the cargo door, despite 23 previous incidents involving DC-9s and DC-8s. None of the previous incidents resulted in an accident. The board said KLM, which owned the aircraft before Evergreen, accomplished only three of the 11 items the manufacturer recommended for the main cargo door and Evergreen took no additional action on the items. All FAA-ordered actions were taken, however, investigators said. The board said the flight's co-pilot probably failed to complete the door locking cycle and the captain was not aware of it because of the malfunctioning warning system. The door opened upon takeoff, investigators concluded. The opening of a cargo door could disturb the stability of an airliner, affecting airspeed and altitude, the board said in recommending that McDonnell Douglas amend its operating manual to include information about the effects of an open cargo door on flight. The plane crashed during a turn as it was preparing to land.

DOC.HEAD: Sweater Prices Found to be Unfairly Cheap
DOC.TEXT: Sweaters made of man-made fibers in Hong Kong, South Korea and Taiwan, representing more than a third of the U.S. market, are being sold at less than their fair market value, the Commerce Department said Monday. The National Knitwear & Sportswear Association had filed complaints against the sweater manufacturers last September. It said that the imports, made predominatnly of acrylic fiber, represent 72 percent of the $1.3 billion U.S. market and that the three countries represent 55 percent of the imports. The Commerce Department said the value of the sweaters imported from Hong Kong in 1989 was $208.8 million; from South Korea, $476.1 million, and from Taiwan, $485.5 million. The department's finding was preliminary. A final determination is due by July 5, it said. If it too determines the sweaters are being dumped, the International Trade Commission will decide within 45 days whether the imports injure or threaten to injure the U.S. sweater industry. If the ITC decision is affirmative, the Commerce Department then will order the Customs Service to collect antidumping duties to make the imported sweater prices comparable to those of U.S.-made sweaters.

DOC.HEAD: Friends, Family Of Polhill Prepare to Welcome Hostage Home
With AM-Hostage Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An old basketball buddy of Robert Polhill said Monday the former hostage is the kind of man who's willing to bend over backward to help people. So folks in the area where Polhill grew up want to do the same for him when he returns. ``We are planning a big celebration,'' said Mayor George Carter, who played basketball with Polhill in the 1960s. Homes and businesses in Fishkill are festooned with yellow ribbons and lights to honor Polhill and the other hostages. When Polhill comes home ``we'll take them down,'' Carter said. ``That'll be to let him know our prayers have been answered.'' Moslem extremists in Lebanon freed Polhill on Sunday after holding him more than three years. Polhill, 55, grew up in nearby Beacon. His mother, Ruth, lives in Fishkill, about 60 miles north of New York City. ``Bob's a very mild individual, a very gentle individual,'' Carter said. ``He's the type of person who will bend over backward to do things for people. We're trying to do the same for him. He's one of ours.'' Fishkill, Beacon and Dutchess County officials will meet Wednesday to plan festivities for Polhill's homecoming, Carter said. Officials don't know yet when he'll be released from a hospital in Wiesbaden, West Germany, where he is recovering from his ordeal. Mrs. Polhill spoke by phone with her son for about 15 minutes Monday. While he ``sounded good, there was a difference in his voice I didn't like too much,'' she said. ``He sounded hoarse.'' Polhill told her he was recovering from bronchitis, she said. Doctors told her that while Polhill appeared in good spirits after his release, hostages ``all are high and happy for a day or two, then feel tired out,'' she said. Polhill's sons, Brian, 23, and Stephen, 26, were preparing to fly to Germany on Monday evening to be reunited with their father. The brothers live in the New York City. Brian Polhill predicted that the first thing his father would do on his return is watch a replay of the 1987 Giants-Broncos Super Bowl. ``He was kidnapped the day before the game,'' he said. Johanne Polhill, Robert's first wife and the mother of Brian and Stephen, shared champagne with her sons Sunday. She also lives in New York City. Polhill's second wife, Feryal, is Lebanese. Ruth Polhill spent most of Sunday and Monday talking with reporters and celebrating with friends at her home. ``She's been up and down on a roller coaster,'' said the Rev. James Edgar of First Presbyterian Church in Beacon, which Mrs. Polhill attends. ``I think it's still just registering with her that he's free.'' Sirens and church bells sounded throughout the community Sunday when word was announced that Polhill was free. A ribbon has been wrapped around the steeple of First Reformed Church in Fishkill since the village held a hostage awareness week in December. A bow was tied onto the ribbon Sunday when the town learned Polhill was released, said church secretary Eva Bettencourt. The church also has a tree decorated with more than 10,000 lights to symbolize the total number of days spent in captivity by Polhill and the remaining seven American hostages in Lebanon. ``That's the only blight to the whole thing, that these other families, whom I've become well acquainted with by phone, are unhappy,'' Mrs. Polhill said. The relatives of some of the other hostages felt Polhill's release was a good sign. ``I think it's only a matter of time before Alann is free,'' Craig Steen, of Orlando, Fla., said of his brother. Alann Steen was taken hostage the same time as Polhill, along with Jesse Jonathan Turner. Peggy Say, whose brother Terry Anderson is the longest-held hostage, also said Polhill's release was ``good news for all the hostage families.'' Polhill's appearance on television was encouraging, Ms. Say said, ``because I need to believe that that is indicative of the improved conditions of the hostages that we had been told about over the past year or so.'' Anderson, 42, Chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Officials Defend Use of Animals in Experiments
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials Monday called experiments involving animals the linchpin of medical advances and said animal rights activists threaten to derail this progress. ``Animal studies ... have been and continue to be an indispensable part of the great biomedical revolution that has brought freedom from disease and suffering to millions of human beings,'' said Constance Horner, under secretary of health and human services. ``Virtually every major medical advance of the last hundred years has involved such studies _ the development of vaccines for polio, tetanus, diphtheria and whooping cough; insulin for diabetics; radiation and chemotherapy for cancer patients; organ transplants; and antibiotics.'' In a pep talk to scientists at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., the day before a planned animal-rights rally there, Horner condemned the activities of ``extremists'' who are cultivating ``a climate of fear'' throughout the scientific research community. Scientists are being intimidated and threatened and their experiments sabotaged, she said ``We must not permit the activities of a handful of extremists to deprive millions of life-sustaining and life-enhancing fruits of biomedical research,'' she said in prepared remarks. Horner said scientists, including those at NIH, have long discouraged and condemned animal research that is unnecessary or cruel. Dr. Frederick Goodwin, head of the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration, told reporters earlier that both NIH and his agency conduct research under the regulations of the Animal Welfare Act of 1966. ``In many cases, it's easier to do research with humans than with animals,'' he said. Animal rights activists planned a demonstration at NIH on Tuesday to protest the use of animals in addiction research. Friends of Animals, which is sponsoring the protest, says too much is being spent on animal experimentation at the expense of treatment and prevention of drug addiction. The group contends scientists' search for a cure for addiction is fruitless and fails to address the underlying social and psychological causes of addiction. Goodwin said the federal government is spending about $1 million this year and hopes to increase that to $20 million next year on various efforts to educate the public, especially the young, about the life sciences. He said that was necessary, in part, to counter the efforts of animal rights activists, who he said use Americans' lack of science knowledge to ``confuse the public.'' People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals characterized the effort as ``indoctrinating children with the idea that animals are no more than test tubes with whiskers.''

DOC.HEAD: Marilyn Quayle Presses Need for Mammograms with Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf pvs, Within six, to CORRECT year of Mrs. Tucker's death from 1974 to 1975.
DOC.TEXT: A teary Marilyn Quayle told a congressional panel Monday that her mother might have been spared a painful death from breast cancer had the disease been detected at an early stage. Mrs. Quayle, making her first appearance on Capitol Hill since her husband, Dan Quayle, became vice president in January 1989, recounted her mother's death at age 56. Her voice cracked with emotion. ``We meet this morning to declare war on breast cancer. ... A war in which there can be no substitute for victory,'' Mrs. Quayle said before the House subcommittee on health and environment. The 40-year-old Mrs. Quayle, who has traveled the country urging women over age 35 to have mammograms, recalled what happened when her mother, a pediatrician in Indiana, found a lump in her breast. ``Her own physician told her not to worry. He had seen many lumps in the past; he was fairly certain this one was benign,'' Mrs. Quayle said of her mother, the late Mary Tucker. Within six months, however, the lump had grown and the cancer had spread to Mrs. Tucker's lymphatic system. After debilitating breast surgery and painful chemotherapy, Mrs. Tucker died in 1975. ``Mary Tucker's story does not have to be repeated,'' Mrs. Quayle said. ``Mammography and self-examination could have kept her alive. Early detection could have given my mother less severe surgical options. It could have slowed the spread of the disease.'' While Mrs. Quayle has promoted the need for mammograms, she did not endorse legislation that would finance screening for low-income women for breast and cervical cancer. The legislation, sponsored by Reps. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., the panel's chairman, and Edward Madigan, R-Ill., is expected, if passed, to cost $50 million in fiscal year 1991. Madigan asked Mrs. Quayle if she could persuade the Bush administration to back the measure. Instead, she dwelt on the fear that keeps some women for having the X-rays. ``Fear is what we are fighting,'' she said. ``Fear, the greatest obstacle to early detection and treatment _ fear of the unknown, fear of what might turn up on the X-ray.'' She also said that ``women don't take care of themselves'' and urged men to be more aggressive in encouraging the women in their lives to have breast cancer examinations. Noting that women frequently are the ones who hound husbands and children on health care, she said, ``It's time for the men in our lives to hound us.'' Also testifying was Rep. Barbara Vucanovich, R-Nev., who said no doctor ever mentioned to her the need for a mammogram until she was 61. Her first examination detected a tumor. ``Early detection of my breast cancer allowed me to go on to live an active and satisfying life, and caused me to dedicate myself to reducing breast cancer,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Stowaways Survive More Than a Week Without Food, Water
DOC.TEXT: Seven stowaways from Ecuador are described as lucky to be alive after surviving nine days without food or water inside the cargo hold of a freighter. Federal officials boarded the Ecuadoran freighter Santa Rita on Sunday in New Haven Harbor to check out the seven men, who were not allowed to leave the ship. Reporters were not allowed on the ship to talk to crew members. The ship's crew discovered the starving, dehydrated men Friday, shortly after the vessel left Philadelphia for New Haven, officials said. ``They wanted to be in the U.S. _ you know, the land of honey,'' U.S. Customs Inspector Vincent Caggiula said Sunday. ``They had food and water for maybe part of the first day. They had a common sleeping place. They're lucky to be alive.'' He said their conditions quickly improved Saturday after gorging themselves on food and drink. The Santa Rita arrived in New Haven late Saturday. Coast Guard Petty Officer Joseph Coughlin said the stowaways did not need hospitalization and remained on the ship in makeshift cells in the crew quarters. The ship was scheduled to return to Ecuador with stops in New York, Florida, Texas and Mexico, said Customs official Robert Curely, director of the port in New Haven.

DOC.HEAD: Reform Communist Elected Slovene President, Center-Right Leads in Croatia
DOC.TEXT: A center-right coalition claimed victory Monday in multiparty parliamentary elections in Croatia, while a reform Communist won the run-off presidential election in neighboring Slovenia. The elections in the two republics were considered crucial for the future of Yugoslavia, a loose federation of six republics and two provinces. There were fears the voting could further divide the country. Slovenia and Croatia have taken the lead in holding the first free multiparty elections in Yugoslavia in almost 50 years. Nearly 4 million voters went to the polls in the two northern republics on Sunday. But Serbia, the largest republic and only one of two still led by hard-line Communists, has accused some Slovene and Croatian leaders of advocating secession from the Balkan nation of 23 million. In Slovenia, with nearly all the 1.2 million ballots counted, Communist reformer Milan Kucan had 58.39 of the vote after Sunday's second-round presidential balloting. Joze Pucnik, leader of the center-right DEMOS coalition, trailed with 41.6 percent of the vote, and conceded the election. Kucan formerly headed the Slovene Communist Party, renamed the Party of Democratic Reform, which has insisted that Slovenia remain part of a reconstructed Yugoslav federation. Pucnik advocated Slovenia's secession from Yugoslavia. Kucan thus becomes Eastern Europe's first freely elected Communist head of state since a democratic upheaval swept the region last year. ``We should now heal the rifts of a very divisive campaign by uniting for the sake'' of Slovenia, Kucan said in a television interview Monday. Kucan, 49, said he had turned in his party membership card for the duration of his four-year term of office in a goodwill gesture toward his opponents. ``I want to be the president of all ... citizens of Slovenia,'' Kucan said. Despite Kucan's victory, his party was soundly defeated in the April 8 parliamentary elections. He will have to work with a government chosen by Pucnik's DEMOS coalition, which is expected to form the first non-Communist government in any of Yugoslavia's republics in 45 years. The center-right coalition won 55 percent of the seats in Slovenia's regional parliament. In Croatia, the second largest republic, a leader of the Croatian Democratic Union, a center-right coalition, claimed victory in the republic's parliamentary elections. Neven Jurica, a coalition leader, said the Union had won an ``impressive victory'' and was expected to take an outright majority of seats in the election's first-round. Jurica said the coalition's first task would be to change Croatia's Communist constitution into a Western-style charter. Voters chose among 30 parties to fill 356 seats in the three-chamber parliament. With nearly one-third of the votes in 106 constituencies counted, the Union's candidates were leading in 60 of them, the reform Communist Party in 38, and the centrist Coalition of National Accord in eight, according to preliminary figures released by the state electoral commission. About 80 percent of Croatia's 3.5 million eligible voters cast their ballots in Sunday's first-round elections for the 116-seat Chamber of Counties and the 80-seat Socio-Political Chamber. Election officials said they would not release any more preliminary results until voting was completed Monday among factory workers for the remaining 160 seats in the Labor Chamber of the legislature. Preliminary results from that voting were not expected before Tuesday. A second round of voting will be held in two weeks in constituencies where no candidate won a majority. The Union advocates a system in which all six republics would have ``full sovereign rights,'' according to the party's leader Franjo Tudjman, a former Yugoslav army general who spent a total of five years in jail for what were termed ``counterrevolutionary activities.'' Yugoslavia's last multiparty elections were held in 1939. Opposition groups claim that a ballot in 1945 was rigged by the Communist Party, which thereafter banned all dissent and turned the country into a single-party state.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Amtrak Train Derails in Southeast Iowa; Scores Reported Hurt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with up 70 to 80 injured; quotes; AP staffer and photographer heading to the scene
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak passenger train carrying about 400 people derailed Monday east of Batavia, injuring scores of people, authorities said. Ambulances and rescue helicopters headed to the scene. Ottumwa Regional Health Center was told to expected 70 to 80 patients stemming from the derailment, said Janice Simpson, a hospital spokeswoman. ``We hear about 20 fairly seriously injured,'' Ms. Simpson said. The eastbound California Zephyr derailed about 1:25 p.m. It was carrying 394 passengers and about 20 crew members, said Debbie Hare, the Amtrak spokeswoman in Chicago. The train had 12 passenger cars and three locomotives, Hare said. Among the injured passengers was Wisconsin State Rep. Marlin Schneider, who was suffered a bruise to his leg. ``We were having lunch and suddenly the train came apart,'' said Schneider, who was traveling with his two young daughters. ``It started to buckle. We didn't get hurt very badly but a number of people did.'' Sections of the California Zephyr originate in Seattle, Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif., and are linked in Salt Lake City for the trip to Chicago, Hare said. Batavia is about 90 miles southeast of Des Moines.

DOC.HEAD: ^Bush's Deal: Better Iran Relations in Return for Hostages
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ ``No deals'' is the word from George Bush. But one deal is held out that clearly interests Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani: Release of American hostages would lead to dramatically improved relations between the United States and Iran. The same offer applies to Syria, the other key government with the ability to influence the hostage situation. The release of an American in Lebanon _ this time it was Robert Polhill _ always sets analysts scrambling to determine if something has changed, if there is reason to hope that the ordeal of the remaining hostages might soon end. The hope this time is that Iran and Syria might be seeing release of the hostages as the price they must pay for improved relations. That would be the reverse of Iran's stance last summer, when the demand was that the United States make the first move. ``I have said many times that if the United States expects us to help in the Lebanese issue, it should show in practice that it has dropped its hostile stand against us,'' Rafsanjani said then. Has there been a significant change? As usual in the Middle East, who knows? Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on the Middle East, said the release of Polhill made it ``appropriate for the United States to send some kind of a gesture that we're willing to enter into a dialogue with Iran.'' ``There are a lot of things that could be done here _ short of aid, short of normalization, short of credits _ that might be a gesture in response to the release of a hostage,'' he said on CBS' ``Face the Nation.'' But the response from the White House was to maintain a tough line. ``As the president said yesterday, we want the release of all hostages. That would open the door towards better relations with Iran,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Bush had to admit on Sunday that he couldn't say what Iran's role had been in gaining Polhill's release. ``I can't tell you I honestly know,'' said the president. American analysts cite Iran and Syria as the two countries with obvious influence on the groups that are holding 17 Westerners, including seven Americans, in Lebanon. But can a one quick command from Tehran or Damascus bring freedom for the hostages? That doesn't seem likely. Richard Murphy, assistant secretary of state for the Near East during the Reagan administration, pointed out on NBC's ``Meet the Press'' that there are no clear lines of authority within Hezbollah, the organization that includes the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, which was holding three Americans including Polhill. Gary Sick, a National Security Council aide when Jimmy Carter was president, appeared on the same program as Murphy. The show aired before Polhill's release and the two men were speculating about the reasons for the delay. Word was circulated last week that one of American hostages would be freed on Friday, but then the release was abruptly postponed. Sick speculated that the delay might be ``simply a demonstration of a long negotiating process that this is not going to be easy, and that if the West wants to get their hostages out they're going to have to provide some concessions to Iran.''

DOC.HEAD: President Hunts for Pet's Attacker
DOC.TEXT: President Bush sought to unravel a White House mystery Monday: What bit presidential pooch Millie on the nose? Bush, returning from a midday speech, stepped from his limousine, conferred with National Park Service groundskeepers and then led them on a search of an ivy-covered hill 50 yards from the mansion. They poked around the knoll for a few minutes before Bush headed for the Oval Office. Reporters, watching from afar, clamored for an explanation. The president, assuming an air of mock gravity, responded: ``There's a very serious problem. When I get ready to announce what I was doing, I'll let you know. It was very serious stuff.'' Then he was ready. ``Millie got bit on the nose by some animal,'' he added. ``There's a big hole over there.'' Millie, an English springer spaniel, had the encounter Friday and still had scabs on her nose, a press aide to first lady Barbara Bush said later Monday. ``Mrs. Bush is speculating it was something big. Millie had her nose where it shouldn't have been and she got bit,'' said aide Jean Becker. Millie's nose swelled up after the incident, but the swelling went down by evening and she required no treatment, Ms. Becker added. Millie went to Camp David later Friday for the weekend with her mistress. It was anybody's guess whether Millie suffered this comeuppance from a groundhog or some other low-lying lawn beast. Bush has boasted of Millie's hunting prowess. The springer spaniel has recorded almost a dozen known kills of squirrels, rabbits and at least one rat.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Directors Pledge Support in Mapplethorpe Issue
DOC.TEXT: An international group of museum directors on Monday pledged financial support to an art gallery facing obscenity charges for displaying Robert Mapplethorpe's sexually explicit photographs. Trustees of the Association of Art Museum Directors came to Cincinnati from across the country and Canada to show their support for the Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie. The gallery and Barrie were indicted April 7 on misdemeanor obscenity charges for displaying the seven disputed photos in the 175-picture collection by the late Mapplethorpe. Some of the photos in the show, which angered Sen. Jesse Helms and prompted debate about federal funding for the arts, depict naked children or homosexual acts. The New York-based association represents directors of 153 museums in the United States and Canada. John Walsh, the association's president and director of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, said the charges are an attack on constitutionally protected freedom of expression. ``If a prosecutor here can use indictments, police actions and confiscation to intimidate an art exhibit, then other prosecutors may be tempted,'' Walsh told a news conference at the gallery. ``We see something sinister here. ... If Dennis is under indictment, we think we're all under indictment.'' None of the photos was confiscated, but patrons were cleared from the Cincinnati show for a time on its opening day while authorities videotaped the exhibit. The museum association criticized Cincinnati prosecutors and those those who supported them. ``This is the tip of the iceberg,'' said Marc Wilson, the association's second vice president and director of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo. ``The question is, is one group _ with the set of values of this group _ allowed to define what the majority should see? ... It's not just about art. It's about your right to do a lot of things.'' The association said it would pay any fine that Barrie, the art gallery and its trustees might incur. It also promised to help defray defense costs and to provide witnesses and testimony if there is a trial. Hamilton County Municipal Judge David Albanese has scheduled a pretrial meeting with the lawyers April 30. Barrie and lawyers for the center have pleaded innocent. Barrie said the art center's legal costs are ``in the tens of thousands of dollars.'' Karl Kadon, an assistant city prosecutor overseeing the prosecution, declined comment Monday. The exhibit has attracted more than 35,000 people since it opened April 7, spokeswoman Amy Banister said. The 50-year-old arts center's previous record attendance for any exhibit was 29,000 for the six-week ``Computers and Art'' show in late 1987. The Mapplethorpe show, titled ``The Perfect Moment,'' continues to be shown in its entirety at the art gallery. The center obtained an April 8 order from U.S. District Judge Carl Rubin protecting the exhibit against confiscation.

DOC.HEAD: Paulette Goddard, Star of Chaplin Films, is Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with reaction from Bob Hope, Macdonald Carey, details. CORRECTS name of film to `Bride of Vengeance.' No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Paulette Goddard, the wide-eyed, waiflike actress who co-starred with husband Charlie Chaplin in films such as ``The Great Dictator'' and ``Modern Times,'' died Monday at her home in southern Switzerland. A municipal employee in the village of Ronco said official records show the actress was born June 3, 1905, making her 84. However, reference books give her year of birth as 1911 or 1915. The employee, Pia DellaMora, said the exact cause of death was not known ``but one could assume she died of old age.'' A member of her household said the actress had a brief illness. Ms. Goddard, born Marion Levy in Whitestone, N.Y., began her career on stage in the New York show ``Rio Rita.'' Her Hollywood debut came with a small part in ``The Girl Habit'' in 1931, the first of 40-plus movies. As a member of the Hal Roach Studio stock company, she starred with Chaplin in two of his classics, ``Modern Times'' in 1936 and ``The Great Dictator'' in 1940. Their marriage, her second, ended in divorce in 1942. ``She turned out to be a fine actress,'' Bob Hope said Monday from his Los Angeles home. ``She was everything. She was beautiful. She was perfect.'' Hope, who appeared with Ms. Goddard in the movies ``The Cat and the Canary'' in 1939, ``The Ghost Breakers'' in 1940 and ``Nothing But the Truth'' in 1941, recalled how he was flattered when his hero Chaplin told him, ``You've got great timing.'' ``It was a very big moment in my professional life,'' Hope said. ``When I was a kid I used to do an imitation of him. Now, here I was, acting with his wife and he paid me a compliment.'' Other films in which the actress had leading roles included ``Dramatic School,'' ``I Love a Soldier,'' ``The Diary of a Chambermaid'' and a 1947 British production, ``An Ideal Husband.'' Her last TV film was ``The Snoop Sisters.'' Her third marriage, to American actor Burgess Meredith, broke up in 1944. In 1958, she married Erich Maria Remarque, the German-born American novelist. He became famous in the 1920s for his anti-war ``All Quiet on the Western Front,'' which was banned in Nazi Germany. They settled in Ronco, a picturesque hillside village close to the Italian frontier and overlooking Lago Maggiore. Remarque died in 1970. ``She was such a wonderful girl, a real woman with a lot of wit,'' said actor Macdonald Carey from his Beverly Hills, Calif., home. ``Sometimes actresses are known for only one anecdote or something, but she was much more down to earth than that.'' Carey appeared opposite Miss Goddard in the 1948 comedy ``Hazard'' and in the 1949 film ``Bride of Vengeance.'' Ms. DellaMora said Ms. Goddard was to be cremated with funeral ceremonies planned for Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Give Record $2.98 Billion to United Way
DOC.TEXT: Nearly two-thirds of the record $2.98 billion that Americans gave to the United Way last year came from individuals, the service organization said Monday.
