An estimated 80 million Americans, or 43 percent of the adult population, gave last year, the group said. Individuals contributed $1.9 billion, or 64 percent, of the United Way's total while corporations gave about $778 million. The rest came from foundations, direct mail and major individual gifts. The money will be distributed to 40,000 groups around the country to help fight drug abuse, homelessness, poverty and other problems, the organization said. Last year's level was $200 million, or 7.2 percent, higher than in 1988. It was the largest dollar increase over a one-year period in the United Way's history and the highest percentage increase since 1985. In addition to cash contributions, companies gave $53 million worth of goods and services, double the value of such gifts in 1988. Also, the National Football League donated more than $45 million in television and radio broadcast time for United Way public service announcements.

DOC.HEAD: Asian Elephant's Calf Dies
DOC.TEXT: A veterinary team tried to perform a Caesarean section on a 36-year-old Asian elephant Monday, but instead removed a dead 266-pound calf from the mother. Officials at the Burnet Park Zoo said they weren't sure why the calf, a male, died. They said the position of the calf's head had prevented the mother, known as Babe, from delivering naturally. The 7,700-pound Babe was expected to survive the operation by the special surgical team, zoo officials said. It was the third time the team had tried a C-section on an Asian elephant, and only one of the operations was successful, said zoo spokeswoman Yvette Pelletreau. Babe would have been been the oldest first-time elephant mother to give birth in a North American zoo. She went into labor Wednesday night. The medical team from Cornell University and zoos around the country decided to operate after labor-inducing drugs failed to bring about a natural birth. As preparation for possible surgery, Burnet Park on Sunday gathered some needed material: two king-size mattresses, a one-ton chain hoist to lift the calf and two five-ton chain hoists to lift Babe. The zoo world followed Babe's pregnancy because of the rarity of captive births by Asian elephants, an endangered species that number less than 45,000 in the wild. There have been just 62 births in captivity and only 14 North American zoos have Asian-elephant breeding programs.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Say Sandinista Army Must `Disappear'
An AP Extra
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A top Contra leader in Nicaragua says rebel troops he commands will not disarm until the Sandinista army disappears, regardless of a demobilization accord with the government-elect. ``The causes for our fight will have been fulfilled once the EPS (Sandinista army) and the Interior Ministry (internal security forces) disappear,'' Dennis Galeano, known as Commander Johnny, told The Associated Press in an interview Sunday. Representatives of the U.S.-backed rebels signed accords with President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's United National Opposition on April 19, agreeing to move into rural security zones and disarm by June 10, 6{ weeks after Mrs. Chamorro takes office on Wednesday. Although Contra negotiators said the agreement was unconditional, they were clearly aware that the Sandinistas agreed to depoliticize the army and forbid officers to serve in party posts. The Sandinista party now controls the army. ``What has been signed is in exchange for something that will happen. If everything goes according to plan, we will disarm.'' said Galeano, the brother of Contra chief-of-staff Israel Galeano, known as Commander Franklin. Dennis Galeano reported had more than 2,000 guerrillas under his command and said they will move into security zones designed to keep the Sandinista army and Contras apart, as called for in the accords. But differences of interpretation and suspicion of each other's intentions after nine years of civil war may cause hangups on demobilization. The Sandinistas note the government agreed to ``respect the integrity and professionalism'' of the Sandinista People's Army, interpreting this to mean the military command will be left intact. Contras in the field, however, said the current command structure could not be retained. ``This is the voice of the people; they didn't vote for a partial change, they voted for a total change,'' said Osvaldo Galeano, another Galeano brother and battalion commander known as El Negro. Dennis Galeano said the Sandinista military ``must understand that political power is the essential element to maintaining an army, and they lost the elections.'' The AP encountered Dennis and Osvaldo Galeano and about 100 other Contras in this hamlet of a dozen wooden houses on a prairie. They were talking with about 300 peasants from around El Guau, in central Chontales province about 100 miles east of Managua. ``I don't think the Resistance should disarm,'' said Santiago Diaz, a 65-year-old peasant, referring to the Contras by their formal name. ``Before the elections, the Sandinistas told us that if we voted for UNO, they would present us with the bill,'' he said, using a Nicaraguan phrase that can be interpreted as a threat. ``Well, we voted for UNO. And now, if they (Sandinistas) stay in place, we'll all be dead. You'll see.'' Another peasant, Candelario Benito Vargas, 60, said, ``We want the army to leave and the Resistance to become our army. That's what we want. ``If you never lived under the repression of the Sandinistas, you don't know what it was like,'' Vargas said. ``We want those piricuacos (an Indian word meaning dogs) to disappear.'' Both Dennis and Osvaldo Galeano hinted the Contras themselves might replace purged Sandinista officers. ``That would be the people's decision: if they ask us to replace the officers, then we would,'' Dennis Galeano said. The Sandinistas have repeatedly said they will not accept the Contras as a new Nicaraguan army, saying such a move would be tantamount to bringing back the hated National Guard of the late right-wing dictator Anastasio Somoza, whom the Sandinistas overthrew in 1979. Outgoing President Daniel Ortega said last week the main task of all Sandinistas was to ensure the Contras kept to their demobilization pact. Asked about the possibility of a renewed war as a result of a deadlock with the Sandinistas, Dennis Galeano said: ``We'll see what happens after the new government reaches power. I don't think open war is possible. But we'll see how Dona Violeta acts, and according to that, we may be satisfied.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Hate Crime Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday signed a bill requiring the government to keep track of crimes against minorities, saying ``hate crimes cannot be tolerated in a free society.'' At a White House ceremony attended by leaders of various minorities, including gay-rights advocates, Bush called the measure ``a significant step to help guarantee civil rights for every American.'' Under the legislation, the Justice Department will keep statistics on offenses related to race, religion, sexual orientation and ethnicity as part of the FBI's annual uniform crime report. Approval of the so-called ``hate crimes'' bill followed complaints about a wave of such offenses on the part of neo-Nazi ``skinheads'' and others. ``Bigotry and hate regrettably still exist in this country and hate breeds violence, threatening the security of our entire society,'' Bush said. ``We must rid our communities of the poison we call prejudice, bias and discrimination.'' The president also said the Justice Department would establish a toll-free number for reporting complaints of such crimes. ``The faster we can find out about these heinous crimes, the faster we can track down the bigots who commit them,'' Bush said. ``Hate crimes cannot be tolerated in a free society.'' The signing ceremony ``marks the first time in history that lesbian and gay Americans have been invited to a White House bill-signing ceremony,'' the Human Rights Campaign Fund said in a statement. Eight representatives of the national gay-rights organization were invited, said fund president Tim McFeeley. Bush, McFeeley said, ``understands how destructive crimes of bigotry and prejudice _ including gay bashing _ are to the fabric of American society.'' The bill's chief sponsor, Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said after the ceremony that he viewed the inclusion of ``sexual orientation'' in the law as a major element of the bill. Bush said the administration would work with Congress ``to determine whether new law enforcement measures are needed to bring hatemongers out of hiding and into the light of justice.'' ``As we speak, 17 racist skinheads in Dallas are waiting to be sentenced by a federal court for conspiring to commit hate crimes against Jewish, black and Hispanic citizens,'' Bush said. ``Mail bombings that killed a federal judge and an NAACP lawyer are being investigated tenaciously by federal authorities. We will not rest until the cowards that committed these senseless crime are behind bars.''

DOC.HEAD: Witness: Youth Charged in Murder Trial Boasted of Guns.
DOC.TEXT: A key prosecution witness in the slaying of a black teen-ager by a gang of whites last summer testified Monday that one of the youths standing trial for murder boasted of having guns shortly before the killing. Gina Feliciano, whom defense lawyers say was the spark that led to the slaying of Yusef Hawkins, 16, on Aug. 23, 1989, said she heard Keith Mondello talk about weapons on the street below her apartment hours before the attack. ``Keith was saying he had five guns altogether, three .38s and two .45s or three .45s and two .38s,'' Miss Feliciano told the jury in Brooklyn's state Supreme Court. She said Mondello then bragged, ``That he can't wait for tonight.'' Mondello and another white defendant, Joseph Fama, both 19, are charged with two counts of second-degree murder and other crimes. If convicted, they face up to 25 years to life. Prosecutors say Fama was the gunman who fatally shot Hawkins and Mondello organized the mob that attacked the black teens. Defense lawyers say the white youths gathered in front of Miss Feliciano's apartment because they believed she had invited black and Hispanic friends whom they considered outsiders and troublemakers to her 18th birthday party. The youths, from the mostly white neighborhood of Bensonhurst in Brooklyn, were armed with baseball bats to protect themselves, the lawyers maintain. A sobbing Miss Feliciano testified that she later was looking out a bedroom window shortly after 9 p.m. when she saw Hawkins and three other blacks walking along the street. The four were in the neighborhood to look at a used car and did not know Miss Feliciano. She testified that she heard Mondello use a racial epithet to describe Hawkins and his companions. Hawkins and his friends were followed by the whites, many carrying bats and guns, she said. She said Mondello and two other whites charged in the attack, James Patino and Joseph Serrano, were in the gang. ``They all had guns,'' she said of the three young men. ``How do you know they were guns?'' asked Justice Thaddeus Owens, the trial judge. ``Cause I seen them,'' Miss Feliciano replied. She said she heard several shots and the whites scattered. Miss Feliciano said she saw Fama, but without a gun.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives, Friends Still Grieve for Victims of L'Ambiance Collapse
DOC.TEXT: Survivors of 28 workers killed when an apartment building collapsed during construction three years ago Monday say the debris-strewn vacant lot at the site is a painful reminder of the tragedy. On the anniversary, city officials unveiled plans to erect an apartment building on the site of the L'Ambiance Plaza complex, where 11 stories of concrete collapsed on the workers. Politicians and friends and relatives of the victims gathered Monday a half-mile from the site to place flowers on a stone memorial, offer words to the victims' families and announce plans for the five-story housing complex, to be called Renaissance Plaza. Construction of the apartment complex is the final piece in the $41 million settlement reached in December 1988 between the survivors and the project's developers. Under the settlement, ownership of the land and anything built on it is transferred from the developers to the victims' families, said Richard A. Bieder, the attorney who represented the families in a class action lawsuit. The building will consist of 60 to 80 apartments for low- and middle-income tenants. Federal investigators blamed the collapse on the failure of a hydraulic jack used to lift floor slabs into place in a building technique known as lift-slab construction. The jack's failure created a chain reaction that brought down the entire building. ``It was a terrible, terrible sight and it was a scary, scary sight, with all the rubble down on everybody,'' recalled Frank J. Carroll Jr., president of the Bridgeport Building Trades, who helped with rescue efforts. Rescue workers dug through the rubble for nine days but only found one survivor. ``That gave us some kind of hope that we would be fortunate enough to get more,'' he said. ``Unfortunately, that was not the case.'' The new $9 million building is being built by two Hartford developers who are putting up $3.4 million. The rest will be financed by the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority and the state Department of Housing. Groundbreaking is expected this summer. ``It's nice to see them get rid of the rubble, but I would have liked to have seen a park,'' said David Schneider, whose uncle, Mario Colello, was among the victims. Others, especially construction workers who attended Monday's service, said they will be glad to see a building rise from the rubble. ``The scars are really too ugly,'' said Bridgeport electrician Dave Henshaw, who lost a friend in the disaster and searched for others in the rubble. ``You don't need to drive by on an almost daily basis and see the twisted metal and concrete.'' But construction workers are less satisfied with efforts to improve job safety. Congress has still not enacted legislation pushed by Sen. Christopher J. Dodd, D-Conn., and Rep. Christopher Shays, R-Conn., to improve safety requirements and give more authority to the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration. During the memorial service, OSHA head Gerard F. Scannell said he had been able to enact a number of administrative changes, such as a new office within OSHA that will concentrate on reducing construction hazards and responding to emergencies. He also said new standards would take effect this summer governing the lift-slab construction like that used at L'Ambiance. ``Our resolve must be that another L'Ambiance Plaza disaster will never again happen in America,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Buy More U.S. Grain
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 149,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices for delivery next month under a long-term grain supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Monday. Christoper E. Goldthwaite, acting general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the wheat was sold by two private companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Goldthwaite said 563,950 tons of wheat remain in the Soviet Union's current EEP allocation. Only wheat has been approved for sale to the Soviets under the price-subsidy program. The seventh year of the U.S.-Soviet grain agreement began Oct. 1. With the latest sales, the Soviet Union has bought more than 3.2 million tons of wheat for 1989-90 delivery and more than 13.1 million tons of corn, plus soybeans and soybean meal. All of the wheat was sold under EEP arrangements. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The 149,000 tons are equal to nearly 5.5 million bushels worth about $19 million at recent U.S. farm prices. Goldthwaite reported the subsidies at an average of $28.87 per ton, or about 79 cents per bushel. The EEP arrangement allows private exporters to sell wheat and other designated commodities to specified countries at reduced prices to meet foreign competition. The exporters then collect free government surpluses of grain or other products as bonuses, or subsidies. Goldthwaite said the latest wheat was sold by Continental Grain Co., 99,000 tons; and J. Aron & Co., 50,000.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Memo Supported Israel's Retention of Golan Heights
DOC.TEXT: President Gerald R. Ford in 1975 secretly promised Israel that the United States would seriously consider backing Israel's retention of territory on the Golan Heights captured from Syria, according to a report by an Israeli think tank. The territory had been used before the 1967 Six Day War for Arab attacks on villages in northern Israel. It has served since then as a security buffer for the Jewish state, but Syria is demanding its return. Ford, in a letter to Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, said the United States had not decided what position to take on the borders between Israel and its Arab neighbors, including Syria. ``Should it do so,'' Ford wrote Sept. 1, ``it will give great weight to Israel's position that any peace agreement with Syria must be predicated on Israel remaining on the Golan Heights.'' At the time, Israel had agreed to relinquish key positions in the Sinai desert to Egypt. In his letter, Ford called the withdrawal arranged through shuttle-diplomacy by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, ``an act of great significance.'' Ford promised to maintain Israel's defensive strength through the supply of advanced F-16 jet aircraft. He also promised that ``the U.S. will support the position that an overall settlement with Syria in the framework fo a peace agreement must assure Israel's security from attack from the Golan Heights.'' The letter, which had been classified secret, was published by the Institute for Advanced Strategic and Political Studies of Jerusalem in a report titled, ``Can Israel Survive A Palestinian State?'' ``I think it's authentic,'' said an official who served in the Ford administration and was involved in Mideast diplomacy. ``It refers to a conversation Ford had with Rabin in the Oval Office.'' The assurance ``probably was not as categorical as the Israelis would have liked,'' said the ex-official, insisting on anonymity. ``It sympathizes with the Israeli position without binding us to it fully and without prejudging the outcome.'' The main conclusion of the study was that establishment of a Palestinian State on the West Bank and in Gaza, territories also captured by Israel in the 1967 war, would pose a danger to the Jewish state. ``A Palestinian Arab state west of the Jordan River would not bring a stable Middle East peace,'' the report said. ``Rather it would likely lead to chronic regional instability ending in a general Arab-Israeli war.'' An independent Palestinian state would be run by the Palestine Liberation Organization, the report said. ``It would be a springboard for surrounding hostile states.'' The report was to be made public at a news conference here Tuesday. It was sponsored by the Simon Wiesenthal Center of Los Angeles. Israel returned part of the Golan Heights to Syria in 1974 in an agreement mediated by Kissinger. Israel subsequently extended its legal authority _ a step short of annexation _ to the rest of the territory. The Bush administration has taken the position that Israel should relinquish occupied territory on all fronts _ the West Bank, Gaza and the Golan Heights. However, U.S. officials have not specified if that means all the land lost by the Arabs in the 1967 war should be returned. The report stressed the importance of the West Bank as ``a natural tank trap,'' saying control of the region would enable Israel to repel a coalition of Arab armies that hold a manpower advantage.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Cutting On Farm Commodity Programs
DOC.TEXT: A new budget-cutting package in the House is putting a further squeeze on farm bill costs, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Monday. The package announced last week by Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, would hold Agriculture Department spending on farm income support under federal commodity programs to $9.8 billion in the fiscal year that will begin on Oct. 1, he said. An administration budget plan sent to Congress in January called for $10.2 billion, a reduction of $1.5 billion from the increase that normally would occur if annual ``baseline'' spending trends were followed. Yeutter told a meeting of the National Association of Agricultural Journalists that the administration and he, in particular, had come in for severe partisan criticism for the proposed $1.5 billion spending reduction. The budget figures by Panetta will be even harder for House Agriculture Committee leadership to reckon with because those amount to a $1.9 billion cut from the baseline, he said. ``We now have a much different situation in farm legislation than we did a few days ago,'' Yeutter said. However, the situation also depends on whose baseline is being used. The current USDA baseline is $11.7 billion, which was based on crop indications last fall. Thus, a $1.5 billion reduction would be required to needed to lower fiscal 1991 spending to the $10.2 billion cited by Yeutter as the Bush proposal. The Panetta figure of $9.8 billion was derived from a Congressional Budget Office baseline of $10.6 billion computed as of February. Under that computation, the Panetta budget reduction would be only $800 million, not the $1.9 billion Yeutter said. Regardless of whose figures are used, farm commodity programs are in for some more paring. And Yeutter made the point that it will be even more urgent for the United States to seek a favorable conclusion to the Uruguay Round negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The GATT talks, scheduled to conclude at the end of this year, are aimed a liberalizing world trade. The U.S. position on agricultural trade calls for the gradual elimination of all trade-distorting policies and subsidies over a period of years. Yeutter said there is a feeling in some U.S. agricultural circles that the GATT talks are being overemphasized and that farmers would be better off relying on Congress to write generous price and income support provisions in the new farm bill. But there will ``not be a lucrative price package'' in the farm bill, Yeutter said. Therefore, farmers will have to generate more of their income from the marketplace. ``We're simply not going to have the flow of federal tax dollars into agriculture in the coming year that we've had in the past,'' he said. Yeutter said a two-price dairy plan approved last week by a House Agriculture subcommittee has some ``very negative'' features and would put a heavier cost burden on consumers. Members of the House wheat, soybeans and feed grains subcommittee also faced grim financial reality last week when Panetta announced the budget figures. The lawmakers' plans for price supports would cost $16 billion more over the five-year life of the bill than the budget would allow, committee staff said. The sections of the farm bill dealing with those commodities were put on hold until this Thursday while the lawmakers find places to cut.

DOC.HEAD: Bronx Cheers as Vanities Bonfire Blazes
DOC.TEXT: The vanities blazed in the Bronx on Monday and courthouse regular Ed McCarthy was steamed. ``It's total chaos,'' he barked, relating in detail his failed search for a parking spot. ``Maybe the book was right.'' The book is ``The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' Tom Wolfe's best-selling story of avarice, ego and corruption in New York, and the chaos was occasioned by the arrival of on-location filming for the movie. There was a 200-member film crew. There were stars _ people such as Tom Hanks and Bruce Willis. There was a simulated subway stop. There were two 100-foot cranes to spray simulated rain. There were hundreds of onlookers. And naturally, there was a traffic jam. ``They had to pick a Monday. They couldn't do it on the weekend,'' groused McCarthy, veteran spokesman of the district attorney's office. ``So now I'm parked at a bus stop where some idiot will give me a ticket. And I'll have to go downtown to get it fixed.'' McCarthy was joking about the ticket, but not about the rest _ and he wasn't alone. ``It's making everybody's life miserable,'' said Nick Kavalos, owner of a delicatessen across the street. ``The bread guy had to park two blocks away and carry in my delivery.'' Others took a more benign view of the proceedings, which focused on a corner outside the Mario Merola Building, housing the Bronx County courthouse. About 200 people watched, obligingly hushing during takes, then resuming their chatter-punctuated gawking at the stars. ``In Manhattan, you see it all the time. Not in the Bronx,'' said Max Gottlieb, a jeweler and aspiring screenwriter who had traveled from his Manhattan office to watch. ``Up here, it's a major event.'' ``So far I've seen only Tom Hanks,'' said Elba Vargas, smiling in the sun with her year-old daughter, Christine. ``Also Geraldo,'' she appended, meaning television personality Geraldo Rivera, who had a 12-word part. ``It's pretty good for the Bronx. This area is still in a rebuilding stage and to have something like this here, it's a boost to the economy,'' said Ron Romano, a clerk in the courthouse. ``It's a morale boost, too.'' The economic benefit garnered some debate. The city says feature film producers spend roughly $100,000 per day locally when shooting here, and the ``Bonfire'' filming may take five weeks. But Kavalos, of the Court Deli, noted with resignation that the crew's meals were catered elsewhere. ``Look around. You don't see nobody,'' said one of his waitresses, Chris Ripkin. ``All we get is bathroom customers.'' There was a more serious economic issue, as well. ``It's fantasy land, that's what it is,'' said the Rev. James McClain, who passed by the crowd and kept on his way. ``They spend $30 million or $40 million for a picture, and there's people here who can't afford to feed their children.'' An equally harsh reality showed its face three blocks from the filming: Just before noon the driver of a van fired a gunshot, tried to run over a police officer and then sped off, authorities said. No one was hurt, and the only disruption at the movie site was a single police car that whizzed past with sirens blaring. Said Kavalos: ``We're in a bad neighborhood here.'' That is not the message the leaders of the Bronx wish to send out, and they eyed the movie-making warily. ``They're in here to make money, but I don't think they're in here to take advantage of the people of the Bronx,'' said Clint Roswell, spokesman for Borough President Fernando Ferrer. ``They've certainly expressed a willingness not to do broad smear.'' One sign of good will: Plans to decorate the recently cleaned courthouse with ersatz graffiti were dropped. ``I can definitely confirm that there is no fake graffiti,'' said Rob Harris, spokesman for the distributor, Warner Bros. Harris said little else, averring that Warner had made a ``marketing decision'' not to encourage media coverage of the movie just yet. Still, some potential customers had already made up their minds. ``Am I going to go to the movie? No,'' said Kavalos. ``When they put it on TV, maybe.''

DOC.HEAD: Ag Reports Say Western States Will Have Low Water Supplies
DOC.TEXT: Western states will have low water supplies this summer in many areas, an Agriculture Department report said Monday. ``With snowfall virtually over and snowmelt beginning, it looks like spring and summer streamflows will be below average for most of the West,'' said Wilson Scaling, chief of the department's Soil Conservation Service. ``The wise use of water will be more important than ever.'' Streamflows are forecast to be less than 70 percent of average in California, Nevada, Arizona, most of Oregon, Utah and New Mexico, southern Idaho, southwestern Wyoming and western Colorado. The only western areas where streamflows are expected to be above average are most streams in southern Alaska, the Cache la Poudre River in Colorado, and the headwaters of the Tongue River in Wyoming, and the Kootenai River in Canada and Montana, the report said. Reservoir storage as of March 31 was reported ``near to slightly above average for most of the western states.'' New Mexico was the only one with ``well-above average'' reservoir water supplies. Nevada, Arizona and California were said to be ``well-below average.'' Western states depend on snowmelt for about 75 percent of their water supply.

DOC.HEAD: President Chamorro Faces Sea of Troubles in 1st Days in Office
DOC.TEXT: Diehard Contra rebels, an economy in such poor shape that it is not producing enough food for its people and opposition from the outgoing Sandinistas are among the problems facing Violeta Barrio de Chamorro when she takes office Wednesday. The effort to find solutions in Central America's largest republic is made more difficult because her United National Opposition is a 14-party coalition that spans the political spectrum from communists to conservatives. But Mrs. Chamorro will be taking over following the mandate of free elections on Feb. 25, something rare in this tropical nation of 3.5 million residents. Nicaragua has been ruled by autocratic and oppressive governments much of the time since it gained independence in 1821. ``It's the beginning of democracy in Nicaragua,'' Mrs. Chamorro said when she and Vice President-elect Virgilio Godoy were officially presented with their election certificate Monday by the Supreme Electoral Council. Nevertheless, it will be a tough start for Mrs. Chamorro, 61, a newspaper publisher who has little political and no governmental experience. She has been relying on a team of experienced advisers to develop economic plans and negotiate with fractious Contras and Sandinistas. The Contras are foremost among the problems her administration faces. They have been fighting the Sandinistas for nine years and don't want to demobilize, as they promised to do so by June 10, unless the army is purged of Sandinista officers. Mrs. Chamorro's team has agreed to ``respect the professional status'' of the Sandinista army but forbid its officers to hold any positions in political parties. Some Contras want their officers to replace Sandinista officers, something that could lead to conflict with still-militant Sandinistas. The army is under their political control and many party activists also have modern weapons. Mrs. Chamorro has repeatedly said Nicaragua cannot support a big army anyway _ the economy, hurt over the years by a now-ended U.S. embargo and ineffectual Sandinista policies, is in shambles. Inflation in 1988 hit 33,600 percent until the Sandinistas curbed spending and brought it down last year to 1,800 percent. Even so, the Chamorro administration will have to do a lot of belt-tightening to bring it to acceptable levels. They need to stabilize the currency, attract foreign investment and bring back some of the money people stashed away abroad for safe-keeping. As it is, Nicaragua is saddled with a $7 billion foreign debt it can hardly meet payments on and that will need renegotiating with creditor banks. President Bush has asked for $300 million in immediate aid to help the Chamorro administration through its first months in office, but the U.S. Congress has been moving slowly and, in any case, the amount will not solve all problems. ``We don't have anything, but I have confidence in Nicaraguans and in our friends from the exterior to reconstruct Nicaragua,'' she told journalists Monday. Mrs. Chamorro's financial adviser, Francisco Mayorga, says the new administration will not know until after the inauguration how much cash the Treasury has. Government employees must be paid five days after she takes office. Even the number of government employees is unknown. The Sandinistas haven't been giving out any figures, although outgoing President Daniel Ortega talked in 1989 of having to fire 30,000 government employees as part of his austerity program. For many years, the government rationed gasoline to save on crude oil, which the Sandinistas imported from the Soviet Union via Cuba. Venezuela and Mexico cut off sales about three years ago because Nicaragua was not paying even at below-market rates. Right now, the country has two months' reserves and Cuba is cutting off sales, meaning Mrs. Chamorro's administration will have to buy on the open market. The Sandinistas, who got 40 percent of the vote in the February elections and are still the country's biggest single political party, have been distributing land titles and making other moves to entrench their reforms. UNO has also accused Sandinista sympathizers of stripping government assets, down to the office furniture. But Sandinista policies, including price controls and limited investment, hurt farm and livestock production in this largely agricultural nation, a problem that will become another priority for Mrs. Chamorro's administration. As recently as January, the country had to import rice _ which it used to export _ and received a donated shiploand of beans from Spain, because it did not grow enough of these staples to feed the population.

DOC.HEAD: Showers In Northern California, Thunderstorms In Mississippi Valley
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms were widely scattered over the Mississippi Valley on Monday, and northern California got locally heavy rain. The strongest thunderstorms along the Mississippi Valley were over northern Iowa and southern Minnesota, the National Weather Service said. Showers associated with a cold front moving off the Pacific Ocean produced the rain in northern California. Fresno Calif. got 0.43 of an inch, a record for the day, and Shelter Cove got 1.40 inches during the early morning. Sacramento got a record 0.52 of an inch Sunday. Rain also fell during the day Monday over parts of Washington and Oregon. Elsewhere, a few showers and thunderstorms associated with a cold front were over Florida and showers developed along a cold front from the northern high Plains to the Great Basin making up most of Nevada and western Utah. Ahead of that cold front, temperatures in the upper 80s were reported as far north as North Dakota and Minnesota. On Sunday, Chamberlain and Pickstown, S.D., both reached 94 degrees, tying Presidio, Texas, as the hottest spots in the nation. Late Sunday, thunderstorms produced severe weather from Florida to the southern and central Plains. One person was killed near Biloxi, Miss., when strong thunderstorm wind overturned several boats in the Mississippi Sound, and at least one tornado touched down briefly near Jacksonville, Fla. Sunday evening, hail 2 inches in diameter was reported 15 miles southwest of Roswell, N.M. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 32 at Elkins, W.Va.

DOC.HEAD: Story of 2 Women Illustrates Depth of Cocaine Problem
DOC.TEXT: It's unlikely that Kimberly Hardy, a black welfare mother, and Lynn Bremer, a successful white attorney, would ever have been thrown together if not for one thing they had in common: cocaine addiction. Bremer joined Hardy last week as two of the first women in Michigan to be charged with delivering cocaine to their babies by allegedly using the drug just before giving birth. The cases are drawing renewed attention not only to the practice of prosecuting drug-addicted mothers but also to the misconception that is it primarily the poor, uneducated woman using drugs during pregnancy. ``We're finding that drug addiction during pregnancy is a problem that crosses all income and social levels, particularly when it comes to cocaine,'' said Suzanne Miel-Uken of the Michigan Department of Public Health's office of maternal and child health. A study conducted last year in Pinellas County, Fla., found no substantial difference in the rate of substance abuse between pregnant women undergoing care in public clinics and more affluent women in private care, according to the National Association for Perinatal Addiction and Research and Education. About 14.8 percent of all American babies born last year were exposed to controlled substances before birth, the organization said. There are 30 to 40 similar similar cases pending across the country. ``Think of how many cases of drug-addicted births there must be in Detroit _ all over the state, but women aren't being prosecuted there,'' said attorney Alan Rapoport of the American Civil Liberties Union, who represents Bremer and Hardy. ``The only places where this is happening is the little jerkwater towns where the local prosecutor wants to make headlines.'' On Monday, Muskegon County Circuit Judge R. Max Daniels denied a request by Rapoport to dismiss the cocaine-delivery charge against Hardy. However, the judge did dismiss a less serious charge of second-degree child-abuse, saying there was no evidence Hardy's cocaine use had caused her son's low birthweight and gastrointestinal problems. The cocaine-delivery charges carries a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison; second-degree child abuse is punishable by a maximum of four years in pison. Muskegon County Prosecutor Tony Tague says he is using the threat of prosecution to urge addicted mothers to seek treatment during pregnancy. ``We're trying to send a message _ that if you are a drug-addicted pregnant women and you seek meaningful treatment during your pregnancy, you will not be prosecuted,'' Tague said. He said if Bremer had sought treatment during her pregnancy, which her doctor had recommended, she likely wouldn't be facing charges. Bremer, 36, checked herself into a 30-day drug treatment center April 15, five days after her daughter, Brittany, was born at Hackley Hospital. Tests showed evidence of cocaine in the systems of both mother and daughter. Bremer was charged Thursday but won't be arraigned until she is released from the center. Tague said Bremer, a general practice attorney since 1982, admitted using cocaine throughout her pregnancy up until about 48 hours before delivery. Police say Hardy, 22, admitted using crack cocaine about 13 hours before she gave birth in August. She was charged in October and went into drug treatment, which she has completed. Rapoport and many health-care providers contend Tague's approach will keep drug-addicted pregnant women out of prenatal programs for fear of prosecution. Tague contends that Hardy and Bremer passed cocaine to their babies through the umbilical cord seconds after the infant exited the birth canal and before the cord was cut. Under Michigan law, a woman cannot be charged with injuring or delivering anything to a fetus. Tague has said he wouldn't seek prison time for the women. Conviction on the 20-year felony charge includes one year of mandatory imprisonment, but the statute allows for a departure from the mandatory minimum if the court finds ``substantial and compelling reasons'' to do so. The infants born to Bremer and Hardy appear healthy, but research suggests babies exposed to cocaine while in the womb suffer from a distressing array of brain disorders and medical problems that appear to stunt their development for years, if not permanently. Bremer's daughter is in the custody of the state Department of Social Services and was placed in a foster home Tuesday. Hardy's newborn son and other two children were taken from her and are living with her parents in Mississippi. Both women are single.

DOC.HEAD: Luken Criticizes Bush Commitment to Environment in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: An Ohio congressman said Monday that he's not convinced the Bush administration is putting enough emphasis on environmental protection in Eastern Europe as it rushes to help emerging democracies. ``Over the last few months we have been watching the Iron Curtain rise only to reveal a ruined landscape blanketed in devastating toxic industrial pollution,'' said Rep. Thomas Luken, Democratic chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on transportation and hazardous materials. But, he said, a turf war between the Environmental Protection Agency and the Agency for International Development threatens the U.S. environmental programs in Eastern Europe. ``Movement is afoot to hand over these U.S. environmental programs to the Agency for International Development, even though all the expertise is at EPA,'' Luken said. Timothy Atkeson, who is in charge of international activities at EPA, said environmental experts will be working with Eastern Europeans though they may be private contractors hired through AID. ``The president has asked for flexibility,'' Atkeson said at a hearing of Luken's subcommittee. ``Some programs would be best addressed by the EPA, some by the Department of Energy and some the private sector through AID contracts,'' Atkeson said. He said EPA would be the lead agency. But Luken admonished: ``In the rush to provide ecomomic assistance to these ruined nations, it is imperative that we not commit the very mistakes that their own governments have made since the Second World War by choosing development at the expense of the environment.''

DOC.HEAD: Vandals Cause Two Power Outages in California
With AM-Earth Day-Wall Street
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with group claiming responsibility
DOC.TEXT: Hand-delivered messages claimed responsibility Monday for vandalism that caused two power outages and left about 92,000 people without power for six hours. Residents of Santa Cruz and Watsonville were affected by the outages Sunday and early Monday, caused by damage to Pacific Gas & Electric power poles. The group that claimed responsibility for the two outages called itself Earth Night Action Group and said the target was PG&E, a ``corporate earth rapist.'' A young male caller to The Associated Press telephoned a few minutes after delivery of the message to ask if it had been received. Similar messages went to Bay City News Service and the San Francisco Examiner. The caller refused to give his name or telephone number. Electricity was out for almost two hours late Sunday after utility crews accidentally ignited a small fire while they repaired a high-voltage wooden power pole that apparently had been cut by a chain saw, said PG&E spokesman Ron Rutkowski. The second outage, beginning shortly after 1:30 a.m. Monday, affected the same area and was caused when someone cut all the bolts at the base of a steel tower near Watsonville, the utility company said. Power was restored to all customers by 5:25 a.m. Rutkowski said the incidents were reported to the Santa Cruz Sheriff's Department.

DOC.HEAD: Ruckus Ignites at Riot-Torn Prison
DOC.TEXT: Guards with electronic stun guns quelled a three-hour disturbance Monday by 20 inmates in a state prison unit housing prisoners under investigation for a bloody three-day riot in October. At least one inmate kicked through a cell wall during the three-hour ruckus at the Camp Hill medium-security prison, and about 60 cells were flooded in the restricted cellblock, said prison spokesman John Palakovitch. Two guards and two inmates were injured during the disturbance in the cell block, which holds inmates being investigated for the October riot. That uprising left more than half the prison destroyed and 123 people injured. Inmates repeatedly have threatened to riot again once state police brought in during the October riots are removed from the prison. The state police, who were not used in Monday's incident, are scheduled to leave beginning Tuesday. The ruckus was the worst at the prison since October, and investigations continue into both disturbances. Around 1 a.m., an inmate under investigation for allegedly participating in the October riots removed a porcelain toilet from the wall, smashed it and began throwing pieces at guards, Palakovich said. About 20 inmates began throwing things and turned on water in their cells, flooding about 64 of them. Some soaked their sheets with water and used them to tie their cell doors closed to keep guards out, Palakovich said. Palakovich said there was no security risk because inmates didn't get out of the cells involved. By 4 a.m. guards had handcuffed the prisoners in their cells, and a cell-by-cell search for weapons or contraband was underway, he said.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Requires Warning System On Small Passenger Planes
DOC.TEXT: Turboprop passenger planes will have to have a ground-proximity warning system under federal regulations announced Monday. The Federal Aviation Administration said the rule, which would become final after a period for public comment, follows a study of accidents in which pilots have flown aircraft into the ground with no apparent awareness that they were about to crash. Of 41 such accidents from 1970 to 1988, two-thirds could have been prevented with such a system, the FAA said. The study was conducted by the Transportation Department on a recommendation from the National Transportation Safety Board, which investigates accidents. A ground-proximity warning system sounds an alarm when a plane that is not preparing to land goes below a set altitude. If the aircraft has its flaps and wheels down for landing, the alarm does not sound. The FAA said 695 turboprop aircraft would have to add the system, which has been required on large jetliners since 1974 and on smaller jets since 1978. Warning devices were not previously required for turboprops, the FAA said, because ``it was believed at the time that they had a greater ability to respond quickly in situations where altitude control was inadvertently neglected.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Bill Delaying New Regulation
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed legislation Monday delaying a regulation that could have put many organizations that arrange human organ transplants out of business. The measure delays from April 1, 1990, to Jan. 1, 1992, a performance standard that would have denied Medicare or Medicaid reimbusement to human organ procurement organizations that arrange fewer than 50 donors a year. There are 71 such organizations; more than half procure organs from fewer than 50 donors annually. The Department of Health and Human Services supported the delay. The procurement organizations are expected to press in the interim for a different performance standard.

DOC.HEAD: British Minister Calls Driver Innocent, Cargo Guilty in Seizure
DOC.TEXT: A British truck driver held in Greece on suspicion of importing part of an Iraqi ``super gun'' is innocent, Foreign Office minister William Waldegrave said Monday. But he told Parliament little doubt exists that the 29-ton cargo was intended to be part of a huge weapon that Iraq was reportedly building. Truck driver Paul Ashwell, 25, from Northampton, England, was moved to Greece's top-security Agios Stefanos prison on Monday. He was charged Saturday with ``a distinct instance of transporting a rapid-firing weapon, at the level of criminal charges'' _ an offense carrying a minimum five-year prison term. Customs officials in the port of Patras in western Greece, working with British customs officers, on Friday seized a truck carrying cargo from Sheffield Forgemasters _ a giant cylinder said to be part of a huge gun. ``I don't know a thing ... about war material,'' Ashwell told reporters Saturday. ``I was not obligated to know the nature of my cargo.'' On April 12, Customs officers seized eight sections of steel pipe at a British port after a military expert said it could be used as a gun. The Iraqi government and the maker, Sheffield Forgemasters, said the tubes were intended for a petrochemical plant. British Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley said the government was convinced the tubes were part of a huge gun. Weapons experts say such a gun, with a 131-foot-long barrel, might be able to fire nuclear or chemical weapons long distances or boost rockets into orbit. Ashwell's truck was stopped April 11, but he said he was told it was because of faulty documentation for his cargo. He was allowed to return to London, and was arrested after he returned to Greece. Lawmaker Michael Morris told Waldegrave he believed Ashwell was being made ``a scapegoat fot he whole of this exercise.'' Waldegrave responded: ``Greece is a law-abiding country. ... They do have an offense of importing a gun, and they have to answer to their own courts as to whether he has committed any offense.'' Waldegrave said Britain did not believe Ashwell was guilty of any offense. Michael Cave Ltd., a freight hauling firm, on Monday issued a statement saying the driver and the agents were ``completely innocent victims.'' Turkish police have detained a second truck, with two Hungarian drivers, carrying a 33-foot-long pipe forged by Walter Somers Ltd. of Halesowen, near Birmingham, England. Walter Somers Ltd, acknowledged Friday that it had made the cylinder and said it was commissioned by Iraq. The British freight agent, Davies Turner Ltd., said two trucks carrying steel forging from Walter Somers reached the Iraqi capital on April 9 and 10. In Istanbul, Turkey a customs official confirmed Monday that authorities seized a steel tube believed to belong to a giant Iraqi weapon. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a Hungarian trailer-truck carrying the 33-foot-long steel tube was being kept at the Haydarpasa customs station on the Asian side of Istanbul. He said the truck arrived in Istanbul last Thursday. Finance and Customs Minister Adnan Kahveci was quoted as telling Hurriyet newspaper that ``a massive investigation'' was under way. Turkish dailies on Saturday quoted authorities as saying the confiscated cargo resembled pipes seized in Britain last week.

DOC.HEAD: Flight Diverted After Passengers Wrongly Suspect Hijack Plot
DOC.TEXT: A flight to Baltimore from San Juan, Puerto Rico, was diverted to Miami after passengers wrongly accused a fellow traveler of carrying a gun, an airline official said Monday. Passengers on American Airlines Flight 704 Sunday night told flight attendants that a man was ``acting a little strange,'' and that he had a gun in his briefcase, said Tim Smith, a spokesman at American's Dallas headquarters. ``The flight attendants then alerted the plane's captain, who decided to divert the plane to Miami'' shortly before 9 p.m., Smith said. ``The man was met by Dade County authorities who searched him and his baggage and found nothing.'' The man, who was not identified, spent the night in Miami and was rescheduled onto a flight to Baltimore Monday morning, Smith said. The airplane refueled during a 30-minute stop in Miami, then continued on to Baltimore's Washington International Airport, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Gets Life For 1957 Killing of Cousin
DOC.TEXT: A man found guilty of murder more than 32 years after his young cousin was found sodomized and strangled was sentenced Monday to life in prison. Albany County Court Judge Thomas Keegan handed down the maximum sentence possible against Richard Ruff, 53, who was convicted March 23 of strangling 11-year-old William Ruff Jr. The boy was killed on Aug. 31, 1957. His body was found the next day, hanging by a clothesline from a tree in a wooded area near his home in the Albany suburb of Colonie. In convicting Ruff of first-degree felony murder, the jury found that he had killed his cousin in the commission or the attempted commission of sodomy. His sentence carries no minimum term, based on 1957 state law. The case marked the longest homicide investigation in state history, prosecutors said. Ruff, reserved and dressed in prison greens, maintained his innocence Monday morning. ``I just never sodomized nobody. I never killed anybody,'' Ruff said. ``... And that's the truth.'' But Keegan told him: ``Here we had a young boy who trusted his family members. ... (Billy) was used for your own self-serving purposes.'' Keegan ordered the sentence to run consecutively with a 4- to 12-year term Ruff is serving for sexually abusing two young girls, daughters of a woman with whom he lived in Rensselaer County. The judge denied a motion by Public Defender Joseph McCoy to dismiss the conviction on the grounds of insufficient evidence. McCoy said his office would appeal. Billy's mother, Mildred Ruff, watched the sentencing then told reporters in a choked voice: ``We're relieved that it's all over.'' ``May God have mercy on his soul,'' she said of Ruff. Ruff was not considered a suspect in the killing until two years ago. In 1988, Christopher Ruff, a brother of the victim who is now an Albany County sheriff's deputy, noticed a police bulletin indicating that Richard Ruff was wanted in connection with the child sex-abuse case in Rensselaer County. Police found Ruff in Florida and questioned him on both cases. He was returned to Albany to stand trial, in the Rensselaer case first. Dwyer based much of his case on statements Ruff made to police in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Agency Denounces Publication of Names of Agents in Mexico
DOC.TEXT: The Drug Enforcement Administration said Monday that the publication of the names of 49 DEA agents in Mexico by a Mexican news magazine was an ``irresponsible act'' that could put them in danger. The DEA said in a statement that the agency is ``open about our presence'' in 46 countries but ``we do not publish the names or location of our personnel for obvious security reasons.'' ``Publication of the names of DEA special agents and others ... by Proceso was an irresponsible act that could potentially threaten the safety of these people,'' DEA said. DEA spokesman Conn Dougherty said ``the motivation behind this is still a mystery to us.'' ``We don't think it's any sort of retaliation at all'' for the arrest by DEA agents of a Guadalajara gynecologist on charges of participating in the 1985 murder of DEA agent Enrique Camarena, Dougherty said. Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain was taken by plane to El Paso, Texas, where he was arrested by DEA agents. An attorney for Alvarez contends the doctor was abducted and taken to the border. That arrest earlier this month sparked a diplomatic protest from Mexico, which demanded a full explanation from the U.S. government. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said a preliminary report of the arrest by DEA indicates that no U.S. agents were present when Alvarez was captured and flown to El Paso. Dougherty said he was unaware of any special security precautions that the DEA agents in Mexico were taking as a result of the publication of their names. ``We're very careful that our people in all the countries exercise proper precautions especially in countries where there may have been any kind of disturbance or incident in the past,'' Dougherty said.

DOC.HEAD: Albania to Allow Emigration of Six Siblings in Italian Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Albanian authorities said Monday they will allow the emigration of six siblings in Albania's capital of Tirana who have been living as refugees in the Italian embassy for more than four years. The Popaj family members, two brothers and four sisters aged 52 to 65, walked into Italia's embassy on Dec. 12, 1985, and demanded asylum. They told diplomats they had been confined almost 20 years to Kules, a village west of Tirana, because a brother had defected to the West. It was the first known case of Albanians seeking shelter in a Western embassy in Tirana. The Albanian state ATA news agency Monday quoted a Foreign Ministry spokesman who said ``the Italian Embassy is informed ... that if the Popaj brothers wish they are free to go abroad, being equipped with Albanian passports and exit visas.'' The statement added that the family could leave Albania, a hard-line Stalinist regime that in recent months seems to be loosening some of its controls, in one or two days after they make a formal request to emigrate. It was unclear why the Albanian statement referred to the six as brothers and there was no information on the condition of the six. ``This humanitarian solution ... serves also the promotion of the spirit of friendship existing in Albanian-Italian relations,'' ATA reported. In reaction, an Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman said: ``There is a readiness and will on the part of Albania, just as there is a readiness and will on our part, for a solution.'' Italian lawmakers have repeatedly asked Albania to permit the emigration of the siblings.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Say Ethiopian Air Raid Killed 50 Civilians, Wounded 110
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian warplanes dropped cluster bombs on the guerrilla-held Red Sea port of Massawa, killing 50 civilians and wounding 110, the rebels said Monday. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front said the death toll from Sunday's air attack was expected to rise as many of the wounded were in ``very bad condition,'' according to a clandestine radio report monitored in the Kenyan capital Nairobi. The radio said 50 homes were destroyed when the warplanes made two bombing runs on Massawa, one in the mid-morning and one in the early evening. The rebel-operated Voice of the Broad Masses of Eritrea reported no further details of the air strikes, the latest since secessionist guerrillas captured the important port from government forces in February. There was no reaction from the Ethiopian government, which rarely comments on rebel claims. The report on the air raids could not be independently verified because observers are banned from areas of conflict. Massawa is one of two strategic harbors that have traditionally handled most of Ethiopia's trade and international relief supplies for millions of people threatened with starvation in the face of war and drought. The Eritrean Front has been fighting for control of Ethiopia's northernmost province since 1961, a year after the former Italian colony of Eritrea lost its autonomy and was forcibly annexed by the late Emperor Haile Selassie. Rebels hold other towns and villages in Eritrea and, with backing from other guerrilla armies, are seeking to overthrow the Marxist regime of President Mengistu Haile Mariam. The rebel radio has reported several previous raids by warplanes dropping cluster bombs and napalm on civilians. The reports have been denied by Addis Ababa. Israel has been accused of supplying the cluster bombs, which contain dozens of smaller grenade-like bomblets that hurl shrapnel over wide areas. Both Israel and Ethiopia have denied these claims.
