DOC.HEAD: Citizens Panel Finds Adult Video Offensive
DOC.TEXT: A panel of residents decided the X-rated movie ``Amber Pays the Rent'' violates community standards, clearing the way for the removal of all adult videos from a store, city officials announced Monday. More than two-thirds of the 45-member panel said the video appealed to prurient interests, and nearly that number said it offended their personal standards. The movie depicts the lives of several female roommates who pay their bills by way of sexual favors. ``I think the result is clear,'' said Stephen Klein, a city attorney for the western Ohio community of 20,000 about 30 miles north of Dayton. ``The marketplace has spoken,'' he said. Neither owner John Rimkus of Home Video Ventures or his attorney, Louis Sirkin, immediately responded to calls seeking comment. Klein said he planned to inform Sirkin of the results and expects all of the adult videos to be removed from the store within about two weeks. The panel was approved last October as attorneys prepared for a court fight over adult videos available at the store. Klein said the owner agreed to remove all adult tapes if the vote went against the film, although the ruling was not binding to Showcase Video, another store renting adult videos. ``These results are clear enough that the city will not hesitate to proceed in court with this as evidence and attempt to have the community standards imposed legally on the other store,'' he said. ``We now have the ammunition.'' Klein said communities can set their own standards on obscenity based on a 1973 U.S. Supreme Court ruling in a California case that established the criteria. He said the test included whether the average person finds that the material appeals to prurient interests. The panel, chosen on the basis of age, race, education, income and religion was designed to represent the makeup of Piqua. Panel members watched the 80-minute video in individual viewings last week and then answered two questions. Asked if they thought the film appealed to a morbid, shameful or unhealthy interest in sex, 66.7 percent said yes and 31.1 percent said no. Asked if it offended their personal standards, 64.4 said yes and 33.3 percent said no. The remainder said they didn't know or were undecided. Male and female panelists differed in their opinions. Eighty percent of women and 50 percent of men said the film appealed to prurient interests. Forty percent of men said the film offended their personal standards, compared with 84 percent of women. Said panelist Eric Fries, 27: ``As far as a porno flick goes, it was fairly obscene.''

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Wakes Up to World of Impending Shortages
An AP Extra
DOC.BYLINE: With AM-Lithuania, Bjt ^By MARK J. PORUBCANSKY
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanians woke Monday to a world of impending shortages, and while the Soviet economic embargo hadn't taken full effect yet, life wasn't exactly proceeding normally either. Vilnius enjoyed another sunny spring day, and tulips were beginning to bloom in carefully tended public gardens throughout the Lithuanian capital. Outwardly, the city seemed to be shrugging off the threat of a cut of most supplies from Moscow. But some bus routes were canceled to save fuel, consumers were lining up for many goods and there was talk of opening ``embargo funds'' for gasoline coupons to get the embattled Baltic republic through what most expect will be a difficult period. ``Whether it's necessary or not, people are lining up to buy it,'' said a saleswoman taking a break in the bright sun outside the city's modern new department store. ``It's for everything. It doesn't matter what it is.'' Inside, there were especially long lines to get into the department selling fabric, blankets and pillows. Long lines also were reported in some city food stores. The threat of a cutoff of all shipments from the Soviet Union has made people of this independence-minded republic realize they have few raw materials and depend on shipments from elsewhere to provide the materials to run their factories, said the saleswoman, an ethnic Pole who declined to give her name. While people were not buying out of panic, they clearly were stocking up just in case, she said. Officials of the Sajudis political movement were collecting money for an embargo fund. At the end of a two-day congress on Sunday, the organization collected $9,230 in rubles from its members. An official said an elderly woman also had pledged the $6,480 in rubles she received from the Soviet government in compensation for being wrongly sent to Siberia years earlier. There also was a proposal to begin collecting items of gold that Lithuanians wanted to contribute to sell abroad and earn foreign currency, she said, but that idea was on hold because there was no safe place to store it. Some bus routes into downtown were canceled. Residents of the Virsuliskis district outside Vilnius were forced to find another way to get to work Monday morning. All along the route of Bus 11 through downtown, handwritten notes were pasted telling riders the route temporarily was out of operation. It normally runs at intervals of 10-20 minutes from about 6 a.m. to midnight. Taxis, hit by the government's strict limit of about 7 gallons of gas per car per month, were difficult to find. But the city's extensive system of trolleybuses continued to operate on schedule. Alla Gecauniene, a middle-aged railroad worker selling her daffodils and carnations on a street corner for extra money, said residents of her village of Lentvis 11 miles from Vilnius were having a hard time getting into the capital. Instead of a bus every hour on Sunday, there was only one bus to the capital and one back, she said. The Russians, Poles and Lithuanians living in her village of about 4,000 were still getting along, and there were no plans so far to shut down the main industry, a sewing factory, she said. Despite the heightened political tension, the ethnic Lithuanian woman said she really didn't know what all the fuss was about. Whatever government is running the republic must fill the store shelves better, she said. ``We produce stockings in Lithuania, soap and shampoo,'' she said. ``Where are they?'' ``I'm not involved in politics,'' she added. ``I just want full stores so I can buy what I want.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Challengers Press For End to Incumbents' Advantages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf: ``The coalition's,'' to identify Kunst
DOC.TEXT: A bipartisan band of past and current congressional challengers called Monday for a political housecleaning to end the ``imperial, permanent Congress.'' ``Our federally elected officials have so rigged the process that they are impossible to unseat,'' said Harold Coker, a Chattanooga, Tenn., Republican who ran unsuccessfully for Congress in 1988. His complaint was the central theme at a meeting of the Coalition to End the Permanent Congress, a grassroots organization formed in protest of the 1988 elections, in which 98.5 percent of House incumbents seeking re-election were successful. Coker was one of about three dozen congressional candidates, some seeking office this year and others having lost earlier contests, to attend the meeting. The coalition members, representing at least 18 states, advocated a lengthy list of reform proposals. Among them were a ban on taxpayer-paid mass mailings by members of Congress; prohibiting lawmakers from accepting honoraria or speaking fees; eliminating political action committees, which contribute mostly to campaigns of incumbents; and imposing a 12-year limit on how long members can serve in the House and the Senate. The coalition's assault on incumbency came as the Senate prepared to consider legislation to overhaul the system of financing congressional campaigns. Lionel Kunst, a Kansas Democrat who helped found the coalition, rejected the legislation as ``pablum'' and said it would do little for challengers. The coalition did approve of one proposal that could surface in the Senate debate, however. Group members embraced the idea of providing free television time to incumbents and challengers. A Senate leadership task force has suggested giving political parties free TV time to divide among candidates. Although the desire to win election to Congress brought the group together, its members maintained they had a much loftier goal of reviving government. ``I'm here because Congress is not doing the job. They're not solving the problems of America,'' complained Coker. Bernard Tomkin, an Elkins Park, Pa., Democrat who is running again after a loss in 1988, put it this way: ``Unless we find a way to clean up and ventilate our political process, then we are letting our future generation down.''

DOC.HEAD: Funeral for Civil Rights Leader Ralph Abernathy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with funeral procession. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Among those...' DELETES first reference to Jackson in 8th graf pvs to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX12
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy was carried to his crypt Monday on a wave of praise, riding in a plain mule-drawn wooden wagon flanked by his sons and colleagues in the civil rights movement. The procession followed a service at which civil rights leaders who criticized Abernathy for his controversial account of Martin Luther King Jr. got a public rebuke. The famous and the humble piled shoulder-to-shoulder inside a southwest Atlanta church for the four-hour service for the man who was King's longtime chief lieutenant in the civil rights movement. Afterward, two mules, pulling a green wooden wagon bearing Abernathy's casket, set out from West Hunter Street Baptist Church, where Abernathy was pastor, for Lincoln Cemetery. King's body was carried to its resting place by a mule-drawn wagon after he was assassinated in 1968 at the suggestion of Abernathy, who considered it symbolic of humility. Relatives said Abernathy wanted the same for himself. Abernathy's bier traveled in a two-hour procession of 22 limousines that passed dilapidated buildings and drug-nfested communities along the street named in honor of King. Groups of people, some with children and pets, lined sidewalks as the wagon inched along in a sea of 150 suited marchers, including Abernathy's sons, Kwame and state Rep. Ralph David Abernathy III, and movement associates Andrew Young and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Among those speaking at the funeral was Georgia state Rep. Tyrone Brooks, who said said the civil rights movement should be proud instead of embarrassed by Abernathy's book, ``The Walls Came Tumbling Down.'' The autobiography, published last year, touched on King's alleged extramarital affairs. Brooks, who was a student activist in the 1960s, stood in the pulpit above Abernathy's rose-covered coffin and waved a copy of the book. He urged the crowd of 2,500 to read it. ``It was not a mistake,'' Brooks said. ``It is the truth. All 636 pages.'' Among those present were King's widow, Coretta Scott King, and three of her children; King's sister, Christine King Farris; Benjamin Hooks, head of the NAACP; U.S. Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga.; Robert Kennedy Jr.; Archbishop Eugene Marino; and Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. Abernathy, who was King's closest friend and adviser, died April 17 of a heart attack induced by a blood clot. He was 64. Jackson said Abernathy's accomplishments through the civil rights movement far outshadow any disagreement brought by his memoirs. ``One cannot judge a player by one exceptional play,'' Jackson said. ``Nor can a player be judged by an error. Ralph Abernathy is in the hall of fame. We must pay homage and thanks.'' Hugh Gloster, president emeritus of Morehouse College, King's alma mater, described Abernathy as ``second only to Martin Luther King as a leader in the civil rights movement.'' ``You have had your share of abuse and scorn,'' Gloster said. Abernathy's son, Ralph David Abernathy III, compared his father to the biblical hero David, saying he slew ``the Goliath of racism'' and served as a stellar role model. ``I am the son of a giant slayer,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Issues Restraining Order Against Religious Group
DOC.TEXT: A state judge Monday ordered a religious group to stop building fallout shelters near Yellowstone National Park after thousands of gallons of fuel leaked from underground storage tanks. The order came on the day that began what the church's spiritual leader says is a 12-year ``dark cycle'' of global danger and catastrophe, from which the shelters are to protect 750 followers. The state requested the temporary restraining order in a petition filed Friday. It bars the Church Universal and Triumphant from continuing construction on the shelter complex near Corwin Springs, where church headquarters are located. District Judge Byron Robb said he signed the order in chambers Monday and scheduled a May 3 hearing on a permanent injunction requested by the state. An estimated 31,000 gallons of diesel fuel and gasoline leaked recently from three underground storage tanks at the shelter complex. Officials of the state Department of Health and Environmental Sciences want work to stop pending an environmental review. The complex is surrounded by at least 35 underground tanks that can hold 634,500 gallons of diesel, gasoline, heating oil and antifreeze. Church spiritual leader Elizabeth Clare Prophet has prophesied that planetary karma _ ``the cumulative weight of mankind's sins'' _ has been building for 25,800 years and would fully descend on Earth as of Monday to begin a ``dark cycle'' of danger that will last 12 years. In the past, Prophet said, cataclysm occurred when enough bad karma accumulated. She said she remembers in a previous life the continent of Lemuria ``breaking up in flames'' and sinking beneath the Pacific Ocean. This time, she said, the bad karma could manifest itself in economic collapse, nuclear war or accident, plague or massive earthquakes.

DOC.SECOND: Former Hostage Is Reported Tired, Malnourished after Long
DOC.TEXT: Captivity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with later information on condition, quotes, U.S. statements, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WIES3,5,7, MDT4
DOC.TEXT: Former hostage Robert Polhill is alert but tired and malnourished after 1,182 days in captivity in Lebanon, doctors said after examining the American educator Monday in West Germany. Polhill, 55, released Sunday in Beirut, was hungry when he arrived at the hospital early Monday. He savored some scrambled eggs and bacon and later enjoyed an afternoon nap of his first day of freedom. Pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem extremists had held him since Jan. 24, 1987. He was the first U.S. hostage to be released in Lebanon in nearly 3{ years. President Bush thanked Iran and Syria for their help in securing Polhill's release. Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati called for a swift reciprocal move _ freedom for a Shiite cleric kidnapped by Israeli troops in July. Velayati also said a second U.S. hostage may be released in the near future. But the Bush administration repeated it would not bargain for freedom. While President Bush searched for ``opportunities for further releases'' of American hostages with phone calls to President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and King Hussein of Jordan, U.S. officials said no rewards, diplomatic or otherwise, would be made for granting freedom to one American while seven remain captive. ``Our hostages should be released unconditionally, safely and immediately, and this barbaric practice should end,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said. Velayati said in an interview with Cable News Network, ``According to the latest information that we have received from Lebanon, maybe after a few days another hostage will be released.'' He did not specify the hostage's nationality. Hussein Musawi, a leading pro-Iranian Shiite cleric, also said one of the 17 remaining Western hostages may be freed soon. Musawi is thought to have influence over Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, the group that held Polhill. Polhill, of New York, an assistant professor of business studies at Beirut University College, was kidnapped from the campus on Jan. 24, 1987, by gunmen posing as policemen. Alann Steen, 51, of Boston, a communications instructor, and Jesse Turner, 42, of Boise, Idaho, a professor of mathematics and computer science, were kidnapped with him and remain hostages. In Tehran, Iran's state radio also said Polhill's release may be a prelude to the release of other hostages. It said Washington and other Western governments ``must show goodwill.'' U.S. officials said they had no information of another pending release. Polhill first went to Syria, where his Lebanese wife, Feryal, met him. They then were flown in a U.S. C-141 military transport plane to West Germany. ``Welcome home, pray for the others,'' read a banner that greeted Polhill in Wiesbaden, a traditional stop for newly freed U.S. hostages before going home. Military spokesman Cmdr. John Woodhouse said Polhill's stay at the U.S. Air Force hospital could last ``a couple of days to a few weeks.'' Polhill would decide. U.S. officials told reporters Polhill spoke on the phone to Bush and Baker. ``We're not aware of any message for Bush,'' one official said. When the kidnappers announced an imminent release last week, they said the freed captive would carry a message for Bush. A statement released after Polhill spent two hours in the hospital said, ``He is alert, stable, ambulatory and somewhat tired. Although he appears to be in relatively good shape, he is malnourished and mildly dehydrated.'' The statement said doctors also would evaluate Polhill's diabetes, a condition he has had for 25 years. The freed hostage is staying in VIP quarters, in a suite with hotel-like accommodations. Polhill walked unaided into the hospital. Two airmen had steadied him as he got off the plane and boarded a helicopter. He clutched a gift football under his arm as he walked slowly down the plane's stairs, greeted by cheers and applause from about 100 people. He wore an Air Force squadron cap and a poncho to protect him from a steady rain. Polhill's two sons, Stephen, 26, and Brian, 23, were expected to arrive Tuesday from the United States. The U.S. officials said Polhill was kept in the same building as Turner and Steen, but ``he probably doesn't know about Terry Anderson or Terry Waite.'' Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held Western hostage. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Most of the others have been missing at least three years. Waite, 50, British envoy of the Anglican Church, disappeared in Lebanon on Jan. 20, 1987, while trying to negotiate the release of Western hostages. The last U.S. hostage to be freed was David Jacobsen, former director of the American University Hospital in Beirut. He was kidnapped May 28, 1985, and released Nov. 2, 1986. He was held by another Shiite faction, Islamic Jihad, or Holy War. Velayati said in New York that Iran and the Shiite movements in Lebanon wanted a prompt reciprocal gesture: the release of Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, a Lebanese Shiite clergyman abducted by Israeli soldiers in July. On Monday, Israel welcomed Polhill's release but made no mention of releasing Obeid. Bush said, ``I want all of those hostages out _ we're not going to trade.'' He thanked Iran and Syria for efforts leading to Polhill's freedom. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the United States made no concessions to Polhill's abductors. On Monday, the Tehran Times, a paper close to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, called for release of another U.S. hostage. Musawi told the Communist-run Voice of the People radio in Lebanon: ``The possibility of another release is in the cards, but I don't know when, how or for what.'' The cleric heads Islamic Amal, a faction within Hezbollah, or Party of God, believed to be an umbrella for groups holding most of the remaining Western hostages. The last Westerns abducted in a group that includes Britons, an Italian and West Germans, were two Swiss Red Cross workers, taken Oct. 16. Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi called Sunday for releasing all hostages in an appeal to Moslems around the world, the official Libyan news agency JANA said in a dispatch. Polhill told a Syrian TV interviewer he played cards with other hostages during his captivity and tried to keep his mind off the possibility of freedom. Before leaving for West Germany, Polhill said his joy was tempered by the knowledge that seven Americans were still held. He said he ``was angry at what was being done to me, being taken away from my wife and family,'' and that during his long confinement he ``strived to continue being angry, knowing at all times that if I began to lose that anger I'd just sort of become a vegetable.'' The government-run Syrian Arab News Agency reported from Damascus that Bush, Baker and Senate Minority Leader Robert Dole, R-Kansas, telephoned to thank Syrian leaders for their help in gaining Polhill's freedom. ``President Bush said nothing would have been accomplished without Syria,'' it added.

DOC.HEAD: Networks To Cover Shuttle Launch Live Unless It's Delayed
With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Coverage of the Atlantis shuttle blastoff will be aired live on the three broadcast networks and Cable News Network, if the shuttle gets off on time. The shuttle is scheduled to be launched Tuesday from Cape Canaveral in Florida at 8:31 a.m. EDT. CBS, NBC and ABC said they will cover the launch live during their regular morning programs: ``CBS This Morning,'' ``Today,'' and ``Good Morning America.'' If the shuttle doesn't go up until after 9 a.m., ABC will follow it with a special news report. NBC spokesman Marc Bien said, ``it depends on the time frame,'' and CBS said it may be seen live on the West Coast but not in the Midwest or East. CBS does not plan to break into regular programming. CNN spokeswoman Kathleen Hobson said CNN will cover it whenever it goes up.

DOC.HEAD: Loyalist Troops Reportedly Thwart Coup Attempt in Sudan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Sudan's military ruler said loyalist forces thwarted a coup attempt by army officers Monday, arrested those involved and quickly restored peace to this East African nation. Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, the country's military leader, said the coup attempt was led by active and retired military officers. It was the second reported attempt in a month to overthrow the ruling junta. ``All those involved in the attempt have been arrested,'' el-Bashir said in a speech broadcast at midday over official Radio Omduran. A government spokesman said most of the rebels surrendered without a fight and there were no casualties. Sources in Khartoum said one soldier was slightly wounded in a brief shootout. El-Bashir said the coup was easily suppressed because the coup's plotters had been under surveillance by authorities from the start of the takeover attempt. Informed sources in the capital, Khartoum, said the army appeared to have had little trouble putting down a series of attacks by junior army officers. Government spokesman Mohammed Khogali Salihein said authorities had previously arrested 30 officers involved in a March coup attempt and later received information that a second group of officers were planning Monday's coup. He said the government ``took measures to prevent the move from the start'' and was able to convince the rebels to surrender without a fight. ``There was no fighting and consequently no casualties,'' Salihein said. He said the coup's two leaders, retired Maj. Gen Abdul-Kadir al-Kadaru and retired Brig. Mohammed Osman Hamid Karrar, gave themselves up after they were assured they would stand a fair trial. El-Bashir said the abortive coup was plotted by ``the alliance in coalition with the outlaws.'' He did not elaborate. ``The alliance'' was possibly a reference to political parties disbanded by el-Bashir after his junta took control of the country on June 30. The government has often used the term ``outlaws'' to refer to the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army, which has been waging a seven-year insurgency seeking autonomy and greater economic reforms for the country's three southern provinces. Sudanese sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the attempted coup began at midnight and the rebels tried to take over Khartoum airport and the official government radio. They were quickly overcome. ``They tried to take over the airport and the radio in a rather pathetic way and were very unsuccessful,'' one source said. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said several rebel officers also tried to shoot their way into the downtown headquarters of the armed forces general command, apparently in search of el-Bashir. They were unable to get through the front gate. One guard at the general command was reportedly wounded in the hand, sources said. Khartoum airport was closed briefly and telecommunications were cut for several hours. By midmorning, Khartoum was peaceful. In the capital, troops supported by tanks guarded bridges and the military's general command. The army was reportedly on full alert, but there seemed to be no special security precautions on the streets of the Khartoum. El-Bashir came to power in June after he overthrew Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi's civilian government. El-Bashir has said his principal aims are to end the rebel insurgency in the south and improve the country's faltering economy. He has had little success.

DOC.HEAD: Amtrak Train Derails in Southeast Iowa; At Least 84 Hurt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with hospitals reporting at least 83 injured; 19 cars on train sted 15; officials saying seven derailed sted nine; train was running late; more quotes; other details.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto OTM1
DOC.TEXT: A 19-car Amtrak passenger train derailed Monday, injuring at least 83 of the 400 people aboard, authorities said. Seven cars of the eastbound California Zephyr derailed about 1:25 p.m. on Burlington Northern tracks, authorities said. Eyewitnesses counted as many as nine cars off the track. ``It made a hell of a noise and then all kind of dust started flying,'' said Robert Franklin of Batavia. ``It was just one big, loud bang. Kind of like a clankety, clang,'' said his wife, Patricia. The train was carrying 394 passengers and about 20 crew members, said Debbie Hare, an Amtrak spokeswoman in Chicago. Area hospitals reported receiving at least 83 people from the accident, 10 of whom were hurt seriously enough to be admitted. Iowa State Patrol Lt. Ronald Moon said there were no known deaths. The cars began to run off the track just before it reached a crossing on the southern edge of this town of 525 residents, 90 miles southeast of Des Moines. Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board and Burlington Northern were dispatched to the scene. The train had 12 passenger cars, four baggage cars and three locomotives, said Sue Martin, an Amtrak spokeswoman in Washington. Marci Larson, another Amtrak spokeswoman in Washington, said the last seven cars derailed: three remained upright, three were left leaning and one, a sleeper car, was turned on its side. Amtrak officials said they did not know how fast the train was traveling when the cars left the tracks and that the train's ``black box'' would have to be examined. The train is authorized to travel as fast as 79 mph in the area, they said. Among the passengers was Wisconsin State Rep. Marlin Schneider, who was returning from the National Conference of State Legislatures in Boise, Idaho, and suffered a bruise to his leg. ``We were having lunch and suddenly the train came apart,'' said Schneider, who was traveling with his two young daughters. ``It started to buckle. Cars are off the tracks everywhere. ... We didn't get hurt very badly but a number of people did.'' Schneider said it was fortunate he and his daughters were in the dining car and not in their sleeping car, which tipped over. Uninjured passengers were taken to a community center about two blocks away from the crash. ``The train just started shaking,'' Jasonna Gibson of Schenectady, N.Y. said. She said she was holding her baby, Tamu, when the train derailed. ``The baby fell. I tried to get him and a lady fell on me,'' Ms. Gibson said. Paula Stater, whose lives about a quarter mile from where the train derailed, said she saw it topple from the tracks. ``It just went over,'' she said. ``It just made a sound, like metal grating metal. It was really unusual, like a bunch of wheels hitting.'' Paul Tray, 29, of Batavia, said workers were using a ladder to climb down into the tipped-over cars, searching for people who might be in the wreckage. Ms. Martin said the train had been running two hours late because the Oakland section had to detour between Oakland and Sacrameto due to a gasoline spill on or near the tracks. Amtrak was busing passengers to Chicago to continue their trip. Sections of the California Zephyr originate in Seattle, Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif., and are linked in Salt Lake City for the trip to Chicago, Hare said. On Oct. 12, 1987, two locomotives and 11 of 14 passenger cars of the California Zephyr collided with maintenance equipment on a side track near the town of Russell, injuring 122 people. That crash was 55 miles west of Monday's derailment. Also Monday, crews in western Pennsylvania skimmed crude oil from the surface of a creek that was fouled when a freight train derailed and caught fire. Twenty-nine cars in a 97-car Buffalo and Pittsburgh Railroad Inc. train derailed in Craigsville, Pa., on Sunday night. No serious injuries were reported in the ensuing explosion and fire.

Iran said was reported to have helped, and Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati called for a swift reciprocal move _ freedom for a Shiite cleric kidnapped by Israeli troops in July. Velayati also said a second U.S. hostage may be released in the near future. But the Bush administration repeated it would not bargain for freedom. While President Bush searched for ``opportunities for further releases'' of American hostages with phone calls to President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and King Hussein of Jordan, U.S. officials said no rewards, diplomatic or otherwise, would be made for granting freedom to one American while seven remain captive. ``Our hostages should be released unconditionally, safely and immediately, and this barbaric practice should end,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said. Velayati said in an interview with Cable News Network, ``According to the latest information that we have received from Lebanon, maybe after a few days another hostage will be released.'' He did not specify the hostage's nationality. Hussein Musawi, a leading pro-Iranian Shiite cleric, also said one of the 17 remaining Western hostages may be freed soon. Musawi is thought to have influence over Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, the group that held Polhill. Polhill, of New York, an assistant professor of business studies at Beirut University College, was kidnapped from the campus on Jan. 24, 1987, by gunmen posing as policemen. Alann Steen, 51, of Boston, a communications instructor, and Jesse Turner, 42, of Boise, Idaho, a professor of mathematics and computer science, were kidnapped with him and remain hostages. In Tehran, Iran's state radio also said Polhill's release may be a prelude to the release of other hostages. It said Washington and other Western governments ``must show goodwill.'' U.S. officials said they had no information of another pending release. Polhill first went to Syria, where his Lebanese wife, Feryal, met him. They then were flown in a U.S. C-141 military transport plane to West Germany. ``Welcome home, pray for the others,'' read a banner that greeted Polhill in Wiesbaden, a traditional stop for newly freed U.S. hostages before going home. Military spokesman Cmdr. John Woodhouse said Polhill's stay at the U.S. Air Force hospital could last ``a couple of days to a few weeks.'' Polhill would decide. U.S. officials told reporters Polhill spoke on the phone to Bush and Baker. ``We're not aware of any message for Bush,'' one official said. When the kidnappers announced an imminent release last week, they said the freed captive would carry a message for Bush. A statement released after Polhill spent two hours in the hospital said, ``He is alert, stable, ambulatory and somewhat tired. Although he appears to be in relatively good shape, he is malnourished and mildly dehydrated.'' The statement said doctors also would evaluate Polhill's diabetes, a condition he has had for 25 years. The freed hostage is staying in VIP quarters, in a suite with hotel-like accommodations. Polhill walked unaided into the hospital. Two airmen had steadied him as he got off the plane and boarded a helicopter. He clutched a gift football under his arm as he walked slowly down the plane's stairs, greeted by cheers and applause from about 100 people. He wore an Air Force squadron cap and a poncho to protect him from a steady rain. Polhill's two sons, Stephen, 26, and Brian, 23, were expected to arrive Tuesday from the United States. The U.S. officials said Polhill was kept in the same building as Turner and Steen, but ``he probably doesn't know about Terry Anderson or Terry Waite.'' Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held Western hostage. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Most of the others have been missing at least three years. Waite, 50, British envoy of the Anglican Church, disappeared in Lebanon on Jan. 20, 1987, while trying to negotiate the release of Western hostages. The last U.S. hostage to be freed was David Jacobsen, former director of the American University Hospital in Beirut. He was kidnapped May 28, 1985, and released Nov. 2, 1986. He was held by another Shiite faction, Islamic Jihad, or Holy War. Velayati said in New York that Iran and the Shiite movements in Lebanon wanted a prompt reciprocal gesture: the release of Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, a Lebanese Shiite clergyman abducted by Israeli soldiers in July. On Monday, Israel welcomed Polhill's release but made no mention of releasing Obeid. Bush said, ``I want all of those hostages out _ we're not going to trade.'' He thanked Syria for efforts leading to Polhill's freedom. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the United States made no concessions to Polhill's abductors. On Monday, the Tehran Times, a paper close to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, called for release of another U.S. hostage. Musawi told the Communist-run Voice of the People radio in Lebanon: ``The possibility of another release is in the cards, but I don't know when, how or for what.'' The cleric heads Islamic Amal, a faction within Hezbollah, or Party of God, believed to be an umbrella for groups holding most of the remaining Western hostages. The last Westerns abducted in a group that includes Britons, an Italian and West Germans, were two Swiss Red Cross workers, taken Oct. 16. Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi called Sunday for releasing all hostages in an appeal to Moslems around the world, the official Libyan news agency JANA said in a dispatch. Polhill told a Syrian TV interviewer he played cards with other hostages during his captivity and tried to keep his mind off the possibility of freedom. Before leaving for West Germany, Polhill said his joy was tempered by the knowledge that seven Americans were still held. He said he ``was angry at what was being done to me, being taken away from my wife and family,'' and that during his long confinement he ``strived to continue being angry, knowing at all times that if I began to lose that anger I'd just sort of become a vegetable.'' The government-run Syrian Arab News Agency reported from Damascus that Bush, Baker and Senate Minority Leader Robert Dole, R-Kansas, telephoned to thank Syrian leaders for their help in gaining Polhill's freedom. ``President Bush said nothing would have been accomplished without Syria,'' it added.

DOC.HEAD: More Testimony About Paintings Bought by Adnan Khashoggi
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Christian Rene ...,' with three grafs to UPDATE with afternoon testimony that Khashoggi paid above market value for paintings; pickup 6th graf pvs. `Testifying through...
DOC.TEXT: A French police official on Monday identified 26 paintings that had been seized in France as works purchased by Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi from former Philippines first lady Imelda Marcos. Prosecutors claim the paintings, as well as four Manhattan buildings, were bought by Mrs. Marcos and her late husband, Ferdinand E., with funds allegedly embezzled from their homeland's treasury. Khashoggi, a co-defendant, is accused of forging documents to help the Marcoses conceal their ownership of the paintings and real estate in violation of a U.S. court order freezing any transactions involving Marcos-owned properties. But Khashoggi's attorneys say his dealings with the Marcoses occurred before the March 1986 injunction, just after they fled the Philippines for exile in Hawaii. An art expert testified that the 26 paintings Khashoggi bought from Marcos had a much lower market value in 1986 than the $6.5 million he paid for the entire group of 38 ``old master'' paintings. The paintings weren't identified in court. Ian Glenn Kennedy, a senior vice president at Christie's auction house, testified that an appraisal of the 26 paintings showed their combined value four years ago would have ranged from $1.7 million to $2.7 million. Ealier in the day, Christian Rene LeBeau, an officer with the French Judicial Police's art theft unit, identified 26 paintings that had been seized in 1987 in Paris and Cannes. He did so from photographs of the paintings supplied by prosecutors. Testifying through a translator, LeBeau said he was in charge of the search for the paintings after U.S. authorities asked France for help. He was called to the stand after the testimony Friday of Jean-Paul Renard, an investigating magistrate from Cannes, France, and Fernand DeZacharia, a French-English translator who had been present when Khashoggi appeared twice before Renard in 1987. English translations of those two interviews, entered into evidence during DeZacharia's testimony, contain Khashoggi saying that his decision to buy the paintings was made in 1985 and that payment of $6.5 million followed in two installments in March and May of 1986. Under cross-examination, LeBeau was asked by lawyers for both Khashoggi and Mrs. Marcos whether their clients ever had been charged in France with trafficking in stolen art. When LeBeau said he could not answer the questions, U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan told jurors that the information had as much to do with this case ``as the man in the moon.'' Mrs. Marcos, 60, has pleaded innocent to charges of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Her husband, who also was charged in the 1988 indictment, died in September in exile in Hawaii. Khashoggi is charged with obstruction of justice and mail fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Two Arabs Die After Clashes, Palestinians Defy Uprising Strike
DOC.TEXT: Two Palestinians died Monday of gunshot wounds suffered in an earlier clash with troops, and merchants in Arab east Jerusalem defied strike orders in a growing rebellion against the uprising's pro-PLO leadership. Also Sunday, Likud hard-liners attacked caretaker Prime Minister and Likud bloc leader Yitzhak Shamir for promising to pursue a government peace initiative in order to win the support of a small religious party. The two Arabs were shot in the head by soldiers dispersing stone-throwers Sunday and died of their wounds early Monday, Palestinian reports said. An army spokesman confirmed the deaths and said the circumstances were under investigation. Arab hospital officials identified the slain youth as Moussa Mohammed Husseini al Alameh, 14, and Yousef Atta Al Kishawi, 10. Israeli authorities said Kishawi was 13. The deaths brought to 676 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians in the 28-month-old uprising against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Since the start of the uprising, another 208 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, mostly on suspicion of cooperating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have also died. In east Jerusalem, merchants opened their shops today after Palestinian activists canceled strike orders by the pro-PLO Unified National Leadership of the Uprising. The leadership had called a strike on Sunday to show Christian-Moslem solidarity after Jews moved into a settlement in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem's Old City. A second day of strikes was called for Monday in support of so-called ``liberated'' villages. The two-day strike order, contained in the latest Unified Leadership leaflet, has angered many Moslem Palestinians because it comes in the middle of the shopping period before the three-day Id al-Fitr holiday later this week. Moslems exchange gifts and prepare festive meals to celebrate Id al-Fitr that marks the end of the month-long Ramadan fast. Both strike days were canceled by local uprising activists in the West Bank's largest town, Nablus. It was reportedly the first time that leaders in Nablus, a hotbed of Palestinian nationalism, have rejected orders from the leadership. Likud hard-liners attacked Shamir after he promised to pursue a government peace initiative to win the support of the five-member ultra-Orthodox Shas Party. Shas' support leaves Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc in a deadlock with the left-leaning Labor Party. Both parties now have the support of 60 of Parliament's 120 members as they vie to form a new coalition government. ``Who authorized you to commit the Likud to continue with the peace process?'' asked former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, a champion of the party's far-right faction. Shamir promised Shas the government would pursue its peace initiative that promises Palestinian elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. He also agreed to accept a preliminary meeting between Israelis and Palestinians to discuss details of the elections. The move comes as Labor is frantically trying to patch together a coalition to present to Parliament. The left-leaning party was chosen by President Chaim Herzog to put together a new government and has until Thursday to present their coalition. Also Monday, Minister of Immigration and Absorption Yitzhak Peretz said that 28,740 immigrants arrived in Israel this year, including nearly 25,000 immigrants from the Soviet Union, Israel radio reported. Israeli officials expect hundred of thousands of Soviet immigrants over the next few years.

DOC.HEAD: Whichard and Five Incumbents Elected to AP Board
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS overline and 4th graf to CORRECT spelling to Whichard sted Wichard.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-AP Annual Meeting
DOC.TEXT: David J. Whichard II of the Greenville (N.C.) Daily Reflector was elected to the board of directors of The Associated Press on Monday, and five incumbents were re-elected. James K. Batten, J. Stewart Bryan III, Ruth S. Holmberg, Tom Johnson and Joe D. Smith Jr. were elected to new three-year terms. Directors were elected from among 12 nominees at the AP's annual meeting. Whichard was elected to the board to represent a city of under 50,000 population. He succeeds retiring director John O. Emmerich Jr. of the Greenwood (Miss.) Commonwealth, who was not eligible for re-election because he has served the maximum three consecutive three-year terms. Batten is chairman and chief executive officer of Knight-Ridder, Inc., based in Miami. Bryan is chairman and publisher of the Richmond (Va.) Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader. Holmberg is publisher of The Chattanooga (Tenn.) Times. Johnson is chairman of the Los Angeles Times. Smith is president of the Alexandria (La.) Daily Town Talk. The voting for directors was based on membership bonds held by the newspapers that make up the cooperative news agency. The results: Batten, 18,495 bond votes. Johnson, 14,846. Smith, 14,814. Bryan, 11,599. Holmberg, 11,291. Robert H. Hartmann of The Evansville (Ind.) Press, 8,945. George W. Wilson of the Concord (N.H.) Monitor, 8,563. Walter E. Bartlett of The Greenville (S.C.) News, 7,329. Beverly Kees of The Fresno (Calif.) Bee, 5,297. Richard L. Conner of the Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram, 2,701. In the separate contest for election to the board to represent a city of under 50,000 population, Whichard received 11,791 votes. Ted M. Natt of the Longview (Wash.) Daily News received 8,739 votes.

DOC.HEAD: Crews Clean Up Oil, Caustic Chemical After Train Derailment, Explosion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with three cars burning, one coal car moved and emptied; picks up 7th graf pvs, `Firefighters sprayed ...'; SUBS 18th graf to UPDATE with thousands of fish thought killed; picks up 19th graf pvs, `Don and ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XCGV1,2; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters worked Monday to extinguish three burning train cars and crews skimmed crude oil from the surface of a creek that was fouled when a freight train derailed and caught fire. Twenty-nine cars in a 97-car Buffalo and Pittsburgh Railroad Inc. train derailed in this sparsely populated rural community Sunday night. No serious injuries were reported in the ensuing explosion and fire. About 100,000 gallons of oil leaked from four cars and up to 10,000 gallons of sodium hydroxide, a caustic chemical used to clean drains, leaked from one car, said John Bell, the railroad's vice president and general manager. Heat from two coal cars that caught fire Sunday night warmed six derailed oil tankers to dangerously high temperatures, officials said. Three oil tankers that had collided burned intermittently, officials said. To ease the heat, one of the two coal cars was moved late Monday afternoon to a field about 150 yards away from the track, Bell said. Smoldering coal was spread over the ground and sprayed with a special water solution to cool it. Crews began moving the second car early in the evening, officials said. ``The situation at present is unstable. There are still isolated fires flaring up on occasion,'' said Lt. Gov. Mark Singel, who visited the scene. Firefighters sprayed the oil cars with water to cool them, said Bob Walker, hazardous materials coordinator for Armstrong County's emergency management agency. Most of the leaks in the tanker cars were plugged by afternoon, Bell said. About 200 people had been evacuated late Sunday, but most were allowed to return home Monday. An evacuation order remained in effect for about 50 people who lived within a quarter-mile of the accident because of the possibility of an explosion, Bell said. Although some oil spilled into Buffalo Creek, most of it burned off in the fire, Bell said.The creek flows into the Allegheny River, the source of drinking water for several Pittsburgh-area communities. The spill was expected to have no significant impact on drinking water supplies, said Charles Duritsa, a regional director for the state Department of Environmental Resources. ``The environmental impact was pretty much controlled by teams diking the accident site,'' Duritsa said. Authorities were investigating the cause of the crash, Bell said. Several of the derailed cars lay in a zigzag pattern, and white smoke poured from burning coal cars Monday afternoon. Fire smoldered in a stream of oil that flowed from one car into a ravine. Firefighters used hoses to suck oil and sodium hydroxide from the ground. Booms set up along Buffalo Creek skimmed globs of oil from the surface of the water. A car that had contained 18,000 to 20,000 gallons of sodium hydroxide had been turned upright. About half of the chemical leaked from an inspection pipe atop the car when it was flipped upside down in the derailment. The two conductors, who were not injured, were given drug and alcohol tests, as is routine after accidents, Bell said. They told the railroad they were traveling about 20 mph when the derailment occurred, Bell said. The company speed limit for the Craigsville area is 25 mph. Thousands of dead fish were found in Buffalo Creek, a popular fishing spot, said Emil Svetahor, an official with the state Fish Commission. The commission had planned to stock the creek with more fish Friday, but those plans have been canceled, Svetahor said. Don and Louise Butler, who live in a mobile home about a block from the crash, were in their living room when the train passed by. ``It was the fastest train I've ever heard go through here,'' Butler said. After the explosion the Butlers ran outside in their nightclothes and drove to a hilltop about two miles away. Even at that distance they felt the heat of the fire, they said. Bell said there was no indication the train was speeding.

DOC.HEAD: Three Injured in Chicago Building Collapse
DOC.TEXT: A three-story building collapsed during rehabilitation work Monday, injuring three people. The collapse damaged gas lines in the building and triggered a gas leak, but there was no fire or explosion, said Ed Joyce, spokesman for Peoples Gas, Light & Coke Co. Firefighters spent the afternoon and evening searching for two people at first thought to be in the rubble of the brick commercial and residential building on the city's west side, which collased at 4:30 p.m. But the search was called off at 7:30 p.m. after the missing were accounted for, said a fire department spokesman. Two of the injured were taken to Cook County Hospital, where one, a woman, was in stable but guarded condition. The other, a man, was still in the emergency room and his condition had not been determined early Monday evening, a hospital spokesman said. Their names were withheld. A third victim, Norman Graham, 65, was in fair condition at Northwestern Memorial Hospital with multiple bruises and was expected to be discharged Monday night, a hospital spokesman said. ``We understand a contractor was in that building doing some rehab work and apparently removed one of the main support beams,'' Joyce said. The three-story building housed two stores on the ground floor and four to six apartments above, Joyce said.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Asked to Reverse Extradition Decision
DOC.TEXT: A private human rights monitoring group appealed to Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Monday to spare an accused Chinese hijacker from probable torture in China and let him be tried in Japan. Extraditing Zhang Zhenhai to China ``would be a serious human rights violation,'' because he would ``likely be tortured by Chinese authorities both for participation in the democracy movement and for his hijacking'' of a Chinese airliner last December, Asia Watch said in a message to Kaifu. Asia Watch appealed to Kaifu on the basis of a Tokyo report that Zhang could be deported to China this week. Justice Minister Shin Hasegawa issued an order for his extradition Monday. ``We obviously do not condone hijacking, but no one should be subjected to torture,'' said the signer of the appeal, Asia Watch executive director Sidney Jones. Asia Watch is affiliated with Helsinki Watch, which oversees human rights guidelines of the 1975 Helsinki agreement on East-West cooperation and security. Asia Watch has documented several cases of torture in Chinese prisons, including many participants in the crushed 1989 democracy movement, Ms. Jones said. The Tokyo High Court last week upheld the Japanese government's intention to deny political asylum to Zhang, overruling his defense that his offense was political. Zhang, now 36, had actively participated in the 1979 Democracy Wall movement and in the 1989 demonstrations in Beijing's Tiananmen square, his lawyers said. Police said he hijacked a Chinese jumbo jet en route from Beijing to New York with 233 people aboard, threatening to blow it up with a bomb he did not actually have. The plane landed at Fukuoka, Japan, and Zhang's wife and 13-year-old son were returned to China the next day. Japanese prosecutors said Zhang was not involved in political activity and was seeking to flee criminal charges described by Chinese television as embezzlement. In another development, two members of the House of Representatives launched a Republican launched a campaign for colleagues in Congress to ``adopt'' some of the perhaps 30,000 people they said are in Chinese prisons for backing the democracy movement crushed last year. ``We want the Beijing government to know that we have not forgotten _ and will not forget _ the courageous men and women who risked their lives in the struggle for democratic reform,'' Reps. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., and John Miller, R-Wash., said in a letter to House members. They asked colleagues to write letters to Chinese authorities in behalf of individual ``adoptees,'' to insert statements in the daily Congressional Record on their behalf and to bring up their names when travelling in China.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Musical `King' Opens in London to Ovation, Poor Reviews
DOC.TEXT: ``King,'' the troubled London musical about Martin Luther King Jr., opened Monday to a four-minute standing ovation but poor reviews from the critics. ``Someone should put on a musical about the making of `King.' It would probably turn out to be a good deal more entertaining than `King' itself,'' Charles Spencer in The Daily Telegraph wrote. The show bowed at the Piccadilly Theater after its original opening date, April 4, was postponed three times. Maureen Paton in The Daily Express wrote: ``This treatment comes across as a simplified version for children. It may be well-meaning, but it's an insult to adults.'' The show stars opera singers Simon Estes and Cynthia Haymon. Their strong singing deflected doubts about the absence of any insight into the private lives behind the public persona of the slain black civil rights leader and his wife, Coretta. Monday's premier brought to an end weeks of speculation about the show, which for several weeks was making headlines almost daily as various directors and writers parted company with the project. On March 6, Coretta Scott King announced in a statement that she was withdrawing her support because the show trivialized her husband. She restored her support a week into previews. The poet and lyricist Maya Angelou, who withdrew at the same time as Mrs. King, has yet to lend her support anew. The finished product bears lyrics by both Angelou and Alistair Beaton, the Briton who co-wrote the 1988 London flop ``Ziegfeld.'' The director, 39-year-old Clarke Peters, is a black American based in London who has the supporting role in the show as the garage mechanic, George. He was hired after Gotz Friedrich and Graham Vick, two directors known for their work in opera, quit the musical. The book is billed as an ``adaptation'' by Lonne Elder III, an Oscar nominee for the film ``Sounder,'' who followed fellow playwrights Ron Milner and Richard Nelson, neither of whom receives credit in the program. The sheer quantity of creative participants must account, in part, for the confused narrative and characterization of ``King.'' Spencer wrote in The Daily Telegraph: ``It is sometimes hard to make out exactly what is going on, still less where or when.'' ``King'' is budgeted at $4.5 million and breaks even at ``close to 50 percent'' in the 1,168-seat theater, according to producer Hans Flury. The top ticket price of $41 puts ``King'' on financial par with London's reigning musical blockbusters, ``Miss Saigon'' and ``The Phantom of the Opera.'' Of the advance sale, executive producer Peter Wilson would say only that it is ``very satisfying.'' There was a standing ovation that lasted four minutes following the opening.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Holy Sites to Close Friday to Protest Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to UPDATE with State Department response, Greek government and Orthodox Church reaction. Pickup 3rd pvs, `The settlement...' and edits thereafter to trim
DOC.TEXT: By SERGEI SHARGORODSKY=

Christian shrines in the Holy Land will close Friday and ring a funeral toll from their belltowers to protest a government-funded Jewish settlement in the Old City's Christian quarter, church leaders said. The announcement came one day after the Israeli government confirmed it put up $1.8 million to help finance the settlement of 150 Jews in a 72-room complex near the Church of the Holy Sepulcher. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler called the settler move into the Christian quarter ``an insensitive and provocative action.'' She said Israel's funding of the settlement ``is deeply disturbing'' and that U.S. Ambassador William Brown was raising the issue with Israeli officials. In response, Foreign Ministry spokesman Yossi Amihud said: ``Jerusalem is the sovereign capital of the state of Israel and the government of Israel will continue to stand by the rights of Jews to settle in Jerusalem.'' In Athens, Foreign Minister Antonis Samaras summoned Israel's diplomatic representative, Moshe Gilboa, to protest the settlement, government spokesman Vyron Polydoras said. The settlement is in a compound owned by the Greek Orthodox Church. Archbishop Serapheim, head of the Greek Orthodox Church in Greece, also protested Monday to Israeli caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir over the occupation. The settlement, set up April 11, has provoked angry demonstrations by Christian clerics and Palestinians, both Christian and Moslem. In announcing Friday's daylong protest, the leaders of 10 Christian sects in the Holy Land said government support for the settlement ``endangers the survival of all Christian communities in the Holy City.'' ``We demand respect of the privileges and rights the Christians have in the Holy Land,'' Greek Orthodox Patriarch Diodorus I said on Monday. The settlement, called Neot David, is the only Jewish presence in the Old City's Christian sector. Its spokesmen have consistently said that no government money was involved in the settlement. Palestinian Christians have complained that the settlement threatened the traditional separation of the Christian, Moslem and Jewish quarters of the Old City. The Greek church, which says a former tenant illegally leased the compound, got an court order to have the Jews evicted. The Supreme Court will consider an appeal of the order on Thursday. Friday's protest will mark the first time all Christian holy places close, said the Rt. Rev. Samir Kafiti, Anglican bishop of Jerusalem. The church leaders included Roman Catholic, Coptic and Lutheran officials. Among the Christian sites to be closed are Jerusalem's Church of the Holy Sepulcher, Bethlehem's Church of the Nativity and the Church of the Annunciation in Nazareth. Israel's Religious Affairs Ministry said in a statement that the action ``gives rise to a suspicion that it might be an attempt to influence the Supreme Court,'' which is hearing an appeal of an order to evict the Jews. The ministry also accused church leaders of a ``basic and serious violation of the status-quo (of holy places) that we try so much to preserve in order to allow an orderly religious worship.'' Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek said he was sorry the churches undertook ``drastic action'' before the legal process was completed. But he condemned the ``damage to coexistence in the city and the standing of Jerusalem'' caused by the settlers. He said government support ``only deepens the doubts and sharpens the fears of the churches in Jerusalem.'' The government's acknowledgement Sunday that it helped finance the settlement was the first confirmation of official involvement in buying Arab property in Jerusalem's walled Old City, captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war. It came as settlers prepared a new settlement in the occupied Gaza Strip and the government authorized the expansion of settlements in the occupied West Bank. The settlement activity follows the March 15 collapse of the coalition Cabinet. That left the government in the hands of Shamir and his right-wing Likud bloc, which favors retaining the occupied territories. Shamir is leading the government on a caretaker basis while Labor Party leader Shimon Peres tries to form a government with ultra-Orthodox parties. About 75,000 Jewish settlers live in the occupied lands, home to 1.7 million Palestinians, who have a rebellion for 28 months against Israeli rule. The Christian leaders said the church will hold the protest regardless of the Supreme Court decision. The church closure will be in effect between 9 a.m. Friday and an unspecified hour Saturday. Church bells will toll on the hour from 9 a.m. until noon Friday. Diodorus I and Kafiti said the closure may be longer than announced.

DOC.HEAD: Orthodox Leaders Protest Jewish Settlements
With AM-Israel-Holy Sites, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Eastern Orthodox leaders have voiced their distress at recent Jewish settlements in the Christian sector of the Old City of Jerusalem, charging that church property was occupied. They asked for a meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III about the ``unjustified occupation'' and ``subsequent provocative incidents,'' church officials announced Monday. Telegrams about the matter were sent last week to Baker, Jerusalem's Greek Orthodox Patriarch Diodoros and to Israel's president Chaim Herzog. American Jewish leaders also criticized the settlement of 20 Jewish families in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem. The move set off criticism in Israel as well as elsewhere. In Jerusalem Monday, church leaders announced that Christian shrines in the Holy Land will close Friday and ring a funeral toll from their belltowers to protest the settlement. Friday's protest will mark the first time all Christian holy places close, said the Rt. Rev. Samir Kafiti, Anglican bishop of Jerusalem. The church leaders announcing the plan included Roman Catholic, Coptic and Lutheran officials. Among the Christian sites to be closed are Jerusalem's Church of the Holy Sepulcher, Bethlehem's Church of the Nativity and the Church of the Annunciation in Nazareth. The Standing Conference of Canonical Orthodox Bishops in the Americas, including eight wings of Eastern Orthodoxy totaling more than 7 million members, termed the settlements ``another obstacle'' to peace. In their message to Herzog, they expressed ``our distress...over the violent occupation by Jewish settlers of property that belongs to the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate of Jerusalem.'' The bishops said they expected a ``prompt and just solution to the problem by the removal of the settlers and return of this property'' to the church. In Jerusalem, the Jewish families totaling about 150 members had moved into St. John's Hospice near the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, on Good Friday, marking the crucifixion of Christ. They claimed that most of the approximately $4 million spent to sublet the property from an Armenian family that had leased it from the Greek Orthodox Church came from unidentified American donors. However the Israeli government acknowledged Sunday that it had secretly provided about $2 million to help establish a Jewish settlement in the Christian quarter. Seymour D. Reich, chairman of the Conference of Major American Jewish Organizations, said the settlement of the Jewish families was ``offensive and an unnecessary provocation.'' He said the action was especially disturbing since it occurred during the celebration of Holy Week by Christians and Ramadan by Moslems. Reich, who also is international president of B'nai B'rith, noted the settlers had covered a cross over a main door with a poster of the Star of David. He said this could be viewed as ``insensitive or even a degradation.'' ``This was a deliberate provocation,'' he added. The bishops' protest was issued after a meeting April 19 of the various national wings of U.S. Orthodoxy under chairmanship of Greek Orthodox Archbishop Iakovos. They told Baker that ``difficulties in the occupied territories and Lebanon,'' coupled with the Jewish occupation in Holy Week of Greek Orthodox property, necessitated an early meeting with him. They expressed ``our painful concern over these violations'' to Baker, and in a separate telegram to Patriarch Diodoros said: ``We are disheartened by the recent illegal actions that occurred during the Passion Week of our Lord.''

DOC.HEAD: Mob Witness Protests Being Dumped From Federal Protection Program
DOC.TEXT: A mob-trial witness held a one-man protest over the government's failure to protect him, marching outside the courthouse Monday with a sign that read: ``Marked to die by the Justice Dept.'' James Cardinali of New York said he was dumped from the federal Witness Protection Program after being granted him immunity in five drug-related murders. He said the government promised to protect him for life in return for his weeklong testimony in 1986 against John Gotti, reputed leader of the Gambino crime family. ``They said they would guard me for the rest of my life,'' said Cardinali, 40, as he paced up and down in front of the federal courthouse downtown. ``If I get killed on the streets of Albuquerque _ if they have me in a pool of blood _ that's what I deserve for trusting the government,'' he said. On one side of a sandwich board draped over his shoulders was a bull's eye and the words ``Mob Star Witness.'' On the other side: ``Marked to Die by the Justice Dept.'' He said he would picket daily ``until there's no pavement left here or until I'm murdered.'' Anthony Baca, Cardinali's federal probation officer in Albuquerque, watched the demonstration but declined to comment. U.S. Marshal Al Solis said he could neither confirm nor deny Cardinali's participation in the program. He declined further comment. ``They have to live up to their promises,'' Cardinali said. ``They have to take me back. If I get killed, I want everybody to see what they do to you. The only way I can fight them is to risk my life. They count on that so you keep your mouth shut.'' Cardinali was arrested in 1983 for murder and made the deal for immunity while serving in jail. After his release and entry into the witness program, he said, ``I got myself together. I went to church. I was doing very good.'' Cardinali, who said he met Gotti while in prison in 1976, testified about three murders Gotti and his co-defendants allegedly committed. Gotti was acquitted after a seven-month trial on racketeering and conspiracy charges. Cardinali said U.S. officials put him on a bus from Oklahoma City to Albuquerque nine days ago. He said he had been living on and off in Oklahoma since he was placed under protection in October 1988. ``I have no allies,'' Cardinali said. ``I know no one here. So I have to fight this way. Once you're a stool pigeon, you don't have no more allies.'' Cardinali said he was released from the program in July 1989 because he breached the rules by confiding his identity to a girlfriend. In January, he said, he was picked up on what he called a phony parole violation for associating with a criminal. He was in prison when he agreed to wear a wire for the Justice Department in its effort to expose an alleged conspiracy to kill a U.S. attorney in Oklahoma, he said. In exchange, he said, it was promised that he would be returned to the protection program for the rest of his life. Cardinali said following his release from El Reno Correction Institute in El Reno, Okla., a week ago, the U.S. Marshals Service failed to return him to the program. He said although he has received no threats since arriving in Albuquerque, ``I'm going to be gunned down. I know it. I have great antennae.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Army Bus Crashes in Netherlands, Several Hurt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. army bus carrying 18 servicemen crashed in an accident that seriously hurt several soldiers Monday, and police said the bus was forced off the highway by a motorist who appeared to be intoxicated. The Americans' identities and the nature of their injuries were not available. National Police spokesman Sergeant Theo Kroes said victims were being treated at area hospitals. The soldiers were returning from Bremen, West Germany, to their base in Suettendaal, Belgium. The purpose of the trip was not reported. Kroes said the 34-year-old Dutch driver of a car tried to pass the bus. ``The car veered left and ran into the left side of the bus, after which both vehicles flipped several times on the shoulder,'' Kroes reported. He said the driver appeared to be under the influence of alcohol, but did not say whether the motorist was hurt. Volunteers and rescue workers who went to the accident site, near the Belgian and German borders, about 45 miles east of Cologne, West Germany, said they had difficulty pulling the trapped driver from the bus, Kroes said.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Bank Robbers Get More Than $3 Million
DOC.TEXT: Eight men with submachine guns robbed a bank in northeast Brazil Monday and fled with $3.5 million, a TV network reported. The gang invaded the Banco do Brasil in Natal, about 1,760 miles northeast of Rio, and escaped in three cars, the SBT television network added. State police set up roadblocks and closed the city's airport, SBT reported.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador Meets Peru's Vargas Llosa
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Ambassador Anthony Quainton met with Mario Vargas Llosa on Monday, two weeks after the novelist emerged from first-round presidential elections with a slim victory. Quainton said the United States ``wants to cooperate with the future government and I am maintaining contacts with the two candidates'' who will take part in the runoff. He said he would probably meet with centrist candidate Alberto Fujimori before the end of the week. Fujimori took 30 percent of the April 8 vote to Vargas Llosa's 32 percent. Vargas Llosa held a commanding lead over eight presidential opponents going into the final weeks of the campaign. Fujimori's surprising late surge came largely at Vargas Llosa's expense. The next president will face grave problems governing bankrupt Peru, which is suffering from hyperinflation and a rapidly shrinking economy. The new president must also confront the Maoist Shining Path guerrilla group, fighting to impose a peasant-worker state. The government says more than 18,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path took up arms in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Scores Arrested in AIDS Protest
LaserPhoto CX4
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of activists clogged downtown streets Monday to protest alleged discrimination by the insurance industry and public health-care system for people with AIDS. The police arrested dozens of demonstrators. The 1{-mile march began peacefully but turned disorderly outside the headquarters of the American Medical Association, where a handful of activists chanted, ``The AMA is killing us.'' Many protesters marching in front of the Prudential Insurance Co. shouted, ``They do nothing, we die.'' Chanting protesters lay down in the streets and others wrote slogans on a county building. No serious injuries were immediately reported. Police said they arrested at least 70 to 100 people on charges including disorderly conduct and mob action during the protest organized by the Chicago chapter of ACT-UP. The nationwide group that contends the insurance industry and public health-care system discriminate against AIDS patients. ACT-UP spokesman Fred Eggan said Cook County Hospital, the sole public hospital that treats people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome in Chicago, only has 30 beds for AIDS patients. He said 15 remain empty because of understaffing and underfunding. ACT-UP also contends the insurance industry denies coverage to some homosexuals and refuses to pay for cetain AIDS drugs. ``We want insurance companies to cover people with AIDS and policies not to be canceled after (people) are diagnosed with it,'' said Jim Wagner, 26. In a statement released by its Newark, N.J., headquarters, Prudential said, ``The company has been a leader in dealing with AIDS-related illnesses.'' The AMA said in a statement that it ``firmly agrees with all concerned parties that people with AIDS must have access to quality health care.''

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Disrupt Financial Districts in NYC, San Francisco
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with additional arrests in New York. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `The major...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY35
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of environmentalists demonstrated Monday in the financial districts of New York and San Francisco, where post-Earth Day demonstrators shattered windows at the Bank of America. Authorities said 268 people were arrested in the two cities. Also in California, hand-delivered messages claimed responsibility Monday for vandalism that cut power to some 92,000 Pacific Gas & Electric customers in Santa Cruz and Watsonville. In New York, police arrested about 204 of an estimated 700 demonstrators. Two protestors were charged with assaulting an officer and the rest with disorderly conduct, according to police spokesmen. ``The major corporations have committed a lot of crimes against nature,'' said Marc Chernoff, 30, a member of New York's Coalition for a Nuclear Free Harbor. ``It's long overdue to place the blame where it directly belongs. If the products that pollute were not made available, people would not buy them.'' Trade on the New York Stock Exchange went on as scheduled and none of the protesters got inside. ``Except for getting up a little early, it's a pretty normal day,'' said the exchange's senior vice president, Richard Torrenzano. At the Pacific Stock Exchange in San Francisco, 49 people were arrested during a demonstration by 300 to 500 protesters that turned violent when some broke windows at Bank of America, threw golf balls, rocks and eggs at police, and overturned newsstands. The exchange also opened on schedule although some employees were delayed. Police closed off two blocks of Wall Street to traffic and all pedestrians except those working there. Traffic elsewhere was disrupted during the morning and afternoon when protesters walked through lower Manhattan streets. The protest was organized by Earth Day Wall Street Action, which described itself as a coalition of 60 environmental organizations in the United States and Canada. It said it wanted to focus attention on ``institutions responsible for much of the ecological devastation which is destroying the planet.'' ``I don't know why they're protesting against Wall Street,'' said James F. Dean, 24, an auditor with J.P. Morgan. ``I don't think anyone is taking this seriously besides them.'' ``I think it's great that these guys in suits are stopping to hear us,'' said Debbie Augustine, 34, of Loudon, N.H., a member of the anti-nuclear power Clamshell Alliance. A spokesman for the San Francisco demonstrators, Daniel Finkenthal of the Earth Day Action Coalition, said the purpose of the protest there was to give the public an alternative to the corporate-sponsored views of environmental action that preceded Earth Day. ``Yesterday these corporations came into our community and spent a lot of money on a media coup to try to convince the American public that environmental protection and reform was high on the corporate agenda, but it's the lowest priority,'' Finkenthal said. ``In fact, they're spending more money on Earth Day promotion than they are on actual corporate reform and the environment.'' The group that claimed responsibility for the two California outages called itself Earth Night Action Group and said the target was Pacific Gas & Electric, a ``corporate earth rapist.'' Residents of Santa Cruz and Watsonville were affected by the outages Sunday and early Monday, caused by damage to power PG&E poles. A young male caller to The Associated Press telephoned a few minutes after delivery of the message to ask if it had been received. Similar messages went to Bay City News Service and the San Francisco Examiner. The caller refused to give his name or his telephone number. Elsewhere, the day after Earth Day was the day to clean up the trash left by the crowds who gathered to celebrate a cleaner Earth. In Baton Rouge, La., the grounds of the old state capitol and the Centroplex auditorium were strewn with trash and it took an eight-person city crew and a few volunteers three hours and about 65 overflowing trash bins to clean up. ``You're not going to change people's actions overnight,'' said local Earth Day Chairman Paul Davidson. ``I'd like to think it's cleaner than at past festivals, but I don't know.'' New York City was better off, even though an estimated 750,000 to 1 million people gathered in Central Park for music and speeches. Before the celebration, the Parks Department put out 250 55-gallon trash drums and 20 15-gallon recycling bins. ``We estimate that 90 percent of all refuse from the concert was either put into the drums or recycling bins or was placed very carefully right next to them on the ground when the receptacles became too full,'' said Parks Department spokeswoman Abigail Meisel. By midday Monday, workers had carted away 1 ton of newspapers for recycling; 3.3 tons of metal and glass for recycling; and 150 tons of other refuse, she said. The crowd on the Mall in Washington, D.C., was smaller, more than 125,000 people, and they left only 6 to 7 tons of trash, said Earle Kittleman, spokesman for the National Park Service. That compares with 35 tons left by 400,000 people last July 4.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Readying Penalties Against USSR
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS name ``Yakovley'' to ``Yakovlev'' in last graf
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is ready to announce a series of economic penalties against the Soviet Union in response to Moscow's crackdown on Lithuania, U.S. officials said Monday. Bush was expected to outline his trategy at a Tuesday meeting with congressional leaders, said officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Among the steps will be postponment and withholding of a variety of trade and economic concessions that the Soviet Union is seeking from the United States, the officials said. However, the administration's measures are not intended to interfere with U.S.-Soviet arms negotiations or to postpone the May 30-June 3 superpower summit, the officials said. Although exact details of the administration's package were not clear, the general thrust will be to slow down U.S.-Soviet trade liberalization talks, which had been scheduled to resume in Paris on Tuesday, the officials said. Among the actions expected to be announced by Bush on Tuesday are a withdrawl of his earlier U.S. support for Moscow's bid for observer status in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the international organization that oversees free-market trading rules. Although such an approach would be a measured one, the sanctions could help mute criticism in Congress that the Bush administration wasn't doing enough to respond to the Soviet's tightening crackdown in Lithuania. Moscow last week sharply curtailed oil and natural gas supplies to the secessionist state. Earlier Monday, the White House welcomed what it called signs of flexibility from Moscow in its standoff with Lithuania. And officials said that the president remained hopeful that the crisis still could be resolved through negotiations between Moscow and the rebellious Baltic republic. Bush earlier had proposed a variety of U.S. help to the ailing Soviet economy _ ranging from technical assistance to an easing of legal restrictions on U.S.-Soviet trade _ that are now expected to be put on hold. Bush, answering reporters who asked if he might call off the trade talks in response to the Soviet economic crackdown, said: ``I'll sure let you know when I make a decision.''
