Secretary of State James A. Baker III cautioned last week that economic relations ``are being put to risk by Soviet actions in Lithuania.'' Before the officials disclosed Bush's course, Baker said consultations with West European governments on a course of action ``will be completed very soon.'' He denied reports the administration was taking its time in the hopes a solution would emerge, saying, ``We are not dragging our feet.'' In a sign of business as usual, a senior State Department official said Monday that Baker will meet May 5 in Bonn with the foreign ministers of the Soviet Union, Britain and France on security concerns raised by prospects of German unification. In Moscow, the spokesman for Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev said the Kremlin might negotiate with Lithuania if it freezes its March 11 declaration of independence for two years. Arkady Maslennikov, Gorbachev's press secretary, said Soviet leaders were willing to talk to Lithuanian leaders if they will acknowledge they are still subject to the Soviet Constitution. Lithuanian leaders have refused to do that, saying the republic was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. The constitution guarantees the right of secession in principle, but the Soviet Union has never passed implementing legislation. Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders have acknowledged that the 1940 annexation was illegal. Lithuania and its sister Baltic republics of Estonia and Latvia had belonged to the Russian czars for 200 years when, in the turmoil that followed the Communist Revolution of 1917, they established themselves as independent countries recognized by the Soviet Union in 1920. Lithuania's 3.8 million people began their first full work week since Gorbachev cut off supplies of oil, natural gas and other raw materials to the republic. On Sunday, Lithuania halted exports to Soviet republics and foreign customers. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday that the Bush adminstration was still consulting with allies on what course to take. The statements from the Kremlin ``do appear to show some flexibility. We are hopeful that that's the case,'' he said. ``It's impossible for us to know exactly what these statements ... mean, but if they are indicative of the two sides being able to get together, that would be a welcome sign,'' Fitzwater said. Baker discussed Lithuania at the State Department with European Community officials. ``We've talked, at some length, of course, about the problems of ethnic divisions that face the Soviet Union, and we've talked about the fact that instability in the Soviet Union does not operate to the advantage of anyone and is not something to be desired,'' Baker said at a news conference. Meanwhile, a planned meeting Monday between Alexsandr Yakovlev, the Soviet Communist Party secretary, and Vice President Dan Quayle was postponed at the Soviets' request, the White House said. The Soviets gave no reason for postponing the meeting.

DOC.HEAD: City's Newest Bank to Cater to Rich
DOC.TEXT: A new bank created to compete with Pittsburgh's finest plans to cater to the rich, and will refuse to open accounts of less than $30,000, company officials said Monday. Services known as ``private banking'' have been available at Mellon Bank and Pittsburgh National Bank for about a decade, but Pennsylvania Capital officials called those services a ``sideline'' at the big banks. ``Our advantage is that's all we do,'' said Charles Warden, a director of the bank, the first in Pittsburgh in 15 years. Officials said there will be no lines for tellers, and for more sophisticated needs, customers will be assigned a ``relationship officer'' who will make house calls in some cases. Warden said impersonl banking brought about by consolidation in the financial industry has opened up a niche for banks like Pennsylvania Capital. The bank, which has been been approved by the state banking secretary, has raised approximately $3 million of the $5 million it needs to open its doors, president Donald Whitehead said. He said officials expect to raise the remaining money through private placements of stock within two months.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for April 16-23:
DOC.HEAD: First Quarter Reports Show Ad Weaknesses
DOC.TEXT: The Gannett Co. Inc., blaming what it called the poorest advertising environment in almost 20 years, reported a barely perceptible increase in first-quarter earnings April 17. Other quarterly reports showed lower earnings for the Tribune Co. and Media General Inc., and a 16 percent increase for A.H. Belo Corp. of Dallas. Gannett said earnings totaled $75 million, or 47 cents a share, in the quarter ended April 1, up slightly from $74.9 million, or 47 cents a share, the prior year. Revenue slipped less than 1 percentage point to $813.4 million from $817.6 million a year earlier. The company said newspaper advertising revenue declined by 3 percent in the first quarter. Gannett said broadcast revenue also was lower, but no figures were provided. The Tribune Co. of Chicago blamed operating losses at the New York Daily News and weakness in its newsprint business for a 9 percent earnings drop. The company had net income of $33.5 million, or 43 cents a share, in the three months ended April 1, down from $36.8 million, or 49 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 6 percent to $584 million from $553 million in 1989's first quarter. Operating profit for the company's newspaper publishing group declined 10 percent to $55.7 million from $61.6 million. The company attributed the decrease to larger operating losses at the Daily News resulting from weaker market conditions and costs related to contract negotiations with the newspaper's 10 unions. Operating profit improved for the rest of the newspaper group largely due to stronger Chicago Tribune results and lower newsprint costs, the company said. Media General Inc. of Richmond, Va., reported lower revenues, net income and earnings per share for the first quarter. ``Although 1990 revenue growth is expected, the uncertainty of the economy currently is clouding the earnings outlook,'' said James S. Evans, the company's president and chief executive officer. Revenues declined to $148 million from $149.3 million last year. Net income dropped sharply, from $11.9 million, or 46 cents a share in the first quarter of 1989, to $2.7 million, or 10 cents a share this year. First quarter 1989 net income included an after-tax gain of $5.7 million, or 22 cents a share, from the sale of a California newsprint recycling mill. Excluding the 1989 one-time gain, 1990 first quarter net income fell 56.3 percent. Media General said newspaper profits were 44.2 percent lower in the first quarter. The company blamed the decline on faltering national, retail and classified advertising sales. Media General is the parent of the Richmond Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader and other daily newspapers as well as several broadcast operations. Broadcast profits increased 2.5 percent. Belo credited increased classified advertising and broadcast revenue for its earnings increase. The company posted a profit of $2.8 million, or 14 cents a share, in the first three months of the year compared with $2.4 million, or 12 cents a share, in the same period last year. Revenue rose to $56.3 million from $53.6 million reported in last year's first quarter. Belo owns and operates The Dallas Morning News, seven community newspapers in the Dallas-Fort Worth area and five televsion stations in several states.
DOC.HEAD: Ad Revenue Drop Forces Job Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of The Berkshire Eagle said April 18 it was laying off 10 employees because of a drop in advertising revenue. The Eagle Publishing Co., which publishes the daily and has a full-time workforce of 286, will make the first cuts by mid-May, said President Michael G. Miller. Five positions will be cut from the newsroom, and the other five will be cut from the sales, marketing and business departments, he said. In addition, Berkshires Week, the Eagle's entertainment supplement, will revert to seasonal publication after the summer and two additional editing positions will be cut, the publisher said in a statement. ``Our ad revenue was down 3 percent last year, and 10 percent so far this year,'' Miller said. ``We used to be gangbusters, but now everything is slowing down.'' A statement from the Eagle News Association, the union representing the paper's editorial employees, said many union members believed the company's purchase and development of an office complex had drained finances and prompted the layoffs. Miller, however, said development of the complex had nothing to do with the cuts. The newspaper has a daily circulation of 34,000 and Sunday circulation of 35,000.
DOC.HEAD: President of Mexico Addresses AP Annual Luncheon
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper executives gathered to hear President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico address the annual meeting of The Associated Press and to choose directors of the news cooperative. The meeting on April 23 was attended by publishers and editors representing the AP's 1,486 newspaper members. It was among the opening-day events at the 104th annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association. The AP meeting included a report to the membership by William J. Keating, chairman of the board of directors, and Louis D. Boccardi, president and general manager of the AP. Keating is chairman and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer. AP members also saw a video presentation called ``AP '89: Witness to History'' and heard a panel discussion on Eastern Europe.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Says Fame Keeps Him Behind Bars
DOC.TEXT: Prison journalist Wilbert Rideau, recommended for parole again April 18, said he would be a free man had he spent his 29 years in the Louisiana State Penitentiary making license plates instead of running a newspaper. Rideau was convicted of killing a woman by cutting her throat and stabbing her in the heart. ``I've tried to make amends the best I could in the only ways available to me. I've done things that counted over the last 29 years,'' he said. ``That was the only violent act of my life, done when I was a wild teen-ager. If I could change it, I would.'' On April 18 the Louisiana Pardon Board recommended for the fourth time in six years that Rideau be set free. Gov. Buddy Roemer said he is inclined to reject the unanimous recommendation to commute Rideau's life sentence. A decision was not expected for at least a week. Rideau has been called a model inmate by prison authorities. The editor of the prison magazine, The Angolite, he also gives lectures to youth groups and gets out to go on national speaking tours on prison reform. Over the years he has had a literary agent and written free-lance articles for up to four figures for publications such as Penthouse. Rideau has won the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Award, the American Bar Association's Silver Gavel Award and the George Polk Award for special interest reporting. The Polk award came on two articles in The Angolite, ``Prison: a Sexual Jungle,'' dealing with homosexual rape, and ``The Other Side of Murder,'' which told of the aftermath of a killing. The Angolite, which has carried stories on inmate suicides, prison riots, prisoner rights, executions, prison sports and special events, was featured in The New York Times Sunday Magazine and has been praised in Time magazine, The Washington Post and Columbia Journalism Review. Rideau has appeared on national TV, including ABC's ``Nightline,'' on which he was on a five-man panel with former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger in a discussion of prison reform. And that is why, Rideau thinks, he's still in prison. ``Let's face it, they've released thousands of murderers since I've been in prison. I've watched them come in and go out _ all anonymous,'' he said. ``The governor hasn't searched out the families of their victims to talk to. They've managed to get out because their greatest achievement as a prisoner was that they remained anonymous.'' Of the 31 prisoners sentenced to either death or life in prison sent to Louisiana State Penitentiary in 1962, only Rideau remains behind bars. ``It's not like I'm asking for special treatment or consideration, not when the system has released everybody else routinely convicted of the same or worse crimes. The system exists for everybody else in the state but Wilbert Rideau,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: UPI Asks Appeals Court To Continue Reuters Picture Exchange
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for United Press International told a federal appeals court April 18 it could go out of business if Reuters is allowed to terminate a photo exchange agreement. Three judges of the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reserved decision on UPI's request for an injunction barring Reuters from terminating the contract. The judges, however, extended an earlier stay that keeps the agreement in effect until they issue a written decision. The contract between the news services was made in 1984 and called for UPI to supply Reuters with pictures from the United States and for Reuters to provide UPI with pictures from other countries. It was to run for 10 years beginning in 1985. ``We will immediately lose customers the minute Reuters cuts us off,'' UPI lawyer Mitchell Karlan told the court. ``If we are unable to get pictures from Reuters, UPI is going out of business.'' UPI is appealing a decision by U.S. District Judge Peter K. Leisure that the agency had not shown it would be irreparably harmed if the arrangement was discontinued. The injunction request stemmed from a counterclaim by UPI to a Reuters lawsuit that seeks to void the picture exchange agreement. Reuters said the agreement was not living up to expectations. Robert Sugarman, an attorney for Reuters, argued against the injunction on the grounds that UPI had not shown how many customers it would lose without foreign photos from Reuters. Sugarman pointed to testimony from UPI Chairman Earl Brian that UPI had negotiated to receive foreign photos from the French news service, Agence France-Presse, for a three-month period in the event the Reuters contract is discontinued. In a statement, Brian said, ``We will continue to pursue UPI's rights by confronting Reuters' erratic and unwarranted behavior. We take further encouragement from today's hearing and continuation of the order against Reuters. ``We at UPI consider photos and graphics a strategically vital component of our business today and in the 1990s,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Editorial Financial Disclosure Bill May Get Watered Down
DOC.TEXT: Legislation requiring newspaper editorial writers to sign their work and disclose financial interests may get watered down in the face of uncertain support, the bill's sponsor said April 16. ``I'd like to salvage the whole thing. But I'm a realist,'' said Rep. Bruce McEwan, R-Orlando. McEwan couldn't gauge the support he had for the bill April 16 before the House Judiciary Committee and asked that a vote be delayed a week. The bill squeaked out of subcommittee earlier this month on a 4-3 vote, and McEwan acknowledged many lawmakers are concerned that it might infringe on the First Amendment's press protections. The bill would include newspaper editorial board members under a law requiring state managers and most elected officials to file financial disclosure forms by July 1 every year or face a possible $5,000 fine. ``The public perception out there is that a lot of the newspapers have special interests too,'' McEwan said. In addition, the bill would make it a second-degree misdemeanor for a newspaper to print any unsigned editorial.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Free Press Passes News Since JOA
DOC.TEXT: The morning Detroit Free Press has passed The Detroit News, published in the afternoon, in the first circulation figures released since they entered into a joint operating agreement. Joseph Ungaro, president and chief executive officer of the Detroit Newspaper Agency, said April 17 the Free Press' total circulation increase moved the pape to the nation's No. 9 spot while dropping the News to No. 12. The JOA began in November. The Free Press reported a total daily circulation of 639,767 while the News reported 526,147 copies per day. Before the joint operating agreement, the News published editions all day. On Sept. 30, 1989, the Free Press reported daily circulation of 626,434, and the News 690,422. The figures are subject to confirmation with the Audit Bureau of Circulations. The combined Sunday edition of the News and Free Press ranks No. 4 in the nation in circulation, trailing The New York Times, the New York Daily News and the Los Angeles Times. The first post-JOA circulation report showed average Sunday sales of 1,270,420 copies for the period ended March 31, down from the combined pre-JOA Sunday sales of 1.5 million. Ungaro said the combined edition has eliminated the sale of many newspapers to subscribers who previously bought both papers' Sunday editions. The News' Sunday editions ranked No. 7 nationally before the JOA and the Free Press ranked No. 9, Ungaro said.
DOC.HEAD: National Geographic Editor Replaced
DOC.TEXT: National Geographic magazine has a new editor following the abrupt departure April 16 of Wilbur E. Garrett, who guided the publication's content for a decade. Neither Garrett nor the magazine would say whether he had been fired. Garrett was replaced by William T.E. Graves, 63, who has been a senior member of the magazine's editorial staff for 12 years. Garrett said there had been some personality conflicts and differences of opinion at the magazine, but he declined to elaborate.
DOC.HEAD: The National Plans San Diego, San Francisco Editions
DOC.TEXT: The National, the sports daily that has been publishing editions in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles since the end of January, says it will add San Diego and San Francisco editions this summer. Publisher Peter Price said April 16 he expects the San Diego edition will start by July 1 and that a San Francisco edition will be launched in July. Price said the newspaper plans to add at least one city a month to its lineup during the last five months of the year. He did not identify those cities. The National, which offers coverage of national sports supplemented with local sports in each city where it appears, began publication Jan. 31. Price said it is distributing an average of about 350,000 newspapers a day. He said the paper hopes to have editions in 10 to 12 cities by the end of the year with average circulation ``approaching 400,000.'' Analysts have said that although The National appears to have made a promising start, it is too early to tell if it can become a profitable national newspaper.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Prosecutor Erred in Withholding Files
DOC.TEXT: A judge on April 17 ordered the state to pay more than $31,000 in lawyers' fees to The Orlando Sentinel and Florida Today after ruling that a prosecutor wrongly prevented reporters from obtaining records in a murder case. State Attorney Norm Wolfinger denied requests for copies of ballistic reports, blood-alcohol tests, autopsy records and other materials following the shooting deaths of six people at two shopping centers on April 23, 1987. Wolfinger said he feared that releasing the information would damage Cruse's opportunity for a fair trial by prejudicing potential jurors. Judge Dean Moxley said in his ruling that the amount of publicity over the case already had been so widespread that release of the records would not have made a difference. State laws provide for release of such public records and assess penalties against officials who refuse to do so. State insurance plans will cover the cost of the payments. William Cruse was convicted of the murders last year and was sentenced to death. He remains under psychiatric care at Florida State Prison.
DOC.HEAD: Specialist: Value Would Skyrocket in One-Newspaper Dallas
DOC.TEXT: The value of The Dallas Morning News could increase by as much as $472 million in the first year alone if the Dallas Times Herald ceased publishing, a Times Herald witness testified April 18. The boost in value could exceed $1 billion after two years if Dallas became a one-newspaper town, William J. McCluskey, president of Henry Anspacher Inc., of New York City, said in the Times Herald's $33 million antitrust suit against its larger rival. McCluskey's company specializes in merger acquisitions, primarily in the publishing industry. Times Herald attorneys are trying to show The Morning News and its parent company, A.H. Belo Corp., wanted to get 26 features and comics moved from the Times Herald to The Morning News in hopes of driving the Times Herald out of business.
DOC.HEAD: AP, British Media Ordered To Give Riot Film to Police
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press, two British news agencies and a television company must hand over all film of a March 31 riot in London that left about 580 people injured, a judge ruled April 20. At a hearing in the Old Bailey Central Criminal Court, Judge Neil Denison said the right of the press to report freely and the need to trace serious offenders clashed and one had to give way. The AP, the British domestic news agency Press Association, and London Weekend Television opposed the application on grounds it made them appear an arm of the police and endangered their photographers. The fourth organization, Fleet Street News Agency, made no objection. ``If applications routinely succeed, there is a loss of the perceived independence of the media,'' Robin Oppenheim, legal counsel for the three news organizations, told the court. Police had sought help from news organizations in identifying those who participated in the riot that engulfed Trafalgar Square and London's theater district. The riot broke out after a demonstration against a new tax. Britain's 1984 Police and Criminal Evidence Act allows a judge to order news media to turn over material in cases involving serious offenses. On April 6, Denison ordered 25 British newspapers and TV companies to turn over their film to help identify rioters. Police then asked for film held by news agencies and London Weekend Television.
DOC.HEAD: Government Doesn't Have To Reveal Information on Retirees
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on April 17 refused to order the government to reveal the names and addresses of retired or disabled federal workers. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by an organization seeking to use the information to recruit new members in its campaign for increased benefits for retirees. The National Association of Retired Federal Employees used to have an agreement with the federal Office of Personnel Management that helped the association's drive for new members. The agency from 1979 to 1981 permitted the association to send information packets to newly retired federal workers through an independent mailing service. After the Office of Personnel Management ended the arrangement, the association sought to obtain the names and addresses under the Freedom of Information Act. A federal judge ruled in favor of the association, but the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here overturned that ruling last July. The appeals court said revealing the names and addresses of retired and disabled workers would violate their privacy.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Preservationists Fight Newspaper Company Over Historic House
DOC.TEXT: The house where Gen. Robert E. Lee planned an attack on Union troops to save the Confederate capital has become the center of a new battle: Preservationists are fighting a newspaper publisher who wants the now-crumbling structure moved. Lockwood House is a two-story, white frame plantation home where Lee spent three nights just before the Battle of Cold Harbor in Hanover County in the spring of 1864. The house rests on property purchased by Media General Inc. for a new headquarters and printing plant for its two Richmond newspapers. The site is about five miles from downtown Richmond. J. Stewart Bryan III, who is publisher of the Richmond Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader and is a member of The Associated Press Board of Directors, has offered $50,000 to help a purchaser move the house. ``It doesn't belong on that site,'' Bryan said recently, noting that the house is insect-ridden and has a rotting foundation. But 11 organizations, including the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities and the Historic Richmond Foundation, wrote to Bryan last November urging protection of the house where it is. ``Historically and architecturally, it would be devastating to move it,'' said Linda Marks, president of the Hanover County Historical Society. Bryan's great-great grandfather owned the house in downtown Richmond where Lee's family lived during the Civil War. His great-grandparents helped launch Richmond's historic preservation movement and save the White House of the Confederacy from demolition. And his father, D. Tennant Bryan, is president emeritus of the Virginia Historical Society. ``It's a simple farm house built in the early 1800s where General Lee spent two, three or four nights when he was sick with a high fever. Since then, nobody was interested in the house until we bought it,'' said Bryan. While at Lockwood House, Lee planned an interception of Union troops that slowed the North's advance on Richmond. He also was visited there by Confederate President Jefferson Davis. The house does not stand exactly where the newspapers' planned $200 million production plant will be built, but Bryan said the plant, slated for completion in 1991, would ``overshadow it, overpower it.'' During an open house viewing for potential buyers earlier this month, at least 20 prospects showed up, and about a dozen more have expressed interest in buying the structure, Bryan said. ``We don't care about dollar offers,'' he said. ``We just want to see it put to good use.''
DOC.HEAD: New Jersey Governor Responds to Article
DOC.TEXT: Want to get the governor's attention? Slam New Jersey. Ellen Emry Heltzel, an editor at The Oregonian in Portland, Ore., made a disparaging reference to the Garden State and got a three-page rebuttal from Jim Florio. ``I believe you overlooked the magnificent splendors of New Jersey, of which there are many,'' Florio says in the April 16 letter to Ms. Heltzel, editor of the newspaper's Northwest Magazine. In the March 4 issue of the newspaper's Sunday magazine, Ms. Heltzel, promoting a new monthly feature on ``out-of-the-way'' Oregon attractions, lamented a homogenization she said could ``leave us indistinguishable from, heaven forbid, New Jersey.'' Carol Keene of Marmora was in Oregon when the barb appeared. Irked, she sent Florio a copy. The governor sent a virtual tourist brochure rebutting fallacies and extolling the Jersey Shore, the Kittatinny Mountains, the Highlands and other points of interest. Nothing personal, Ms. Heltzel said in an interview April 18. ``I didn't create the myth. I was just fueling it,'' she said. ``New Jersey is the victim of a lot of mythology. ... You think of problems ... a lot of oil refineries.'' Ms. Heltzel noted that she found the Jersey Shore lovely, though somewhat flat compared with Oregon's rugged coast. She says her criticism was partly a friendly prod at Oregonian Publisher Fred Stickel, who was born in Weehawken. But New Jersey got it again in the April 18 Oregonian. Columnist Jonathan Nicholas, voicing disgust with fake bookshelves, suggested that any Oregon designer who uses one ``should immediately be arrested and shipped to Newark.''
DOC.HEAD: Eastern European Journalists To Visit U.S. Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: Journalists from three eastern European countries will get a practical look at the workings of American newspapers under six-month competitive fellowships to be offered by Times Mirror, the media company announced April 16. The company said reporters and publishing executives from Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary will be assigned to regular reporting beats and management duties. ``Our hope and expectation is that our own newspapers will benefit from this kind of exposure to journalists for whom a `free press' is still a revolutionary concept,'' said Robert F. Erburu, chairman and chief executive officer of Times Mirror. ``We further hope that these journalists will find their experiences in American-style reporting and publishing techniques useful when they return to the newly independent newspapers of eastern Europe,'' he said. The European journalists, who are to have varying levels of experience, will be assigned to slots at the Los Angeles Times, Newsday, The Baltimore Sun and Evening Sun, The Hartford Courant, The Morning Call in Allentown, Pa., and the (Stamford) Advocate and Greenwich Times in Connecticut. The program is to be managed by the Times Mirror Center for The People and The Press located in Washington.
DOC.HEAD: Life Magazine Changes Logo Color for Earth Day
DOC.TEXT: Life magazine's red and white logo is turning green in May to commemorate Earth Day. It's only the second time in the magazine's 53-year history that it has changed the colors. The only other time was when it appeared in black in 1963 after President Kennedy's assassination. The May issue includes several articles about the environment, including a cover story on trees. Earth Day was April 22.
DOC.HEAD: Afternoon Paper Switching to Morning Publication
DOC.TEXT: The Springdale News will shift from afternoon publication to morning beginning May 1 and will be called The Morning News. General Manager Gene Kincy said the change reflects an industry shift to morning publication, which he said allows news to be delivered faster.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Leifeld Named Executive Editor
DOC.TEXT: Ellen Leifeld, managing editor of the Lansing State Journal, was named executive editor of the Battle Creek Enquirer on April 18. Leifeld succeeds David M. Smith, who resigned to pursue other interests, Publisher Bob Miller Jr. said. Leifeld has been a senior news executive at the 71,000-circulation Lansing newspaper since September 1988. She joined the Journal in July 1986. The Enquirer publishes evenings Monday through Friday and morning editions on Saturday and Sunday. It has a daily circulation of about 30,000. The Enquirer and the State Journal are owned by Gannett Co. Inc. There was no immediate announcement of Leifeld's successor at Lansing.
DOC.HEAD: King Named Regional Vice President
DOC.TEXT: Van King, personnel manager of the Greensboro (N.C.) News & Record, was named April 19 as a regional vice president of Landmark Community Newspapers Inc. He will also be general manager of the tri-weekly Lancaster News. King worked as a reporter for The Item in Sumpter and as a reporter, columnist and editor in Greensboro. The appointment takes effect in early May.
DOC.HEAD: Gibson Named Executive Editor
DOC.TEXT: Malcolm D. Gibson, editor of The Times-News in Hendersonville, N.C., will move to The Gainesville Sun as executive editor June 1. Gibson has been a reporter and news editor at the Florida paper. He succeeds Diane McFarlin, who is moving to the Sarasota Herald-Tribune as executive editor. Gibson also worked previously at The Miami Herald, Tampa Tribune, The Ledger in Lakeland and The Associated Press.
DOC.HEAD: Whitin Moves at Worcester Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: Harry T. Whitin, managing editor of the Sunday Telegram, moved to its sister newspaper, the Telegram & Gazette, as managing editor for news April 20. Whitin replaces Lincoln R. McKie Jr., who will remain as a consultant to the newspaper. William T. Clew replaces Whitin as managing editor of the Sunday Telegram.
DOC.HEAD: Rust Named Educational Services Director
DOC.TEXT: Joe Carroll Rust, associate editor of the San Antonio Light, has been named the paper's educational services director and will head its Newspapers in Education program, to be initiated this summer. Publisher George B. Irish said April 19 that Rust also will coordinate a citywide literacy project for the newspaper.
DOC.HEAD: APSE Great Plains Region Elects Officers
DOC.TEXT: Steve Koehler, sports editor of The News-Leader in Springfield, was elected to a two-year term April 17 as chairman of the Great Plains Region of the Associated Press Sports Editors. Stan Johnston, sports editor of the St. Louis Sun, was elected vice chairman during the two-day spring workshop hosted by the group, which attracted about 60 people from 40 newspapers in Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska and Oklahoma. Koehler and Johnston took over leadership of the group from Ralph Routon of the Colorado Springs Gazette Telegraph, the outgoing chairman, and Sherry Johnson of The Wichita Eagle, who is moving to The Miami Herald as an assistant sports editor. The national AP Sports Editors convention will be held June 26 to July 1 in Boston.

Jack D. Burson, who covered police and courts for the Progress Bulletin of Pomona for more than 30 years, died April 14 at age 62. Burson worked for the City News Bureau of Chicago after studying journalism at Northwestern University. He joined the Progress Bulletin in 1953 as a sports writer but soon switched to the police and court beats. He received the Governor's Crime Prevention Award for the media in 1985. Survivors include his wife, Nancy, and two daughters.

John Worth Cloud, a longtime newspaperman, poet and former president of the Texas Historical Association, died April 16 at age 81. Cloud was a former reporter for the Chicago Daily News and had published several weekly newspapers. His poem, ``The Legend of Old Stone Ranch,'' was named the best publication of 1968 on local and regional history by the Texas State Historical Survey Committee. He is survived by his wife, Josie Herrington Cloud, one son and two daughters.

Brian Hogben, a senior executive with Rupert Murdoch's News Limited media group, died April 19 at age 64 after a long illness. He began his career as a intern on the Sydney Daily Mirror at age 17. He later became editor of that paper, as well as of the Sydney Daily Telegraph. Hogben, group general manager (editorial) of News Limited, also served on the company's board of directors. News Limited is the Australian corporate entity of Murdoch's international News Corp. Ltd. He is survived by his wife, Peg, two daughters and two sons.

A. Alfred Marcello, former executive news editor of the Worcester Telegram & The Evening Gazette, died April 14 at the age of 85. He began his newspaper career as a reporter in 1923 with the Providence News, where he eventually became assistant managing editor. Marcello was city editor of the Telegram from 1949 to 1966, when he was named executive news editor of the Telegram & The Evening Gazette. He left the newspaper business in 1971 to enter public relations. Survivors include two sisters.

Boston University Professor James P. O'Donnell, author of a best-selling account of the final days of Hitler and a former European bureau chief for Newsweek, died of cancer April 16. He was 72. O'Donnell was working on his second book about Hitler, to be titled ``The Hitler Court,'' at the time of his death at Brigham and Women's Hospital. O'Donnell was chief of bureau of Newsweek in Berlin from 1945-1948, later was Paris correspondent for The New York Daily News and associate editor for Europe for the Saturday Evening Post. His book, ``The Bunker,'' was a bestseller in 1978. He is survived by his estranged wife and two sisters.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Chronicle Cited for Service to First Amendment
DOC.TEXT: The San Francisco Chronicle has been named winner of the Scripps Howard Foundation National Journalism Award for service to the First Amendment. The foundation on April 18 commended the newspaper and Sunday Punch section editor Peter Sussman for publishing the writings of a convict-journalist and then defending their right to do so. Inmate Dannie Martin's writings led to the release of an unjustly sentenced man and a review of medical treatment received by convicts, the judges noted. ``The effort of the Chronicle and Sussman not only has helped illuminate the workings of America's prisons, institutions often overlooked by the press, it has emphasized the important principle that to deny an inmate the right to report about what he experiences is to violate the First Amendment rights of all Americans,'' the judges said. Finalists included The Kentucky Post, Covington, Ky.; The Milwaukee Journal; and the Richmond (Va.) Times-Dispatch. The Chronicle received $2,500 and a bronze plaque. The newspaper was among 14 winners in print and broadcast journalism who shared $41,000 in cash prizes presented at the foundation's National Journalism Awards banquet in Cincinnati. Staff members from eight newspapers, three television stations, two radio stations and one college cartoonist were recognized for their efforts. The Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram received the foundation's award for public service among newspapers with more than 100,000 circulation for its investigation of former U.S. House Speaker Jim Wright; finalists included The Courier Journal of Louisville, Ky.; Newsday of Long Island, N.Y., and the San Francisco Examiner. The Charleston (W.Va.) Gazette was the winner among papers with less than 100,000 circulation for its 31-part series on the economic plight of West Virginia; finalists included The Ledger of Lakeland, Fla.; Mail Tribune of Medford, Ore.; The Patriot Ledger of Quincy, Mass.; and The Salina (Kan.) Journal. Ann Daly Goodwin of the St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch won the top award for editorial writing. Finalists included W. Russell G. Byers of the Philadelphia Daily News; Samuel T. Francis of The Washington (D.C.) Times; and Michael Lacey of New Times, Phoenix, Ariz. For environmental journalism, The Boston Globe received the top award among newspapers with more than 100,000 circulation for its report of unrestricted industrial development in Eastern Europe; finalists included David White of The Birmingham (Ala.) News; Tom Harris of The Sacramento (Calif.) Bee; and Eric Nalder of The Seattle Times. Sam Atwood of The Sun of San Bernadino, Calif., took first place among newspapers with less than 100,000 circulation for his report on county pollution; The Press Democrat of Santa Rosa, Calif., was a finalist, and special recognition was given The Albuquerque Tribune and The Bay City (Mich.) Times. The foundation's National Journalism Award for commitment to literacy, broadcast division, went to WFSB-TV of Hartford, Conn., for a program about adult illiteracy. The newspaper division award went to The San Antonio Light for a series of articles on literacy efforts in the community; finalists included The Kentucky Post, Covington, Ky.; and The Patriot Ledger of Quincy, Mass. Columnist Rose Post, a 40-year veteran of The Salisbury (N.C.) Post, was honored for her human interest writing. Finalists included Mike Kelly of The Record of Hackensack, N.J.; and Dan Carpenter of The Indianapolis Star. WSM Radio in Nashville, Tenn., received the foundation's National Journalism Award for excellence in broadcast journalism, large market radio category, for its crime prevention series. KWTO Radio in Springfield, Mo., was the winner in the small market category for its investigation of a county deputy sheriff. WCBS-TV in New York received the award for excellence in journalism in large market television for its focus on street drug trafficking; WFAA-TV of Dallas, Texas, was a finalist. KARK-TV of Little Rock, Ark., won the award for small market television for its program about an outdoor learning place for disadvantaged children; WJXT-TV of Jacksonville, Fla., was a finalist. Nick Anderson of The Ohio State Lantern in Columbus, Ohio, received the foundation's National Journalism Award for college cartoonists. Finalists included Bill Costello of the University of Maryland, David Luebke of Creighton University and Jay Ramsey Carr of Stephen F. Austin State University.

Cable News Network founder Ted Turner says he expects to lose $10 million on this year's Goodwill Games _ compared with $26 million in the games' 1986 debut in Moscow ... Former NBC News President Lawrence Grossman says the public is increasingly relying on public broadcasting to fill a news void left by the networks. In-depth, provocative broadcasts characteristic of Edward R. Murrow in the industry's past are no longer common, he says: ``I think the Murrow legacy in many ways is a legacy of dedication, really outstanding public service news presentation. It's an endangered species.''
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: The first American released by pro-Iranian Lebanese captors in nearly 3{ years, a frail-looking Robert Polhill, walked slowly off a plane today after winning freedom with the aid of Syria and Iran. The 55-year-old educator's release Sunday after 1,182 days of captivity was followed by a reported call by Iran's foreign minister for a swift reciprocal move _ freedom for a Shiite Moslem cleric kidnapped by Israeli troops in July. Polhill arrived here on a U.S. Air Force plane, then was taken by helicopter to a U.S. military hospital in nearby Wiesbaden, where he was to undergo a medical examination and debriefing by U.S. intelligence agents. President Bush thanked Iran and Syria _ whose military forces in Lebanon picked up Polhill in west Beirut and drove him to the Syrian capital of Damascus _ for their help in securing the release. But the president said he would make no deals with the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants in Lebanon still holding 17 Western hostages, seven of them Americans.

An estimated 200 million people all over the planet celebrated the 20th anniversary of Earth Day. Activists pleaded for the rise of a new ``conservation generation'' to care for the fragile environment. Even as a hot air balloon representing the Earth rose in Times Square and tens of thousands demonstrated at the U.S. Capitol on Sunday, some worried about sustaining interest in the environment so that it becomes more than a fad. ``Earth Day is primarily a light we turn on so that we can see the work. The work is still yet to be done,'' said novelist Wallace Stegner, who led a pledge of allegiance to the Earth in Palo Alto, Calif., where Earth Day has its headquarters. More than 100,000 people massed at the foot of the Capitol in Washington, and the event was celebrated in more than 3,600 U.S. communities and in 140 other nations, according to organizers. Environmentalists collected tons of garbage from Japanese beaches, sculpted a giant thermometer from a French glacier to protest global warming and carried a globe on a stretcher, symbolizing a sick Earth, in a parade in Hong Kong's twin city of Kowloon.

Mario Bonilla was traveling outside Nicaragua in 1981 when he was tried for promoting human rights. He never returned home after learning he had been sentenced to 23 years in prison for counterrevolutionary activities. Like an estimated 150,000 other Nicaraguan professionals, Bonilla, a doctor, fled to South Florida to escape the leftist Sandinista regime of Daniel Ortega. But now that the euphoria of Violeta Chamorro's upset presidential victory over Ortega in February has subsided, the professionals Nicaragua needs desperately are weighing a return carefully _ and many are choosing not to go back. Some of the reasons are financial. But much of the concern is over the role the defeated Sandinistas will play after the new government is sworn in Wednesday and how those returning will be treated. ``We are afraid,'' said Bonilla, president of the Nicaraguan Medical Association in Exile. ``(The Sandinistas) are in the same place with the same weapons. There are only some changes in the administrative area at this moment.''

Several environmental organizations at the forefront of Earth Day celebrations are under fire from a seemingly unrelated group planning its own march on the Capitol next weekend _ the National Right to Life Committee. The anti-abortion leaders are asking members to withhold support from environmental groups they regard as pro-abortion. Among those on the list: the Sierra Club, the National Audubon Society and the National Wildlife Federation. They also are criticizing the League of Conservation Voters, the environmental movement's major political action committee, for including ``abortion-related votes'' on its 1989 congressional scorecard. Douglas Johnson, Right to Life's legislative director, said the listed groups are trying to overturn ``major pro-life policies.'' But Ali Webb, director of elections for the League of Conservation Voters, said her organization was targeted because it advocates family planning. ``They (Right to Life) represent a point of view that family planning is not an appropriate arena for environmental action. But if something isn't done, the world population will double in the next 37 years,'' Webb said.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, May 5, the 125th day of 1990. There are 240 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: On May 5, 1920, two Italian anarchists, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti were arrested and charged with the murders of a shoe factory paymaster and guard in South Braintree, Mass. Their execution more than seven years later was preceded by worldwide sympathy demonstrations. On this date: In 1494, during his second voyage to the New World, Christopher Columbus first sighted Jamaica. In 1818, the political philosopher Karl Marx was born in Prussia. In 1821, Napoleon Bonaparte died in exile on the island of St. Helena. In 1891, Carnegie Hall, originally named Music Hall, had its opening night in New York City, with a concert that included works conducted by Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky and Walter Damrosch. In 1904, Cy Young pitched the American League's first perfect game as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Philadelphia Athletics, 3-0. In 1912, the first issue of the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda was published. In the Soviet Union, where the old-style calendar was still in effect, the date was April 22. In 1925, John T. Scopes was arrested in Tennessee for teaching Darwin's theory of evolution. In 1926, author Sinclair Lewis rejected the Pulitzer Prize for his novel ``Arrowsmith,'' telling the selection committee in a letter that ``all prizes, like all titles, are dangerous.'' In 1942, sugar rationing began in the United States during World War II. In 1955, West Germany became a sovereign state. In 1955, the baseball musical ``Damn Yankees'' opened on Broadway. In 1961, astronaut Alan B. Shepard Jr. became America's first space traveler when he made a 15-minute sub-orbital flight in a capsule launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla. In 1981, Irish Republican Army hunger-striker Bobby Sands died at the Maze Prison in Northern Ireland in his 66th day without food. In 1987, the congressional Iran-Contra hearings opened with former Air Force Major Gen. Richard V. Secord the lead-off witness. In 1987, the federal government began a yearlong amnesty program, offering citizenship to illegal aliens who met certain conditions. In 1988, the Most Rev. Eugene Antonio Marino became the nation's first black Roman Catholic archbishop during an installation Mass in the Atlanta Civic Center. Ten years ago: A siege at the Iranian embassy in London ended as British commandos and police stormed the building. Five years ago: President Reagan kept a promise to West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl by leading a wreath-laying ceremony at the military cemetery in Bitburg. One year ago: A federal judge ordered sweeping changes in the FBI's promotion system, months after the judge found that the bureau had systematically discriminated against its Hispanic employees in advancements and assignments. Today's birthdays: Actress Alice Faye is 75. Singer Tammy Wynette is 48. Comedian-actor Michael Palin is 47. Actor Jean-Pierre Leaud is 46. Actress Tina Yothers is 17. Thought for today: ``Outside the kingdom of the Lord there is no nation which is greater than any other.'' _ Haile Selassie, Emperor of Ethiopia (1891-1975)

For Release PMs Tues April 24 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Nixon on Gorbachev: `The Most Remarkable Statesman of Our Time'
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In thumbnail appraisal, the man is described as a consummate pragmatic politician, a leader who likes power and will do what is necessary to keep it. That aim is said to have been the major influence in shaping his drastic political, economic and foreign policy moves. The description comes from Richard M. Nixon, and it sounds as though the ex-president is looking in the mirror. But it is not a self-portrait, it is his judgment of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, ``the most remarkable statesman of our time.'' The Nixon comments on Gorbachev in a new book, an undelivered speech and a public television interview are a blend of admiration for the Soviet leader's ability and style, and suspicion of his aims. ``Despite what you may hear, that he could be a closet democrat or even a closet Christian ... Gorbachev is in fact a true-believing communist,'' Nixon says. ``His goal is not to abandon communism, but to save it ... not to dismantle the Soviet empire but to preserve it, as demonstrated by the hard line he is taking on Lithuanian independence. ``But the most dominant facet of his complex personality is that he is a consummate pragmatic politician who likes power, knows how to use it, and will do what is necessary to keep it,'' says Nixon, who lost his own in 1974 when he resigned to avoid impeachment over Watergate. ``It is this characteristic which has primarily influenced his decisions to adopt his revolutionary political, economic and foreign policy reforms.'' Nixon made those comments in a speech he was to have delivered to the Boston World Affairs Council, postponed after he was diagnosed as suffering from a heart rhythm problem. Nixon, 77, is recuperating at home in Saddle River, N.J., and is expected to resume his normal schedule in about a week. In that text and his newly published eighth book, ``In The Arena,'' Nixon's comments about the Soviet leader sometimes parallel his observations about his own career _ 44 years in office, in resignation and political disgrace, and in what he now calls renewal. ``He is a world class strategic thinker,'' says Nixon _ neither saint nor a softheaded do-gooder but a skilled, adroit operator in his own and his nation's interests. Reflecting on his own foreign policy in a Public Broadcasting System interview to be broadcast May 4, Nixon says his course of detente toward Moscow ``wasn't softheaded negotiation'' but calculated to serve U.S. objectives. ``The detente strategy, hardheaded detente, that I pursued, worked,'' he said. He describes his single most dramatic foreign policy move, the 1972 mission that reopened U.S. links with China, in similar terms. He says it had nothing to do with any softening of his opposition to communism. ``It had to do with strategic relationships.'' Politically, Nixon says, Gorbachev's reforms do not meet American standards, but have meant breathtaking change in the Soviet Union. ``After having had their voices stilled for over 70 years, the great silent majority of the Russian people are finally being heard,'' he says. That is a special phrase for Nixon; as a candidate and in his early White House years he appealed for, and claimed support from ``the great silent majority of my fellow Americans.'' Nixon calls Gorbachev ``the most intelligent and creative leader in Soviet history'' _ and also the most powerful since Stalin. He says the instincts of the pragmatic politician led Gorbachev to his attempted reforms at home and to acquiescence in the wave of democratic change that swept Eastern Europe. Simply put, Nixon says, ``he had no choice but to reform at home and to retrench abroad.'' He argues that it will not serve U.S. interests to help Gorbachev if that produces an economically stronger Soviet Union that continues to aid anti-American regimes in the Third World. He says those Moscow subsidies still amount to $15 billion a year in arms and economic aid, and challenges Gorbachev to end them as part of the price of U.S. trade, credits and technology. Still, as an athlete warily praises a rival, Nixon praises Gorbachev, ``a world class strategic thinker'' and a wily leader who will survive the perils around him. ``I think he will make it,'' Nixon says, ``because he is a very capable and shrewd politician. And his political instincts will make him land on his feet even though the problems are infinitely great.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

CLEAN WATER
The court rejected a chemical company's challenge to federal standards for clean water. The court, without comment, left intact rules that govern more than 1,000 factories producing organic chemicals, plastics and synthetic fibers. The case is PPG Industries vs. Environmental Protection Agency, 89-1079.
AMISH
The court raised the possibility that Minnesota officials may enforce a traffic safety law against certain members of an Amish sect in rural Fillmore County. The court set aside a Minnesota Supreme Court ruling that barred such enforcement. The justices told the state court to reconsider the case in light of their decision last week allowing states to outlaw the religious use of the illegal drug peyote. The case is Minnesota vs. Hershberger, 89-804.

For Release Wednesday AMs, April 25, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Justice Brennan Turns 84
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court's nine members are among the most private of public officials. They wield enormous power, but rarely hold news conferences or give interviews. Recent polls indicate only one in three Americans can name any of the nine. This, the seventh in an occasional series, offers an up-to-date look at a member of the nation's highest court.

He's 84 now, a passionate liberal on an increasingly conservative Supreme Court. His health is not the best, but William J. Brennan says he is having too much fun to retire. ``I'm still enjoying myself. Nothing possibly could be as satisfying,'' he told The Associated Press in an interview days before his 84th birthday Wednesday. ``I've been having some bad health of late. I had that doggone attack (in March) that started, I thought, as influenza (now thought to have been a more serious bronchial infection). They gave me some antibiotics and I had a bad reaction, lost a lot of weight,'' Brennan said. ``They told me it might be as long as three months before I finally get fully recovered from it.'' But retire? ``If I can keep on the way I am, I'm going to stay,'' he said. His stay to date has lasted 34 years and transcended the administrations of eight presidents. In the court's history, only one justice _ William O. Douglas _ wrote more opinions. Only three court members served at more advanced ages _ Oliver Wendell Holmes at 91, Roger Taney at 87, and Hugo Black at 85. Few have written with such literary grace and eloquence. Appointed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower, Brennan helped lead a liberal revolution in American law through the 1960s. The protection of individual rights was elevated to new heights. Some called Brennan an ideologue and an activist. Some called him a champion of the underdog. In a 1987 law school speech, he said, ``When I think of the progress we have made over the last 30 years, I look upon our system of civil liberties with some satisfaction and a certain pride.'' Gradually, his role changed. Ronald Reagan's legacy _ three key court appointments _ has left Brennan often outmanned in his fight against a nascent conservative counter-revolution. ``In recent years, the other side has pretty much carried the day,'' Brennan said. ``That strikes me as nothing to be surprised about. After all, the president fills the vacancies.'' In a recent interview published in New Yorker magazine, Brennan was quoted as saying, ``I'm not discouraged to the point of giving up. I hope people don't overdo the suggestion that we're headed for perdition.'' He added: ``I'm not going to walk out and say the hell with it.'' Even in recent years, Brennan has registered major successes. Some of them prompted Daniel Popeo of the conservative Washington Legal Foundation to state, ``Unfortunately, I think the man is extremely intelligent. He's been a key player now under three chief justices. He deserves professional respect.'' Brennan told AP of one possible exception to his resolve against retirement: ``If the Good Lord steps in and something happens that I wouldn't be able to carry on.'' ``I have a pledge from my wife that the day she notices it she'll tell me, so I'll act accordingly,'' he said. ``I think it would be so wrong to stay here unless you're fully able to do your job. Too much rides on what we do around here.'' Among the more than 1,200 opinions written by Brennan are landmarks that imposed a ``one person, one vote'' standard for electing state legislatures, created constitutional protections for libel lawsuit defendants, and helped invent a legal definition of obscenity. New York University law professor Burt Neuborne, evaluating Brennan's opinions and his contribution to the justices' deliberations, once called him the most influential Supreme Court member since John Marshall, the great chief justice of the early 19th Century. The comment makes Brennan wince. ``Honestly, that's so overstated, so overdrawn. Even the greats of the past _ Holmes, Brandeis _ they'd never stand for such a claim,'' he said. But retired Justice Lewis F. Powell, for 15 years Brennan's colleague, said in a recent interview, ``I have no doubt he will have a high ranking among the court's members. Bill is one of history's great justices.'' Although far more conservative than Brennan in his judicial views, Powell said their professional differences ``never impaired our friendship. He is a man of great personal warmth.'' Reminded of his reputation as a skilled behind-the-scenes coalition builder, Brennan took exception. ``I don't know who invented that. You know damn well it's not true,'' he said. ``You do your best, and as often as not when you end up with a majority it reflects many ideas of your colleagues and not only yours.'' He said the court's members persuade each other in written memos, not in backroom deals or smoke-filled meetings. A sample of Brennan's writing style, and perhaps his power of persuasion, was displayed in a speech he wrote to celebrate the Constitution's 200th birthday. ``Our entire Constitution is a national treasure; a document of heady ideals and eloquent, elegant language; a political landmark for individual rights,'' he wrote. ``But one thing the old parchment is not is a china doll that has to be protected from the regular world by a good layer of cotton wool. It is a tough old soldier that's collected quite a few respectable dents in the line of duty.''

DOC.HEAD: Taft Proud of Family Name But Trying To Establish Own Identity
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Robert Taft II, whose family produced a president and two U.S. senators with careers spanning most of this century, has found that being a Taft is not what it used to be. The 48-year-old lawyer, serving his third four-year term as a Hamilton County commissioner in Cincinnati, abandoned his bid to become Ohio's next governor in February after disappointing showings in the polls. He said his aborted try for the Republican gubernatorial nomination made him understand that he needs to become better known to younger voters. ``Among those who knew me, the reaction was positive,'' Taft said. ``But there was a number who didn't know the family name. Among those who knew the name, many don't know who I am.'' Taft is now running unopposed in the May 8 GOP primary for secretary of state, leaving former Cleveland Mayor George Voinovich unopposed for the GOP gubernatorial nomination. It has been 20 years since a Taft won a statewide election, although the family name was on the ballot in 1976, 1982 and 1986. James Wray, political director for the White House, said that while the Taft family made ``a tremendous contribution'' to the GOP and the nation, Taft will have to work to increase his name recognition. ``He's going to have to get out there and identify himself,'' Wray said. James Ruvolo, Ohio's Democratic chairman, said Taft is not well known outside of Cincinnati. ``The name is not the drawing card it once was,'' Ruvolo said. Taft quit the governor's race after party contributors balked at funding a costly battle between him and Voinovich. His switch to the secretary of state's race will pit him in November against two-term incumbent Democrat Sherrod Brown, who is unopposed in his party's primary. Voinovich, state Chairman Robert Bennett and other party leaders praised Taft as a team player whose willingness to change races reflected his family's party loyalty. Taft's father, Robert Jr., served three terms in the U.S. House before his election to the Senate in 1970. He was defeated in a re-election bid in 1976. Robert Jr.'s father, Robert A., was known as ``Mr. Republican'' while serving in the Senate from 1939 to 1953. He sought the GOP presidential nomination in 1952 against Dwight Eisenhower. William Howard Taft, father of Robert A. and great-grandfather of Robert Taft II, served from 1909 to 1913 as the 27th president and then became U.S. chief justice. In 1982, Seth Taft of Cleveland, a businessman and distant cousin of Robert Jr., ran for the GOP nomination for governor, finishing second in a field of four. Robert Taft II became involved in politics when he helped his father get elected to the Senate. He served in the Peace Corps and was a State Department aide in Vietnam. Taft served in the Ohio House for two terms, from 1976 to 1980. He ran for lieutenant governor in 1986 as the running mate of former four-term Gov. James A. Rhodes, who tried to make a comeback at age 77 but lost to Democratic incumbent Gov. Richard Celeste. ``I think I got some visibility in 1986, but Rhodes was the issue,'' Taft said. ``It was difficult to emerge clearly.'' Last year, Taft decided to head his own ticket in the race to succeed Celeste, who ends his second consecutive four-year term in January and is barred by law from seeking a third. Taft announced his candidacy in June and insisted through most of the year that he was in the race to stay. ``But among a lot of voters, particularly, maybe younger voters, maybe there wasn't a lot of awareness built up. I had never been involved on my own in a statewide campaign,'' he said. Taft's exit from the gubernatorial race sparked rumors that a deal was cut for a future party endorsement, perhaps for the U.S. Senate in 1992, when Democratic incumbent John Glenn's term expires. Taft denied having plans beyond this year. ``I think in politics, it's a mistake to look beyond the office you are seeking,'' he said.

DOC.TEXT: With the two Germanys moving toward unification, here is a chronicle of a dark period in World War II, the war that led to the division of Germany in the first place. It was 50 years ago this month that Adolf Hitler's forces blitzed across Western Europe, forcing the heroic evacuation of more than 300,000 Allied troops at Dunkirk, and France collapsed.

The stalemate in Europe ended. Sitzkrieg became blitzkrieg. Fifty years ago next Thursday, at dawn on May 10, 1940, Adolf Hitler blew the whistle and for the second time in nine months let loose the full force of his dogs of war. On the same day, almost by acclamation, Winston Churchill was called on to be prime minister of Great Britain. During the winter German forces had taken Norway and Denmark almost as military exercises, adding them to the bulging Nazi sack with Poland, Czechoslovakia and Austria. Now Hitler's targets were the Low Countries, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg, all neutrals, all assured repeatedly of Germany's peaceful intent. In five days he leveled Rotterdam and crushed Holland, sending Queen Wilhemina and the Dutch government into exile in Britain. But Holland was only a battle in passing. His steel phalanxes, spearheaded by Stuka dive bombers and paratroopers, next turned to Belgium, having breached the steep banks of the Meuse. Across four bridgeheads poured an armored assault the likes of which Europe had never seen before. German tanks in three columns a hundred miles long roared and clanked through Sedan, shattering two French armies in a dash toward the English Channel, cleaving the Allied forces in half, trapping the best of the British and French divisions in Belgium to the north. Tactically, the Germans uncorked one innovation after another. Special task forces were assigned specific targets, fortresses and bridges, and delivered by parachute and glider. For this they had practiced on replica targets in Germany the previous winter. The formidable Fort Eben Emael was a case in point. It was the strongest fortress in all of Europe, a steel and concrete bastion dug deep into Belgian soil, heavily armored with gun turrets and manned by 1,200 men. The German assault was mounted by a task force of 80 men, commanded by a sergeant and borne to the fort by nine gliders that landed on the roof. Specially made hollow explosives knocked out the gun turrets, spreading gas and flame everywhere. Flamethrowers were then turned against every aperture, essentially blinding the fortress. Panzer units and dive bombers finished the job. A white flag was posted at noon of the 11th. The fortress had fallen in 30 hours. Of the 80-man task force, there were only six killed and 19 wounded. It presaged what would happen to France's vaunted Maginot Line. On the second day of the advance, German commanders felt the 15 divisions and six in reserve of the Sixth Army in the north could fend off any attack by the 24 British and French divisions and the 15 Belgian divisions facing it. To the south they greatly outnumbered the Allied forces. A week after the invasion of Holland, the German forces were rolling across undefended French countryside. Churchill was astounded to discover the French had committed all their reserves and were essentially broken. Although his generals were confident, Hitler himself was a bundle of nerves. He expected a French counterattack that would isolate his armies. His caution was clearly uncalled for. He authorized a ``reconnaisance in force'' and with that permission seven armored divisions pressed westward and by May 19 were only 50 miles from the Channel. The next day the Second Panzer Division had reached the mouth of the Somme River and the British Expeditionary Force, three French armies and the Belgians were trapped, 40 divisions in all. The formerly worried Hitler was overjoyed. Then came an incredible series of events. The French chose this moment to change commanders and precious time was lost, leaving little chance to move south and break out of the German circle of fire and steel. By the 24th the Allies had their backs to the Channel. The Germans were in sight of Dunkirk. Evacuation by sea was the only option left. Then, at the edge of victory, Hitler ordered his panzers to stop, probably in a bow to the Luftwaffe and Hermann Goering who wanted his Heinkels and Messerschmitts to finish the Allies off. Or perhaps he thought of conserving his army. The British, smelling defeat, had been gathering all kinds of boats, anything that could make it across the Channel. Churchill ordered all non-combatants taken off first. Meanwhile, the Belgians, holding the northern rim of the Dunkirk peimeter, were beginning to weaken.

DOC.TEXT: On the evening of May 26, the British ordered up the hastily designed Operation Dynamo. The first British troops, most of them from heavily hit divisions, were home that night, plucked from port and beach by the makeshift flotilla. The British searched boatyards for motorboats and launches, yanked lifeboats from liners at London docks, mobilized tugs from the Thames, and called into service barges and pleasure craft, fishing boats and small coastal steamers. On the night of May 27, this second fleet headed toward Dunkirk. In all, 400 small vessels joined the British Navy, an armada that eventually numbered 860 craft. Churchill noticed that some of his own staff were mysteriously absent as all of England established a lifeline to its stricken troops. At first, the huddled British and French were pummeled by the Luftwaffe, but gradually the Royal Air Force eroded their numbers. Wrote Churchill, ``To and from between the shore and the ships plied the little boats gathering the men from the beaches as they waded out or picking them from the water, with total indifference to the air bombardment...Their numbers alone defied air attack. The Mosquito Armada as a whole was unsinkable. In the midst of our defeat, glory came to the Island people, united and unconquerable.'' It continued until June 4, beyond the point anyone thought the rear guard could hold out. In the end, more than 338,000 troops were rescued, including 60,000 of the 100,000 French. Left on the beaches and docks of Dunkirk were 7,000 tons of ammunition, 90,000 rifles, 2,300 artillery pieces, 82,000 vehicles, 8,000 Bren guns and 400 anti-tank rifles. But the men were saved to fight again. To re-arm them, the United States went to its military warehouses and sold the defeated Allies 500,000 World War I rifles, 900 French 75 field guns and 80,000 machine guns. It left the arsenal of democracy with weaponry for only 1.8 million men. While the Dunkirk evacuation proceeded, King Leopold III, against the advice of his government and with the shortest possible notice to his Allies, surrendered Belgium to the Germans on May 28. On June 5, the day after Dunkirk fell, Hitler turned his full attention to the 65 French divisions and less than two British divisions in the south. To that task he unleashed 143 divisions, 10 of them armored. On June 10, the French government fled to Bordeaux and four days later German troops raised the swastika over the Eiffel Tower. The French asked for armistice, but Hitler said he would have to consult first with Italian dictator Benito Mussolini, who now felt he could join the party. On June 11, he ordered his 32 divisions to attack on the Alpine front. After a week of fighting they had not been able to advance against six French divisions. On the afternoon of June 21, at Compiegne where the Germans had surrendered to the Allies in World War I, William L. Shirer, author of ``The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich,'' watched as Hitler read the inscription on the memorial plaque that said: ``Here on the eleventh of November 1918 succumbed the criminal pride of the German Empire _ vanquished by the free peoples which it tried to enslave.'' About Hitler on that day, Shirer wrote, ``I have seen that face many times at the great moments of his life. But today! It is afire with scorn, anger, hate, revenge, triumph ... Suddenly, as though his face were not giving quite complete expression to his feelings, he throws his whole body into harmony with his mood. He swiftly snaps his hands on his hips, arches his shoulders, plants his feet wide apart. It is a magnificent gesture of defiance, of burning contempt for this place now and all that it has stood for in the 22 years since it witnessed the humbling of the German Empire.'' Seventeen days earlier, before the House of Commons, as the Dunkirk evacuation ended, Churchill directed himself to the free world in a one-sentence pledge that will never be forgotten: ``Even though large tracts of Europe and many old and famous states have fallen or may fall into the grip of the Gestapo and all the odious apparatus of Nazi rule, we shall not flag or fail, we shall go on to the end, we shall fight in France, we shall fight in the seas and oceans, we shall fight with growing confidence and growing strength in the air, we shall defend our island whatever the cost may be, we shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender, and even if, which I don't for a moment believe, this island or a large part of it were subjugated or starving, then our Empire beyond the seas, armed and guarded by the British Fleet, would carry on the struggle, until, in God's good time, the New World, with all its power and might, steps forth to the rescue and liberation of the Old.''

Music Was His Comfort During Shriek of Bullets
DOC.TEXT: When Les Tyler talks about his rescue from Dunkirk, the story is told with music and tears. Tyler was a 20-year-old private in the British army in May 1940 as he waited under enemy fire and prayed for a boat to save him from the advancing German guns. He had been shot in the arm during fierce fighting near Arras, Belgium, and was sent to a medical station for evacuation. But while awaiting transport home, he was instructed to retreat to Dunkirk on foot. It was every man for himself. Burrowed between the sheltering dunes, wounded and watching other young men dying all around him, Tyler had some doubts he would survive. ``But I'm not the kind of person to give up easily,'' says Tyler, 71. ``Instead of giving up, I get a tune in my head.'' So while the bullets blazed around him and his comrades watched the sea and prayed, Tyler took out a harmonica and played. ``I played everything I knew,'' Tyler recalls. ``And the more scared I got, the harder I played. ``I played `Roll Out the Barrel,' and `Pack Up Your Troubles in an Old Kit Bag,' pieces from operettas and marching songs and, over and over, Vera Lynn's `White Cliffs of Dover.''' Often during his two-day wait, Tyler thought he'd never see the familiar cliffs again. German Stuka fighters screamed overhead, strafing and bombing the beach. Bullets struck the sand inches away. He wanted to go home. ``It just made me so angry to be stuck there only a few miles from Dover,'' he says. ``Every time a plane came over I shot at it, even though I knew it was impossible to hit with a rifle. I was just so mad.'' Just across the English Channel, a huge armada of ships large and small was assembling for the Dunkirk evacuation. ``We were told ships would come,'' he recalls. ``It was chaos. More and more men were joining us all the time. Lads were spread out along the sand as far as you could see.'' Tyler's narrative stops as his eyes fill with tears and he chokes back a sob. His wife helps fill gaps in the story. All along the road were terrified French refugees fleeing advancing German troops. ``I had been separated from my unit, the Northamptonshire Regiment,'' Tyler says. ``So while I was with a crowd on the road and beach, I was all alone and knew no one.'' Toward dusk at the end of the second day, the Little Ships finally appeared on the horizon. ``I thought: `Thank God.''' But it was still a long while before he set sail for home. He spent hours standing in neck-deep waves. A short man, Tyler had trouble keeping head above water. He lost his rifle. Some men gave up in exhaustion, sank and drowned. German planes continued their murderous fire. Long after dark, Tyler finally was pulled aboard a commercial ferry, the SS Canterbury. Later he learned that of the 1,000 men in his regiment, only 20 survived. Historians say the evacuation from Dunkirk was the key to the war, saving the lives of 338,000 men needed to fight later battles. But Tyler was sent to mine coal in Surrey for the duration of World War II. He became a railroad guard. Now retired, he is president of the Dover branch of the Dunkirk Veterans Association. Dunkirk was not Tyler's last war. He was sent to Korea, captured in the Battle of Imjim River and survived two years in the prisoner of war camp at Chong Song. ``I'm not the kind of person to give up easily, '' Tyler says.

With BC-APN--Dunkirk
Veterans and History Buffs To Mark Flotilla
DOC.TEXT: A flotilla of hundreds of vessels will sail across the English Channel in a re-enactment of the dramatic rescue of more than 300,000 Allied troops trapped on the beaches of Dunkirk 50 years ago. The voyage in late May will kick off a summer of exhibits, concerts and parties commemorating the evacuation. At least 5,000 veterans are expected in Belgium, England and France for events ranging from a quiet service in a military cemetery to a beer bash in a NATO airport hangar. A few of the veterans already are in their 90s. Some are coming from as far away as Australia. Organizers are hoping to make the commemoration worth the trip for the vets and for the thousands of history buffs and tourists who also will be on hand. ``Some people regard Dunkirk as a defeat, but for us it was the beginning of a bigger victory,'' says Lucien Pelfrene, who was 11 at the time of the evacuation and now is helping organize events in De Panne, Belgium. ``For us, these men are heroes and will be welcomed here just as they were at the liberation.'' About one-third of the 338,000 men evacuated were taken from beaches at De Panne, about 20 miles from Dunkirk. Cafe and bar owners in the Belgian resort will compete May 25 to see who can make their establishment look most like a traditional English pub. Fireworks will light the sky over the English Channel and military music will fill the air. On May 28, after a day of commemorative ceremonies at Town Hall and on the beach, veterans and their friends will dance to 1940s swing in an enormous hangar at NATO's Koksyde Airbase nearby. Fireworks, parades and concerts by military bands also are planned in Dunkirk, but the centerpiece of the commemoration will be the arrival of the so-called Little Ships. About 70 of the original boats will sail out of Dover's Wellington Docks on May 24, escorted by the modern naval frigate HMS Alacrity and hundreds of modern boats. ``Everybody who owns a boat wants to sail along,'' says Chris Lean, an organizer of the events and the director of tourism for the Dover District Council. ``It will be spectacular,'' he says. ``On a clear day you can see France from the cliffs and on that day you will see a huge flotilla of fishing boats, yachts, paddle steamers, ferries, boats of all kinds, sailing across the channel.'' The boats will dock for three days in Dunkirk. Then they will form a circle into which a helicopter will drop a wreath. Exhibition flying teams from England and France will do flyovers during the events. Dover's events will extend through July and include concerts, dances, a harborside exhibit on the evacuation, and the opening of an unusual historic site under Dover's imposing 12th century Norman castle. More than a mile of cavernous tunnels carved into the chalky White Cliffs in Napoleonic times will open to the public on May 14. Sections of these tunnels were the headquarters for Operation Dynamo, the code name for the evacuation. Visitors to the tunnels can stand on the same 500-foot high vantage point overlooking Dover Harbor where Winston Churchill looked across to his helpless troops under fire. The tunnels, begun in the early 1800s, saw their finest hour as Vice-Admiral Bertram Ramsey and his staff worked non-stop 200 feet below ground planning the miraculous nine-day evacuation.
