DOC.TEXT: History is repeating itself in Cyprus. The east Mediterranean island, which grew fabulously rich in the Middle Ages as the main link between Europe and the Orient, is becoming an international offshore banking and business center. The merchants of Cyprus in the 15th century grew so wealthy that they used to produce fruit bowls laden with diamonds and other gems for important visitors, who could choose one as a gift. Cypriot hospitality is not so lavish now. But official statistics list more than 6,000 offshore companies _ including 19 foreign banks, and numerous financial services _ based on the island, which has emerged as the principal transit point to what used to be the thriving city of Beirut, Lebanon. Many companies are there in name only, as Cyrprus provides a convenient mailing address and a way to keep a presence in a part of the world continuallly racked by war and terrorism. But nearly 700 maintain offices employing more than 3,000 people. The Central Bank said they pumped $95 million into the economy of the Greek sector of the war-divided island last year. Cyprus was divided in 1974, when the Turkish Army invaded and seized the northern one-third of the island. It is now a breakway Turkish Cypriot republic. The island has become the regional center for major news organizations, including the West's three major wire services. It also has the world's fastest growing shipping registry. Nearly 2,000 ships call Cyprus home, making it numerically the third largest fleet in the world. In terms of tonnage, it ranks seventh with a gross total of nearly 19 million tons. The island has a long way to go to catch up with Bahrain, financial center of the oil-rich Persian Gulf with 60 offshore banks. But recently banks from the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia and Jordan have set up in Cyprus and a group of 30 Japanese bankers visited the island. Cyprus got its start as a regional business hub when the civil war in Lebanon, 100 miles to the southeast, broke out in April 1975. Many Beirut-based companies relocated to Cyprus, a bonanza for the island that the year before had been ravaged by the Turkish invasion. The majority Greek Cypriots, who lost rich farmlands, tourist facilities and a major port in the invasion, had little choice but to rebuild their economy with new tourist facilities and offshore business. Tourism, lifeblood of the economy, has now reached 1.3 million visitors a year, bringing in an estimated $900 million annually for the 550,000 Greek Cypriots. It still is expanding. Hani Yamani, son of the former Saudi oil minister, Ahmet Zaki Yamani, recently announced a $300 million project for ``the most luxurious hotel in the world,'' a Greek history theme park and other facilities on 2,500 acres on Cyprus' west coast. But the focus is to build Cyprus up as a business center. It got a major boost when George Vassiliou, a self-made millionaire business consultant, was elected president in February 1988. Addressing a business seminar last month, Vassiliou said that in a small country with scant natural resources, ``the provision of services is probably the only sector of activity that we can develop steadily to provide employment and a steady increase in the standard of living of our people.'' Late last year, the Central Bank launched a campaign to attract more investment and offshore business. Central Bank Gov. Afxentis Afxentiou stressed the island's geographical position at the crossroads of Europe, Asia and Africa and its satellite communications network as advantages for businessmen. He also cited air and sea transport, banking and legal services, a skilled labor force, a low cost of living with minimal inflation and generous financial incentives _ half the normal income tax rate and one-tenth of the normal corporation tax. Other advantages are a high living standard in a society with such a low crime rate that automobiles can be left unlocked in the street. Also, most people speak English, a legacy of British colonial rule that ended with independence in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Eurotunnel Seeks Billions More To Complete Half-finished Tunnel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Alastair in 7th graf and Alistair in 11th graf are cq.
DOC.TEXT: Soaring costs are forcing Eurotunnel to seek an extra $4.1 billion from banks and investors to finish the 31-mile rail tunnel under the English Channel, the Anglo-French consortium said Monday. But Eurotunnel said it has dug half the tunnel and maintained that the historic link between England and France would open as scheduled in June 1993. When operating, Eurotunnel trains will travel from London to Paris in three hours. The consortium said higher construction and borrowing costs had pushed the project's total price tag to as high as $12.4 billion, up from $11.4 billion in October and $7.9 billion three years ago when the project was launched. The company said it would sell up to $815 million worth of new shares to existing stockholders after it completed its talks with its bankers about expanding credit facilities. Shareholders already have put up $1.63 billion and Eurotunnel's 208 banks have provided $8.2 billion in credit. The consortium said it expected to increase its total available funds to as much as $13.9 billion. ``We don't intend to go through this process again,'' Eurotunnel Deputy Chairman Alastair Morton told a news conference. The deputy chairman expressed confidence in Eurotunnel's ability to raise the extra money. Eurotunnel's shares were up the equivalent of 20 cents at $9.54 late Monday on London's Stock Exchange. The expanded credit should be in place by the end of the summer, and the share sale should take place by the end of the year, said Graham Corbett, managing director of finance. The digging has improved recently because of increased reliability of boring machines and better ground conditions, said Alistair Fleming, managing director of construction. English and French workers, digging toward each other, have bored a total of 50 miles of tunnel, he said. Eurotunnel comprises three tubes, one train tunnel for each direction, and a service tunnel which is expected to be completed this autumn. ``We will break through at the end of November,'' Fleming said. The consortium blamed the increased costs primarily on added expenses forecast by its main contractor Trans-Manche Link, which cited inflation and the need to add workers to assure that the project is completed as scheduled. Eurotunnel also cited rising interest costs as it increased borrowing. British interest rates are around 15 percent. Some of the additional costs might be slightly offset by savings from a cost-control agreement reached in January between Eurotunnel and Trans-Manche Link, Eurotunnel said. Relations between the two have been strained over cost differences. Eurotunnel said it still was in dispute with Trans-Manche over $1.1 billion in costs.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with closing figures.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices dropped Monday on London's Stock Exchange amid worries over interest rates. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 27.9 points, or 1.2 percent, to 2,159.2. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 19.9 points at 1,692.7 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 12.26 points to close at 1,173.16. Volume amounted to 382.6 million shares, compared with 410.7 million shares traded Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Protesters Snarl Wall Street, But Trading Starts On Schedule
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with arrests in San Francisco, picking up 6th graf pvs, `In New...'. SUBS last graf to add detail on charges in California. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY27
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Post-Earth Day demonstrators blocked traffic and overturned trash bins along Wall Street this morning, but trading started up normally, authorities said. More than 170 protesters were arrested and six people including five police officers were slightly injured, said police Sgt. Peter Berry. At the Pacific Stock Exchange in San Francisco, 49 people were arrested during a simultaneous demonstration of 300 to 500 protesters that turned violent when some broke windows at Bank of America, threw golf balls, rocks and eggs at police and overturned newsstands. Employees at some of the large corporations around the Pacific Stock Exchange were delayed getting to work as the demonstrators moved from one company headquarters to another. But as in New York, stock trading got under way normally, authorities said. Earth Day Wall Street Action, the group sponsoring the New York protest, said it was intended to spotlight ``institutions responsible for much of the ecological devastation which is destroying the planet.'' ``The corporate people are responsible for lending the money for much of the destruction,'' said demonstrator Ron DeChristoforo, citing disappearing forests as an example. ``All these projects have to come to a halt.'' A spokesman for the San Francisco demonstrators, Daniel Finkenthal, said their purpose was to give the public an alternative to the corporate-sponsored views of environmental action that surrounded Earth Day. Finkenthal, 23, predicted there would be an increase in environmental demonstrations and more violence in coming months and years. In New York, as many as 700 demonstrators blocked traffic and overturned trash bins before police arrived in numbers to contain the demonstration, said police spokesman Ralph St. Just. Officers closed one section of Wall Street to everyone but people showing work identification, and trading began on schedule at 9:30 a.m. ``Except for getting up a little early, it's a pretty normal day,'' said Richard Torrenzano, the exchange's senior vice president. As for the purpose of the protest, he said: ``We're all concerned about these issues in our society. But we want to make sure the exchange is open for investors throughout the world.'' A brokerage employee, Tony Concepcion, called the demonstration ``stupid. We have nothing to do with what corporations do. I agree with what they want, but this is just securities trading.'' Kathy Hinds of the National Toxics Campaign said the protest was intended to ``get a message to the folks who invest in companies who don't respect their workers or the planet and get them to divest.'' Hinds, 38, of Litchfield, Maine, said she believes the death of one of her children and illness of another was caused by her living near a superfund dump site. In New York, one of the arrested demonstrators was accused of assaulting a police officer and 172 others were charged with disorderly conduct, Berry said. In California, charges against the 49 included unlawful assembly, vandalism and battery on a police officer.

DOC.HEAD: Agrees to Review Ruling on Bank Holding Company
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to review a ruling that, if upheld, could cost a bank holding company over $13 million in damages. The court said it will decide whether First American Bankshares Inc. (FABI) violated federal securities law prior to a 1987 merger of its subsidiary Virginia Bankshares Inc. and the First American Bank of Virginia. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last Dec. 15 that FABI violated securities law by sending First American Bank of Virginia minority shareholders misleading proxy statements. Before the merger, Virginia Bankshares owned 85 percent of the stock in the First American Bank of Virginia. A merger was proposed so FABI, through its subsidiary, would buy up the remaining 15 percent and own all the bank's stock. FABI paid $42 per share for the minority shareholders' stock. But the merger was challenged in federal court by Doris I. Sandberg, who owned 2,242 shares of First American Bank of Virginia. A federal jury ruled for her, and awarded her $43,956 _ or $18 per share _ in damages. The presiding judge had refused to certify the suit as a ``class action'' filed in behalf of all the bank's minority shareholders. The 4th Circuit court upheld the jury's verdict, but ruled that the trial judge should have certified the lawsuit as a class action. ``The result of this ruling is that the $43,956 judgment that the jury awarded to Sandberg might now be transformed on remand into a judgment in excess of $13 million,'' lawyers for FABI told the justices. In the appeal acted on Monday, the FABI lawyers argued, among other things, that the proxy statements found to have been misleading ``could not possibly have affected the outcome of the proxy vote.'' The appeal said that FABI had far more than the two-thirds of the share votes needed to bring about the merger without the consent of any minority shareholders. The appeal also contended that no minority shareholder proved to have actually relied on the statements. The appeals court ruled that reliance does not have to be proved in lawsuits invoking the securities law banning false or misleading proxy statements. The case is Virginia Bankshares Inc. vs. Sandberg, 89-1448.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of New England Announces New Vice Chairman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: McNamar is cq
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp. announced Monday that former deputy treasurer secretary R.T. McNamar will join the bank as vice chairman. McNamar, 51, fills the post vacated by Richard Driscoll, who resigned several weeks ago as a part of restructuring efforts by the bank. Officials hope McNamar's experience as an alternate governor of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund will help the bank regain its soundness, the bank said in a statement. BNEC announced earlier this year that it suffered heavy losses when a large number of loans went bad from a decline in the real estate market. The bank reported losses of more than $1 billion for 1989. McNamar served as deputy treasury secretary from 1981-85.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures End Mixed After Soybean Rally Fails
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mixed Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade after a rally in the soybean complex faded late in the session. Wheat futures closed moderately lower while corn and oats were narrowly mixed. Soybean futures rallied strongly at midday as talk of continued slow Brazilian soybean exports prompted speculators to attempt a push above recent highs. The contracts for 1991 soybean deliveries established new lifetime highs but the rally faded after buying faltered in the soybean meal market, said John Frazier, director of agricultural commodity trading for Gerald Inc. ``Once the meal broke, the beans broke,'' he said. At the close, wheat futures were } cent to 3{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.70 a bushel; corn was 1\ cents lower to { cent higher with May at $2.77} a bushel; oats were unchanged to 2{ cents lower with May at $1.57{ a bushel; and soybeans were } cent to 3{ cents higher with May at $6.05{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Labor-Based Peronist Government Would Limit Right to Strike
DOC.TEXT: The right to strike, a constitutional guarantee unions consider sacred, would be severely restricted by legislation President Carlos Menem sent to Congress on Monday. The Peronist Party president, elected last May with the support of organized labor, said the measure is needed to curtail walkouts that have disrupted schools, commuter trains, federal courts, municipal hospitals, phones and other public services. ``If we obtain consensus for it, that's great. If we don't, we will push it through anyway,'' a determined Menem said last week. The measure would require unions that provide ``essential services'' to give at least 10 days notice of a strike, and submit to mediation by the Labor Ministry that could last 15 more days. Management would be authorized to hire enough workers for a ``minimum'' level of service. If strikers did not comply with the notice, or tried to block all service, they could be fired and unions could lose their legal status. The legislation cites public health, transport, energy, schools and telecommunications as ``essential'' services, and leaves open the possibility that strikes by private unions also might be regulated. Victor de Gennaro, director of the 145,000-member Association of State Employees, said the bill ``has as its objective the intimidation of workers.'' Juan Manuel Casella, the Civic Radical Union's candidate for vice president in the May 1989 national elections, said the legislation is aimed more to ``punish'' workers than to regulate strikes. The measure, which Menem at first said he would impose by decree, upset even Peronist legislators reluctant to alienate a group whose support has been steadfast during three decades of repression. Peronist Sen. Orando Britos said flatly he would vote against it. A bloc of eight dissident Peronist deputies in the lower house indicated they would, too. Technically, the ruling party has an absolute majority in the Senate and a working majority in the Chamber of Deputies. Menem, 59, is a lifelong member of the party and a three-time provincial governor. He was arrested and held in detention with many Peronist politicians and labor leaders following the March 1976 military coup that toppled President Isabel Peron. The measure is not his first that unions say is anti-labor. Since Menem took office last July amid hyperinflation and recession, public service rates have risen faster than salaries, contributing to the contraction of real wages. Despite campaign promises of massive wage hikes and a ``productive revolution,'' Menem has imposed an austerity budget that has exacerbated unemployment. As many as 4.8 million Argentines, of a workforce of 12.5 million, are unemployed or under-employed, according to the Labor Ministry. Menem appointed executives from Argentina's largest multinational company as his first two economy ministers. He ignored union pleas by lifting controls on wages, prices and foreign exchange and by committing the government to sell money-losing public companies. Anticipating conflict, Menem tried to unseat Saul Ubaldini as leader of the 3-million-member General Labor Confederation. That failed, but the confederation split into rival camps. In recent weeks, public school teachers from grade school through university have boycotted classes. Employees of the state-owned airline and telephone company have staged wildcat strikes. Doctors at municipal hospitals and court clerks have walked off the job. Unions are demanding pay increases which the government says it cannot afford. Also, they are seeking a greater voice in the sale of state companies, two of which _ the airline and telephone company _ are to be sold this year. After months of currency devaluation and inflation that soared by 95 percent last month, there are signs the government is bringing the economy under control. Inflation in April is projected at 12 percent to 15 percent. The austral has held steady at 5,000 for every U.S. dollar, or less, since early March. Prices in supermarkets and department stores have begun to come down. After an estimated 60,000 union members staged an anti-government demonstration on the steps of Congress, that many and more rallied at Government House to shout their support for Menem.

DOC.HEAD: Goldsmith Drops BAT Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with additional details, BAT reax. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Sir James Goldsmith's Hoylake Investments Ltd. said today it would not renew its $22 billion bid for the British conglomerate BAT Industries PLC. The hostile bid of 878 pence, or $14.31, a share would have been the world's second-largest takeover, after Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co.'s $25 billion purchase of RJR Nabisco Inc. completed early last year. The Hoylake investors group dropped the bid because it ``simply felt that the combination of the time the bid would take to get through U.S. regulatory hurdles and the costs thereof tipped the risk-reward ratio the wrong way,'' said a spokesman for one of Hoylake's merchant banks, who spoke anonymously. Hoylake said in a statement: ``The directors of Hoylake wish BAT and its unbundled offspring great success within their new structures.'' Hoylake's withdrawal comes after California's state insurance regulators decided April 9 to bar a change of control of BAT's Farmers Insurance Group Inc. of Los Angeles. The offer needed approval from the commissioners of the nine states where Farmers operates. The withdrawal is a major defeat for Goldsmith, an Anglo-French financier who has built a worldwide reputation by taking over and breaking up companies. The news of the withdrawal came after London's Stock Exchange closed. BAT shares ended at 724 pence, or $11.80, a share, down 4 pence. Hoylake launched the offer last July, but suspended it in September while it sought the clearance from the U.S. state insurance commissioners. BAT has been restructuring itself to fend off the bid. The Hoylake withdrawal probably will not affect the restructuring, which is designed to boost BAT's share price. ``I am pleased that Hoylke and Axa-Midi have finally abandoned their bid,'' BAT Chairman Patrick Sheehy said in a statement issued in the United States. ``We can now devote our full attention to running the continuing Group based on our financial services and tobacco businesses. The Hoylake investors group also included British merchant banker Jacob Rothschild and Australian businessman Kerry Packer. Goldsmith, and other shareholders, have complained that BAT's stock price does not reflect the stock's real value because it is dragged down by the slower growth of its tobacco businesses. BAT is selling and spinning off its retailing and paper businesses to concentrate on tobacco and financial services. Last week, BAT announced the sale of its U.S. retailer Marshall Field's to Dayton Hudson Corp. Its Saks Fifth Avenue unit also is on the auction block. BAT also is in the process of buying back up to 10 percent of its own stock.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Company Makes Friendly Offer for Aquascutum
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese company has made a friendly offer of 73.8 million pounds, or $120 million, for Aquascutum Group PLC, the classic British clothing retailer, the companies said Monday. Renown Inc., a Japanese clothing manufacturer that specializes in middle-range ladies' wear, offered 200 pence, or $3.26, for each of Aquascutum's 27.3 million special A shares, the companies said. In addition, Renown offered 550 pence, or $8.97, for each of the company's 3.5 million ordinary shares, they said. Aquascutum's board of directors approved of the deal, and Renown already has acquired enough of Aquascutum's shares to control the company, said Gerald Abrahams, Aquascutum's chairman and chief executive. The companies said Renown already has bought 9.35 percent of the A shares and 65.6 percent of the ordinary shares from the Abrahams family and other shareholders. The deal appears to block attempts by dissident holders of ordinary shares who have been seeking to end the special voting rights of Aquascutum's A shares. Those efforts had raised the prospect of a hostile offer for the company. Founded in 1851, Aquascutum operates a dozen of its own stores, with flagships in London and New York, and wholesale outlets in 45 countries. It has 1,600 employees. Abrahams said the offer was ``an exciting opportunity to expand'' and that it would allow Aquascutum to ``get on with our business.'' The Japanese firm is seeking to upgrade its clothing line, Abrahams said. ``We are a growing business in the Far East, a prestigious brand of very high quality goods,'' Abrahams said. Aquascutum will remain based in London, he said. The company also announced that its net profit for the year ended Jan. 31 fell 3 percent to 1.93 million pounds, or $3.1 million, from 1.99 million pounds a year earlier. Earnings per share declined to 6.26 pence, or 10.2 cents, from 6.53 pence. Sales rose 5.6 percent to 52.6 million pounds, or $85.7 million, from 49.8 million pounds in the previous year.

DOC.HEAD: CalFed Earns Up 8 Percent
DOC.TEXT: CalFed Inc., parent of California Federal Bank, reported first-quarter earnings of $18.9 million, partly attributing the 8 percent increase to a $1.3 million gain from the sale of its London-based insurance subsidiary. The earnings of 74 cents per share compared with earnings of $17.5 million, or 67 cents per share, for the first quarter of 1989. CalFed, which is shedding assets as part of a plan to concentrate on the core savings and loan operations, also said it expects layoffs and other belt-tightening at banking operations save about $24 million in 1990. Those savings were not expected to show up until the second quarter, CalFed said. The Feb. 6 sale of the Anglo American Insurance Co. Ltd. was part of CalFed's strategy of concentrating on banking. The company also said it had agreed during the first quarter to sell its term life and accident and health insurance businesses to Montgomery Ward Life Insurance Co. CalFed said it expects to break even on the sale, scheduled to be completed during the second quarter. CalFed listed assets of $25.3 billion as of March 31, compared with $28.3 billion a year earlier.

Stock prices fell for the fourth straight session today, still in the grip of interest-rate and inflation worries. Analysts said fears of rising interest rates kept a dominant hold on the mood among investors. A sharp rise in rates last week raised yields on long-term government bonds close to 9 percent, their highest levels since last May. As a new week began, predictions abounded of further increases in rates, partly on the basis of signs that business activity had picked up recently. Higher interest rates are seen as an increasingly significant obstacle to hopes that corporate earnings might improve as the year progresses.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Frustrated By U.S. Regulators, Goldsmith Ends Nine-month Takeover Battle
DOC.TEXT: Frustrated by U.S. regulatory delays, Sir James Goldsmith's Hoylake Investments Ltd. on Monday ended its acrimonious, nine-month takeover battle for the British conglomerate BAT Industries PLC. The decision marks a major defeat for Goldsmith, the noted raider whose group's $22 billion all-securities offer for BAT would have been the world's second-largest takeover after the $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. last year. BAT, whose U.S. companies include Brown & Williamson tobacco and the Saks Fifth Avenue department stores, has been restructuring by selling its retailing and paper businesses to concentrate on tobacco and financial services. Goldsmith and other shareholders have complained that the slower growth of the tobacco businesses has dragged down BAT's stock price, and that several of its business lines needed to be jettisoned. But two weeks ago, California insurance regulators decided to block the proposed sale of BAT's Farmers Insurance Group Inc. of Los Angeles, a key element of the planned takeover. Hoylake had planned to sell Farmers for $4.5 billion to the French insurance group Axa-Midi Assurances. The offer needed approval from the commissioners of a total of nine states where Farmers operates. A London source close to Hoylake said the group, which also includes British merchant banker Jacob Rothschild and Australian businessman Kerry Packer, dropped its offer because of U.S. regulatory delays. ``We have always felt we could achieve a favorable position but it could take quite a while,'' said the source, who didn't want to be identified. ``We didn't feel it was in the best interests of the shareholders given the uncertainties.'' After Hoylake announced Monday that it was withdrawing, Axa-Midi announced in Paris that it had dropped its bid. Axa's statement said that ``we understand Hoylake's decision, but we are sorry that it obliges us to give up the acquisition of Farmers.'' Jeffrey Beyer, a Farmers Group spokesman in Los Angeles, said state regulators' objections to Axa-Midi's debt-financed offer for Farmers and the way Hoylake proposed to transfer ownership had been wide-ranging and nearly impossible to remedy. ``Certainly Axa was facing what we thought were insurmountable difficulties,'' Beyer said. Hoylake's offer of 878 pence _ the equivalent of $14.31 _ worth of securities for each BAT share had been suspended since last September while it sought regulatory approval. BAT's shares finished down 4 pence at 724 pence, or about $11.80, on London's Stock Exchange. The statements came after the exchange close, and BAT declined about 40 pence in after hours trading. BAT Chairman Patrick Sheehy issued a statement that he was pleased about Hoylake's decision, which he called overdue. He said the company would press ahead with its massive defensive restructuring. Last week, BAT announced the sale of its U.S. retailer Marshall Field's to Dayton Hudson Corp. for $1.04 billion. Saks Fifth Avenue also is on the auction block. ``Shareholders gave overwhelming support to our reshaping proposals (in a vote) last October,'' Sheehy stated. ``Today's overdue decision by Hoylake does not alter our resolve to see that program through to its completion and to continue to maximize value for our shareholders.'' For Goldsmith, who built a worldwide reputation for taking over and breaking up companies, the withdrawal represents a major defeat. ``I think he's gone (from BAT) for good,'' said Jack Jones, an analyst with the London investment firm UBS Philips and Drew. Jones said he was somewhat surprised by the decision, given recent positive comments by Hoylake and Axa-Midi. But William de Winton, of Nomura Research Institute in London, said he was surprised how long the expensive bid dragged on. ``From the start everyone knew the regulatory hurdle would be the problem,'' de Winton said. ``They took it further than some people expected them to. ``Anyone going for BAT will face what in effect seems to amount to a poison pill in the form of the U.S. state regulatory system,'' he said. Hoylake controls about 19 million BAT shares, or about 2 percent of the company, said a Hoylake spokesman. No decision had been made on what to do with the stake, said the spokesman, who was not identified, in accordance with British practice.

DOC.HEAD: New Daily Newspaper Launched in Rural New York State
DOC.TEXT: The Daily Editor, a new morning newspaper, began publication Monday with an initial press run of 25,000 as copies were distributed free to many homes in this rural area southwest of Albany. The Daily Editor was launched by Lee Publications Inc., which also publishes weekly newspapers, trade papers and shoppers in and around the Hudson and Mohawk valleys. Copies of Lee Publications' only daily newspaper were also being sold on newsstands. Beginning Tuesday, all copies will cost 35 cents. Assistant publisher Dennis Hogeboom said the Daily Editor is the first daily newspaper designed to principally serve Schoharie and northern Delaware counties, where residents have been served by newspapers from Albany, Schenectady and Oneonta. ``The news content will emphasize local happenings and the tone will be positive,'' said Frederick W. Lee, president of Lee Publications and acting publisher of the newspaper. Robert Balme has been appointed editor. The Daily Editor, a standard broadsheet with six columns, will receive world, national and state news and photos from The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon's Net Down 29.3 Percent in First Quarter; Amoco Has Slight Gain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 2 new grafs to include Amerada Hess. Picks up 3rd graf, For the ... ADDS 4 new grafs with Amerada Hess details.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Exxon Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Oil giant Exxon Corp. reported Monday that its net income declined 29.3 percent in the first quarter due to an accounting change, while fifth-ranked Amoco Corp. said its profit edged up 1.7 percent. Ashland Oil Inc., meanwhile, posted net income of $1 million for the second quarter of its fiscal year, compared with a $14 million loss a year earlier. Amerada Hess Corp. said its first-quarter profit plummeted 82 percent. For the three months ended March 31, Exxon's profit fell to $1.28 billion, or $1.01 a share, from $1.81 billion, or $1.41 a share, in the first quarter of 1989. Net income in the year-earlier quarter included a $535 million accounting gain resulting from Exxon's adoption of a new accounting standard for income taxes. Excluding the one-time gain, New York-based Exxon earned $1.275 billion, or 99 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1989. First-quarter revenue for Exxon, the nation's largest oil company, jumped 20.3 percent to $26.7 billion from $22.2 billion. ``Crude (oil) production, natural gas sales, petroleum product sales and chemical sales all increased over last year's quarter,'' Exxon Chairman L.G. Rawl said in a press statement. ``Higher crude prices and increased operating volumes helped boost earnings from exploration and production operations to their highest quarterly level in four years.'' The company plans nearly $8 billion in capital spending this year, Rawl noted, up from $7.2 billion in 1989. On Wednesday, Exxon shareholders gathering at the annual meeting in Houston are expected to consider six environmental proposals seeking to make the company more ecologically responsive, in the wake of the Valdez oil spill last year. Amoco said its first-quarter net income edged up to $466 million, or 91 cents a share, from $458 million, or 89 cents a share, a year earlier, mainly reflecting higher crude prices. Revenue of Chicago-based Amoco rose 9.2 percent to $7.1 billion from $6.5 billion. Ashland, the fourteenth-largest U.S. oil company, saids its earnings per share amountred to 2 cents in the quarter ended March 31 in contrast to a loss of 25 cents a share a year earlier. The $14 million loss a year earlier included a $9 million after-tax charge stemming from an arbitration award in a commercial dispute. Second-quarter revenue increased 10.5 percent to $2.1 billion from $1.9 billion a year earlier. ``Although Ashland improved its results from a year ago, the second quarter again proved to be a difficult earnings period,'' said John R. Hall, Ashland's chairman. ``Refinery margins were strong in early January but deteriorated rapidly before improving in late March.'' For the six months ending March 31, Ashland had net income of $23 million, or 41 cents a share, down from earnings of $82 million, or $1.48 a share, in the same period a year earlier. Six-month revenue rose to $4.3 billion from $4 billion. Amerada Hess, based in New York, said it earned $39.7 million, or 49 cents per share, in the three months ended March 31, down from $220.2 million, or $2.70 per share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 12.2 percent to $1.66 billion from $1.48 billion a year earlier. The decline in net income was due to sharply lower earnings from refining and marketing operations and higher corporate charges. Refining and marketing operations had earnings of $24.5 million in the latest quarter, down from $208.4 million a year earlier, while corporate charges including interest expense rose to $42.5 million, up from $17 million.

DOC.HEAD: Tyson Earnings Up After Holly Farms Acquisition
DOC.TEXT: Tyson Foods Inc. on Monday reported a 21.2 percent jump in its second-quarter earnings as sales almost doubled due to the takeover of poultry rival Holly Farms. Tyson earned a record $26.3 million, or 40 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31, up from $21.7 million, or 34 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said in a news release. The higher earnings came on sales of $931.9 million for the quarter, compared with $534.9 million for the corresponding 1989 quarter. Gerald Johnston, Tyson's executive vice president of finance, attributed the large growth in sales and earnings to the merger with Holly Farms, which was completed on Aug. 19. Tyson would have expected a 10 percent increase in sales had the merger not taken place, Johnston said. For the six months ended March 31, Tyson reported a profit of $49.4 million. That was 19 percent higher than $41.5 million in 1989's first half. Earnings per share were 75 cents during this year's first half, compared with 65 cents a year earlier. Sales grew to $1.83 billion from $1.04 billion. Tyson produces and markets prepackaged, precooked and convenience poultry and other foods.

DOC.HEAD: PPG Acquires French Chemicals Firm
DOC.TEXT: PPG Industries announced Monday it has acquired the French chemicals firm of Establissements Robert Ouvrie S.A. for an undisclosed price. Ouvrie, based in Lille, France, reported 1989 sales of more than $11 million, said Richard Rompala, PPG group vice president for chemicals. The French company makes surfactants and paper specialty chemicals. ``Lille, in northern France, is an ideal location from which to efficiently serve customers'' in Europe, Rompala said. ``The business also will benefit from combining excellent technology developed by PPG and Ouvrie, which has a reputation for the high quality of its products and service.'' PPG, based in Pittsburgh, produces glass, paints, chemicals and industrial coatings. It had sales of $5.8 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains; Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened against most major currencies Monday, benefiting from the West German mark's weakness. Speculation that U.S. interest rates will move higher as the economy continues to expand also encouraged dollar buying, dealers said. Gold prices were mixed, rising in New York after falling in some overseas markets. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for April delivery settled at $378.90 a troy ounce, $2.30 higher than Friday's close. Later, Republic National Bank of New York quoted a troy ounce of gold bullion at $378.65 as of 4 p.m. EDT, up $2.40 from Friday's late bid. Ronald Holzer, chief currency dealer at Harris Trust in Chicago, said the mark was sold heavily amid worries about the consequences of planned German unification. The governments of East and West Germany have said they will merge their economies completely on July 1 as a prelude to full unification, expected next year. But the governments have not reached a final agreement on linking their currencies. The dollar, which is considered a safe investment refuge in times of economic or political uncertainty, also benefited from news of growing oil shortages in Lithuania caused by the Soviet economic embargo on the republic. Also contributing to the dollar's strength were expectations of domestic economic growth accompanied by rising credit costs. Higher U.S. interest rates would enhance returns on dollar-denominated investments and tend to boost demand for dollars. ``I would say the dollar is benefiting in general from higher U.S. rates and the perception that the U.S. economy is still moving along at a moderate to good pace,'' Holzer said. It was anticipated that a report due Tuesday on orders for durable goods and a report Friday on the gross national product would confirm that the economic expansion has staged a modest revival. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 157.55 Japanese yen from 157.60 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it was unchanged. In New York, the dollar settled at 157.55 yen, up from 157.50 yen on Friday. The British pound rose to $1.6365 in London from $1.6357 late Friday. Later in New York, sterling dipped to $1.63565 from Friday's $1.6388. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late quotes, included: 1.6995 West German marks, up from 1.6872; 1.4935 Swiss francs, up from 1.4895; 5.7020 French francs, up from 5.6655; 1,246.75 Italian lire, up from 1,238.20; and 1.16155 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1628. Selected late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's levels were: 1.6960 West German marks, up from 1.6895; 1.4925 Swiss francs, up up 1.4910; 5.6930 French francs, up from 5.6695; 1.9090 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8910; 1,244.00 Italian lire, up from 1,240.00; and 1.1610 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1619. Gold prices moved mostly lower in overseas trading before rising in domestic dealings. In London, the late bid for gold was $376.25 a troy ounce, up from $374.50 late Friday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $375.85 from $376.50 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 38 cents to close at $376.98. Silver prices also were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery fell to $5.093 a troy ounce from Friday's settlement of $5.099. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $5.09 a troy ounce from $5.08 bid late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Move Higher
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures prices closed higher Monday in anticipation of OPEC's meeting next month about its soaring production levels. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, rose 25 cents to close at $19.07 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The May contract for delivery of home heating oil advanced 0.18 cent to close at 53.12 cents a gallon, while the May contract for unleaded regular gasoline picked up 1.61 cents and settled at 63.54 cents a gallon. Analysts said the market moved higher on momentum that began Thursday, when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced that its price monitoring committee would meet May 2 to discuss the cartel's soaring production. Oil analysts have estimated the 13-nation cartel is pumping more than 24 million barrels of crude a day, well over its ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day. The increased output had depressed oil prices in recent weeks. The possibility that the organization might put a cap on its production raised traders' hopes that prices might return to their higher levels, and energy futures rallied on Thursday. Prices were mostly lower on Friday, but traders were again optimistic Monday, according to Andrew Lebow, an analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery closed at $1.555 per million British thermal units Monday, up from $1.543 on Friday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: IMA Acquisition, 2nd graf, is cq
DOC.HEAD: Debt-Burdened Hospital Chain Sells Four Swiss Hospitals
DOC.TEXT: American Medical International Inc., working to reduce debt from its buyout by an investor group, agreed Monday to sell its Swiss hospitals for about $167 million to Klinik Hirslanden AG, a Swiss health-care provider. IMA Acquisition Corp. borrowed heavily to finance the $1.7 billion takeover completed in October. It also took over payments on about $1.4 billion in existing loans to AMI, bringing its debt to about $3 billion. Monday's agreement involves four acute care hospitals in Zurich, Aarau, Bern and Lausanne, the largest privately owned hospital group in Switzerland. AMI operates 61 hospitals, mostly acute care facilities in California, Florida and Texas, and is the country's fourth-largest hospital chain in terms of beds. AMI's chairman and chief executive, Harry J. Gray, described the sale of the Swiss hospitals as a significant part of the company's 18-month plan to sell off about $1 billion in assets. ``AMI's divestiture program continues to progress on schedule at our pricing expectations,'' he said. AMI also hopes to halve its annual administrative costs, which topped $93 million in fiscal 1989, as corporate offices are moved from Beverly Hills to Dallas.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market declined broadly for the fourth straight session Monday, extending a losing streak blamed largely on interest-rate worries. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 29.28 to 2,666.67, extending its loss since last Tuesday to 99.10 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by nearly 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 328 up, 1,229 down and 425 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 136.15 million shares, down from 174.26 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 164.62 million shares. Analysts said fears of rising interest rates kept a dominant influence on the mood of investors. A sharp rise in rates last week raised yields on long-term government bonds close to 9 percent, their highest levels since last May. As a new week began, predictions abounded of further increases in rates, partly on the basis of signs that business activity had picked up recently. Higher interest rates are seen as an increasingly significant obstacle to hopes that corporate earnings might improve as the year progresses. Current profit reports for the early stages of 1990, meanwhile, continued to get a subdued to negative response from traders, even though Wall Street had been braced for a good many unpleasant surprises. Among actively traded blue chips, DuPont dropped ~ to 35}; American Telephone & Telegraph { to 40]; General Electric 1 to 64{, and American Express ~ to 27\. James Robinson III, chief executive of American Express, said he expected the company's Shearson Lehman Hutton brokerage operation to return to profitability soon. Among other securities-industry stocks, Merrill Lynch fell } to 22{; Salomon Inc. { to 20|, and Charles Schwab \ to 15[. Pansophic Systems tumbled 5[ to 10{. The company estimated results at about break-even for the fiscal year that ends next week. Digital Microwave plunged 13~ to 14[ in the over-the-counter market. At the weekend the company said its earnings for the quarter ended March 31 would be significantly lower than expected. Storage Technology bucked the downtrend, gaining 1] to 22~, as the company posted an increase in first-quarter operating profits that exceeded most analysts' estimates. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $39.35 billion, or 1.22 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 2.13 to 181.93. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 4.69 to 385.21, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 4.07 at 331.05. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 5.69 to 420.10. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 344.95, down 3.01.

DOC.HEAD: Santa Fe Railway to Lay Off 850 Workers
DOC.TEXT: About 850 workers for the Santa Fe railroad face layoffs because of sharp drops in shipments of automobiles and grain, two of the railroad's most important commodities, the company announced Monday. ``Some of the layoffs will start as early as a week from today,'' Robert Gehrt, spokesman for the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Co., said Monday. ``We hope to have most of them in place by May 15.'' The layoffs will affect about 125 workers at the locomotive shop at San Bernardino, Calif., and an additional 100 from the railroad car repair shops in Topeka, Kan., the company said in a statement. About 70 workers will be laid off from the company's centralized work equipment plant at Albuquerque, N.M., and 15 will be laid off at the Newton, Kan., rail plant, the statement said. An additional 200 section gang workers, one from each gang, and 75 specialty gang employees will be laid off. About 100 management employees will be laid off, but the departments affected by those cutbacks have not been determined, company president Michael R. Haverty said in the statement. Santa Fe, which employs about 18,000 people, said the remainder of the layoffs ``are not expected to have a major impact in any one community.'' Automobile shipping dropped 47 percent in early April and grain shipping declined 40 percent. The two normally account for about 22 percent of the railroad's business. ``When you get a big hit like this in those two areas, it's something to be concerned about,'' Gehrt said. Piggybacking semi-trailers account for more than 20 percent of the company's business, Gehrt said, while shipments of food and farm products other than grain accounts for about 14 percent and chemicals for about 12 percent. Haverty said the layoffs are similar to seasonal employment reductions the company has undergone in the past but are more severe. Santa Fe blamed a $10 million increase in fuel costs during the first quarter and ``mediocre'' first-quarter performance for the layoffs. The company reported first-quarter operating income of $66.1 million, compared with $34.2 million for the same quarter last year. ``But we had a big property tax refund in California of over $30 million this quarter, and without that we would have been just about even,'' Gehrt said. ``And last year's figures included a special charge of over $50 million. (The first quarter of 1990) wasn't a good quarter.''

DOC.HEAD: Bass Group Supports Vote on Avon Shareholders Rights Proposal
DOC.TEXT: An investment group headed by Texas financier Robert M. Bass said Monday it planned to vote in favor of a shareholders' rights plan at the Avon Products Inc. annual meeting next month. The Robert M. Bass Group decision was disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. The Bass Group, which holds a 5.9 percent stake in the New York-based cosmetics company, said it would vote in favor of submitting the company's `poison pill' defense to a shareholder vote. Bass Group said it also supported a proposal seeking confidential voting for shareholders. But the Bass Group said it would vote against a proposal to set up a Shareholders Advisory Committee at the annual meeting in New York on May 3. A spokesman for Avon, John Cox, said the company _ which opposes the poison pill and confidential voting proposals _ had no comment on the Bass Group disclosure. A poison pill defense makes it prohibitively expensive to take over a company. Keeping the identity of those voting in shareholder elections secret from management has been a growing issue among shareholders rights groups. The Bass Group announcement came three weeks after Avon's largest shareholder, Chartwell Associates, said it had boosted its stake to 16 percent. Chartwell had been pressuring Avon management for representation on the board. Chartwell Associates is a limited partnership that includes oil heir Gordon P. Getty's Family Trust, a subsidiary of Dallas-based Mary Kay Corp. and the Fisher real estate family of New York. Avon rejected takeover proposals twice last year from Amway Corp. and Minneapolis-based investor Irwin Jacobs.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Slip
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices slipped Monday in light trading, echoing declines overseas as the market awaited economic reports due later this week. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell 7-32 point, or about $2.19 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, rose to 8.96 percent from 8.94 percent late Friday. The last time the yield on the 30-year bond was as high was last May 11, when it stood at 9.07 percent. The 30-year bond has plunged more than $41 per $1,000 over the past seven trading days in response to signs of increasing inflation, a stronger economy and worries about upcoming bond issues, including the Treasury's quarterly refunding auction set for next month. Higher inflation and an economic upturn could prompt the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates high. Higher rates decrease the value of fixed-return investments such as bonds. An increased supply of bonds can temporarily drive down prices until the market absorbs the new issues. There were few forces acting on the bond market Monday except for a softness in prices in overseas trading before U.S. trading began, said William V. Sullivan, director of money market research for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``It was lethargic,'' he said. ``So the market was just really drifting. The market's looking ahead to the upcoming data release.'' On Tuesday, the government is scheduled to release reports on durable goods orders for March and the employment-cost index for the first quarter, while the first report on the gross national product for 1990 is set to be announced Friday. The market had little reaction to news that West Germany agreed to exchange a limited number of East German marks for West German marks at a 1-1 ratio. Some economists believe such a ratio could cause inflation in West Germany, but Sullivan said bond traders probably viewed the proposal as preliminary. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments fell from 1-32 point to [ point, intermediate maturities lost between 5-32 point and 7-32 point, and long-term issues were off from 3-16 point to \ point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.41 to 1,133.05. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 5-32 point to 90 15-32 point. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.61 percent from 7.59 percent late Thursday. At an auction Monday, the Treasury sold $8.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.78 percent, up from 7.71 percent last week. Another $8.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.91 percent, up from 7.75 percent last week. The rates were the highest since three-month bills sold for 7.80 percent April 9, and six-month bills averaged 7.92 percent March 19. In the secondary market for Treasury bills, yields on three-month bills rose to 7.97 percent as the discount rose 3 basis points to 7.72 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 8.28 percent as the discount gained 6 basis points to 7.86 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 8.49 percent as the discount gained 6 basis point to 7.89 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, unchanged from late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Subsidies Still Snag in U.S.-EEC Talks
DOC.TEXT: American and West European officials agreed on Monday to strengthen their economic and political ties but disagreed on how to resolve a simmering discord over farm subsidies. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who led the U.S. delegation to the talks with the European Economic Community, said the two sides discussed the changes in Eastern Europe and how these would affect the EEC and the United States. The two teams also discussed the Soviet sanctions against Lithuania. Baker said the EEC shared with the United States the ``growing international concerns'' about the Soviet response to the secessionist Baltic state. The U.S.-EEC ministerial talks, held for the first time in the United States since they began in 1981, also focused on the effects of German unification on the European economy. The subject, as well as the U.S. views, will come up Saturday at the EEC summit in Dublin, Ireland. Both Baker and EEC President Jacques Delors stressed the importance of coordinating their positions as the pace of European unification accelerates toward the target date of 1992 and as the EEC tries to handle the changes brought about by the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe. The United States is particularly concerned that as the EEC moves toward a monetary and trade union among its 12 member nations, U.S. business will be shut out. The EEC is determined to reassure the Americans that the new system will leave plenty of room for trade with the United States. ``This meeting has taken place at a crossroads in Atlantic history, at a time of new significance to the partnership between the Community and the United States,'' Delors told reporters after his day-long talks with Baker. Both sides agreed on the need to bring the Uruguay Round of international trade talks to a successful conclusion by the end of the year. But officials on both sides said they were worried that their dispute on agriculture could endanger the trade talks among 96 nations, which began in 1986 and are intended to liberalize commerce around the world. The agriculture dispute revolves around the question of farm subsidies, with the United States demanding the 12 EEC nations do away with support for farmers and the Europeans saying this is an unrealistic demand. ``It's certain the United States wants to go down the road f reform more than the EEC,'' said Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. ``That doesn't mean we can't resolve our differences until December.'' The two delegations agreed to speed up their talks on the subject and appointed staff members to deal with various aspects of the dispute, including the question of market access and export subsidies. But the EEC's agriculture commissioner, Raymond McSharr, cautioned that ``there are many difficulties, and they musn't be underestimated.''

DOC.HEAD: American Express: Shearson on Road to Recovery
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. Chairman James D. Robinson III told shareholders Monday the company's troubled Wall Street subsidiary Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. was ``well positioned'' to return to profitability. Shearson reported a $915 million first-quarter loss _ the largest in securities industry history _ in large part to pay for a restructuring that included 2,000 layoffs and business cuts initiated by American Express. American Express lost $620 million in the first three months of 1990 because of the troubles at Shearson. ``It's the price we paid to put Shearson's major problems behind us,'' Robinson told about 500 shareholders attending American Express' annual meeting in New York. ``Shearson needed time and capital but market conditions demanded immediate action,'' he said. American Express last month announced a plan to buy all the remaining publicly held shares of Shearson, capping several months of turmoil at the Wall Street firm that analysts say overexpanded in the 1980s. The payment card and travel services giant moved to gain management control of Shearson by ousting Peter Cohen as chairman and installing an American Express executive in his place, Howard L. Clark Jr. Shearson then laid off 2,000 workers in March, with more expected by the end of the year, and began plans to eliminate or scale back several business lines. In addition to extending its current 61 percent stake to full ownership, American Express has provided $1.15 billion to shore up Shearson's capital base in recent months. Robinson said that six months ago Shearson ``didn't fit as a core operating entity'' and had been reduced to a strategic investment. He attributed Shearson's troubles to declining stock trading activity since the 1987 market crash, rising worldwide interest rates, a slumping domestic real estate market and the collapse of the junk bond market last fall. ``The environment for securities companies changed rapidly and radically,'' Robinson said. ``The result was a crisis for Shearson.'' But he said American Express' changes at the investment firm had left Shearson ``well positioned'' to make money. He did not say when he expected Shearson to become profitable. Robinson admitted that some of Shearson's expansion moves in the 1980s under Cohen were wrong, including the 1988 purchase of E.F. Hutton Inc., which added an extensive retail brokerage network and expensive overhead while causing animosity among employees. ``In retrospect the Hutton acquisition or at least the way it was structured was a mistake,'' he said. At the annual meeting, shareholders elected three new American Express board members: Motorola Inc. Chairman George M.C. Fisher, New York City Opera President Beverly Sills Greenough; and Dow Chemical Co. President Frank P. Popoff.

DOC.HEAD: Repeating for all needing
Pork Bellies Soar On Smaller-Than-Expected Stocks
DOC.TEXT: Prices of most pork belly futures contracts surged the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound Monday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after an Agriculture Department report showed smaller supplies than traders had anticipated. On other commodity markets, hog futures rallied while cattle futures were mixed; orange juice futures fell sharply; oil futures advanced; cotton was up; precious metals were mixed; and grain and soybean futures were mixed. Frozen pork belly futures settled 1.1 cents to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in May up 2 cents at 64.32 cents a pound. Hog futures ended .20 cent to .95 cent higher with June at 62.02 cents a pound; live cattle were .27 cent lower to .20 cent higher with June at 73.90 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .28 cent lower to .25 cent higher with April at 83.90 cents a pound. The runup in the belly market had been expected since late Friday afternoon, when the USDA released a monthly report showing 97.5 million pounds of the raw bacon meat in the nation's commercial freezers at the end of March. The figure was nearly 3 million pounds below the average market estimate and compared with 86 million pounds at the end of February and a record 129 million pounds a year ago. The USDA also released a cattle supply report Friday _ the quarterly estimage of cattle on feedlots in the 13 largest producer states _ which showed a larger-than-expected number of cattle placed on feedlots during the first quarter. But analysts said the futures market's deep discount to cash prices last week had already reflected expectations for larger supplies by June, so the futures market had little reaction Monday to the report. Orange juice futures plunged on the New York Cotton Exchange, largely reflecting speculative selling ahead of May 1, the first day for traders to declare intentions to deliver orange juice against the May contract. Speculators holding obligations to take delivery of a commodity typically liquidate those positions as first notice day approaches so as to avoid taking physical delivery. Celeste Georkakis, an analyst with Cargill Investor Servicers Inc., said further selling was prompted by a Florida Department of Citrus report estimating a 10 percent decline in U.S. demand for orange juice, mainly reflecting a drop in consumption of frozen concentrate. Orange juice futures settled 3.35 cents to 5.85 cents lower with May at $1.8965 a pound. Cotton futures advanced strongly on the Cotton Exchange, reflecting position-evening ahead of Tuesday, first notice day for the May contract. Cotton specialist Ernest Simon of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said world demand for high-quality U.S. cotton has strengthened due to a poor Australian crop. Cotton settled .20 cent to 1.30 cents higher with May at 75.31 cents a pound. Oil futures rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid jitters about the May 2 OPEC meeting and what measures the oil cartel may take to support oil prices. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 7 cents to 25 cents higher with June at $19.07 a barrel; heating oil was .15 cent to .67 cent higher with May at 53.12 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .35 cent to 1.61 cents higher with May at 63.54 cents a gallon. Gold futures benefitted from weakness in the stock and bond markets, as investors shifted assets to the perceived safety of gold. Gold settled $2.30 to $2.90 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with April at $378.90 a troy ounce; silver was 0.4 cent to 0.8 cent lower with May at $5.10 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures prices ended mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade after a rally in the soybean complex faded late in the session. Wheat futures settled { cent to 3{ cents lower with May at $3.70\ a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to } cent higher with May at $2.78 a bushel; oats were \ cent to 2 cents higher with May at $1.57} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 3{ cents higher with May at $6.05} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Announces Plans to Buy Up to 5 Million Shares of Stock
DOC.TEXT: Computer giant Digital Equipment Corp. has been authorized by its board to buy back up to 5 million shares of its own common stock on the open market, a company spokesman said Monday. The purchase would represent about 4.1 percent of the company's outstanding common stock, which amounts to more than 122 million shares. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Monday, Digital stock rose 25 cents a share to close at $83.25. At that price, a buyback of 5 million shares would cost $416.25 million. ``We believe the current market value of Digital stock does not reflect the underlying strengths of the company, its customers, products and the markets it serves, as well as its strong financial position,'' said James M. Osterhoff, vice president of finance. The shares purchased would be ``a way to return some of that value to the stockholders,'' said Bradley Allen, spokesman for Digital. ``Some of the shares will be used to supply the employee purchase stock fund,'' Allen said. He said the company had previously repurchased 18 million shares of its common stock on the open market for $2.1 billion in cash during the last few years.

DOC.HEAD: United Flexes Political Muscle in Fight for Japan Route
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS new 3rd graf to UPDATE with American Airlines' position; picks up 3rd graf pvs bg'ng, The letters ...; SUBS 9th graf pvs to UPDATE with comment from American official; picks up 10th graf pvs bg'ng, American has ...
DOC.TEXT: On the eve of government hearings to choose six more U.S.-to-Japan air routes, United Airlines is counting on its political connections to help it beat out archrival American Airlines for a Chicago-Tokyo link. United bragged Monday that it had successfully solicited letters from five state governors, two state congressional delegations and the Nebraska legislature in support of its proposed route between Washington's Dulles International Airport and Tokyo, with a stop at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport. American is seeking approval for an identical route and says it hopes economic and competitive issues hold more sway with the Transportation Department than politicians' endorsements. The letters of support have been sent to John J. Mathias, a Transportation Department law judge who will conduct hearings expected to result by Oct. 1 in the selection of six new U.S. ``gateways'' for non-stop flights to Japan, United said in a statement. The hearings are scheduled to begin Tuesday in Washington. A gateway is the departure point for a non-stop flight. Chicago would be the U.S. gateway for United's proposed flight. United spokesman Joe Hopkins said a number of airlines are proposing multiple routes, but United is concentrating on only one in what amounts to an all-out effort to stop American from further humiliating United on its home turf. Hopkins said Dallas-based American also has proposed a non-stop Chicago-Tokyo route, setting up a head-to-head contest for the connection between the nation's two largest airlines. ``We're putting all of our efforts into this one,'' Hopkins said. American, a subsidiary of AMR Corp., pulled ahead of United in sales and market share last year to become the nation's largest airline. Barry Clark, manager of American's international route strategy, said that since United already is the leading trans-Pacific carrier among U.S. airlines, competition would be better served if the Transportation Department awarded the route to American. As for United's political connections, ``we obviously hope it's not that terribly important,'' Clark said in a phone interview. American has been expanding and advertising aggressively in Chicago during the past year, trying to make a splash here while the management of United's parent, UAL Corp., has been caught up in a long-running battle for control of the company. UAL's board of directors recently agreed to sell the company to its employees for about $4.4 billion, but financing for the deal hasn't yet been completed. It is possible that neither airline would get the route, since Northwest Airlines and Japan Air Lines already fly between Chicago and Tokyo. But it is virtually certain that United and American won't both get authority for the route. Supporting United are Illinois Gov. James R. Thompson, Indiana Gov. Evan Bayh, Kentucky Gov. Wallace G. Wilkinson, Nebraska Gov. Kay A. Orr and Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder. Other politicians backing United's bid include Chicago Mayor Richard M. Daley, the 24-member Illinois congressional delegation, Indianapolis Mayor William H. Hudnut III, the Nebraska legislature and the 12-member Virginia congressional delegation. UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf said in a statement that the politicians ``speak not only for themselves but for the constituents in their areas with strong interest in a more efficient air link with Japan.''

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 1,954,000 net tons during the week ending April 21, down 3.2 percent from the previous week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The week's production represented 86.9 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said Monday. American steelmakers produced 2,054,000 net tons in the same week last year, AISI said. Domestic steel production so far this year is 30,513,000 net tons, 3.9 percent below last year's pace, AISI said. Production by district for last week, (previous week in parentheses). North East Coast 234,000 tons (234,000 tons); Pittsburgh-Youngstown 319,000 tons (323,000 tons); Lake Erie 157,000 tons (159,000 tons); Detroit 161,000 tons (164,000 tons); Indiana-Chicago 496,000 tons (531,000 tons); Southern 285,000 tons (302,000 tons); Western 108,000 tons (113,000 tons).

DOC.HEAD: Tupperware Owner Buys Tile Maker in $215 Million Deal
DOC.TEXT: Premark International Inc., maker of Tupperware and West Bend products, said it has agreed to buy Sikes Corp., the third-largest U.S. maker of ceramic tiles, in a deal worth $215 million. for $201 million in cash. Premark will pay $201 million in cash for Sikes and assume $14 million of the company's debt, Premark spokesman Bob Matha said. Sikes, based in Lakeland, Fla., reported net income of $7.4 million on sales of $137 million in its fiscal year ended Feb. 28. The results included $2.4 million in charges for restructuring, renovation and plant remodeling. In a statement from its headquarters in Deerfield, Ill., Premark said it was commencing a tender offer to buy Class A common shares of Sikes for $16.40 in cash and Class B shares for $26.78. Premark said the Class B shareholders also own about 9 percent of the Class A shares, which they have agreed to tender to Premark. The deal is subject to antitrust clearance. Premark also announced Monday that its net income fell 41 percent in the first quarter to $13.2 million, or 39 cents a share, from $22.4 million, or 64 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 3 percent to $620 million. Chairman Warren L. Batts said the company had lower profits from Tupperware and from its food equipment group, which includes the Hobart, Vulcan and Foster brands.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Authorizes Sale of Trademarks, Flight Certificates
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge Monday authorized Braniff Inc. to sell its trademarks, flight certificates and operating manuals to a former investor who wants to use them to start up his own airline. Jeffrey Chodorow, a major Braniff stockholder from Philadelphia, paid $313,333 for the documents required by the federal government to operate an airline, according to court documents cited by The Orlando Sentinel. Chodorow recently formed BN Air Inc. in New York. He has said he will use Braniff's flight certificates to start an airline in Dallas. BN Air wants to initiate scheduled and charter operations utilizing the Braniff name and former Braniff employees, the court documents disclosed. BN Air intends to begin flight operations in late summer, subject to regulatory approvals. Braniff said in a news release that some Braniff employees will be offered jobs with the airline within the next two weeks. Braniff, which went into Chapter 11 bankruptcy last Sept. 28, is slowly disposing of its assets and employees. The Orlando-based airline has about 95 employees remaining on its payroll and expects to reduce its work force even further in the next week. Chodorow said further details on BN Air's plans would be released within the next two weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Group Complains New Rules Would Make Housing Too Costly For Disabled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after lede and 2 grafs after 14th graf pvs, bgng: Mansfield, however xxx to include denial from separate group representing disabled.
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of physically handicapped and homebuilders complained on Monday that proposed guidelines designed to guarantee disabled people access to apartments would price many of them out of the market. However, those assertions were promptly denied by the government and another group representing the disabled. The guidelines were described as ``impractical, inflexible and too costly'' in an analysis by the Task Force on Handicap Accessibility formed by the National Coordinating Council on Spinal Cord Injury and the National Association of Home Builders. Gordon Mansfield, assistant secretary of Housing and Urban Development, questioned the task force figures. ``We are very concerned that we meet the intent of the law and make sure that (Secretary) Jack Kemp's priority on affordability on housing be paid attention to,'' Mansfield said. The Department of Housing and Urban Development is required by the 1988 Fair Housing Amendments to issue guidelines insuring disabled persons have easy access to new multi-family units first occupied after next March 13. They affect such things as door hallway widths, bathroom and walk-in pantry sizes and grading and ramping of steeply sloped sites. But the task force study said draft guidelines ``go far beyond the original intent of the Fair Housing legislation.'' Unless modified, it said, costs of building rental apartments and condominium and cooperative units ``will increase signficantly, further slowing an already depressed multi-family industry and exacerbating the affordability crisis currently confronting millions of low- and moderate-income households.'' ``We estimate that the cost per unit of meeting HUD's proposed guidelines will range from $1,300 to $3,700 for walk-up units and from $3,200 to $4,250 for mid- to high-rise units,'' R. Jack Powell, president of the spinal cord injury council and executive director of the Paralyzed Veterans of America, told a news conference. Since the added costs would be added to rents, it would mean monthly increases of $13 to $37 for walk-up units and of $32 to $43 for mid- or high-rise units, the coalition's study contended. The coalition said its proposed guidelines would mean increases of between $7 and $26 for walk-up units and $14 to $23 for mid- or high-rise apartments. ``If HUD's design guidelines result in significant increases in the cost of housing, they we have really defeated the purpose of the Fair Housing Amendments ... and created another barrier to accessibilty,'' Powell said. Mansfield, however, said the HUD guidelines would increase the cost of a $50,000 apartment by 1 percent, or $500, which both HUD and the task force agree is within the cost that Congress intended. Bonnie Milstein, cochair of the Housing Task Force of the Consortium for Citizens with Disabilities, also said the coalition's claims were inaccurate. Ms. Milstein said the coalition figures include expenditures not required by the Fair Housing amendments and added that, while the HUD guidelines are far from perfect, they are supported by her organization which includes the United Cerebral Palsy, Easter Seals and the American Foundation for the Blind. Kent W. Colton, Home Builders executive vice president, also said uncertainty over the guidelines has severely disrupted the multi-family construction industry which finished 1989 with only 373,000 building starts, down nearly 50 percent from 1985 and the lowest level since 1975. Mansfield said the guidelines are now being considered by the Office of Management and Budget whose approval is required for many government regulations. The Home Builders is a federation of more than 800 construction associations with more than 157,000 members. The coordinating council is comprised of 17 organizations associated with spinal cord injuries. The largest is the Paralyzed Veterans with 14,000 members.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Disrupt Financial Districts in NYC, San Francisco
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with additional arrests in New York. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `The major...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY35
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of environmentalists demonstrated Monday in the financial districts of New York and San Francisco, where post-Earth Day demonstrators shattered windows at the Bank of America. Authorities said 268 people were arrested in the two cities. Also in California, hand-delivered messages claimed responsibility Monday for vandalism that cut power to some 92,000 Pacific Gas & Electric customers in Santa Cruz and Watsonville. In New York, police arrested about 204 of an estimated 700 demonstrators. Two protestors were charged with assaulting an officer and the rest with disorderly conduct, according to police spokesmen. ``The major corporations have committed a lot of crimes against nature,'' said Marc Chernoff, 30, a member of New York's Coalition for a Nuclear Free Harbor. ``It's long overdue to place the blame where it directly belongs. If the products that pollute were not made available, people would not buy them.'' Trade on the New York Stock Exchange went on as scheduled and none of the protesters got inside. ``Except for getting up a little early, it's a pretty normal day,'' said the exchange's senior vice president, Richard Torrenzano. At the Pacific Stock Exchange in San Francisco, 49 people were arrested during a demonstration by 300 to 500 protesters that turned violent when some broke windows at Bank of America, threw golf balls, rocks and eggs at police, and overturned newsstands. The exchange also opened on schedule although some employees were delayed. Police closed off two blocks of Wall Street to traffic and all pedestrians except those working there. Traffic elsewhere was disrupted during the morning and afternoon when protesters walked through lower Manhattan streets. The protest was organized by Earth Day Wall Street Action, which described itself as a coalition of 60 environmental organizations in the United States and Canada. It said it wanted to focus attention on ``institutions responsible for much of the ecological devastation which is destroying the planet.'' ``I don't know why they're protesting against Wall Street,'' said James F. Dean, 24, an auditor with J.P. Morgan. ``I don't think anyone is taking this seriously besides them.'' ``I think it's great that these guys in suits are stopping to hear us,'' said Debbie Augustine, 34, of Loudon, N.H., a member of the anti-nuclear power Clamshell Alliance. A spokesman for the San Francisco demonstrators, Daniel Finkenthal of the Earth Day Action Coalition, said the purpose of the protest there was to give the public an alternative to the corporate-sponsored views of environmental action that preceded Earth Day. ``Yesterday these corporations came into our community and spent a lot of money on a media coup to try to convince the American public that environmental protection and reform was high on the corporate agenda, but it's the lowest priority,'' Finkenthal said. ``In fact, they're spending more money on Earth Day promotion than they are on actual corporate reform and the environment.'' The group that claimed responsibility for the two California outages called itself Earth Night Action Group and said the target was Pacific Gas & Electric, a ``corporate earth rapist.'' Residents of Santa Cruz and Watsonville were affected by the outages Sunday and early Monday, caused by damage to power PG&E poles. A young male caller to The Associated Press telephoned a few minutes after delivery of the message to ask if it had been received. Similar messages went to Bay City News Service and the San Francisco Examiner. The caller refused to give his name or his telephone number.
